HEADLINE: G.E. Succeeded With Hungary Venture

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"G.E. Finds Tough Going in Hungary" (Business Day, July 25), which describes the birth pains when General Electric bought Tungsram, Hungary's largest industrial company, in 1989 after the Iron Curtain fell, does not reflect today's Tungsram. 
 Certainly, there were problems in teaching basic concepts of accounting, marketing, sales and profitability to employees who had known only a planned Communist economy. Every American company that invested in a former Eastern Bloc country faced the same issues.
Today Tungsram is one of the great success stories of Eastern Europe. Its employees have developed dozens of leading-edge lighting products for world markets; its market share has increased; it's profitable and it's hiring production workers for the first time in five years. Your article should have been titled "Success Story in Hungary."
 
JOHN D. OPIE
President, G.E. Lighting
Cleveland, July 25, 1994

HEADLINE: U.N. AUTHORIZES INVASION OF HAITI TO BE LED BY U.S.

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 31

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council voted today to authorize a United States invasion and occupation of Haiti if sanctions fail to remove its military Government.
The approval, by a vote of 12 to 0 with abstentions from China and Brazil, and with Rwanda absent, opens the way for American forces, now stationed just north of Haiti, to move in to restore democracy there. 
 In Washington, officials said a decision on whether to use force is still weeks away. [Page A6.]
The resolution authorizing the United States action contains no date or deadline for carrying out any such invasion, unlike the resolution adopted before the United States-led action that drove Iraq's invasion forces out of Kuwait.
The United States' chief delegate to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, hailed the vote and said that it helps "lay the diplomatic groundwork" to give President Clinton a choice of options for dealing with Haiti that is wider than just the choice of an invasion.
She added that the vote sent a signal to the members of the military junta in Haiti that "you can depart voluntarily and soon, or you can depart involuntarily and soon."
During the three-hour meeting of the Security Council, representatives of Brazil, China, Mexico, Uruguay and Cuba expressed reservations about any military operation in Haiti, which would be the first invasion in the Western Hemisphere that would have United Nations support.
Brazil and China abstained from voting, with the delegate from Beijing, Li Zhaoxing, stating that his country considered that the resolution set "a dangerous precedent." The other countries that objected, whose representatives spoke at the meeting with permission of the Security Council, are not currently members of the Council. In addition to Brazil and the United States, Argentina -- which supported the measure -- is the only Western Hemisphere country now on the Council.
Speakers from Britain and Argentina cited accounts of terrorism and human rights violations in Haiti, saying that it was the right and duty of the United Nations to stop them. Hundreds of people were killed in Haiti in the aftermath of the overthrow of the elected Government on Sept. 30, 1991.
The delegate from Spain, Juan Antonio Yanez-Barnuevo, said the world "could not close its eyes to the horrors" in Haiti.
The resolution would divide an invasion and occupation operation into two stages. In the first, a multinational force led by the United States of as many as 15,000 members would invade Haiti, disarm its armed forces, unseat its military junta, take control of the country and start training a new Haitian army and police force.
The United States supports the restoration of the democratically elected president of Haiti, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who was ousted in the 1991 coup and went into exile.
The first phase would be roughly patterned after the Persian Gulf war operation, with the United States in command of what might be an international force, although it is not clear what other countries would contribute troops or how much the operation might cost.
After the vote, Ms. Albright said the United States had obtained commitments from other countries to join the first phase of any operation, although she declined to name those nations.
 
Participants Pay
 The resolution says that "the cost of implementing this temporary operation will be borne by the participating states," language that had been omitted from the first draft. Money is a delicate issue in the United Nations, which is strapped for cash largely because of its many peacekeeping operations.
The United States already has 2,400 troops and 14 warships near the Turks and Caicos Islands, just north of Haiti.
In the second phase, a smaller force of perhaps 6,000 militia and police reporting to the United Nations would take over and would work to bring about political stability while giving further training to the new army and police force.
The United States views the dissolution of the present Haitian Army and its reconstitution as one of the most important elements in restructuring the country, and some supporters of the resolution contend that this objective could be achieved only through an invasion and occupation.
A United Nations observer force of as many as 60 members would accompany an invasion force "to carry out the monitoring of the operations of the multinational force" and to prepare for the arrival of the participants in the second stage.
The resolution states that any invasion force will terminate its mission "when a secure and stable environment has been established."
 
Latin Hesitation
 A letter sent by Mr. Aristide to Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali helped clear the way for passage of the resolution. In the letter, Mr. Aristide called for the international community "to take swift and determined action," but he did not specifically address the issue of a possible invasion.
While the letter reiterated Mr. Aristide's pleas for help it also placated some United Nations members who were uncomfortable with the idea of yet another invasion in Latin America or the Caribbean.
Argentina and Venezuela insisted on the letter, in which Mr. Aristide cited what he considered to be the compelling and unique political and circumstances affecting Haiti that required United Nations help.
The resolution that was adopted by the Security Council said that "the goal of the international community remains the restoration of democracy in Haiti and the prompt return of the legitimately elected President." It added that "the situation in Haiti continues to constitute a threat to the peace and security in the region."
The military rulers in Haiti have come under heavy economic and political sanctions. The sanctions have increased since the junta blocked the arrival in Haiti earlier this year of a United Nations mission.
A year ago on Governors Island in New York, both President Aristide and the leader of the military, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, signed an accord brokered by the United Nations that would have restored Mr. Aristide to power. It stipulated that his return was to take place by Oct. 30, but General Cedras reneged on the agreement and remained in power. During the resulting impasse, thousands of Haitians fled the country, many to the United States.
 
'We Want Them Out'
 After today's vote, Haiti's delegate to the United Nations, Fritz Longchamp, who represents the Aristide Government, said that he was "disappointed that it has taken so long to act."
"We are not looking for a military operation, but we want them out," he said, referring to the military rulers.
Jamsheed Marker of Pakistan, the Security Council president for July, said the resolution -- which went through many drafts -- was "very carefully written" and that there had been "immense difficulties" in putting together the final version.
In the end, the Clinton Administration got what it said it wanted: international approval to mount a coalition operation against the junta and then turn control over to the United Nations. The goal of relinquishing control might yet be a problem; some diplomats here pointed to the enormous difficulties that resulted a year ago in Somalia during the switch from United States to United Nations command.

HEADLINE: U.S. Move on Haiti May Be Weeks Away

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
Despite the Security Council's authorization of an invasion to oust Haiti's military rulers, a decision on American military action there is still weeks away, Administration officials said today.
The White House hopes that United Nations endorsement of the use of force will give credibility to the months of American threats, which Haitian military leaders have appeared to belittle. Some American officials say a combination of tighter economic sanctions and a strong show of international resolve may still force the leaders to quit. 
 The White House chief of staff, Leon Panetta, warned Haiti's military rulers today that they must leave soon to avoid a United Nations-sanctioned invasion. "I think that it is sufficient to say 'soon,' " Mr. Panetta said on CNN's "Late Edition." "And they better get that signal: soon."
But American intelligence analysts here and in Haiti predict that the Haitian military will defy Washington right to the end.
Before President Clinton would order any invasion -- which his advisers say he is trying to avoid -- the Administration would still need to muster support in Congress, among allies in the Caribbean and with the American public. Opposition to an invasion is running high in all three groups.
With the flow of Haitian boat people dwindling to a trickle, there are no immediate reasons to push Haiti to the crowded front burner of national security and domestic issues, at least for the moment, Administration officials say.
The United States is increasing its military involvement in the relief operation in and around Rwanda and is preparing for stiffer measures against the Bosnian Serbs, who have rejected an American-backed peace plan in the Balkans.
On the domestic front, the Administration faces important votes in the House and Senate on health-care legislation in the next two weeks.
"Wait and see what happens in Rwanda," said a senior military planner. "If that situation settles down in the next couple of weeks, the focus could turn back to Haiti."
Senior Administration officials have said a decision on using force in Haiti could wait until late August at least, barring some unforeseen provocation, like harassment of the 3,000 Americans in Haiti, widespread attacks on Haitian civilians or a new surge of refugees taking to the seas.
Meanwhile, Administration officials are still lining up support among countries in the Caribbean and elsewhere for a force that would follow the initial troops, mainly Americans, into Haiti after the military rulers step down voluntarily or are forced out. The first force would restore order in the country and reinstall the exiled Government of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. The second force would help maintain security after the Americans leave.
United States naval forces finished four days of war exercises near Puerto Rico on Saturday and steamed toward Haiti to resume patrols off the coast.

(Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: A Suburban Eden Where the Right Rules

SERIES: New South And Old: Second of four articles.

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MARIETTA, Ga.

 BODY:
It is a long way culturally and politically from Roslyn, L.I., to conservative Cobb County. But Mitchell Kaye, who two years ago became the first Jewish Republican in Georgia history ever elected to the State Legislature, seems to have made the transition.
"Every year they release two liberal Democrats in the wild here so they don't become an endangered species," said Mr. Kaye, a 36-year-old, first-term State Representative who grew up on Long Island and moved to Georgia after going to college in Florida. "If Bill Clinton came into the district, he probably would not see the light of day again." 
 The South of myth and fable still lives in Carolina mill towns, where the kudzu snakes over crumbling bricks. It lives on in the juke joints and the shotgun shacks of the Mississippi Delta. But to really understand the South today, it makes sense to visit Cobb County, a suburban Atlanta sprawl of glistening new malls, shady green subdivisions, lush golf courses and Chevrolet Suburbans bearing Christian fish symbols and "Rush Is Right" bumper stickers.
Rather than being precisely typical, Cobb is the booming suburban South in bold caricature. It is at the heart of the Republican surge in the South, a party that went from holding about 10 percent of the South's 106 seats in the House of Representatives in 1964 to about 38 percent of its 125 seats now. Not just prosperous, Cobb has been one of America's growth leaders for a quarter century, surging to more than 500,000 people today from 196,793 in 1970, according to the Census Bureau.
Not merely conservative, it was represented in Congress by the former head of the John Birch Society, Larry McDonald, until his death in 1983. It continues to make national news because of a resolution passed by the county commission condemning "the gay life style" as incompatible with community standards. The resolution set off a furor that on Friday led Atlanta Olympics organizers to pull Olympic volleyball out of the county.
Newt Gingrich, who represents 70 percent of the county in Congress, is not just one of the growing cadre of Southern Republicans who are accounting for much of the party's growth, he is in line to be the next House minority leader and, should the party gain control of the House, perhaps the first Republican Speaker since Joseph W. Martin Jr. of Massachusetts in 1955.
The phrase New South, vaguely denoting a reasonably tolerant place where people wear shoes and don't support segregation, has become enough of an empty cliche that the novelist Walker Percy once groused, "My definition of a new South would be a South in which it never occurred to anybody to mention the New South."
Cobb is not what the South was, but it isn't the idealized New South either. It's the South of the easy-listening saxophonist Kenny G, not the gritty wails of Hank Williams; of the pugnacious sound bites of Newt Gingrich, not the peanut country drawl of Jimmy Carter; of white wine, not bourbon and branch water; of tidy air-conditioned suburban churches, not hard-shell backwoods ones. Oddly, it's a new suburban South where blacks and whites don't have the proximity to one another that defined the South even during segregation.
It's the fastest growing part of America, and what goes on there says as much about the nation as it does about the South.
 
The Good Life
'Great Place To Raise Kids'
 As he watches the East Side All-Stars go through their paces under the tutelage of a small army of Little League dads, David Smith sounds like an advertisement for the Southern good life.
"I came here in 1973," Mr. Smith said, sitting in the metal bleachers at Fuller's Park, watching his 9-year-old son, Quincy, play on a manicured diamond. "I had a friend who said: 'You've got to come down here. If you don't like it, I'll pay your way back.' It was paradise. It was vibrant, growing. Detroit was stagnant. You can travel around the whole world and not find a better place to live than this."
In a county that doubled in population in the 1980's, that is a familiar refrain.
It was echoed by Steve Delaney, a lawyer. "When my father came to visit me from New York when I was in law school in Atlanta in 1978," Mr. Delaney recalled, "he said: 'Stay here. This is the next New York.' What he meant was the old New York, the New York of the 40's, a great place to live and raise kids. He was right. Being here, I feel I've died and gone to heaven."
 
Friendliness and Manners
 Barbara Wolfe, a 36-year-old mother of two, was so appalled by the anti-gay resolution that she joined the Cobb Citizens Coalition, a group organized to oppose it. But when she talks about life in Cobb County, she has mostly good things to say. She loves the hills and trees, the friendliness of the people, the good schools, the affordability of housing, even to a point the Sunday-school manners and well-scrubbed sensibilities.
"I like that people are more down to earth, more polite, that you don't have to walk around screaming and yelling and being rude -- you know, the whole New York thing," said Mrs. Wolfe, a native New Yorker who formerly lived in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. "It seems crazy listening to myself say this, but sometimes I think that there are a lot of the characteristics that come from some of this fundamentalist religious stuff that I hate that also cause it to be so pleasant here. If they didn't make it political it might be perfect. But it's not."
Median household income in Cobb, which is about 90 percent white, is $41,297, compared with a national average of $30,056. Two-thirds of the housing units are single-family homes, and the rest are apartments and condominiums. There are plenty of high-end $300,000 and $400,000 houses. But most houses range from $70,000, which brings an older three-bedroom ranch house in the blue-collar towns of south and west Cobb, to $225,000, which can buy a new two-story four-bedroom house, in the more affluent areas of East Cobb.
More than 72 percent of the work force is in white-collar jobs, most of them in expanding areas of the economy like insurance, electronics and computers, and trade. The largest employer is Lockheed Aeronautical Systems Company, a division of the Lockheed Corporation, which depending on its contracts employs about 12,000 people and is designing the Air Force's F-22 advanced tactical fighter while also producing two other military aircraft.
In a region that has been in the forefront of attracting foreign investment, Cobb has drawn a considerable share of it; 200 international companies have set up operations here in the past decade.
In a nation worried about crime and the economy, Cobb and places like it offer -- particularly to whites -- a sense of prosperity and safety, conservative Southern values and a relaxed, friendly way of life.
 
'Norman Rockwell World'
 "These people want safety, and they believe big cities have failed and are controlled by people who are incapable of delivering goods and services," said Mr. Gingrich, who narrowly survived the Republican primary two years ago when he first ran in Cobb after Georgia legislators redistricted the state. He easily won the party primary this month and is heavily favored to be re-elected.
"What they find here," Mr. Gingrich added, "is a sort of Norman Rockwell world with fiber optic computers and jet airplanes. But the values that would have been The Saturday Evening Post of the mid-50's are the values of most of these people now."
Mr. Gingrich talks up Cobb's work ethic and entrepreneurial values, but the anti-government conservatives in Cobb have done extraordinarily well with the Federal Government.
A 1993 study in Common Cause Magazine found that Cobb took in $3.4 billion in Federal money in 1992. Only two suburban counties in the nation, Arlington, Va., outside Washington, and Brevard County, Fla., home of the Kennedy Space Center, took in more.
Still, if a skeptical eye is going to be cast on Cobb, it is likely to come from the outside.
"The only liberal voices we've got in Cobb County," Ric Cross, a computer operator, said as he drank coffee recently at a local Waffle House, "are in the early editions of The Atlanta Journal and Constitution."
 
Intolerance
Serious Instances Of Inhospitality
 Beneath the suburban idyll is a more troubling history.
It was a group of citizens from Marietta, the county seat, who in 1915 abducted from a state prison and lynched Leo Frank, the Jewish factory owner wrongly convicted of a 1913 murder in what became one of the most infamous instances of anti-Semitism in Southern history.
With integration that began in the 1960's, Cobb became the favored destination for whites fleeing Atlanta. Linked by Interstate 75, Cobb was an easily accessible suburb about 20 miles from downtown Atlanta and a place with a history of inhospitality toward blacks.
"They love that river down there," Joe Mack Wilson, a State Representative who later became the Mayor of Marietta, said in 1975 of the Chattahoochee River, which separates Cobb County from Atlanta, now 70 percent black. "They want to keep it as a moat. They wish they could build forts across there to keep people from coming up here."
Marietta had trolley service to Atlanta as far back as 1905, but in recent years has repeatedly refused to join the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority and re-establish a rail link. Mr. Wilson said it would take a "complete breakdown" of public transportation in Cobb before the county's whites would increase ties to Atlanta. A former Cobb Commissioner, Emmett Burton, said he "would stock the Chattahoochee with piranha" to keep rapid transit out.
Blacks make up a slim fraction of Cobb's population, and those who have been attracted to the area, Mr. Gingrich said, "don't want to be black in the unity convention, N.A.A.C.P. sense."
"They want to be Americans, integrated, assimilated, living in neighborhoods that are safe," he said.
But when asked what Cobb should do to foster that integration and assimilation, particularly for the black poor, Mr. Gingrich raises the specter of crime and collapsing schools brought on by people "with no middle class values." Instead of opening up places like Cobb to the black poor, "what makes sense is to replace the culture of poverty," he said.
Many blacks in Cobb say the pluses of the suburban life style are countered by a sense of not quite fitting in. Joe Shifalo, executive director of Metro Fair Housing, which monitors housing discrimination in the Atlanta area, said two-thirds of blacks seeking housing in the county received different information and got different treatment than white applicants.
"If it was still legal to pass a referendum against black folks, Cobb County might do it," Mr. Shifalo said.
Over the years Cobb has attracted a striking number of figures from the fringes of the right -- people like Ed Fields, one of the nation's most active white supremacists and anti-Semites who disseminates his views in a newspaper he publishes, "The Truth at Last," or J. B. Stoner, a convicted church bomber and former Ku Klux Klansman.
Next to the friendly little Shanty House restaurant in the little town of Kennesaw, at the northern end of the county, sits Dent Myers's Civil War curios shop, where the wares includes Klan and white-power T-shirts, hate-group literature and bumper stickers reading: "Fight Crime. Deport Niggers."
A recent report by an Atlanta organization, Neighbors Network, which studies extremist groups, said that the homosexual resolution was largely driven by groups at the fringe of the Christian right. John Greaves, a gay resident who became a spokesman for opponents of the county, left Cobb after living there for four years, he said, because of harassment and threatening phone calls.
"We got a lot of calls of support," said Mr. Greaves, a 36-year-old credit analyst, "but we also had people call and say things like, 'I'm going to drag you outside and slit your throat and watch your queer blood run in the street.'
"You can't live that way. I got exhausted by it."
No one thinks that religious or racial extremists make up more than a tiny percentage of the population of Cobb County, and many people are quick to rebut the notion that there is something odious in anyone, white or black, wanting to flee crime and poverty.
"I find that criticism to be almost amusing," said Whit Ayers, a Republican poll taker and political consultant. "Somehow you are criticizing someone for not wanting to have their kids' lunch money extorted in their school. Somehow they're selfish because they don't want to be mugged when they go out for a walk with their dog."
 
Upset by Bigotry
 Many residents, perhaps most of them, are horrified by the political uproar over the anti-gay resolution and the notion that Cobb is a hotbed of intolerant zealots.
"I've been involved in this community for over 20 years and found it to be a very loving, wonderful place to live, and I'm just startled by this," Tucker McQueen said. Her daughter Kate spoke out against the resolution in her speech as the valedictorian of Marietta High School this year. "It makes us look like a bunch of bigoted jackasses," Mrs. McQueen said. "It just startles me, and it upsets me tremendously."
Mr. Greaves said the problem was that in a political spectrum that ranges from center right to extremist right, those at the fringe could play a disproportionate role in political life.
"Cobb County is like a boat where all the people have run to the right side," he said. "You get enough people on the right side, eventually the boat just tips over."
 
The Suburban Outlook
Conservative Life, Conservative Soul
 Cobb's growth has parallels in Western and Rocky Mountain states, which have also benefited from people seeking simpler values and an easier life. Cobb is in some ways less Southern than it is purely suburban, with politics not much different from that of Orange County, Calif., which also has an aerospace economy and conservative politics.
The difference is that rather than a right-wing node, Cobb reflects the conservative heart of a conservative region, like a fragrance distilled through an alembic.
Mr. Gingrich is not the only one to argue that Cobb represents a fundamental divide in American life between the values that dominate the media and the cultural capitals like New York and Los Angeles and the broader values that for now seem to be driving politics and demography. He and others say the media, by viewing the South almost solely through the prism of the civil rights era, miss more of it than they capture.
"An awful lot of reporters were civil rights Southerners," Mr. Gingrich said. "How much they hated segregation and how much they had a disdain for the Old South blocks them from seeing the new. They refuse to try to walk in the shoes of the people who created a Cobb County. They're more willing to try to understand Indians in India than they are to understand Americans outside their own prejudices."
Many people in Cobb think the uproar caused by the anti-gay resolution has been such an embarrassment that it will help bring the county back more toward the political center.
"This is not Christianity that I know, that I've been raised to believe in," Mrs. McQueen said, "and I think there is a silent majority that knows it."
It's a sentiment that mirrors the worries of national Republican strategists that divisive social issues like the ones that have played out here have the potential to cut the party in two and turn off precisely the kind of corporate conservatives who are flocking to places like Cobb.
But it is not at all clear that Cobb's excesses are as repugnant to its residents -- even the moderate ones -- as they are to some outsiders. And there is nothing on the horizon to indicate that the growth of the South's Cobb Counties is likely to slow anytime soon.
"This is a trend," Mr. Ayers said, "that has a long way to run."
Next: Selma, Ala., where racial divisions and poverty live on three decades after it became a battleground of the civil rights era.

HEADLINE: Dollar Plunges, Then Steadies Against Yen

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 1

 BODY:
The failure of the United States and Japan to resolve a longstanding trade dispute sent a jolt of disappointment through the foreign exchange market today, putting the dollar into a temporary freefall against the yen and dashing any optimism that its long slide would end soon.
After a plunge as the market opened, the dollar leveled off at 98.55 yen in early trading here then rose slightly to 98.78 yen, well below the rate in New York late Friday of 100.1 yen but still a way from its historic low of 96.60 yen. An earlier decline had put pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates as a means of bolstering the dollar, pressure that may be renewed once again. 
 But there were signs that the failure of the talks did not mark a complete breakdown in the increasingly strained relations between two of the world's greatest trading powers. Japan's Foreign Ministry had said two weeks ago that the Government would consider retaliating for any American move toward sanctions by formally cutting off further talks.
This morning a senior Foreign Ministry official here said that the Government had decided not to move toward such a breach.
"We are not exercising our right to break things off," the official said, who spoke on condition that he not be further identified. "We'll take some time for reflection, and then will have some informal talks later."
He added a warning, though, apparently with the reaction of the markets in mind. "Perhaps they would do well not to just kick out the chair and leave the table," the official said, referring to the American negotiators.
Kozo Igarashi, the Chief Cabinet Secretary, said today that if the United States did eventually enact sanctions, Japan would retaliate by cutting off any further talks on the government procurement issue or other trade topics.
Yukuo Takahashi, the chief foreign exchange trader here for Chemical Bank, said the currency market activity was relatively light and that the dollar had suffered the losses in one brief plunge in the day's early hours.
The bad news, he added, was that the breakdown of the trade talks, which took place in Washington over the weekend, had pushed most of the optimists who had purchased dollars last week out of the market, at least for the time being.
"The majority feel now that we're going to see further declines" in the dollar's value, Mr. Takahashi said.
Jorn Simonson, a trader with the Chase Manhattan Bank, observed: "The only thing people had been looking for was something on trade. The feeling was about 50/50 on the talks. When it didn't come out people were all ready to sell. But we may level off here for a while."
The United States has fought with Japan for more than a year on opening five Japanese markets: autos, auto parts, insurance, and government procurement of telecommunications and medical equipment.
The Clinton Administration had twice postponed a deadline on concluding the talks on government procurement of telecommunications and medical gear, but insisted it would stand by the latest date, July 31.
Japan's overall trade surplus and its surplus with the United States have been running at record levels for the last two years -- a key reason that the dollar has been sinking. The soaring value of the yen has put enormous pressure on Japanese manufacturers, whose products are now far more expensive for foreign buyers.
The pressure has also slowed the Japanese economy and taken a big bite out of corporate profits, but it has not been enough pressure to force the Government to agree to Washington's terms -- a guarantee of increased purchases of foreign telecommunications and medical equipment by government entities.
"At this point, I'm not really optimistic, but we still have hope," the Foreign Ministry official said.

HEADLINE: Report Expresses Concern on Pentagon Budget

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
Congressional investigators and some senior military planners are expressing growing concern that the Pentagon cannot afford its ambitious long-term strategy of being prepared to fight two regional wars at the same time.
The General Accounting Office says in a report to be issued on Monday that the Defense Department may have overstated savings and underestimated costs by more than $150 billion in its $1.2 trillion budget for 1995 to 1999. 
 That figure is substantially higher than the estimate figured by the Senate Armed Services Committee in June. Figuring the gap at $60 billion, the panel declared itself "seriously concerned" that the Pentagon would be unable to finance the strategy.
Defense Secretary William J. Perry has repeatedly assured Congress that the Pentagon can deliver on its plan. The Pentagon said last December that the deficit was about $50 billion over five years. That gap shrank to $11 billion to $20 billion after more optimistic inflation estimates were calculated and after President Clinton agreed to give the armed forces more money to offset a decision by Congress to increase military salaries.
 
Estimates on Overruns
 In their defense, Pentagon officials also cite a March report by the Congressional Budget Office, a frequent critic of the Defense Department, calling the Pentagon's budget sufficient to pay for the military's future force structure. The budget office, however, said the Pentagon might have underestimated potential cost overruns on new weapons and overstated expected savings from closing military installations.
Since last year, when Les Aspin, then Defense Secretary, unveiled the Pentagon's long-range war-fighting strategy and the budget to pay for it, the Defense Department's plan has fallen under two main criticisms.
Some lawmakers and senior officers say that the number of troops, tanks, ships and aircraft in the plan is not adequate to carry out the two-war scenario. Even if they were, the critics complain, the Pentagon cannot afford the force it wants with the budget it has.
The analysis by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, said that in addition to whatever inflation costs were counted, the Pentagon might have overestimated $32 billion in savings from closing bases and more efficient business practices. The report also says the Pentagon understated as much as $112 billion in extra costs associated with new weapons systems, military pay increases, environmental cleanup and peacekeeping operations.
Senior Pentagon officials expressed amazement at the accounting office's findings, with a senior Defense Department official calling the analysis "superficial and transparent."
The accounting office's analysis was requested by Senator Charles E. Grassley, an Iowa Republican; Senator William V. Roth Jr., a Delaware Republican; Representative John Conyers Jr., a Michigan Democrat, and Representative John R. Kasich, an Ohio Republican. All four lawmakers are longtime critics of Pentagon spending.

HEADLINE: Bosnians Urge Tougher Response to Serb Rejection of Accord

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzego vina, July 31

 BODY:
Bosnian Government leaders today criticized the United States and four other major powers for failing to take decisive action against the Bosnian Serbs for rejecting a peace plan.
In Belgrade, President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia recommended that Bosnian Serb leaders reverse their rejection of the peace proposal, which would require the Serbs to acknowledge Bosnia's sovereignty, at least temporarily, and hand back a third of the territory they have captured and "ethnically cleansed." 
 At a meeting in Geneva on Saturday, the foreign ministers from the so-called "contact group" countries -- the United States, Germany, France, Great Britain and Russia -- warned that they would, among other things, press the United Nations Security Council to tighten spottily enforced economic sanctions against Serbia because of the Bosnian Serbs' rejection of the peace plan. But the five countries avoided tougher measures like a renewed threat of air strikes.
 
U.N. Review Scheduled
 The Security Council is expected to consider the foreign ministers' recommendation in about a week.
At a news conference today, members of Bosnia's Muslim-led Government used words like "disappointing" and "indecisive" to describe the contact group's response to the Serbs' rejection of the plan.
"We are disappointed at the lack of an effective response," President Alija Izetbegovic said, adding that the foreign ministers' recommendation "doesn't mention military retaliation if the plan is not implemented."
"Economic sanctions are by their very nature uncertain and long-term," he said. "The deadline for the Serbs to accept has also been pushed back twice, indicating a dangerous indecisiveness on the part of the international community."
 
The Price of Unity
 Bosnia's Prime Minister, Haris Silajdzic, said the Geneva meeting showed a lack of consensus by the members of the contact group on more energetic punitive measures against the Serbs, including the lifting of a United Nations arms embargo that has left Bosnia's legal Government at a decided disadvantage against the better-armed Serbs since the beginning of the war.
The ministers' response, Mr. Silajdzic said, "is probably the price for the unity of the contact group."
Mr. Silajdzic was clearly referring to a refusal by Russia to agree to sharper punitive measures against the Serbs. Russia has long had strong ties with the Serbs, sharing an Eastern Orthodox religious tradition.
Mr. Milosevic waited until after the foreign ministers threatened to tighten sanctions against Serbia to make his first public statement on the peace proposal, in which he urged the Bosnian Serbs to accept the deal.
The Bosnian Serbs have received military and economic support from Serbia. But the Serbian Government has consistently denied providing such aid and has called repeatedly for the lifting of the punitive United Nations economic sanctions -- the most effective provisions of which are the freezing of Serbian assets abroad, the cutting of Serbia's ties with the international banking community and the closing of Belgrade Airport to international air traffic. Trade sanctions against Serbia have largely been ignored, especially by Russia, Greece and Macedonia.
"Commitment to peace is in the interest of the entire Serbian nation," Mr. Milosevic said in a statement released to Serbia's main press agency. "This means that the international community's proposal must be accepted, enabling a continuation of the peace process.
"A compromise is necessary. Giving one half of the territory to the Bosnian Serb republic and the other half to the Muslim-Croat federation cannot be called 'anti-Serb.' "
The Bosnian Serbs' leadership, which is strongly under the influence of ultranationalist military commanders loath to abandon their dream for the creation of a greater Serbian state, has been at odds with Mr. Milosevic since before the Serbs began the war in Bosnia in April 1992.
Last year, the commander of the Bosnian Serbs' militia, Gen. Ratko Mladic, singlehandedly engineered the defeat of a similar international peace plan that would have required Serbian military pullbacks. It is highly unlikely that Mr. Milosevic's appeal will carry any more weight this time.
More powerful, and popular, than any other Serbian political leader, Mr. Milosevic has recently begun a campaign to present himself as a peacemaker and a defender of Serbia's interests. Protecting "endangered" Serbs outside his republic formed the heart and soul of the nationalist oratory that brought the Serbian President to power.
Mr. Milosevic's statement said acceptance of the peace plan, which would lead to a lifting of the economic sanctions against Serbia, was the least the Bosnian Serbs could do to repay the Serbs in Serbia for their sacrifices on the Bosnian Serbs' behalf.
Sarajevo's battlefront went relatively quiet after Bosnian Army and Bosnian Serb militia forces squared off in the heaviest firefight in months on Saturday evening.
Three women and a 5-year-old girl were wounded today when Serbian militiamen launched two rocket-propelled grenades into the Sarajevo suburb of Dobrinja.
Fighting was also reported today near the towns of Teslic, Bihac and Gorazde.

HEADLINE: U.S. Moves Against Japanese

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
After another collapse in their long-running trade talks, the Clinton Administration today formally accused Japan of discriminating against American companies in awarding Government contracts there for medical equipment and telecommunications gear.
The legal move could lead to a retaliatory ban later this year on Japanese bids for certain Federal contracts here. 
 While the maneuvering over Government contracts is unlikely to have any immediate impact on the countries' $155 billion a year in two-way trade, it could drive down the dollar's value in international currency markets. Many currency traders said that if trade talks did not succeed, the United States might try to drive down the value of the dollar so as to make American goods cheaper in the Japanese market and give them a larger market share there than negotiations have produced.
 
 
Denial by Administration
 Administration officials have denied any such intention and called in recent weeks for a stronger dollar. Private economists have pointed out that the dollar's 10.3 percent decline against the yen already this year should be enough to have an effect eventually on trade flows, even without further Administration action.
[The failure of the talks jolted the foreign exchange market in Tokyo Monday morning, putting the dollar into a short free fall against the yen before rebounding. Page D4.]
The dollar rose above 100 yen last week for the first time in a month after rumors swept currency markets that a deal in the Government contract dispute might be pending, contrary to the conventional wisdom here and in Tokyo.
 
 
Two Months of Talks
 Today's announcement starts a two-month period of talks between the two countries. If no settlement is reached by the end of September, the Administration would have the option of notifying Congress of possible bidding restrictions, and could impose those restrictions 30 days later.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, played down the possibility of retaliation in a statement today announcing the formal accusation of unfairness by Japan. "The time has come to use our trade laws to, first, proceed with the period of consultation and negotiation, and then, if necessary, to address the question of continued discrimination against U.S. companies," he said.
Japanese officials nonetheless responded indignantly. The section of American law invoked today by Mr. Kantor "is purely a question of U.S. domestic law and is not relevant to the Government of Japan," said a Japanese Embassy official here who insisted on anonymity.
[On Monday in Tokyo, Japanese officials said the Government would not take countermeasures now. But Kozo Igarashi, the Chief Cabinet Secretary, said that if the United States actually enacted sanctions, Japan would break off talks entirely.]
In making today's accusation after the talks broke down on Saturday evening, the Administration showed a willingness to continue confronting Japan despite possible damage to diplomatic relations and despite the continuing political turmoil there. Japan has had four Prime Ministers in a little more than a year.
American and Japanese trade officials have said the lack of strong political leadership makes it more difficult to strike deals on Government procurement issues. The Prime Minister's office has traditionally played the role of forcing greater openness in trade on Government ministries with strong ties to the industries they regulate, according to trade experts.
 
 
'No Japanese Government'
 "Part of the problem is there is no Japanese Government, there's a collection of ministries," said Joseph A. Massey, the assistant United States trade representative for Japan and China during most of the Bush Administration. "Just trying to get a decision out of that process is like punching a marshmallow."
The Administration is accusing the Japanese Government of "persistent and discriminatory practices" in the awarding of contracts for medical and telecommunications equipment. Under a 1988 law, the President can bar bids for certain Federal contracts from countries that do not let American companies compete for Government contracts on an equal footing with domestic companies.
But the legislation bars broader trade sanctions. The United States and Japan are also members of an international pact affiliated with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that prevents countries from imposing restrictions on all but the smallest contracts involving goods.
When the Clinton Administration invoked the Government procurement law last year to issue a list of bidding restrictions on companies from the European Union, the proposed restrictions mostly involved contracts for services, like construction, the dredging of harbors and the operation of cafeterias in Federal buildings. A handful of these restrictions are still in effect on bidders from some European Union nations.
 
 
Technical Merits
 Mr. Kantor accused the Japanese Government today of ignoring the technical merits of American bids, giving little warning of upcoming procurements and using technical standards that appear tailored to Japanese companies' products. But according to Japanese officials, the Administration has spent most of its energy seeking numerical standards for measuring success, like requiring that American companies win a rising percentage of contracts in each quarter in the coming years.
The Japanese Government has resisted numerical standards, fearing that if such standards are not met they will become the basis for American trade sanctions.
Japan issued a plan four months ago to revise its procurement procedures for telecommunications and medical equipment, but Mr. Kantor today dismissed these changes as inadequate. The plan "is not sufficient to address the persistent pattern of discrimination in the telecommunications and medical technology sectors faced by American firms, which are global leaders in their industries," he said in a statement.
Imports, mostly from the United States, occupy only 5 percent of the Government and private markets in Japan for telecommunications equipment, compared with 25 percent of the overall market in other industrialized countries, according to figures released by Mr. Kantor's office today. American businesses hold less than 20 percent of the Japanese medical equipment market, compared with nearly 40 percent of the European Union market, the figures indicate.
 
 
Europe's Neutral Battleground
 The Japanese Embassy official said imports accounted for even less of Government procurement in the United States than in Japan. American officials have rejected similar arguments in the past, saying that American companies should fare better because they have outperformed Japanese rivals in the European market, which they describe as a neutral commercial battleground.
The current trade talks revolve around American efforts to make Japanese procurement procedures less secretive and to set some criteria for measuring whether American bids are becoming more successful.
One mystery about the currency markets in recent days is why so many traders apparently believed a deal would be struck, when Japanese newspapers, which follow in great detail even the slightest twist and turn in trade talks, have been predicting imminent failure.
Mr. Massey, the former assistant United States trade representative, said currency traders have long done a poor job of following trade conflicts. "They don't understand this is a step-by-step process during which for a day or two things will seem better and for a day or two things will seem worse," he said.
Also today, American and Canadian officials continued talks by telephone over Canadian wheat exports to the United States. Congressional officials and American farming representatives consulted in the talks said that the two sides were close to a deal but would not rule out the possibility of American sanctions against Canada on Monday.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
International
The Clinton Administration formally accused Japan of discriminating against American companies in Government contracts for medical equipment and telecommunications. The legal move could lead to a retaliatory ban later this year on Japanese bids for certain Federal contracts and comes after another breakdown in the two nations' long trade talks. [Page D1.] The failure jolted the foreign exchange market in Tokyo Monday morning, putting the dollar into a temporary free fall against the yen. [D4.]

[D1.]
China barred new stock listings in an effort to halt plunges on the Shanghai and Shenzhen exchanges. Regulators sought to calm millions of first-time investors who evidently went into the market believing that stock prices could only go up. [D1.]
Banks in India have been accused of misreporting millions of dollars in 1991 and 1992 and illegally diverting government bonds. The central bank of India has fined 10 foreign banks, including Citibank, which has been told to pay $16.1 million. [D3.]
 
The Media Business
 Why are some books that sell hundreds of thousands of copies every year not on best-seller lists? In large part, it has to do with the way such lists are calculated. Perennial hidden best sellers -- many of them inspirational, how-to and service books -- are crucial to publishers because they bring in a steady annual income. [A1.]
ABC and NBC will wage war for dominance of Tuesday night when "Frasier," NBC's comedy challenger, goes head-to-head against the champion, ABC's "Roseanne," in the fall. And the stakes are high: dominance of a night in prime time means millions of dollars of additional advertising revenues. [D1.]
Time Inc. has been sprouting a number of new magazines. The recent flurry of new publications is largely a result of a decentralization that has given individual magazines the freedom to generate ideas and spin off other publications. [D6.]
At a convention of minority journalists, there was much debate about the way the news media cover the world. Are news organizations paralyzed by political correctness or are they simply being sensitive? William Glaberson: Press. [D6.]
The owner of Hong Kong's largest circulation weekly magazine has managed to enrage China and provoke Hong Kong gangs. The Hong Kong publication, Next Magazine, is a thick journal of local politics, crime, fashion and life styles. [A4.]

 A report on second-quarter economic growth set off rallies in the stock and bond markets on Friday. But the Federal Reserve may still raise interest rates, which would weaken corporate profits and hurt stocks. Analysts say the financial markets are not at the beginning of a sustained rally but are merely heading into the happy end of some wide trading ranges. [D1.]
An auto club is making its data base of travel information available for use on personal computers. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Despite 3 Primaries on Tuesday, Michigan Voters Go Fishing

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAMTRAMCK, Mich., July 31

 BODY:
On the eve of this state's Democratic primary for the United States Senate, Representative Bob Carr is leading his five opponents in the polls.
But at the Clock Restaurant in this working-class town, which is surrounded by Detroit, customers who peered over their apple waffles had trouble this morning placing the Congressman, who could pass for Dick Van Dyke's younger brother. 
 One diner asked Mr. Carr if he was running for governor. At a corner booth nearby, Irene Karas knew better than to ask that. Her question: "You're a Republican, right?"
The early expectations were that the three statewide primaries here would make for the liveliest that Michigan has seen in decades. For the Senate seat that Donald W. Riegle Jr. is leaving, there are a six-way Democratic race and a two-way Republican contest, and for the right to challenge Gov. John Engler, a Republican, a four-way Democratic fight.
 
Voters Stay Silent
 But despite the interest from candidates, voters do not seem to be paying attention, and those who do seem confused by the large number of candidates. Forecasters are predicting record-low turnouts on Tuesday. Among people who do expect to vote, polls indicate that many are just now starting to make up their minds. In a state where many residents devote their summer leisure time to fishing up north, there is no contest: fishing triumphs over politics.
Part of the problem seems to be a lack of compelling candidates, or compelling issues to drive their campaigns. Though Mr. Carr is enjoying a slight lead in the Senate race, voters hardly seem enthusiastic about him. The top contenders in both the Republican Senate primary and the Democratic race for governor are neck-in-neck in the latest polls.
There has been no lightning-rod issue. The candidates do not have the economy because Michigan is rebounding with the lowest unemployment rate in two decades. The health care debate has barely been mentioned. That has left the candidates struggling to make the most out of the issue at the top of the polls: crime.
"It has been an almost issueless, completely vapid campaign," said William Ballenger, the editor of a newsletter, Inside Michigan Politics. "It has been one of the most soporific Senate campaigns in Michigan history. People are barely aware that it even has a pulse."
Ronna Romney, a former radio talk show host who is seeking the Republican Senate nomination, did not disagree. "Quite frankly," she said, "I don't think we ever got to substantive issues in this campaign."
Yet, the importance of the outcomes on Tuesday cannot be underestimated: Michigan is one of the pivotal swing states in the Presidential elections, and the Republican have made Mr. Riegle's seat one of the top targets in their uphill, yet not impossible, drive for control of the Senate. Mr. Riegle, a Democrat, is retiring in the aftermath of his involvement with the former savings-and-loan operator Charles Keating. And Mr. Engler's campaign will be viewed as a test of the success of his program to reduce the welfare rolls and to stop using property taxes for schools.
The most interest in the closing days of the campaign has been in the Republican Senate primary, where Ms. Romney's lead over Spencer Abraham, a former state Republican chairman, seemed to be eroding. Ms. Romney, who benefited as the former daughter-in-law of a former Governor, George W. Romney, led Mr. Abraham throughout most of the campaign. But a poll published today by The Detroit News put the two, who have similar conservative views, in a virtual tie.
Mr. Abraham, who was a deputy chief of staff to former Vice President Dan Quayle, has sought to turn his lack of charisma into a virtue by portraying himself as more substantive. In a stinging new television commercial from the Abraham campaign, Ms. Romney is described derisively as a socialite. The tag line about her: "Glitz, not guts."
While he attacked her as shallow, Mr. Abraham also argued that it was disingenuous for Ms. Romney to deny her long involvement in party politics. "She's been in every smoke-filled room in the Michigan Republican Party for 16 years," said Mike Murphy, the media consultant for Mr. Abraham and Mr. Engler. "I've seen her there."
But Ms. Romney, who is smooth on the stump, presented herself as an outsider who would have a better chance of winning in November. "No. 1 is the electability factor," she said, adding that Mr. Abraham was the consummate insider. The tag line for Ms. Romney's commercial: "Spence Abraham. Just another double-talking politician."
On the Democratic side, Mr. Carr has hung on to a bare lead by continually reminding voters that he has steered resources to Michigan during his 18 years as a Congressman from East Lansing. Mr. Carr, who has become increasingly moderate to mirror his district's accelerating shift to the right, portrayed himself as "the only candidate with a moderate mainstream message."
Close behind is Lana Pollack, a State Senator from Ann Arbor who has run an aggressive campaign and is seen as having a lock on liberal voters. Joel Ferguson, a wealthy businessman from Lansing, also seemed to be gaining support in the closing days of the campaign. He helped engineer Jesse Jackson's upset victory in Michigan's 1988 Presidential primary, but has emphasized his moderate positions.
Also running is William M. Brodhead, once a popular Congressman who has struggled to recapture his political base in the Detroit suburbs since retiring from the House in 1982. Carl Marlinga, the Macomb County prosecutor, has been unable to convince many voters that he can move beyond crime issues. And there is John Kelly, a State Senator, who is bright but dismissed by many as a gadfly.
Only in the last week or so has the race for governor turned nasty, with the leading contenders unleashing attack advertisements. Perhaps the early politeness held because the candidates were friends. At the wedding last year of one candidate, former Representative Howard Wolpe, another contender, Lynn Jondahl, an ordained minister and State Representative, conducted the ceremony. A third candidate, State Senator Debbie Stabenow, was a guest.
A fourth candidate, Larry Owen, is a former Mayor of East Lansing. He was not at the wedding. but he, too, has known the other candidates. His best asset in the race is an endorsement from the powerful Michigan Education Association, which wants to punish Mr. Engler and Ms. Stabenow for backing a school-financing proposal that it strongly opposed.
The battle has largely been between Mr. Wolpe, who has gained from an endorsement from the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. but is viewed by some as too liberal to beat Mr. Engler, and Ms. Stabenow, who has sought to distinguish herself as the only woman in the race. The latest polls show the race going either way.

State Senator Debbie Stabenow, above center, gestured as she pressed a point in Detroit about the Democratic race for governor. Above right, Spencer Abraham campaigned in Royal Oak in the Republican Senate contest. (Photographs by Peter Yates for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Friday's Wall Street Rally May Be Less Than It Seems

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
After Friday's impressive rally in the stock market and sensational increases in the bond market, Wall Street traders may be tempted to pinch themselves to see if they are dreaming.
If they do, they will find that they are, say those who have studied the Government's report on second-quarter economic growth that prompted Friday's buying of stocks and bonds. The lean months are yet to pass and the fat ones in the financial markets are not yet here, these analysts say. 
 Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, may look at the figures in the report on the gross domestic product that cheered Wall Street and do the opposite of what the markets expect and raise interest rates, they say. Indeed, he implied as much in his recent Congressional testimony.
A fifth increase in interest rates would be sure to slow the economy further, perhaps bolstering bonds and strengthening the dollar. But it would also weaken corporate profits and thus hurt stocks, at least for the short run.
Wall Street economists had expected that economic growth in the second quarter would come in at 3.9 percent or more, a worrisome pace that could tempt the Fed to raise rates. But the figure came in at 3.7 percent. More important, inventories rose sharply while consumer spending was weak and many traders and investors seemed to conclude that this combination would discourage the Fed from lifting rates.
"It was one of those positives that was really a non-negative," said Christine A. Callies, equity market analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company.
Whatever the case, on Friday the Dow Jones industrial average jumped almost 34 points, to 3,764.50, and the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond plummeted to 7.39 percent from 7.54 percent.
But the likelihood is that the financial markets are not at the beginning of a sustained rally, but merely heading into the happy end of some wide trading ranges, analysts say. For stocks, that trading range may be 3,600 to 3,800 for the Dow. For bonds, it may be 7.62 percent to 7.25 percent on the long bond.
A yield below 7 percent, a level not seen since March and one that would prompt a torrid rally in stocks, seems highly unlikely, analysts say.
And what of the summer rally and the dream long ago (in January) of a Dow soaring to 4,000?
 
 
'Predisposed to Find Inflation'
 "Getting to 4,000 would presume that Alan Greenspan is no longer worried about inflation," said Neal M. Soss, a former Wall Street economist who recently co-founded Soss & Cotton Enterprises, a hedge fund and economic consultant. "And we know that he is predisposed to find inflation" and thus raise rates.
There are many other reasons for caution, analysts say. In the short run, the Government's release of July employment figures this Friday could move the markets in a nasty way if they turn out to be surprisingly strong.
The week after that, the Government plans its quarterly sale of debt, the auction of some $40 billion in new 3-year and 10-year Treasury notes that can make the bond market stumble.
And there is continuing trade friction between Japan and the United States. The nations broke off trade talks Saturday, a move certain to prompt currency speculators to act.
"The only wild card is the dollar," said Glen T. Insley, who is otherwise optimistic about the course of stocks and bonds. "The hot-money boys could take another run at it." Mr. Insley is director of fixed-income investments at the First Union Corporation and helps manage $14 billion in fixed-income assets.
But perhaps the biggest reason for wariness is in the second-quarter gross domestic product figures, the proximate cause of Friday's rally in stocks and bonds.
True, inventories of unsold goods rose sharply, perhaps indicating that consumers and businesses were buying less and thus a sign of a slowing economy. Indeed, when the inventory increase, about $28.6 billion, is factored out, second-quarter growth would have been an even weaker 3.16 percent, good news for those concerned about inflation.
 In his written testimony submitted on July 20 to the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan acknowledged that accumulating inventories could signal a weakening economy. "Conversely," he said, "the inventory accumulation may reflect pressures on firms who had brought inventories down to suboptimal levels and now need to replenish them."
If so, he said, "stock-building may continue at an above-normal rate, supporting production for quite some time." In other words, inflationary pressures. Moreover, "the improving economic conditions of our trading partners should add impetus to aggregate demand from the external sector." In other words, inflationary pressures.
"The fact of the matter is, we went into this quarter with awfully, awfully low inventories," said Jan Terbrueggen, a portfolio manager with Flagship Financial who helps manage more than $5 billion in fixed-income assets. And that may mean that while inventories surged in the second quarter, they may not be high enough to force the cutback in production in the months ahead that some analysts were suggesting Friday.
Thus Mr. Greenspan, looking at the same statistics that convinced Wall Street that he would not raise interest rates as soon as expected, might raise them anyway.

HEADLINE: U.N. Resolution for Invasion of Haiti

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 31

 BODY:
Following is the text of Security Council Resolution 940 adopted today, which clears the way for the United States to lead an invasion intended to topple Haiti's military leaders and restore President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who was ousted in a coup in September 1991. The resolution was adopted 12-0 with Brazil and China abstaining and Rwanda absent.

 THE SECURITY COUNCIL,
REAFFIRMING its Resolutions 841 (1993) of 16 June 1993, 861 (1993) of 27 August 1993, 862 (1993) of 31 August 1993, 867 (1993) of 23 September 1993, 873 (1993) of 13 October 1993, 875 (1993) of 16 October 1993, 905 (1994) of 23 March 1994, 917 (1994) of 6 May 1994 and 933 (1994) of 30 June 1994, 
 RECALLING the terms of the Governors Island Agreement, and the related Pact of New York,
CONDEMNING the continuing disregard of those agreements by the illegal de facto regime, and the regime's refusal to cooperate with efforts by the United Nations and the Organization of American States (O.A.S.) to bring about their implementation,
GRAVELY CONCERNED by the significant further deterioration of the humanitarian situation in Haiti, in particular the continuing escalation by the illegal de facto regime of systematic violations of civil liberties, the desperate plight of Haitian refugees and the recent expulsion of the staff of the International Civilian Mission, which was condemned in its Presidential statement of 12 July 1994,
HAVING CONSIDERED the reports of the Secretary-General of 15 July 1994 and 26 July 1994,
TAKING NOTE of the letter dated 29 July 1994 from the legitimately elected President of Haiti and the letter dated 30 July 1994 from the Permanent Representative of Haiti to the United Nations,
REITERATING its commitment for the international community to assist and support the economic, social and institutional development of Haiti,
REAFFIRMING that the goal of the international community remains the restoration of democracy in Haiti and the prompt return of the legitimately elected President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, within the framework of the Governors Island Agreement,
RECALLING that in Resolution 873 (1993) the Council confirmed its readiness to consider the imposition of additional measures if the military authorities in Haiti continued to impede the activities of the United Nations Mission in Haiti (UNMIH) or failed to comply in full with its relevant resolutions and the provisions of the Governors Island Agreement,
DETERMINING that the situation in Haiti continues to constitute a threat to peace and security in the region,
1. WELCOMES the report of the Secretary-General and TAKES NOTE of his support for action under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations in order to assist the legitimate government of Haiti in the maintenance of public order;
2. RECOGNIZES the unique character of the present situation in Haiti and its deteriorating, complex and extraordinary nature, requiring an exceptional response;
3. DETERMINES that the illegal de facto regime in Haiti has failed to comply with the Governors Island Agreement and is in breach of its obligations under the relevant resolutions of the Security Council;
4. ACTING under Chapter VII of the Charter of the United Nations, AUTHORIZES Member States to form a multinational force under unified command and control and, in this framework, to use all necessary means to facilitate the departure from Haiti of the military leadership, consistent with the Governors Island Agreement, the prompt return of the legitimately elected President and the restoration of the legitimate authorities of the Government of Haiti, and to establish and maintain a secure and stable environment that will permit implementation of the Governors Island Agreement, on the understanding that the cost of implementing this temporary operation will be borne by the participating Member States;
5. APPROVES the establishment, upon adoption of this resolution, of an advance team of UNMIH of not more than sixty personnel, including a group of observers, to establish the appropriate means of coordination with the multinational force, to carry out the monitoring of the operations of the multinational force and other functions described in paragraph 23 of the report of the Secretary-General of 15 July 1994, and to assess requirements and to prepare for the deployment of UNMIH upon completion of the mission of the multinational force;
6. REQUESTS the Secretary-General to report on the activities of the team within thirty days of the date of deployment of the multinational force;
7. DECIDES that the tasks of the advance team as defined in paragraph 5 above will expire on the date of termination of the mission of the multinational force;
8. DECIDES that the multinational force will terminate its mission and UNMIH will assume the full range of its functions described in paragraph 9 below when a secure and stable environment has been established and UNMIH has adequate force capability and structure to assume the full range of its functions; the determination will be made by the Security Council, taking into account recommendations from the Member States of the Multinational Force, which are based on the assessment of the commander of the multinational force, and from the Secretary-General;
9. DECIDES to revise and extend the mandate of the United Nations Mission in Haiti for a period of six months to assist the democratic Government of Haiti in fulfilling its responsibilities in connection with:
a. sustaining the secure and stable environment established during the multinational phase and protecting international personnel and key installations; and
b. the professionalization of the Haitian armed forces and the creation of a separate police force;
10. REQUESTS ALSO that UNMIH assist the legitimate constitutional authorities of Haiti in establishing an environment conducive to the organization of free and fair legislative elections to be called by those authorities and, when requested by them, monitored by the United Nations, in cooperation with the Organization of American States (O.A.S.);
11. DECIDES to increase the troop level of UNMIH to 6,000 and establishes the objective of completing UNMIH's mission, in cooperation with the constitutional government of Haiti, not later than February 1996;
12. INVITES all States, in particular those in the region, to provide appropriate support for the actions undertaken by the United Nations and by Member States pursuant to this and other relevant Security Council resolutions;
13. REQUESTS the Member States acting in accordance with paragraph 4 above to report to the Council at regular intervals, the first such report to be made not later than seven days following the deployment of the multinational force;
14. REQUESTS the Secretary-General to report on the implementation of this resolution at sixty-day intervals starting from the date of deployment of the multinational force;
15. DEMANDS strict respect for the persons and premises of the United Nations, the Organization of American States, other international and humanitarian organizations and diplomatic missions in Haiti, and that no acts of intimidation or violence be directed against personnel engaged in humanitarian or peace-keeping work;
16. EMPHASIZES the necessity that, inter alia:
a. All appropriate steps be taken to insure the security and safety of the operations and personnel engaged in such operations; and
b. The security and safety arrangements undertaken extend to all persons engaged in the operation
17. AFFIRMS that the Council will review the measures imposed pursuant to resolutions 841 (1993), 873 (1993) and 917 (1994), with a view to lifting them in their entirety, immediately following the return to Haiti of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide;
18. DECIDES to remain actively seized of the matter.

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1256 words

HEADLINE: Ex-Mayor Barry Rises From Ashes

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
At first glance they seem the most improbable of scenes: crowds hailing Marion S. Barry Jr. as a savior of the city, cheering him on as he seeks a fourth term as mayor.
After all, this is the same man whose third term effectively ended four years ago when Federal agents videotaped him smoking crack. He was convicted on a misdemeanor charge of cocaine possession and served six months in prison. 
 But in the strange brew of local politics in Washington, Mr. Barry is marching through rehabilitation and redemption.
In the most recent independent poll of District of Columbia voters, conducted in late June by The Washington Post, 38 percent said they would vote for Mr. Barry, compared with 26 percent for John Ray, a member of the City Council, and 16 percent for the current Mayor, Sharon Pratt Kelly, whose political troubles have left a political opening for Mr. Barry. All of the candidates are black. The survey had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.
 
Talents as a Politician
 "I call him the 'It' politician," Terry Lynch, executive director of the Downtown Cluster of Congregations, a local alliance of 29 churches, said of Mr. Barry. "Like the 'It Girl,' he's got it. He has innate political abilities, a talent cultivated to a fine expertise. And unlike Mayor Kelly, he has the ability to reach out."
Mr. Barry's rise from political ruin began when he left prison and moved into the city's poorest ward, where he was elected two years ago to the City Council. If the next step, a leap to City Hall, might seem ambitious, Mr. Barry's appeal to lower-income blacks makes it easier to understand. This is a city in which blacks constitute 70 percent of the population, and only a plurality is required to win the Democratic primary in September, with the winner virtually assured of victory in November. Democrats in Washington outnumber Republicans by more than 10 to 1.
Mr. Barry was a longtime civil rights worker before he was first elected mayor, in 1978, and he still draws strong support from many of the same groups he served after he arrived in Washington in 1965: middle- and lower-income blacks, especially the elderly, the young, the unemployed and others who feel a sense of alienation from the system. But it is less certain that he retains as much support from business leaders and middle-class blacks, whose backing was important in his first two terms.
To many of his supporters, his fall and ascent parallel their own struggles and have a ring of Biblical triumph akin to those they celebrate every Sunday in church. "You should not be penalized because you have made a mistake," said the Rev. Charlene Monk, pastor of a Methodist church in a black middle-class neighborhood. "If a Christian cannot find repentance, then something is wrong."
Also, said Dr. Lorenzo Morris, a professor of political science at Howard University in Washington, many black voters are more willing to forgive personal transgressions than political ones.
"Blacks," Dr. Morris said, "would not forgive President Nixon."
It is clear in campaigning that Mr. Barry has measured the political risks of discussing the past. Mindful of the opportunity created by Mrs. Kelly's sagging fortunes and sensitive to the willingness of many voters to forgive, he openly acknowledges the "difficult times of my valley experience" and spins them into a resume that portrays him as a better prospect for mayor because of his rehabilitation, which he continues for drug and alcohol abuse, and personal redemption.
"People are beginning to examine what I would do as mayor," he said before a brief ceremony last week with a handful of police officers endorsing him. "My programs are becoming the issue, not my problems. It's about there with a lot of people. It'll happen with more."
At the ceremony, he alluded to his arrest, saying, "When you have been on the other side, you see things firsthand and you know the criminal justice system needs to be fine-tuned."
 
Weakened Competitors
 But Mr. Barry's popularity with some voters is also a result of a growing feeling that his successor, Mrs. Kelly, has botched her chance to govern well and that Mr. Ray, who lost in three previous bids for mayor, is not strong enough to lead. Never mind that Mrs. Kelly inherited some problems from Mr. Barry, including a bloated city government and budget deficits, or that Mr. Ray has served more than a decade as a City Council member.
Their problems have only energized Mr. Barry's campaign, making his return to power that much more conceivable, even with most white voters firmly opposed to him. The Post survey said that 50 percent of white voters favored Mr. Ray, 27 percent favored Mrs. Kelly and just 1 percent preferred Mr. Barry. Campaigning at a Fourth of July parade in the city's most affluent district, Ward 3, which is mostly white, Mr. Barry was booed and derided.
Yet many blacks and lower-income voters support Mr. Barry because of what he once meant to their communities by creating jobs, especially since Mrs. Kelly has been forced to eliminate thousands of government jobs.
"This is not all an issue of race," said Jamin B. Raskin, associate dean of the American University Law School in Washington. "A lot of working-class people in Washington remember Marion Barry and the 'fat days' in Washington. Under Barry, the government swelled but the job force grew, and he made concerted efforts to give business to black entrepreneurs."
"Keep in mind," Mr. Raskin added, "black Washington and white Washington have diametrically opposed expectations of local government. Whites want lower taxes and a shrinking government. The black community looks at the D.C. government not as a burden but as an employer, a safety net. The black community wants local government strong, vibrant and active in their lives. Mayor Kelly brags about making the tough decisions to cut back jobs. But that is a direct slap for working-class blacks who count on the D.C. government for their livelihoods."
 
Modest Promises
 With Congress expected to cut the District's budget by at least $100 million for the next fiscal year, Mr. Barry has avoided promising a return to the flush days, which led to corruption scandals in his second term.
But he has campaigned on the issues that affect the quality of life in the city, especially for many people in the less affluent sections, issues like the high crime rate, deterioration of schools and decline in services, as well as the need to expand the District's tax base by attracting more businesses through property tax exemptions and by requiring city employees to live in Washington.
He has also promised to put more uniformed police officers on the streets and focus investigative efforts on "the most violent criminals." He promised the police officers that "the No. 1 plank on my program is to get the guns off the streets."
To his detractors, and to many undecided voters, Mr. Barry, while perhaps still the champion of the poor, also remains a shrewd opportunist. It remains unclear whether Mr. Barry can expand his base deeper into the black middle class, voters he will need if Mr. Ray finds a way to revamp his own campaign or if Mrs. Kelly makes what would be widely considered to be a miraculous recovery.
"There is a lot of ambiguity in this race," Dr. Lorenzo said. "Everything is so divided. Any single event could change things, any faux pas by Barry or a good performance by Ray. Right now, I would have no predictions."
