HEADLINE: In Selma, Everything and Nothing Changed

SERIES: New South and Old: Third of four articles.

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SELMA, Ala.

 BODY:
Bob Mants came to the Alabama Black Belt to work for civil rights in 1965 and still has a cattle-prod scar in his back to remind him of "Bloody Sunday," the attack on civil rights marchers here that evoked the worst of the dying empire of Jim Crow.
Mr. Mants is still here working as director of a hand-to-mouth economic development agency, trying to bring jobs to desperately poor Lowndes County. But his dream that he would see an old order steadily giving way to a new and better one died long ago. 
 "I thought back then, if there was any place I wanted to raise my kids, it would be here, because they could see black people moving forward, advancing ourselves as a race," said Mr. Mants, 51, who on that fateful Sunday stood second in line behind John Lewis, now a United States Representative from Georgia, as mounted sheriff's deputies attacked and sprayed tear gas on marchers advocating voting rights. "I was naive. People may even be poorer now than when I came here in 1965. The progress hasn't taken place."
No one can say the old Alabama cotton country is the same place it was during the 1960's, when civil rights workers -- blacks like Jimmie Lee Jackson and whites like the Rev. James Reeb and Viola Liuzzo -- were killed trying to get blacks the right to vote; when the Black Panther Party was formed in Lowndes County, and when Bloody Sunday and the Selma-to-Montgomery march led to the Voting Rights Act of 1965.
Today, in a region where they were long denied the right to vote, blacks hold as much political power as any other place in America, controlling most of the local and county governments in this southwest corner of the state.
But instead of a place transformed, the Black Belt, so named for the color of its soil, not the bulk of its population, is a reminder that though the civil rights movement ended one world, it did not create another.
The schools here are generally still segregated, with the old white public schools virtually all black and the whites -- working class as well as wealthy -- in private academies. The racial violence of the past is largely gone, replaced by a flood of drug-related, black-on-black crime that dwarfs the violence of Jim Crow. The civil rights leaders of the 1960's are now the entrenched political class, but the state-mandated tax code still protects the interests of the white landowners who preceded them. The median family income of $18,349 is about half the national average and $10,000 below the state average, in a state that is one of the poorest.
Perhaps worst of all, it is a place where blacks and whites, like punch-drunk boxers, are still fighting the same old battles of race.
"If the swords had been laid down long ago, things could have progressed further," said James E. Ware, who is black and who now heads the Dallas County welfare department in Selma. "Here we are the cradle of the civil rights movement, the mecca of the Voting Rights Act. You'd think that with all the sacrifices that were made and the lives lost, we could have found a way to capitalize on it. What saddens me most is that we've never done that."
 
The Economy
Stark Poverty And Tax Breaks
 The rich black humus of the Black Belt was built up over millions of years from the remains of the tiny shelled organisms in what was once a shallow marine sea.
The black soil begat cotton, and cotton begat a flourishing economy based on slavery. And just as millions of years of geologic history determined the Black Belt's economic destiny, the economics of the past have shaped the identity of the Black Belt today, a place that is 66 percent black and one of the poorest parts of the United States.
With its enduring landscape of white-columned antebellum houses and weathered shotgun shacks, its social ritual of cordiality masking dense layers of turmoil, the Black Belt defines the South of William Faulkner, where the past is inseparable from the present, where the dead still walk, and where everything has changed and nothing has.
The past is alive in the ledger dating to 1928, proudly displayed in the Old Beechwood Grocery near Hayneville, with its rolling pine floors, dusty canned foods and a 1937 Chevy and a 1940 Packard rusting outside. It is alive in the 19th-century portraits of the founders of the J. B. Hain Company, a cotton and agricultural firm that operates from the back of the Old Sardis Store south of Selma. It is alive in the countless Old South and Civil War and civil rights and Bloody Sunday observances with which blacks and whites celebrate their separate histories.
And mostly it is alive because, for all the sacrifice and triumph of the civil rights era, nothing touched the economic structure that continued to give whites control of the land, the jobs and the capital as well as the tax system that revolves around them.
 
'Our Critical Mistake'
 "When the civil rights movement ended, institutional building didn't begin," said Rose Sanders, who is black and a prominent civil rights lawyer in Selma. "People were so elated to have a victory, to have a President say, 'We Shall Overcome' and sign the Voting Rights Act, that many people thought the battle was over. That was our critical mistake. Now there are less institutions, particularly economic institutions, that meet the needs of black people than there were 30 years ago."
The statistics are dismal. Though the South led the nation in population growth in the 1980's, the 10 Black Belt counties saw their population fall by 13 percent, to 187,994, with a net migration out of 29,052 people.
More than half the blacks live in poverty, led by Wilcox County, where the black poverty rate is 60 percent. Only 10 percent of Wilcox County's whites live in poverty. In Lowndes County 5.8 percent of whites live in poverty and 50 percent of blacks do. In Selma, home to most of the Black Belt's wealth, median household income for whites is $25,580. For blacks it is $9,615.
Selma, with a population of 24,000 in a metropolitan area of 31,000, lost one of its economic underpinnings in 1978 when Craig Air Force Base closed, eliminating 2,400 jobs. The agricultural economy that supported small black and white farmers in the civil rights era has collapsed, leaving the industry to big agricultural and timber interests.
"I made loans 30 years ago of $100 secured by a mule, a wagon and a plow to put in a crop," said Richard P. Morthland, the white chairman of the People's Bank and Trust Company of Selma. "Since then, the whole system of sharecropping has fallen to pieces. Thirty years ago, a farmer who had $100,000 in his equipment was a major investor. Today, you couldn't buy one cotton picker for $100,000."
 
No Industrial Plums
 Other than the jobs no one wants, like those at the nation's largest toxic-waste dump, in Emelle, about 100 miles northwest of Selma, almost none of the industrial plums that the South has won in recent years have come to the Black Belt, the Mississippi Delta or any of the South's other largely black rural areas.
"A lot of these corporate representatives or folks in economic development will tell you that corporations are reluctant to locate in places where the black population is 35 percent or more," Mr. Mants said.
To climb out of poverty, blacks depend on some of the worst schools in the nation. Testimony in a landmark school-equity lawsuit last year described Black Belt schools as having sewage leaking onto playgrounds, library books infested with termites, fire ants roaming the concrete floors and tables supported by milk crates.
In the city of Selma, and nearly all of the surrounding counties, public schools are virtually all black, particularly once students get to high school. The one exception is in Dallas County, outside Selma, where there is still a fair degree of integration in schools that are 75 percent black. Indeed, in many of the small cities of the South, where the black population is not as dominant as it is in Selma, the city schools are largely black and most whites go to the county schools, which are usually controlled by whites.
In Alabama, the problems of poverty are compounded by a state tax code that leaves most of the wealth base off the tax rolls, making the black electoral gains in the Black Belt a hollow victory.
The tax code is a result of legislation passed in 1972 and affirmed in 1978 and 1982 giving extraordinary tax breaks to landowners; in the Black Belt that means the white owners of the timber and farm land. The legislation pegged the value of farm and forest land at an arbitrary value set in 1982 and said that value could not be increased. As a result, an acre of timberland that is taxed at $3.93 to the east, in Georgia, and more than $4 to the west, in Mississippi, is taxed at only $1 in Alabama.
"It doesn't matter what color gets elected at the city or county level," said Keith Ward, an Auburn University political scientist and an expert on Alabama's tax policies. "They have no authority to make the tax burden any more equitable than it now is."
Many blacks and whites say the problems also reflect the reality that more than improving education, black control of the schools has simply shifted the flow of patronage jobs, to blacks from whites, in an area where local government jobs are often the only jobs.
"Blacks didn't have a problem with the model of political power," said Wayne Flynt, a white professor at Auburn University who has led the state's efforts to overhaul education, often finding himself on the side opposite from educators in poor black areas. "Their only problem was that it was whites who were in control of handing out the jobs. We've gone from patronizing, condescending, self-serving white rule to patronizing, condescending, self-serving black rule."
 
The Races
Resegregating The Schools
 In the spring of 1990, just as Selma was preparing to commemorate the 25th anniversary of Bloody Sunday, something eerie happened.
Amid torrents of rain, the Alabama River crested at its highest level in 100 years. Elmwood, the city's oldest cemetery, was flooded, sending coffins bobbing to the surface.
It summed up a year's worth of turmoil that showed once again that racial division here has not died.
First came a battle between blacks and whites over who would control the commemoration of Bloody Sunday. Next came a showdown over Selma's first black school superintendent, whose contract was not renewed by the school board in a vote along racial lines. After that came a boycott and takeover of the schools by blacks led by Mrs. Sanders and her law firm. Schools were shut down for a week amid threats that blacks would shut down the city as well.
In the ultimate role reversal, the National Guard was called in to protect minority -- that is, white -- students and keep the peace. When the unrest was over, Selma was on the way to resegregating its schools. Selma High School, where 411 of the 1,200 students were white in 1989, now has only a handful of whites, most of them orphans from the city's Methodist Children's Home.
Mrs. Sanders argues that the boycott was needed to end the education policy of tracking, in which blacks were routinely steered to the slower classes, leaving the accelerated ones for whites.
"The same people that were told 100 years ago that they couldn't build businesses, that they were inferior, have an educational system that reinforces the same thing today," she said.
 
Conceding Public School System
 Blacks do not have to go back 100 years to find reasons to be suspicious. In the mid-1980's, an extensive Federal investigation of allegations of voter fraud in the Black Belt produced indictments of eight black elected officials. The prosecutions resulted in only one felony conviction, which was later overturned and one plea bargain for a guilty plea on a misdemeanor charge. Many black politicians were left convinced that whites would do anything to roll back black gains.
But though most people believe that tracking was an issue, there is much dispute about how pervasive it was. And even many who think tracking was a problem say the boycott was so divisive that it all but killed community support for the public schools.
Whites, many of whom had worked to build and maintain the interracial makeup of the public schools, were embittered. The resentment only deepened over time among working-class whites, who pay taxes to public schools they believe they cannot use and then pay for private schools they believe they cannot afford. Many believe that the real agenda of the boycott was to recreate a world that guaranteed black valedictorians, black homecoming queens and black class presidents -- a return to segregation, but with the public resources going to blacks.
"My kids went to school with black kids, they made their first communion with black kids, they competed in school with black kids, and to me that was a wonderful thing," said Alston Fitts, who is white and who works for the Edmundite Missions, a Roman Catholic organization that does health and education work in the Black Belt. "The greatest disappointment to me was how much of that was swept away by the debacle. I remember my friends telling me, in great distress, that their children were now more racist than their parents had ever been, not out of ignorance but out of bitter experience that they were generalizing and making absolute."
Even many blacks believe that the boycott was a disaster for the schools and for Selma.
"It was almost like an attempt to relive the 1960's that caused a lot more harm than good," Mr. Ware said. "Now whites have pretty much conceded the public school system to the blacks. But if you don't have the support of the community, if people with wealth don't invest in what you're doing, then what difference does it make who's in charge?"
 
Down the Road
Murky Issues Seem Daunting
 Just five years ago, Selma recorded four murders. Last year it had 16, most involving young blacks killing one another. So far this year there have been five, but no one sees that slower pace as a sign of a big downturn in drugs and violence among black youths.
"We had two young black children murdered like dogs this week, only you don't kill animals the way we're killing children," Mrs. Sanders, the lawyer, said in April. "We never had crime like this in Selma. Now it's impossible to find a community in the rural South that does not have a crack house."
Unlike the morally clear goals of the civil rights era, the issues in Selma today -- crime, drugs, jobs and education -- are as murky and daunting as they are everywhere else. And though the politics here invariably break down along racial lines, the views of ordinary people on how to address those issues often do not.
Almost as many blacks as whites are quick to bring up welfare when they talk about why the revolution of the 1960's produced such mixed results.
"Whosoever wrote the welfare bill knew exactly how to mess up a race of folk," said the Rev. Fairro J. Brown, the black pastor of the Selmont Community Baptist Church in Selma.
 
The Need for Jobs
 He sees the shortage of jobs as Selma's biggest problem, but then says that jobs alone are not the answer -- that what is also needed is a fundamental improvement in the black family.
"Most of these fellows would rather be working than to be in jail," Mr. Brown said. "Unless he's extraordinarily sorry. You know some people are so sorry they wouldn't work if you got them a job in a factory eating holes out of doughnuts."
Even among many veterans of the civil rights movement, there is a sense that the new black politicians are, well, politicians, not the exemplars of virtue they could appear to be when contrasted with the evils of segregation.
"Now that they have gotten a chance to be in office, they are doing some of the same things the white ones are doing," said Sarah Logan, a retired black teacher, who was dismissed in the 1960's for joining the civil rights movement in Lowndes County. "Just like the white people, they have their own little ring, their own friends to take care of."
Yet there are people here who are still trying to make things work. There are groups like One Selma, made up of 30 black and white professionals and business people who gather at a meeting room at a local hospital every Tuesday morning for earnest conversation about bridging the divide. There are Afro-centric cultural programs for black youths, run by Mrs. Sanders, that have won national praise.
People genuinely want to move forward. But in an area that is poor and black, where the glistening new South of corporate relocations and shopping malls seems as distant as Jupiter, people just don't know how.
 
Through It All
 At the time of Bloody Sunday, Selma's Mayor was a young segregationist named Joe Smitherman.
Today, Mr. Smitherman, still Mayor, sits in his office chain smoking amid 30 years of civic proclamations and photos, a shotgun leaning against a wall, old cigar boxes, an antique cash register, a Bear Bryant houndstooth hat.
Mr. Smitherman, who has skillfully slid toward the political center over the years, says this will probably be his last term. But he does not see Selma's inevitable election of a black mayor, either when he steps down or after that, as fundamentally changing things.
"The old Selmians, the people of wealth, they'll still be powerful people, whoever the mayor is, whether's he's black or white," Mr. Smitherman said, the cigarette smoke curling around the City of Selma seal behind him. "You can't run a city without money. You've got to deal with bankers. It won't be the South as we've known it. It won't be Selma, Ala., as we've known it. But it will still be Selma."
NEXT: Voices of the two Souths.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1463 words

HEADLINE: OFFICIALS APPROVE PLANS TO REBUILD WEST SIDE ARTERY

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
Rejecting more ambitious and costly proposals for a roadway that would dip under and rise over intersections, transportation officials have chosen to reconstruct the West Side Highway as an enhanced version of what is there today.
The $380 million plan is a drastically scaled-back successor to the Westway project, an Interstate highway proposed in 1974 that was to tunnel through landfill and under new real-estate development along the Hudson River shoreline of Manhattan. When the Westway project was abandoned in 1985, its cost was estimated at $2 billion. 
 Under the new proposal, the highway would be rebuilt as an "urban boulevard" for five miles, from Battery Place to 59th Street. The roadway would be at surface level, crossed by numerous intersections, divided by a tree-lined median and bordered by a walkway and bicycle path on the river side.
Perhaps the most notable change, besides the addition of pedestrians, cyclists and greenery to the dilapidated route, would be the straightening of a notorious S-curve in the highway at 23d Street and the expansion of a small triangular park there.
With its selection by state and Federal transportation agencies, the boulevard project has advanced farther in the planning process than any proposal since Westway.
Financing is in place for the first three years of what is seen as a seven-year project, said Robert J. Ronayne, executive director of the project for the State Transportation Department. The Federal Government is expected to pay 85 percent of the cost, with the rest from the state.
He said traffic would continue to flow along the West Side route during construction, which could begin in 1996, barring complications. But complications are almost guaranteed with a project of this size, in a critical location, with a contentious history and many concerned neighbors.
The endorsement of the boulevard plan by the Transportation Department and the Federal Highway Administration was widely expected.
Before contracts are signed, the final design must be completed. Then the project must clear at least one more regulatory hurdle. Also, now that it is an official choice -- rather than one of several alternatives -- the boulevard plan could be the subject of lawsuits by opponents who believe that officials have paid too little attention to the road's effect on both the natural and urban environments.
State and city officials said nonetheless that they were confident that a new roadway, known formally as Route 9A, might finally be built -- 21 years after most of the dangerously deteriorated elevated highway was closed and 20 years after the Westway was offered in its place.
 
Community Involvement
 "The likelihood is very good," said State Transportation Commissioner John C. Egan. "What distinguishes it from many other projects is the amount of deliberation that's gone into the planning and design stage, the amount of community involvement and the fact that we've built upon the input of the community.
'I hate to call it a highway. It's a boulevard. It doesn't pass through the community; it's within the community and part of the community."
Fran Reiter, Deputy Mayor for Planning and Community Relations, said the Giuliani administration supports the proposal. "I think it does stand a chance of getting built," she said. "There are a couple of pockets of disagreement, but they're the kinds of things that the State Department of Transportation can resolve."
Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan said the boulevard proposal was the "best way to get cars moving and make the waterfront attractive and safe." She added: "It commits the largest amount of land west of the highway for a park and esplanade. And it provides a continuous bikeway and walkway."
 
A Fight Is Vowed
 But it is not universally welcomed. One of Westway's leading opponents, Marcy Benstock, executive director of the New York City Clean Air Campaign, said yesterday that the plan "brushes off serious transportation, economic and environmental concerns" and vowed to fight it. She said a better alternative would be to use the transportation money for mass transit and for immediate construction of a bikeway, walkway and park.
Ms. Benstock said the plan failed to anticipate potential development west of the roadway and the effects that development would have on traffic congestion and pollution. She also said it did not comply with Federal rules that require serious consideration of ways to reduce the demand for automobile traffic. Further, she said, the environmental-impact statement ignored potential threats to "an extraordinarily important habitat that is critical for the survival of fisheries up and down the Atlantic."
In contrast, Commissioner Egan said that the proposal was "very sensitive to environmental issues" and that, "if anything, this will limit development." He added that there was still room for change in the project as it went through final design.
During that design, other issues will have to be resolved. These include whether to limit access to the highway from the streets of the West Village and how to control access to the Passenger Ship Terminal from the pedestrian and bicycle paths.
Mr. Ronayne, the project director, said the single governmental approval still needed was an air-quality certificate from the State Environmental Conservation Department.
During construction, he said, almost no traffic would be diverted from the West Side corridor.
Southbound traffic would first be diverted to the area intended for the walkway and bicycle path. Then, the new southbound roadway would be constructed. Next, northbound traffic would be diverted to the new southbound lanes while the northbound segment was built. After that, traffic would be restored to the normal flow and the pathways could be finished.
 
 
Tortuous History of a Highway
 1974: After a dump truck falls through an elevated section of the West Side Highway, officials propose a $1.1 billion project to create a new superhighway and to redevelop the West Side corridor. Named Westway, the highway would run from the Battery to 42d Street and for half of its 4.2-mile route would be tunneled through landfill. Opposition arises quickly; among the opponents are Hugh L. Carey, a Congressman from Brooklyn running for governor, and Representative Edward I. Koch.
 1975: After his election, Mr. Carey joins the Westway camp, rejecting a Federal option to trade in funds set for Interstate projects for money to improve mass transit.
 1978: After his election as Mayor, Mr. Koch agrees with Governor Carey on a plan that includes a state park and state support to freeze mass-transit fares at 50 cents through 1981.
 1981: The Army Corps of Engineers issues a dredging and landfill permit for the Westway. President Reagan presents Mr. Koch with a symbolic $85 million check for the Westway right of way.
 1982: Judge Thomas P. Griesa of Federal District Court blocks the landfill permit, saying the Corps of Engineers failed to assess the landfill's impact on striped-bass hatcheries in the Hudson River.
 1983: A report commissioned by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo recommends abandoning the Westway and trading in the money for funds to benefit mass transit. The Governor rejects the recommendation.
 1984: The Army Corps of Engineers holds two days of public hearings on the Westway and its effect on the environment, especially the striped bass.
 1985: After hearings on the environmental impact, the Army Corps of Engineers issues a new permit, and the matter returns to Judge Griesa. He decides to overturn the landfill permit. But on Sept. 19, citing Congressional opposition, New York's leaders say they will abandon the Westway project and trade in the Federal commitment for $1.7 billion, which would be spent on mass transit and a scaled-down highway.
 1986: A state task force begins considering four alternative plans for what amounts to a modest riverfront boulevard. The panel chooses a half-billion-dollar, six-lane road that includes several sections that would go under or above cross streets. Planners say the proposal would improve traffic flow while also allowing safe access to the waterfront.
 1987: Mr. Koch and Mr. Cuomo endorse the plan, whose price tag has risen to $810 million.
 1988; Now known as Westway II or Son of Westway, the plan faces opposition from environmentalists and community leaders, who say it is much too ambitious. The Department of Transportation evaluates the task force's recommendations as well as other proposals.
 1994: Transportation officials reject Westway II for a street-level project eliminating service roads while adding trees, walkways and bicycle paths. Projected cost: $380 million.

The highway would be rebuilt as an "urban boulevard" from Battery Place to 59th Street. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times) (pg. B3)

HEADLINE: Yangon Journal;
She's the Junta's Friend (and That's Not in Vogue)

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: YANGON, Myanmar

 BODY:
Her two-tone Chanel pumps were not made for wading through puddles. But there was Miriam Marshall Segal, a white smock pulled over her couture-clad frame, touring her new shrimp-packing plant in a warehouse district in this most dilapidated of Asian capitals.
"Now this, this to me is human rights," Mrs. Segal said, admiring the work of her young, stern-faced Burmese workers as they cleaned and packed handfuls of the morning's catch of meaty Black Tiger shrimp. "We are giving jobs to 200 people here. These people have pride in their work. And that is what human rights is all about." 
 Remarks like those set teeth on edge among human rights campaigners, who say this Manhattan businesswoman has been doing the devil's work in Myanmar, the country formerly called Burma.
Mrs. Segal, they say, is a callous apologist for a military Government that imprisons, tortures and sometimes kills those who dare stand up to it. Nonsense, says Mrs. Segal, who might seem an unlikely candidate for a one-woman crusade to burnish the image of one of the world's most notoriously repressive Governments.
"Most of the people who claim to have great thoughts about this country have never been here," she said.
For someone who made a name for herself as an arbiter of fashion -- in the 1960's, she opened trend-setting accessories boutiques at Henri Bendel, Neiman Marcus and other expensive department stores -- Mrs. Segal could not have picked a less fashionable cause. The junta has almost no friends in the outside world.
"The criticism doesn't worry me because I know what I believe," said Mrs. Segal, whose designer clothes, long crimson fingernails and ruby-encrusted jewelry make her an unusual sight on the crumbling streets of Yangon, formerly Rangoon. She has been doing business in Myanmar for the better part of two decades, traveling here often from her home in New York.
"I am not a political person," she said. "I'm here to do business. But I think most of the reporting about this place is wrong. This country is certainly not all perfect, but it's certainly not all wrong, and we need to recognize what is right."
Mrs. Segal says Myanmar is unfairly singled out for international scorn even as larger Asian countries with equally serious human rights problems -- notably China and Indonesia -- are accorded United States trade privileges and diplomatic recognition.
Her praise for the junta puts Mrs. Segal at odds not only with human rights groups, but also with Washington. The United States has long refused to sell arms to Myanmar and, as a result of the violent crackdown on the democracy movement in the late 1980's, has refused to send an ambassador.
Although the junta has embraced the free market and welcomed foreign investment, few large American corporations do business in Myanmar.
Simon Billenness, chairman of the Coalition for Corporate Withdrawal from Burma, a Boston-based human rights group, said Mrs. Segal "has an unseemly eagerness to provide this regime with character references."
Mrs. Segal recently testified in Congress in support of American investment in Myanmar, comparing the struggles of the Burmese Army to those of the United States during the Civil War.
"Lincoln was also unwavering in establishing his priority -- national unity," she said. "Can we really blame the leadership in Myanmar for doing the same?"
That comparison struck some in the hearing room as absurd, but it clearly delighted the junta, which printed her testimony in full across two pages of the Government newspaper. A page 1 photograph showed Mrs. Segal in discussions with Lieut. Gen. Khin Nyunt, the military's intelligence chief. "A very intelligent man," she said.
With its globe-trotting rags-to-riches drama, Mrs. Segal's life story could have been dreamed up by Danielle Steele. She was born on a fishing boat off the coast of Palestine, the child of Polish Jews eager to fight to establish a Jewish state, and was raised in Australia until, at the age of 18, she made her way to the United States. There she broke into the world of high fashion in New York and made a fortune with her Port of Call boutiques. She will not disclose her age.
Mrs. Segal first came here in 1976 in search of Burmese handicrafts that she could sell as fashion accessories. Her business ties did not become an issue until after the military's crackdown on the democracy movement, in which thousands of civilians were gunned down. In 1989 the movement's leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, was placed under house arrest. She remains in detention only a few blocks from the hotel where Mrs. Segal makes her home in Yangon.
But as Myanmar was turned into a pariah state, Mrs. Segal expanded her business ventures, setting up a fishing company three years ago in a joint venture with the junta. The company is a showpiece of the Government's efforts to open up the economy to foreign investors while holding tight to political power.
Asked about the Government's brutal actions in the late 1980's, Mrs. Segal says "it was a very panicky situation -- when you are faced with a situation like that, what do you do?"
As for Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, who was awarded the 1991 Nobel Peace Prize and who is beloved by millions here for her willingness to defy the junta, Mrs. Segal offers an appraisal that is something less than flattering.
"I think she's become a prisoner of the Nobel Prize because it's an incredible thing to live up to," she said. "I don't have criticism of her, but I feel that there should be compromise on her part and on their part. You can't be defiant in a marriage. You can't be defiant in politics. You can't be defiant in business."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Miriam Marshall Segal, a Manhattan businesswoman who made a name for herself as an arbiter of fashion, is now accused by rights campaigners of being an apologist for a brutal military junta in Myanmar, the former Burma. Nonsense, she says. "This country is certainly not all perfect, but it's not all wrong," she said in Yangon, the capital. (Stuart Isett for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Where Profit and Tradition Mingle;
Oneida Nation's C.E.O. Runs New York's First Indian Casino

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: VERONA, N.Y.

 BODY:
The blackjack tables are crammed as the Indian leader enjoys a risk-laced, bountiful day, the kind of day he envisioned when he applied to Harvard Law School, the better to get inside the C.E.O. world of the white man.
"An exclusive club," said Ray Halbritter, the New York Oneida Nation's representative and chief executive, who did indeed get his Harvard law degree on top of a business degree four years ago and has gone on to operate his own exclusive club. He runs New York's first Indian gambling casino, Turning Stone, which has just begun its second year netting a sudden fortune in tribal profits and the respect of its job-depressed neighbors here, 30 miles east of Syracuse. 
 "It's about more than making money; we've created a new self-esteem for our people," stressed this 44-year-old son of poverty-steeped Indians who epitomizes the new class of chief executive officers among Indians who must juggle millions in instant riches while repairing centuries of eroded cultural tradition.
 
No Alcohol Allowed
 At least 91 tribal chiefs are spreading casino gambling across the nation among millions of reservation visitors. Only one year into it, Mr. Halbritter is one of the recognized comers, who talks easily of "maximizing our business leverage."
Even without slot machines, banned under the Oneida compact with New York State, his leadership has already made Turning Stone one of the 10 most successful Indian casinos in the nation, according to International Gaming & Wagering Business magazine. Net dollar profits are as yet undisclosed but they most likely run into the scores of millions of dollars, since the gambling action already is in the hundreds of millions.
In terms of tribal culture, Mr. Halbritter is the sort of executive who had alcoholic drinks, a mainstay of casinos, banned at Turning Stone as a poetic payback to history's ravaging of the Indian through drink. He celebrates the gambling handle for its power to send 70 young Oneidas to college and trade schools, when there were only four in 1990. And the casino profits must never be a variation on addictive Federal handouts, he vowed in shaping a housing plan that, unlike those of other tribes, would require matching funds or sweat equity from his people.
"That may sound hardhearted, but it's not," the executive said. "You have to create and not take away incentive from people.". He cited his mother's example in moving from stoop laborer to registered nurse. Thus, he was encouraged to quit the traditional tribal dangers of walking the iron on skyscraper construction and to fulfill his Harvard dreams as a key to tribal modernization.
"Ironworking had a certain level of dignity because it was dangerous and a man needs that, at least as we Indians understand work," said the Oneida leader, a natty, dark-haired figure in a tweed jacket, tailored denim jeans and a wolf-symbol amulet.
"But there's also risk and a greater deal of fulfillment in helping your people," he added, smiling upon some of the 45,000 gamblers who each week crowd the modernistic, low-key casino set on regained tribal woodlands here, just off Exit 33 of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway.
"The risk is political," he says of the high-stakes negotiations that tribes are facing with state and Federal officials intent on reining in the unexpected prosperity that has come of court decisions bolstering Indian sovereignty. "And there's so much money involved every time you make a decision that everything you have is at risk."
Harvard was the only law school he applied to, Mr. Halbritter noted in recounting his frustration with the limits of tribal politics a decade ago when the white world always seemed to have the upper hand. "I wanted to sort of break into the key of what motivated these people and these politicians and these judges," he said. "I wanted to get the education that, in my opinion, the most powerful people in America have had."
Degree in hand, he turned down a clerkship on the state's high court and plunged back into tribal leadership where, he said, his law degree proves handy "most every day."
 
Sharing the Prosperity
 "The key is that to influence people, you have to understand what it is they want," he said. "Before, I sat at the table and understood what I wanted but not what they wanted. Now I understand the complex world we all live in."
He said he had more than 300 meetings with local officials to assure the community beyond the reservation that it would share in the casino's prosperity through jobs and budget grants.
In terms of business savvy, Mr. Halbritter goes beyond the $300,000 in support funds paid to the county government under the state compact; he voluntarily pays the master planning board an extra $100,000 to better influence the wider effects of the casino boom. He thinks deals in journeying to Manhattan each spring to teach a course on Indian law at New York University. He recently announced that the tribe might finance a new regional water and sewer system both for new reservation housing and as a neighborly boon to local communities.
"It's appropriate because the Oneida Nation was always allies with this country," Mr. Halbritter said of the tribe's position in the Revolutionary War. He took care to invite as many outside politicians as tribal elders to heft shovels together for the ground-breaking of a $25 million casino hotel in July.
"This is part of bringing history full circle," he said, in reference to the six million acres the tribe held and his plans to recoup perhaps 300,000 acres of it. "We were once very wealthy."
 
Seeking Diversity
 With a business degree from Syracuse University to complement his law degree, Mr. Halbritter wants to use the casino's healthy betting handle to diversify beyond gambling because he is convinced that Federal and state political interests will impinge once more on the tribes by legalizing more non-Indian casinos. "The Indian people can't have things too long before the white man begins coveting them," he calmly complains.
But, characteristically, he then shifts into classic Chamber of Commerce resolve to expand the tribe's nongambling business into spheres like organic farming and to create a regional "economic zone that keeps jobs and opportunities in this country, where they belong."
In this, he projected an air of business collegiality rather than triumphalist bragging before the area's impressed local politicians.
"The Indians couldn't have a better advocate than Ray Halbritter," said Michael David Hartwell, an Oneida County legislator who beamed amid the ground-breaking photo opportunity. "He's a modern C.E.O. who keeps his word and backs it tough as an attorney. The tribe's already the county's second-largest employer and they're increasing every day."
He took note of the casino's 2,000-person payroll and the estimated $30 million in local vendor and construction business engendered this year by the 1,100 Oneidas.
For the future, Mr. Halbritter talks less of gambling and more of strengthening tribal culture, particularly through its "consensual democracy" tradition of long discussions within the Oneidas' three clans aimed at practical agreement and individual self-confidence. "You've got to believe in yourself: That's what this is all about," he summarizes of the buzzing casino.
It seems a paradox that he fears that gambling prosperity may make tribes too dependent on charismatic leaders. The Oneida executive, who personally dreams of moving on to a career in writing, said he wanted to leave a system of greater consensual leadership rooted in a cultural sovereignty braced by gambling profits. "The need for political stability is one of the biggest problems that haunts Indian country nationally," he said, cautioning that "all this money can make it worse."
Far from fear, however, it is the sheer fun of the tribe's mushrooming success that occupies the outlook of this Oneida, 20 years after he first walked the iron in surveying the white man's world.
"We've never owned things!" he exulted in managing the millions. "We've never broken ground for a hotel! These are people who were bean pickers!"

HEADLINE: Pataki Unveils a Television Ad Campaign

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 1

 BODY:
In his first major advertising blitz, State Senator George E. Pataki unveiled two television advertisements today aimed at defining who he is for a public that knows little about him or his qualifications to become governor.
Mr. Pataki's campaign would not say how much he spent but called the amount "substantial." The 30-second commercials for Mr. Pataki, a Republican, will be broadcast around the state starting on Tuesday. 
 "The purpose of these spots is to introduce Senator Pataki to the voters that don't know him as well as we would like them to," said Caroline Quartararo, Mr. Pataki's spokeswoman. "We want people to have some background on Senator Pataki and what his qualifications are, what he has done."
But the commercials, by the campaign's own admission, say nothing about Mr. Pataki's plans for governing, should he defeat Gov. Mario M. Cuomo this fall. And many of the ads' assertions about the level of taxation and spending in the state are contradicted by government statistics, although the actual numbers are not especially helpful to Mr. Cuomo either.
One spot is a variation on Mr. Pataki's standard stump speech, in which he claims, "New York State is No. 1 in high taxes, No. 1 in wasteful spending and No. 1 in lost jobs."
"It's a fact," Mr. Pataki says earnestly as he walks toward the camera against a background of soft-focus trees and leaves.
But according to numbers from the Census Bureau and the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, the state is not first in state taxes, overall taxes, government spending or jobs lost, except for total jobs lost during the nine-month period (July 1990 to March 1991) defined as the national recession.
Mr. Cuomo's campaign aides were quick to point out the discrepancies, as the Governor's campaign continued to portray Mr. Pataki as not trustworthy and deceptive.
"The first test of leadership is having the courage to be honest, and if you continue to abuse the facts, you're just not passing that test," Joel R. Benenson, Mr. Cuomo's campaign spokesman, said.
Aside from their content, Mr. Pataki's advertisements represent yet another step in a well-orchestrated -- and increasingly well-financed -- challenge to Mr. Cuomo and his effort to win a fourth term as Governor.
The advertisements also underscored the ties between Mr. Pataki and his political patron, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. Under the direction of Arthur Finkelstein, Mr. D'Amato's campaign guru, the advertisements' creators are Russo Marsh & Associates, of Sacramento, Calif., who produced the devastatingly negative, but also humorous, ads against former State Attorney General Robert Abrams during the 1992 Senate race.
The commercials depart from the campaign's ongoing strategy of repeatedly blaming Mr. Cuomo by name and instead seek to introduce Mr. Pataki in two ways: by his resume and for the first time in his ads, by having him speak directly to the camera. Mr. Cuomo is mentioned only once in the two ads.
One ad lists Mr. Pataki's accomplishments, from his academic scholarships to Yale and Columbia, to being the youngest Mayor of Peekskill, to his terms as a state assemblyman and state senator. Mentioning his support for the death penalty and opposition to taxes, they also include the words "husband" and "father" as the ad leads to a conclusion: "uniquely qualified to be a great governor."
Because the ads largely do not attack Mr. Cuomo, they may be helpful as Mr. Pataki runs in the Republican primary against Richard M. Rosenbaum, a former party chairman. Ms. Quartararo said, however, that the campaign -- which has been seeking to dismiss Mr. Rosenbaum as irrelevant -- did not consider him when creating the ads.
Mr. Rosenbaum is set to release a radio commercial criticizing Mr. Pataki's deduction of $9,738 on his income tax return last year by using a Federal tax loophole that applies to all of the nation's state legislators. The loophole allows lawmakers to take a specified deduction even on days when the Legislature is not in session.
"While George Pataki is choosing to ignore the fact that he has a primary on is hands, Dick Rosenbaum is not," said Lisa Linden, the Rosenbaum campaign spokeswoman.
 
 
 
The Ad Campaign -- Race for Governor: Pataki Defines Himself

 
CANDIDATE: George E. Pataki
 
PRODUCER: Russo Marsh & Associates, Sacramento, Calif., and Alexandria, Va.
 
VISUAL: The advertisement runs like a video scrapbook of Mr. Pataki's academic and political career. Against the strains of soft music, it opens with a black-and-white photo of a younger Mr. Pataki speaking at a podium, hinting that he is no newcomer to politics even if few voters know who he is. The rest of the ad rounds off his life, showing newspaper clippings, copies of his diplomas from Yale and Columbia Law School, a shot of him walking out of City Hall in Peekskill, where he served as mayor, and footage of his wife and two of his four children.
 
THE SCRIPT: "Hard work, intelligence, achievement. George Pataki. He grew up on the family farm, earned academic scholarships to Yale University and Columbia Law School. A husband. A father. George Pataki was elected the youngest mayor in his city's history. An assemblyman. A state senator. George Pataki fought for the death penalty and against Mario Cuomo's massive tax increases. George Pataki. Uniquely qualified to be a great governor."
 
ANALYSIS: Republican leaders have been convinced that voters will like Mr. Pataki as soon as they learn more about him. In this first effort to use television to define Mr. Pataki, the Republican candidate is portrayed in the most general terms: as a scholar with rural roots, as a regular family man fighting for his community. The mood is soft and light, nearly devoid of Mr. Pataki's usual attacks on Mr. Cuomo's record, as he tries to build a positive image for himself. The strategy of laying off Mr. Cuomo may be helpful because Mr. Pataki's first fight is against another Republican, Richard M. Rosenbaum, in the party's primary next month.
But as usual in his campaign, Mr. Pataki does not say specifically what he would do if elected. And the ad does not spell out why he is "uniquely qualified" to be governor, a question he will have to answer more fully as the campaign unfolds.
There are few facts to dispute in this biographical ad, aside from the question of "Mario Cuomo's massive tax increases." While some taxes have risen and others have fallen, the tax burden on New Yorkers, by a number of measures, has remained relatively constant since Mr. Cuomo's first year in office. And while Mr. Pataki has been a constant opponent of the budget, all tax increases must also be approved the legislature, including the Republican-controlled Senate. IAN FISHER

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Regain Most of Early Losses

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Interest rates were flat yesterday as Treasury prices regained most of their early losses that came after a morning spurt of data showed glimpses of economic strength.
But traders said it was the dollar's performance in the currency market that contributed to much of the bond market's weakness and later to its near comeback. Over all, the market was quiet and only mildly influenced by reports on construction spending and personal income and the National Association of Purchasing Management index. 
 The price of the 30-year bond was unchanged at 8615/32 , to yield 7.39 percent. The 10-year note was also unchanged at 1011/32 , to yield 7.10 percent. For intermediate maturities, a three-year note was unchanged to 10019/32 , to yield 6.26 percent, and a five-year issue down a tick, to 10019/32 , to yield 6.73 percent.
Traders thought much of the weakness in Treasury prices yesterday was dollar related because of the collapse of trade talks between the United States and Japan over the weekend. The dollar fell to 99.41 yen in New York trading yesterday, down from 100.10 yen on Friday. For foreign investors, a weaker dollar makes investments denominated in the currency less attractive.
 
Dollar Considered Nonevent
 But while the decline of the dollar influenced the market yesterday, Charles Roden, managing director and head of fixed-income investing for Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said that in the long run the dollar would be a nonevent for bonds.
"There is a real tug of war going on in the market right now, and it will not take much to tip the balance in terms of lower rates for business or higher rates for investment," Mr. Roden said. "Investors are turning to the short maturities, but my gut feeling is that interest rates may be in their top area now."
Many expect trading of Treasury securities to waffle ahead of the Treasury's refunding announcement tomorrow and the employment report for July on Friday. The size of the next refunding is estimated at $40 billion, including 3- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds
With the new government securities due to be offered in the second week of August, market analysts and traders find that the tone of the market has not completely shifted despite last week's rally, which saw the yield on a 30-year issue drop 15 basis points, to 7.39 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
The data for July point to a healthier third-quarter economy, which alongside a refunding and the question of Fed intentions is likely to put upward pressure on Treasury yields over the near term.
The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its index of manufacturing activity rose to 57.8 percent in July from 57.5 percent in June. The index, despite a slight weakness in the price component, was stronger than expected, traders said.
The price component remained high at 73.1 percent, down just slightly from 73.5 percent. Employment rose to 51.8 percent from 49.1 percent, a very healthy reading, while inventories fell sharply to 45.8 percent.
The association's index overshadowed June construction spending, which was weaker than expected, rising two-tenths of 1 percent. .
The Commerce Department reported that personal spending rose four-tenths of 1 percent in June after a similar four-tenths of 1 percent gain in May. Personal income rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in June, with wages and salaries remaining flat.
 
A Positive Development
 The income report was a positive development for the inflation outlook, said Marilyn Schaja, vice president and money market economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. She also noted that the significant sharp drop in the purchasing managers' inventories component was another indication of continued improvement in the manufacturing sector of the economy and in the overall economy as well.
At the Treasury's regularly scheduled auction of new three- and six-month bills yesterday, rates dropped to their lowest levels in two weeks. These auctions are often harbingers of where investors are betting rates are headed.
The averge discount rate for the three-month bill was 4.35 percent, down from 4.43 percent last week, while the six-month bill fell to 4.75 percent, from 4.83 percent a week earlier.

HEADLINE: Wheat Pact By Canada And U.S.

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
Embracing the kind of trade restrictions it has sought to eliminate in foreign markets, the Clinton Administration today struck a deal with Ottawa to sharply reduce Canadian wheat shipments to the United States for one year.
The reduction fulfills a promise the Clinton Administration made last November to help win votes for the North American Free Trade Agreement from wheat-state lawmakers who said that Canadian imports held down wheat prices. 
 Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said today's agreement would not mean higher prices for American consumers. "We don't believe there will be any appreciable cost to consumers although the limitation of wheat imports will have a positive effect on the competitiveness of American wheat farmers," he said in a telephone conference call with reporters.
 
Voicing Criticims
 But lobbyists for the grain trade and consumer advocates criticized the deal. "Clearly this is something that is bad for consumers, and to say otherwise is to try to pull a fast one on the American people," said Bryan G. Riley, the trade policy director at Citizens for a Sound Economy, a conservative consumer group here.
American wheat farmers have contended for years that Canada subsidizes its wheat farmers with a Government marketing assistance program and low railroad freight rates.
Today's pact does not address whether any Canadian wrongdoing took place, Mr. Kantor said, but it calls for a panel of 6 to 10 American and Canadian farm experts to review the evidence and make a report a year from now. American and Canadian officials will then use the report to decide what to do next, he said.
 
Increased Shipments
 Canadian wheat exports to the United States have doubled in the last four years, reaching an estimated 2.7 million metric tons over the last 12 months, including 816,000 tons of durum wheat, used in making pasta. The shipments have slowed the rise in durum wheat prices in the United States, holding down the average price for all wheat and thereby leading to the payment of extra Federal Government subsidies to wheat farmers totaling $680 million over the last four years, according to the International Trade Commission.
Mr. Kantor refused to give the precise level of the new limits on wheat shipments, saying that the pact, negotiated by two Canadian ministers, was still subject to formal approval on Tuesday by the Cabinet in Ottawa; approval is considered likely.
An American official briefed on the deal said the United States would limit Canadian wheat shipments to 1.5 million tons, including 450,000 tons of durum wheat. The limit on durum is important because the United States depends on Canada for 40 percent of its durum wheat but only 6 percent of all wheat imports.
Any shipments beyond the limit would face a tax of $50 a ton. With Canadian wheat prices only slightly below the current United States price of $121.50 a ton, the $50 tax would price any extra shipments out of the American market.
Robert R. Petersen, the president of the Washington-based National Grain Trade Council, which represents grain processors, said that Canadian shipments had already been forecast to fall to 1.7 million tons in the coming year as American farmers recover from a bad crop. He said today's pact would add to forces pushing prices higher.
"Anything below 1.7 is a disappointment and will probably result in higher costs to consumers," he said.
 
Pasta Costs Disputed
 Jula J. Kinnaird, the president of the National Pasta Association, said that semi-processed durum wheat represented a quarter of the cost of a box of pasta, and that prices for this raw material had already almost doubled in the last year as a result of the weak American harvest.
But Karen M. Fegley, the trade director at the National Association of Wheat Growers, said the trade pact should be evaluated in terms of its effect on the price of raw wheat. The wheat in a $1.50 box of pasta costs 8 cents, she said, adding that she expected today's pact to have no effect on consumer prices.
The negotiations that produced today's pact were sometimes heated. The Clinton Administration had warned that it would impose even lower unilateral limits today on Canadian wheat if Ottawa did not strike a deal. Canadian officials had publicly threatened to limit American exports of California wine and Arkansas poultry in retaliation for any unilateral limits -- a threat calculated to win the attention of President Clinton, a former Arkansas Governor whose re-election hopes may hinge on whether he can carry California in 1996.
President Clinton and Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada discussed the wheat issue in Naples three weeks ago at the economic summit meeting of the seven leading industrial democracies. "That was helpful," Mr. Kantor said today.
Canadian officials had an incentive to make a deal today because they are in separate negotiations with American officials on how to open up their highly protected dairy and poultry industries to competition under the North American Free Trade Agreement. But Mr. Kantor said today that those negotiations were separate, suggesting that no American concessions were made in those areas to win today's wheat deal.
Reaction in Congress to today's decision varied by region. Senator Max S. Baucus, Democrat of Montana, a big wheat-growing state, praised the deal, while adding that he would have preferred even lower limits on Canadian wheat shipments.
"It should restore stability to wheat markets and allow Montana farmers to make a living," he said.
But Representative Charles E. Schumer, a New York Democrat who opposed the North American Free Trade Agreement, was much less happy. "It's a sad day for consumers, especially those who eat a lot of pasta," he said. "It's against the spirit of Nafta and against the spirit of free trade, as were many of the side deals made."
Representatives of wheat farmers were pleased, with Ms. Fegley, the lobbyist, cooking pasta for her family tonight in celebration. "I had lost an appetite for it for a long time," she said in a telephone interview from her home as she prepared lasagna. "Things had gotten so personal."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Prices Hit 17-Month High On Growing Nigerian Fears

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Oil prices surged to a 17-month high yesterday on fears that a strike by Nigerian oil workers would further disrupt Nigeria's exports of crude.
The strike by Nigeria's oil workers, which has already reduced exports of the country's rich sweet crude oil, is in its fifth week. 
 The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, which normally accounts for about half of Nigeria's output of roughly 1.6 million barrels a day, said it would not be able to deliver most of its August cargoes on schedule.
 In addition, Nigeria's striking oil unions said yesterday that they would not attend talks with the military-run Government because their demands had not been taken seriously.
 The country's main labor consortium, with some 3.5 million members, is preparing for a general strike tomorrow.
Crude oil for September delivery closed 25 cents higher at $20.55 on the New York Mercantile Exchange after surging as a high as $20.98 -- the highest level since March 1993. September unleaded gasoline rose 1.26 cents to end at 59.97 cents a gallon.
Analysts said oil prices could soar to $23 if Nigeria's exports of 1.6 million barrels a day -- mostly to the United States and Western Europe -- were eliminated. They fear that other oil producers would be unable to make up the shortfall.
Nigeria, a major producer in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, is one of the world's main suppliers of high-quality, gasoline-rich sweet crude oils. Though Nigeria's oil exports could be replaced by higher production from other members of OPEC, analysts still believe that a loss of Nigerian production would push prices higher. Nigerian supplies are vital for American and European refiners at a time of reduced production from the North Sea because of maintenance work this month at Norwegian and British drilling platforms there.
An OPEC official said yesterday that the group was monitoring the situation but saw no reason currently to raise its production.
"Things seem to be getting worse and if the 1.6 million barrels per day is lost to the market, we could see it at $23 easily," said Tom Bentz, energy analyst at Quantum Financial Services. "It doesn't seem like an easy solution is at hand."
For the oil market, the disruption comes as world supplies and demand have been moving back into balance, recovering from 20-year lows of less than $14 a barrel in February.
On other commodity markets, coffee prices leaped after selling off last week. September coffee jumped by 8.85 cents, to 211.60 cents a pound, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York. Traders cited fears that prolonged dry weather in southern Mexico and Central America would affect coffee crops there.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rally Despite Trading Disruption

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
It was another day of crosscurrents in the financial markets yesterday. Despite a computer mishap at Nasdaq, the stock market as a whole rallied for the third consecutive day, amid further evidence that the economy might be slowing.
Meanwhile, bond prices fell but then recovered in the afternoon to close essentially unchanged. The rebound in bonds, which started around 11 A.M., appeared to heighten and accelerate the rise in stocks. The bond surge was probably aided by European investors who appeared to buy back a dollar weakened by the latest chapter in trade friction between the United States and Japan. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 33.67 points, to 3,798.17, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 2.75 points, to 461.01. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index gained 2.69 points, to 724.85.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 258.5 million shares. That was below the year's average, which is 287 million shares, but about equal to the more cautious trading volume posted by traders since June 1, about 259 million shares.
 Trading was disrupted for at least 34 minutes, starting at 1:17 P.M., in the over-the-counter markets by a power interruption, or dip, at the United Illuminating Company, the electric utility that serves the Bridgeport and New Haven areas of Connecticut. A United Illuminating spokeswoman said a squirrel -- "an animal contact" -- may have chewed through a power line, which shut down as a precaution.
But backup power at a Nasdaq computer operation in Trumbull, Conn., did not take over computer operations, a Nasdaq spokesman acknowledged and technicians were trying to determine why. It was the second time in two months that trading was interrupted; a software installation went awry July 15.
William R. Rothe, head of Nasdaq/ OTC trading at Alex. Brown & Sons, said the trading disruption "was a considerable inconvenience that was promptly fixed; on a scale of 1 to 10, with 10 being major, it was a 5."
Nonetheless, the Nasdaq composite index, like the Dow and S.& P. 500, reacted favorably to reports that seemed to indicate that the economy was not overheating and was not therefore producing inflation that hurts both stocks and bonds.
 
 
Friday's Report
 The new reports followed Friday's report on second-quarter gross domestic product growth that the markets interpreted then as discouraging the Federal Reserve Board from raising interest rates soon.
But, at the same time, other analysts argued that the Friday data did not conclusively prove the economy was slowing. And they said that while the Federal Reserve could choose not to raise interest rates when its policy makers meet later this month, the central bank would still raise short-term interest rates later this year.
A Commerce Department report yesterday showed that consumer spending, the driving force behind the economy, rose a weaker-then-expected four-tenths of 1 percent in June. A National Association of Purchasing Management report indicated that backlogs of orders, a signal of future inflationary pressures, had decreased in July.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond was whipsawed by trading in the currency markets. However, the long bond ended unchanged at 8615/32 , to yield 7.39 percent.
The dollar, while sharply lower in overnight trading because of the escalation in Japanese trade tensions, steadied after traders, especially those in Europe, realized there was a 60-day grace period before the harshest American trade sanctions went into effect against Japan. In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 99.41 yen, from 100.10 yen late Friday and declined to 1.5787 German marks from 1.5840 marks.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 1.43 points, to 254.05, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining stocks by 1,408 to 802. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 1.93 points, to 439.62.
Of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 17 rose, led by United Technologies, which gained 2 1/2, to 62 3/4, following news that it had raised its dividend.
Of the 500 stocks that make up the S.& P. 500, 312 rose, led by General Motors, which gained 1 1/2, to 52 7/8.

HEADLINE: Spending and Incomes Up Modestly

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1

 BODY:
The Commerce Department reported today that consumer spending rose four-tenths of 1 percent in June, a sign that economic growth was slowing.
An increase of just one-tenth of 1 percent in Americans' incomes in June also pointed to slower growth. In May, spending rose four-tenths of 1 percent, while incomes also gained by four-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said. 
 Bruce Steinberg, an economist with Merrill Lynch in New York, remarked, "The U.S. economy is not overheating, but instead growing at a pace consistent with stable inflation."
Other reports today confirmed that assessment. Construction spending rose two-tenths of 1 percent in June, and a widely followed measure of business activity showed a small gain. The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its index of manufacturing activity rose to its highest level in July since 1988 -- 57.8, up from 57.5 in June. Still, the association said that both imports and backlogs of orders, a measure of pent-up demand, slowed in July. The index is based on a survey of 300 industrial companies.
Analysts said that as higher interest rates took hold and the economy slowed further, the Federal Reserve would probably refrain from an aggressive assault on inflation, as it pursued earlier in the year. The Fed has raised rates four times since Feb. 4.
For the rest of the year, the economy is likely to grow at an annual rate of 2.5 percent to 2.75 percent, said Dana Sorrentino, an economist with Stone & McCarthy in Princeton, N.J. On Friday, the Commerce Department reported that the gross domestic product grew at a slower-than-expected annual rate of 3.7 percent during the second quarter.
The income and spending reports today showed that Americans' wages and salaries grew at a slower pace in June than in May, while Government subsidy payments to farmers continued to decline.
On the spending side, consumers committed less in June to major purchases like cars and home appliances. But their spending increased for food, clothing and services. Spending accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
 
Americans Save Less
 The Commerce Department also said that disposable income, the money left over after paying taxes, rose one-tenth of 1 percent in June after rising a full percentage point in May. The savings rate, meanwhile, declined to 4 percent in June from 4.3 percent in May.
In another report, the department said construction spending rose two-tenths of 1 percent in June, less than expected. The increase, the fourth in a row, pushed the seasonally adjusted annual rate to $508 billion. This spending increased 1.3 percent in May, a revision up from nine-tenths of 1 percent.
Spending on private projects increased two-tenths of 1 percent in June as outlays for golf courses and parking lots outstripped spending on housing and office buildings.
Spending on public projects also rose two-tenths of 1 percent, spurred by transit systems and outdoor recreational facilities like baseball diamonds and swimming pools.
Compared with a year earlier, total construction spending increased 10.2 percent in June. Still, housing construction is expected to slow in the months ahead amid higher mortgage rates. Starts of new homes, for example, dropped 9.8 percent in June, a previous Government report said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes With Losses As U.S.-Japan Talks Falter

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the Japanese yen and other major currencies yesterday after trade talks aimed at getting Japanese Government agencies to buy more American goods broke off during the weekend without reaching an agreement.
Even so, the dollar managed to pare its losses, rebounding more than one yen from its low in Tokyo trading. Helping the dollar to recover somewhat were reassurances from the White House that it did not favor a weaker dollar as a way to cut the trade deficit. 
 "The dollar is bottoming out," said Michael Perelstein, managing director for international investments at MacKay Shields Financial Corporation, a money management firm. "Today's trading gives me more confidence to say that. This should have been a day when the dollar tumbled."
In February, the dollar plunged as much as 5 percent against the yen when earlier trade talks collapsed.
The dollar was last quoted at 99.41 yen, down from 100.10 yen in New York late Friday. It fell as low as 98.40 yen in Tokyo trading.
The dollar also fell to 1.5787 German marks from 1.584 marks.
The discontinued negotiations on government procurement policies were part of a broader series of talks aimed at reducing Japan's $60 billion annual trade surplus with the United States.
"Traders use any glitch in the trade negotiations as a reason to sell dollars for yen," Mr. Perelstein said. The feeling in the currency market is that "the alternative to diplomacy is to have a strong yen," he said.
The dollar tumbled last year after Clinton Administration officials said a strong yen would help curb Japan's trade surplus by making Tokyo's exports more expensive.
Analysts said the dollar fared better yesterday in part because the Administration was working hard to convince traders that President Clinton and his aides did not want the dollar to weaken, even if trade negotiations failed to curb Japan's surplus.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said yesterday that the United States wanted a strong, stable dollar and that the Administration would not use the dollar as a weapon in its trade dispute with Japan.
"The U.S. has made it clear that it is not using the dollar for leverage" in talks with Japan, said Chris Widness, an economist at Chemical Bank.
Traders were also wary of selling dollars aggressively because the talks on government procurement could resume soon, analysts said.
"They haven't ruled out more talks," said Amy Smith, senior currency-market strategist at IDEA, a consulting firm.
