HEADLINE: Belgrade Issues Warning to Bosnian Serbs

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Aug. 2

 BODY:
With the threat of stiffer economic sanctions dangling over it, Serbia warned today that it would "end cooperation" with Serbian nationalist rebels in Bosnia if they do not accept an international plan to end the Bosnian war.
The Serbian Government has made such threats before, and even claimed to have closed the Serbian-Bosnian border for a time in 1993 in an effort to show that it was complying with international demands that it pressure the Bosnian Serbs to make peace. 
 But the harsh Serbian statement today is its strongest in support of the current peace plan, which would require the Bosnian Serbs to acknowledge Bosnia and Herzegovina's sovereignty and hand back a third of the territory they control.
The plan's engineers -- the United States, Germany, Britain, France and Russia -- have warned the Belgrade Government that they will push the United Nations Security Council to tighten economic sanctions against the Yugoslav federation, which includes Serbia and the much weaker Montenegro, if the Bosnian Serbs do not sign the agreement.
 
Talk of a Referendum
 Calling the deal a humiliation for their victorious army, Bosnian Serb leaders have so far refused to accept the plan despite appeals by their main backer, President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia.
Bosnian Serb leaders said today that they might put the peace proposal to a referendum, a move that could buy time without any serious prospect that the plan would be approved. The Bosnian Serbs' parliament is scheduled to meet on Wednesday, apparently to discuss the peace plan for a third time.
The Serbian Government's statement today said that Bosnian Serb leaders would be guilty of a "crime against their own people" if they do not accept the peace plan.
"If at this time, when you are being offered peace, you usurp the right to determine the fate of the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, you by this act will be severing all possibility of cooperation with us," the statement said. "There is no sense in 11 million Yugoslav citizens waiting for sanctions to be lifted while you clarify for yourselves things that are clear to the whole world."
"If you are still blinded by some selfish, personal or collective interest," the statement continued, "and if it is not enough for you that peace is being offered to you on a basis that would leave the Srpska Republic occupying half of the territory of Bosnia and Herzegovina, then you are on your way to committing a crime against your own people." The Srpska Republic is the government proclaimed by the Bosnian Serb rebels.
 
Skepticism About Appeal
 The statement, however, did not specifically threaten to cut off funds, food, military support or any other aid to the Bosnian Serbs, who have relied heavily on support from Serbia throughout the 28-month war. Western analysts remain skeptical of the sincerity of the Serbian appeal as well as Mr. Milosevic's ability to sever ties with the Bosnian Serbs.
Today, one member of the Bosnian Serb presidency, Biljana Plavsic, accused Mr. Milosevic of betraying the Serbian people.
"Radovan Kradzic was elected president and his goal was the creation of a Serbian state," she said, referring to the Bosnian Serb leader. "Slobodan Milosevic has supported his work until now. Why has he changed his mind? If it's a matter of power, then this is horrible, it is national treason."
Momcilo Krajisnik, another Bosnian Serb leader, referred to the pressure by Serbia as blackmail.
Western diplomats said Serbia's economy might collapse if the Security Council tightened the sanctions it imposed in May 1992.
Enforcement of the trade ban on Serbia has largely broken down, but an international freeze on Serbia's assets abroad, its isolation from the world banking community and closure of Belgrade's airport have hobbled some of the most productive sectors of the country's economy.
The Bosnian Serbs, rankled by the diplomatic pressure they are facing, retaliated by temporarily reimposing a blockade of Sarajevo, intensifying sniping attacks on pedestrians on city streets and forcing a cutoff in international aid flights into the Bosnian capital by targeting cargo planes.
United Nations officials here said that Bosnian Serb gunmen wounded three people in an attack today on a bus traveling down a mountain road near the Sarajevo suburb of Hrasnica. The Serbs killed a British peacekeeper in an attack on a United Nations convoy at the same location last week.
United Nations officials have reported a surge in fighting across Bosnia over the last two days, including heavy clashes near the town of Bihac between mostly Muslim Bosnian Army forces and rebel Muslim contingents loyal to a local underworld figure.

HEADLINE: Region Whose Borders Are in Eye of Beholder

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Aug. 1

 BODY:
There's one small problem with the South.
No one can agree on what it is. 
 The simplest definition would be the 11 states that went to war in 1861. But that leaves out the Bluegrass country of Kentucky and leaves in the dusty oil fields of West Texas and the Latin bustle of Miami.
The Census Bureau uses a South of 16 states plus the District of Columbia, running from Delaware to Texas and Oklahoma. The Bureau of Labor Statistics's South is eight states from Kentucky to Florida, with Arkansas, Louisiana and Texas joining Oklahoma and New Mexico in a separate region.
An economist at Georgia State University, Donald Ratajczak, who compiles economic figures on the region, uses a 12-state area of the 11 states of the Confederacy, minus Texas, but with Kentucky and West Virginia. John Shelton Reed, of the University of North Carolina, who surveys Southern attitudes, uses a 13-state South, the Confederacy plus Kentucky and Oklahoma. For this series, The New York Times used a 12-state South of the Confederacy plus Kentucky.
Neither state boundaries nor geography define culture. South Texas and South Florida are as close to the equator as the South gets, and both have more in common with San Juan or Mexico City than Chattanooga and Yazoo City. On the other hand, the Florida Panhandle and the piney woods of East Texas are as Southern as you get.
Mr. Reed has some fanciful definitions of the South that don't hew to state borders. There is the South where students in an informal survey said the state was Southern (90 percent agreed on a core of seven states from Louisiana to North Carolina).
He maps the South as a place where kudzu grows, cotton is cultivated, Baptist churches can be found, whites read Southern Living magazine or there are the most listings for Dixie in the telephone book. There is a South defined by the number of times a state is mentioned in country songs (Texas is first, Tennessee, second).
Of course, those definitions can miss the point.
"If you care to define the South as a poor, rural region with lousy race relations," Professor Reed said, "that South survives only in geographical shreds and patches and most Southerners don't live there any more."

HEADLINE: From Atlanta to Birmingham, Blur of Progress and Stagnation

SERIES: New South and Old -- Last of four articles.

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.

 BODY:
She was only 14 when she joined Martin Luther King 31 years ago in the civil disobedience that broke the back of the South's fiercest segregation, but Frances Foster White knew just where she wanted to go -- the grand spiral staircase in the Pizitz department store that led to the whites-only mezzanine cafe.
"I always had a thing for Loretta Young," said Mrs. White, now a medical assistant at a local hospital, recalling the 1950's television series that began with Miss Young sweeping down a stairway in a glamorous gown. "And that's why I chose Pizitz, because I wanted to walk down that staircase, proud, with my head held high. And I did it. And it's something I'll always be proud that I did." 
 She was one of the children of Birmingham, the students as young as 6 who braved T. Eugene (Bull) Connor's fire hoses and attack dogs and changed the South three decades ago. What she did not know was that the spiral staircase would lead to another, and another, and another, leaving the South a blur of progress and stagnation, past and present, black and white, like the M. C. Escher etchings of endless stairways leading everywhere and nowhere.
To the extent that progress has stalled, some see the age-old ills of the South.
"You don't think people with power were just going to give it up, do you?" said Nelson Rivers, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People's regional director for the Southeast. "They don't have the same allies in government, but the people who had the economic power 30 years ago are the people who have it now."
Others see the inability of blacks to take advantage of the new opportunities open to them.
"It's not enough to say things have not changed," said Andrew Young, the former Mayor of Atlanta. "We have not changed."
Across the South, in places like Birmingham, which is still trying to live down its past, or Atlanta, which is still trying to live up to its artful image of prosperous racial amity, or the Mississippi Delta, which is still in the grip of desperate poverty, Southerners, black and white, are still trying to make sense of it. Sometimes, they even do.
 
Two Mayors
Crossing Barriers, Feeling Losses
 During the civil rights era, they were the two poles of the South. Birmingham, with its racial violence and terror, was branded "Bombingham." Atlanta, with its peaceful integration and go-go business leadership, became "The City Too Busy to Hate."
In many ways they are as different as ever, Atlanta the site of the 1996 Olympics, Birmingham the scene of Michael Jordan's dubious foray into minor league baseball. But when it comes to the plight of the black poor, the two intersect.
Behind his desk at Birmingham's City Hall, Mayor Richard Arrington Jr. keeps an old photograph of his neighborhood baseball team, the 1948 Fairfield Grey Sox, who played in Birmingham's old Negro industrial leagues. In the front row is a young outfielder named Willie Mays.
The photo is a memento of segregation, when Birmingham was a swaggering steel town of black smoke and open hearths, Atlanta was a hustling hub for bankers, salesmen and promoters, and the two cities, 150 miles apart on Interstate 20, were vying to see which would dominate the South.
Birmingham's racial turmoil doomed its hope of regional dominance. But the city has had a substantial renaissance over the past decade, diversifying from steel to health care, banking and services and making strides in race relations. Across from the 16th Street Baptist Church, where four black children were killed by a bomb planted by segregationists on Sept. 15, 1963, now sits the magnificent Birmingham Civil Rights Institute.
Still, there is enough friction between past and present, in endless battles over affirmative action, city contracts with minority business, that Mr. Arrington, a courtly 59-year-old former zoology professor serving his fourth term as Birmingham's only black Mayor, has the weary air of a man who has been fighting the same old battles for too long.
"I'm just a symbol here of something that frightens a lot of whites or that a lot of whites resent," Mr. Arrington said. "I am a symbol of black political strength in Alabama's largest city. I have very strong backing by the black community. I have not had to have my knees knocking every time the Birmingham News or Post wrote something about me. A lot of whites resent that."
 
Front Lines of Integration
 Weariness is not a word that comes to mind when describing Mayor Bill Campbell of Atlanta. Energetic with wire-rimmed glasses and a quick, dry wit, he personifies the changed South that Atlanta will celebrate with much pageantry two years hence, when it plays host to the Summer Olympics.
The son of the head of the Raleigh, N.C., chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., Mr. Campbell, now 40 years old, integrated the Raleigh schools at the age of 7 and spent five lonely years as the only black student at his elementary school. He graduated from Vanderbilt University and Duke University Law School, came to Atlanta in the mid-1970's and in 1981 was elected to the City Council representing the district where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. once preached and where he now lies entombed. Last year, Mr. Campbell became Atlanta's third black Mayor, following Maynard Jackson and Mr. Young.
He has also come to represent the remarkable continuity in vision and civic promotion between Atlanta's new black mayors and its old white ones.
"I think Atlanta has dealt with its racial concerns better than any other city in this country," Mr. Campbell said, picking at a 4 o'clock lunch of sausage pizza one recent afternoon. "What people will see is the capital of the New South, a high-tech city that works. They'll see a great city at its peak."
But when asked about the nostalgia that many blacks have for the unified black community of the segregated South, with its black role models and support systems, he starts talking with surprising passion about the lost world of his father, the world of the Fairfield Grey Sox.
"There was this wonderful gumbo, self-contained, where everyone was treated with respect and dignity," Mr. Campbell said. "It didn't make any difference whether you were a millionaire or a person who washed dishes, you all lived in the same area, so the kids saw doctors and teachers and lawyers and policemen. But with integration, that all changed when the middle class moved out. The black community spent so much of its energy on fighting the social barriers that we have simply lost our ability to comprehend the terrible effect it was going to have on the black economy."
 
Struggling for Prosperity
 As different as Atlanta and Birmingham are, Mr. Campbell and Mr. Arrington both preside over cities that are largely poor and largely black and are struggling to get their share of the prosperity washing over their metropolitan areas.
While the Atlanta metropolitan area grew to 2.8 million in 1990 from 1 million people in 1960, the city of Atlanta shrunk to 394,017 people, 31 percent white, in 1990, from 487,455 people, 61 percent white, in 1960. Birmingham fell to 265,968 people, 36 percent white, in 1990, from 340,887, 60 percent white, in 1960.
In Atlanta, most of the growth and prosperity is coming in suburban Cobb and Gwinnett Counties. In Birmingham, it's not just out of the city but "over the mountain," on the other side of Red Mountain, in southern Jefferson and Shelby Counties.
Bill Campbell, who from the time he could walk has been living out his father's dream of an integrated South and has succeeded even beyond what his father could have imagined, would be the last person in the South to want to turn the clock back or to minimize the gains. And Atlanta's successes are precisely what his father envisioned -- a better world created largely through the cooperation of blacks and whites in business, government and the arts.
But he talks for a while about the world his father knew and then, the booster voice uncharacteristically gone, he says: "If my father or if Martin Luther King were to come back down Auburn Avenue, hand in hand, I think they would be horrified. I think race was a much greater factor than anyone originally believed. It turned out that what the racists said was true -- 'You can change the laws, but you can't change the minds.' "
 
Two Views
From Optimism To Stark Reality
 Unita Blackwell came to Jackson, Miss. in June to remember Freedom Summer, when students from the North and ordinary Mississippians braved the Klan in 1964 to work for civil rights in a state where crimes, including murder, against blacks and those working with them were prosecuted about as often as the Delta fields sprouted purple cotton.
She and other veterans of the civil rights movement came to celebrate a changed world and their role in helping to bring it about. But they also confronted how far they still had to go.
"I think a lot of us 30 years ago were optimistic; we had to be to survive," said Mrs. Blackwell, then a young volunteer who later became Mayor of the town of Mayersville in the Mississippi Delta. "Since then, lots of people have been disappointed. I guess all of us in our own ways have disappointments. It wasn't long before you found out that this was a resistant society. We didn't know then how imbedded all this was in the state of Mississippi, how imbedded it is in America. You don't get rid overnight of what took 400 years to grow."
To Mrs. Blackwell and many other blacks, the civil rights movement only began to chip away at a vast empire of inequality: of black colleges that got a fraction of the dollars that white ones did, of a political structure that was all white, of an economic system in which all the money and power was in the hands of whites.
The clear lesson to her and many others is how much work still needs to be done in electing blacks to office, fighting discrimination, staying the course.
"It all ties to who we put in office," Mrs. Blackwell said. "Nothing is more important -- and when I say nothing, I mean absolutely nothing -- than your vote, my vote and how we exercise it. People are staying in houses because they had a vote. People have paved streets, water to drink, because they have a vote. Every economic piece in this world is hinged on some vote or other."
 
Different Agendas
 More often than not, that vote is cast along racial lines. Indeed, unlike the biracial nature of Freedom Summer, in Southern politics today, blacks and whites come together only in passionless marriages of convenience in the Democratic Party or local city halls.
There may be much in Southern culture that binds blacks and whites -- from religion and food to manners and morals -- but when it comes to government, blacks and whites have political agendas almost as divergent as they were 30 years ago. Nobody in Rush Limbaugh's America professes as much hatred for government as white Southerners do. Nobody in America is as aware of what government can do for its people as black Southerners are.
Robert Proctor is a lawyer from the Atlanta suburb of Sandy Springs who has made a name for himself as an anti-tax crusader and as a critic of Atlanta's largely black city government. In blunt language, he says what many whites believe but few will say openly -- that blacks cry "racism" to excuse their own failures, that blacks have gone from wanting equality to demanding special treatment, that the time is long gone when blacks can blame the past for their troubles. He oozes contempt for Atlanta's black-controlled city government.
"I think they're corrupt," said Mr. Proctor, who is 36 and whose parents became Goldwater Republicans back when Georgia was still a one-party state -- that is, Democratic. "I think they're wasteful of taxpayer dollars. I don't think they attend to the basics of government, and I think a lot of what they do is for their own personal economic benefit."
He rails against government programs to foster black businesses; to Mr. Proctor, the programs simply help "a small group of blacks in Atlanta who trade political favors with each other." Asked about the legacy of slavery and Jim Crow, he says: "Should we take 50 percent of the wealth of white America and give it to black people, pay reparations, as some of them are urging? When does it end? I think what we need to do in this country, if we're truly interested in dealing with quote, unquote, racism, is we need to stop talking about race all the time. That is all we talk about: race, race, race, race, race."
Mr. Proctor's critics say that the whites who profess to hate government so much have long been the ones who most benefited from it and did business with it. Tyrone Brooks, a black State Representative in Georgia, calls Mr. Proctor "the new sophisticated racist of the 90's."
Mr. Proctor, voicing the views of many other whites, said it was blacks obsessed with race and the past who were today's racists. "I am not a member of the Ku Klux Klan," he said. "I'm one of those who sat silent for a long, long time. Increasingly, a great many people in the middle and upper middle classes in the South are saying what I'm saying, not publicly, but they're saying it to all their friends. And right now, I don't think we're heading toward any kind of solution."
 
Two Eras
Black Gains Vs. Tradition
 John Egerton is a 59-year-old author in Nashville, the son of a traveling salesman, who has spent most of his career dealing with two great constants of the South.
One is food, Southern cooking and its six major food groups -- sugar, salt, butter, eggs, cream and bacon grease. The other constant is race.
For the last five years Mr. Egerton, who is white, has been working on a book titled "Speak Now Against the Day," about a period seemingly as ancient as Byzantium, the period from 1932 to the Brown v. Board of Education decision in 1954 that declared racially segregated schools unconstitutional.
"For people then, it was like encountering a hurricane or a tornado," said Mr. Egerton, whose best-known book is "The Americanization of Dixie" (Harper's Magazine Press, 1974). "You may live in a place where those things happen, but you always think it will hit someone else. Everyone knew things had to change, but the leadership of the South absolutely abdicated responsibility. When integration finally came, no one had a sense of how to make it work. Even the people who knew it was wrong didn't have a clue how to make it right."
Forty years later, in a South that has come further than most people would have dreamed of 40 years ago, somehow the world looks much the same.
"You know, we had the chance to fix things after World War II that we had after Brown, that we have now," Mr. Egerton said. "But you talk to people on both sides of the racial divide and you don't find a hell of a lot of people who really believe the South was ever going to fix anything. It makes me cry when I hear people say, 'Maybe segregation wasn't so bad' -- hear blacks say that. You could fill a phone booth with the people, black or white, who think school desegregation is important. This talk of self-segregation, it's suicidal. But you talk to whites, and it's hard to find a lot of people who can demonstrate they've learned anything either."
 
Enduring Turmoil
 Indeed, 40 years after Brown and 30 years after Freedom Summer, racial disputes are becoming more common and the language of race more pervasive as black political and cultural gains hit the bedrock of Southern tradition and entrenched economic interests.
The struggle plays out in the battles over whether to remove the Confederate battle flag from the Georgia state flag or whether to stop flying it above the Capitol in South Carolina. It plays out in the court fight over the financing and autonomy of historically black state colleges in Mississippi. It plays out most significantly in the lawsuits challenging black Congressional Districts across the South.
For every Malcolm X cap worn by a black, there's a T-shirt worn by a white with the Confederate battle flag and the slogan, "You Wear Your X, I'll Wear Mine." For every T-shirt worn by a black reading, "It's a Black Thing. You Wouldn't Understand," there's a bumper sticker reading, "Don't Blame Us. We Voted for Jefferson Davis."
That so much turmoil comes after so much progress between blacks and whites is perfectly in keeping with the age-old split personality of the South. And in a region where blacks make up 18.6 percent of the population -- and as much as 35 percent in the Deep South state of Mississippi -- as opposed to 12.1 nationally, the South's future, now as always, is inextricably tied to how it deals with race.
But there is one very real difference from the days when the nation looked at race as the province of Bull Connor and Ross Barnett, of "Bloody Sunday" and George Wallace's stand in the schoolhouse door.
"The big difference I see from 40 years ago is that the North is caught up in the same thing," Mr. Egerton said. "Forty years ago, the North had no experience with racism, because they had always lived in essentially segregated environments. Now, they find themselves like the South in all the worst kind of ways. They're realizing now they're knee-jerk racists like the rest of us."
He paused for a moment. "Instead of getting out of the woods in 1954, we have found, all of us, that the woods are lonely, dark and deep, and we still have promises to keep. And the truth is, if we don't fix it, we all go down."

HEADLINE: A Rise in Lending Fuels Optimism

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Rarely has the economy been harder to decipher than it is today. Evidence of a slowdown is building up. But in the midst of the glum news, two important indicators -- consumer borrowing and bank loans to companies -- are still rising smartly, suggesting that there is still optimism and growth. Until this lending dies down, if it does, the economy probably won't slow very sharply.
"The borrowing is a sign that people are relaxing and the expansion will stay for a while," said Prof. Robert Gordon, an economist at Northwestern University. "And it is a sign that people in most of the country, while they might not be getting raises, are no longer so worried about losing their jobs. That's more important." 
 Such assertions, backed up by weekly surveys by the University of Michigan's Consumer Research Center and by interviews with bankers, don't go unchallenged, of course. There is the view that lenders, awash with money, are aggressively pushing loans on people who would not borrow and spend so much without the sales pitch. And some of the business loans are undoubtedly going to pay for stockpiles of merchandise that companies cannot sell so quickly.
But the more common explanation among economists is that the rise in business and consumer loans, excluding home mortgages, reflects an economy that is healthy today, whatever the future might hold.
"As long as this borrowing continues to expand briskly, you certainly raise questions about the imminent slowdown of the American economy," said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
Mr. Roach, in fact, is among the more pessimistic forecasters. He predicts that the rise in lending, which began last year, will soon lose its edge. That will happen, he says, as the national economy slows to an annual growth rate of 2.5 percent or less in the second half of this year, from a 3.5 percent growth rate in the first half.
Already, falling home sales, slowly rising inventories of unsold goods and some easing in the purchase of cars and appliances herald the coming slowdown, some economists say.
That is not the view of the Clinton Administration. The White House optimistically expects economic growth in the second half of the year to be closer to 3 percent, at an annual rate, than to 2.5 percent. "These borrowing numbers signify a basically healthy economy, with lots of consumer confidence and business optimism," said Robert F. Wescott, chief economist at the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
The Administration view gets some endorsement from the Consumer Research Center in Michigan -- but with a twist.
"We have been recording an increasing number of people who say if you are going to make a purchase on credit, you had better do so now, to avoid higher interest rates later," Richard T. Curtin, director of the Michigan surveys, said. He was referring to the likelihood that the Federal Reserve, which has raised interest rates four times this year, will do so again, in an effort to hold down economic growth and with it the inflation rate.
But Mr. Curtin also finds in his surveys a more positive reason for the borrowing. There is confidence, he says, that the worst of the layoffs is over, and that jobs are more secure. Rising employment feeds this sense of security, and also adds to the total income that the population has to make payments on loans.
Nevertheless, Mr. Curtin added, "people are becoming more concerned that their wages won't rise in the future, and that is beginning to temper their plans."
If so, Robert Hawkins, chairman of Southern Commercial Bank in St. Louis, has not noticed. Loans to his business customers, many of them machine shops, repair shops and parts makers, had fallen off until about four months ago. Then, just as the Federal Reserve began to raise interest rates, lending picked up, and Southern Commercial's loan portfolio rose by about $5 million, to $150 million.
 
Building Inventories
 Some of the business borrowing is for capital spending to buy labor-saving automated machinery, Mr. Hawkins said. But most of the pickup reflects a backlog of orders. To service these orders, companies are taking loans to build up their inventories of supplies and parts.
"I have a couple of guys who make wooden shipping pallets, and they cannot find enough pallet wood, so whenever they can they stockpile to keep their order flow going," Mr. Hawkins said. "We have another guy who makes pulleys that go into lawn mowers and Mack trucks, and he is stockpiling the rough castings. But he does not get paid until he machines the castings and ships them, so he does not borrow to buy castings unless he has orders in hand."
Chase Manhattan Bank in New York reports similar lending to businesses, as well as loans to finance mergers and to switch from long-term to short-term debt at lower rates.
"Interest rates have gone up by as much as 2 percentage points in some cases, even on short-term debt, but whatever the increase, it has not been enough to inhibit business borrowing yet," Richard J. Boyle, vice chairman of Chase, said.
 
'Pendulum Has Swung Back'
 Quite apart from demand, the banks themselves, having written off their bad debts, are pushing to supply loans to borrowers, easing up on their reluctance to lend to anyone other than the most creditworthy borrowers.
"The pendulum has swung back and the banks are competing for loan business," said Lynn Reaser, chief economist at First Interstate Bank Corporation in Los Angeles.
Reflecting these trends, total commercial and industrial bank loans, which had fallen all of last year, are now rising at an annual rate of 8 percent, reaching $619 billion late last month, the Federal Reserve reports. Installment credit, which represents a wide range of lending to individuals -- including personal loans and credit-card debt but not mortgages -- started rising last year. It is now growing at an annual rate of 9 percent, reaching nearly $840 billion.
But if business lending and consumer credit is booming, total lending in the United States is not so robust. The sum of all lending, by banks and others -- excluding only the Federal Government's debt -- is rising today at an annual rate of 4.5 percent, to about $9.2 trillion.
That rate of increase, despite the slowdown in mortgage lending in recent months, is still greater than at any time since 1990, when a recession set in. But it is not as robust as the annual increases of 10 percent or more that were characteristic of the 1980's.
 
Growth in Credit-Card Use
 Only consumer borrowing approaches the spirit of the 1980's. Still, some of it probably represents a growing trend to buy with credit cards rather than with cash. Many supermarkets, for example, that once accepted only cash and checks now permit payment with credit cards. And the credit-card companies, competing for business, are offering numerous bonuses to cardholders who run up debt on their cards.
"I learned that I could charge my son's college tuition on a credit card, so I did, paying $11,000 and getting frequent-flier mileage as a reward," Mr. Boyle of Chase said. "I will pay the debt right away, but it is clearly substituting debt for cash, and I get a premium."
But Edward S. McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, questions whether consumers can continue to increase their debt load at a faster rate than their incomes. He and other analysts note, however, that debt payments as a percentage of disposable income, while rising, are not yet as high as they were in the 1980's.
"My thesis is that consumers took the money saved from refinancing of mortgages at lower interest rates and used this money to pay installments on new debt," Mr. McKelvey said. "Now that the mortgage refinancing has ended, the leverage to take on more debt should disappear."
"We should see spending for cars and appliances purchased on credit decline, and we are beginning to see some of this," Mr. McKelvey said. "But what is puzzling is that borrowing still remains strong."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Prices Post Steep Drop As Worries on Nigeria Ease

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Oil futures prices tumbled yesterday ahead of an important meeting of the largest Nigerian labor union, which had planned a nationwide strike for today.
September crude oil dropped 41 cents, to $20.14 a barrel. Oil prices had touched a 17-month high of $20.98 for a brief time on Monday. 
 Nigeria's oil workers have been on strike for five weeks, demanding that the military-run Government recognize the results of an election that it had annulled.
There were rumors that Moshood Abiola, a detained politician who had apparently won the presidency in the election, would be freed. Those rumors led to selling by oil traders, whose heavy buying on Monday had been fed by reports of increasing political turmoil in Nigeria.
"There was talk about Abiola being released, and while that may not be enough to end the oil workers' strike, it would ease some tensions," one oil broker said. "But it's totally headline trading, and that's why volume over all in the last week hasn't been that great."
Traders said the market had been so volatile that prices could move $1 a barrel in either direction because of Nigerian developments.
Nigerian crude is especially well suited for gasoline production, and gasoline futures are often strongly affected by developments there. But gasoline for September delivery settled only 0.04 cent lower yesterday at 59.93 cents a gallon.
The gasoline futures were relatively firm because a huge fire at Chevron's refinery in Philadelphia shut a 35,000-barrel-a-day operation and because spot prices in New York harbor were strong. By contrast, September heating oil tumbled 1.24 cents, to 53.02 cents a gallon.
The weaker crude prices contributed to losses in gold and other precious metals that are considered hedges against overall inflation. August gold fell $4.80 an ounce, to $378.40, on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
On other commodity markets, wheat prices rose in reaction to an agreement to limit Canadian imports into the United States.
September wheat rose 5.25 cents, to $3.3575 a bushel, the highest closing price since June 15 for the spot contract at the Chicago Board of Trade.
The agreement limiting Canada's tariff-free wheat exports to 1.45 million metric tons this year will probably not have much impact on trade.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Off 14% in June

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Sales of new homes fell 14.1 percent in June to a two-year low, the Government reported yesterday, providing another sign that an important part of the economy was slowing down.
Analysts said the home sales figures confirmed what recently reported declines in housing starts and sales of existing homes had been suggesting: that interest rate increases engineered by the Federal Reserve Board were putting a crimp in home building and related businesses. 
 The June drop was bigger than anticipated, but a number of economists said it would be a mistake to infer that the decline in housing activity would spread quickly to other sectors of the economy. Indeed, they said that what was happening was fairly typical of past economic expansions.
 "Housing sort of lifts the economy off the launching pad and is the first to show a sign of weakening," said Joseph Liro, chief economist at S. G. Warburg. "And the housing numbers are now decidedly weak."
 
 
Crucial Meeting on Aug. 16
 Still, weakness in the housing market is unlikely to dissuade the Fed from raising interest rates further, particularly if broader economic reports expected over the next two weeks are strong.
The Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee is scheduled to hold its next meeting on Aug. 16.
The bond market, which thrives on weak economic data, was unimpressed with yesterday's housing report. After rising sharply in early trading, bond prices gave up all of their gains and closed with little change from Monday. [Page D5.]
The Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development said yesterday that new-home sales totaled 591,000 at a seasonally adjusted annual rate in June, down from the revised May rate. The sales pace was the slowest since June 1992, when new-home sales totaled 584,000.
In addition to the downward revision to the May sales figures, which were cut to 688,000 from 738,000, new- home sales figures for April and March were also lowered.
Since early February, when the Fed began to rachet up the short-term interest rates it controls, rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages have risen about 1.5 percentage points, to around 8.6 percent, said Michael Carliner, an economist at the National Association of Home Builders.
 
 
Market Could Rebound
 Typically, it takes four months before a rise in rates translates into slower home sales. But Mr. Carliner said he did not expect conditions in the housing industry to deteriorate further.
"I think we will see something of a rebound from this number," he said. "I would not expect to see a further decline. The peak of this housing cycle probably occurred in the fourth quarter of 1993. But taken as a whole, this year will be an improvement over 1993."
In the fourth quarter of last year, new-home sales averaged 769,000 at a seasonally adjusted annual rate. The average for this year's second quarter was 651,000.
Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, said a slowdown in residential home building "could certainly" cut growth in the second half of the year by as much as half a percentage point.
But he added that weakness in housing would probably not persuade the Fed to stop pushing up short-term interest rates.
"We think they have some more tightening to do here," he said.
Expectations of additional increases in interest rates remain in place. Even though second-quarter growth was a slower-than-expected 3.7 percent, the Fed would like to see growth at around 2.5 percent, a pace it sees as consistent with stable prices.
 Engineering that sort of a slowdown will require higher rates, because as the expansion progresses, sectors of the economy that are less sensitive to interest rates gather momentum. Analysts argue that such a process is happening now.
"I see other sectors strengthening," said Paul Mastroddi, a managing director at J. P. Morgan & Company. "Business investment is booming, a number of state and local governments are cutting taxes and foreign economies are picking up, which will help exports. I think it is a mistake to misinterpret sectoral rotation for a weakening in the economy."
At their Aug. 16 meeting, members of the Federal Reserve's policy-making Open Market Committee will probably place more emphasis on reports due later this week and next on employment, prices and retail sales for July, Mr. Mastroddi said.

HEADLINE: An Impatient Advocate Stirs Up the Education Department's Right
Office

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the year that she has served as the Assistant Education Secretary for Civil Rights, Norma V. Cantu has moved through the once-moribund office like the blustery winds that sweep across the plains of her native Texas.
She has ordered her 10 regional offices to double the number of complaints they investigate. She has told regional officials to hire more bilingual staff members. And her office, which acts as a watchdog against civil rights violations in educational institutions, has unleashed a flurry of regulations on age discrimination and racial and sexual harassment on the job and in the classroom. 
 She has even taken on the National Collegiate Athletic Association, pushing for an increase in the scholarships and other resources that colleges dedicate to women's athletics.
"People who know me know how much I love my work as an advocate for children and education," said Ms. Cantu, a 39-year-old Harvard-educated lawyer who seems to speed-walk to the meetings that punctuate her day. "And I'm not real accepting of people's excuses for why things can't get done."
 
Earlier Critics Satisfied
 By getting things done, she is muffling many of the critics who long complained that the office was an ineffective voice for women, minorities and the disabled, a reluctant defender of those whose civil rights it is charged with upholding.
Three years ago, for instance, Ms. Cantu's predecessor, Michael Williams, created a maelstrom by prohibiting colleges from awarding scholarships based on race, a practice widely undertaken by institutions as a way to diversify enrollments.
"What was so disheartening was the focus seemed to be that the greatest civil rights problems we had were those relating to the discrimination against whites," said Janell Byrd, assistant counsel for the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund. "I get the sense that the department is more in sync with reality now than it was under the Reagan and Bush Administrations."
But others say their sense is that Ms. Cantu is more litigious than her predecessors, a legacy from her years as a lawyer for the Mexican-American Legal Defense and Education Fund. In that role, Ms. Cantu tended to build her anti-discrimination lawsuits around the remedy of mandatory busing.
"As a litigator, she pushed the outer boundaries for forced busing for desegregation," said Clint Bolick, the litigation director for the Institute for Justice, a conservative public-interest law firm in Washington.
"She continually urged courts to engage in social engineering schemes like busing," said Mr. Bolick, who opposed Ms. Cantu in a school desegregation case in Austin, Tex., in the 1980's. "But fortunately her position was firmly repudiated by the recent Supreme Court decisions on busing."
In those decisions, issued in 1990 and 1992, the Court held that school districts could be released from court-ordered desegregation plans -- and mandatory busing -- if they had made good-faith efforts over the years to eliminate racial segregation. The Justices left the determination of good faith to state courts.
Ms. Cantu says she would rather resolve complaints early than let them escalate into protracted and costly litigation. But she does not shy from court action, either. "We are spending a lot of money in adversarial proceedings," she said. That money comes from a $55 million annual budget that, given her office's mandate, she describes as modest.
 
Roots in the Rio Grande
 Ms. Cantu, warm and friendly with a ringing laugh, has in many ways spent a lifetime preparing for her new post. She was reared in the agriculturally rich but economically poor Rio Grande Valley of Texas. The Cantu family -- she is the eldest of six children -- made do for years on the paycheck of her father, Federico, a postal carrier. Ms. Cantu excelled academically and received scholarships and other aid after graduating from high school in three years with honors.
She double-majored in English and education at Pan American University, graduating summa cum laude in two and a half years, and entered Harvard Law School at age 19. She graduated there in 1977.
She taught English in San Antonio public schools briefly and then joined the Texas Attorney General's office, where she spent two years on a high-profile case investigating fraud and corruption in nursing homes.
But it was her next job, as a lawyer for the Mexican-American Legal Defense and Education Fund, that embroiled her in the politics of education. Ms. Cantu was one of two of the organization's lawyers pressing the State of Texas to narrow the spending gap between rich schools and poor ones, a case that has been in and out of state courts since 1968 and has served as a model for impoverished school systems in 27 other states where similar lawsuits have been filed.
She later took the state to court over the inequitable resources it allots to colleges and universities (including her alma mater, which has since become the University of Texas-Pan American) in South Texas, where more than 90 percent of the population is Hispanic.
 
The Homecoming
 When she returned to Brownsville to try that case two years ago, she stayed with her parents in a homecoming that held special significance.
"It was the first time my parents saw firsthand what I did," said Ms. Cantu, who worked late into the night on their dining-room table preparing for the next day's testimony. She even enlisted her father's help; he picked up witnesses from hotels and drove them to the courthouse. "That was a pretty close time for all of us," Ms. Cantu recalled.
Friends, family and colleagues describe her as approachable but hard-driving and a stickler for preparation. A recent visit to the Education Department's civil rights offices found her setting a torrid pace for herself and her staff, yet refraining from meddling as staff members went about their work.
But those who know Ms. Cantu well also say she has a tendency to take on too much. That can be a decisive weakness for an administrator, a point on which she agrees.
"She's always anxious to help people," said Albert Kauffman, the lawyer for the Mexican-American Legal Defense and Education Fund who worked with her in the Texas public-school-financing lawsuit. "Because she is rare -- being a woman and a minority -- and because she is high-profile, she got a lot of invitations to be a speaker or to be on panels. After a while, she found out it wasn't possible to do everything. She got better at saying no."
She did not, however, say no to Bill Clinton. After his election as President, she was quickly chosen to become one of the Administration's highest-ranking Hispanic officials.
Ms. Cantu says she uses her own modest beginning as a reference point in her work, since it gives her an intimate understanding of how poverty and discrimination can undermine minority students.
"I don't feel like I'm on a mission impossible," she said, referring to the task of writing regulations that attempt to eliminate racism and age and sex discrimination. "Every time I hear of a new instance of discrimination, I also hear of a new instance where people are treated more equitably. That's what keeps me going."

HEADLINE: Pataki Rival Outlines Plans to Cut Taxes

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Combining economic policy with political jabs at a Republican rival, the insurgent Republican candidate for governor issued a detailed proposal today for cutting state personal income taxes by 24 percent and reducing state spending by almost $4 billion a year.
The proposal by Richard M. Rosenbaum draws abundantly from the policies of two Republican governors whose legislative successes are becoming issues in New York State's race: William F. Weld in Massachusetts and Christine Todd Whitman in New Jersey. 
 But coming six weeks before the Sept. 13 Republican primary, the proposal served as much a political purpose as an economic one. On the one hand, it provided a critique of the policies of the Democratic incumbent, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who is being painted as a tax-and-spend liberal by the Republicans.
On the other, it provided a vehicle for Mr. Rosenbaum to attack his Republican rival, State Senator George E. Pataki, who has endorsed cutting taxes but has yet to release a plan explaining how much he would reduce taxes or how he would pay for it.
 
Pataki Under Attack
"I'd like him to stop being the stealth candidate," Mr. Rosenbaum said of Mr. Pataki. "He doesn't release his taxes. He doesn't release his economic program, if he has one. He says he won't debate me, even before I challenged him to one."
Caroline Quartararo, Mr. Pataki's spokeswoman, declined today to comment about Mr. Rosenbaum's plan, saying: "George has said he would cut taxes; he's said some specific things. There will be more specifics on his proposal as the campaign progresses."
Political aides to Mr. Cuomo believe Mr. Pataki's intention is to offer few details about how he would govern until after the Republican primary, a strategy that could help him avoid criticism and give him greater control over his campaign message.
But if Mr. Rosenbaum conducts a vigorous campaign that draws widespread attention, he could pressure Mr. Pataki to define his platform sooner than he wanted, political analysts say. And though Mr. Pataki continued to ignore Mr. Rosenbaum today, some analysts said he does so at the risk of remaining an unknown to fence-sitting voters would could still swing over to Mr. Cuomo.
 
Opportunity for 'Substance'
 "It would be a mistake to take Rosenbaum for granted," said Fred Siegel, senior fellow at the Progressive Policy Institute in Washington. "Here's his opportunity to introduce substance into the campaign. Let him talk about welfare reform and infrastructure problems. Let him show he can be governor."
Mr. Rosenbaum, a former state Republican chairman, developed his plan largely with the assistance of his chief political strategist, Dick Morris, who was also a consultant to Mr. Weld's gubernatorial campaign.
Under the plan, the state personal income tax would be reduced in several ways over the coming three years. First, the top rate of 7.785 percent would be cut to about 6.7 percent. He would eliminate state income taxes on capital gains. He would raise the taxable income at which the top rate takes affect from $26,000 a year for married couples to $100,000. And he would increase the number of poor people who do not pay any income taxes.
To pay for the estimated $4 billion in revenue lost each year by those cuts, Mr. Rosenbaum would drastically reduce spending on several programs. He would, over two years, end welfare payments to able-bodied adults without children, a program known as home relief. He would cut welfare payments to poor families by about 20 percent.
He would also cut "soft" prison costs like transportation programs for prisoners' families and cable television. He would sell public bus routes in New York City to private companies. He would seek a Federal waiver to reduce Medicaid spending on illegal immigrants. And he would raise tuition for the state and city university systems for wealthier families and out-of-state students.
Mr. Rosenbaum has been fighting the perception that he represents the party's liberal wing, and his economic plan, like a welfare reform plan he recently released, seems intended to bolster his campaign contention that he is "conservative enough" to be a tough governor.
But advocates for the poor said Mr. Rosenbaum was using poor people as scapegoats for the state's economic problems. And critics said many of his proposals -- including raising tuition and reducing welfare benefits -- would face an uphill fight in the State Legislature, particularly in the Democratic-controlled Assembly.
Mr. Rosenbaum demurred. "These are not pie in the sky," he said. "We have to put the harsh light of reality on these programs. It's absurd to say you need an open-ended relief program."

HEADLINE: In School

BYLINE: By Jane Gross 

DATELINE: CARSON, Calif.

 BODY:
There was no talk of college in Daniel Gonzalez's home when he was growing up, despite his straight A average. Nor was the boy encouraged in junior high school in South-Central Los Angeles, where most of his teachers set meager goals for him.
"They used to tell me, 'Get a high school diploma,' " Daniel said. "Even to be a custodian, they said, you need a high school diploma." 
 But one teacher pushed harder than that. Four years ago he urged Daniel to apply to a new public high school here, the California Academy of Mathematics and Science, which is a joint venture of the California State University system, eight school districts in the Los Angeles area and a consortium of high-technology companies.
Today, Daniel is headed for the University of Rochester in New York, college-bound like everyone else in his 114-member graduating class, each of them testimony to a bold educational experiment that offers promising minority students a demanding math and science curriculum, access to the resources of a university and lots of remedial attention. The early results have been extraordinary.
"When you think big and offer a nurturing environment, all of a sudden you get these kids contemplating the same schools as the kids at Andover and Exeter," said Linden Beckford, a counselor at the academy, which is sending its first graduates to universities like Stanford, Columbia, Brown, Cornell, Yale and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, as well as to state campuses from one end of California to the other.
The academy, founded in 1990 in response to several studies and task force reports about the erosion of the nation's scientific and technical work force, was the brainchild of W. Ann Reynolds, then the head of the California State University system and now chancellor of the City University of New York.
While many high schools across the country offer accelerated math and science programs, CAMS, as the academy is known here, has carved itself a special mission.
The academy, which operates out of a bank of modular classrooms at Cal State's Dominguez Hills campus here, concentrates on women and minorities, many of them the impoverished children of immigrants who will become the first in their families to graduate from high school. Mirroring the demographics of the districts on which it draws, including Los Angeles, Long Beach and Compton, the student body is 52 percent female and 86 percent minorities.
The academy, with 60 feeder schools, seeks out students with potential, not merely those of honor-roll achievement. Any applicant in the top one-third of the class is considered, not just those in the top 5 percent.
Because the academy shares a university campus, including classrooms, laboratories and libraries, its students have a chance to earn enough college credits to begin higher education as sophomores. Daniel, for instance, has already taken college-level sociology, political science, philosophy, psychology and economics.
And while the average grade point average for freshmen in the state system is 2.48 on a 4.0 scale, CAMS students taking college-level courses at Cal State/Dominguez Hills have a mean grade point average of 3.2 in those courses.
The academy uses educational innovations that include school-based management, in which teachers help make many of the policy decisions usually reserved for administrators; cooperative learning, which has students work in teams, and scope-and-sequence curriculums, where subjects like algebra, geometry and trigonometry are integrated, rather than taught in isolation, one grade at a time.
Those techniques are endorsed by many high-technology companies and make the students attractive to such employers. "They are marketable when they arrive at the doorstep of industry," said Joanne Maguire, the deputy general manager of the defense systems division at TRW, the leading corporate sponsor of the academy. The academy has a $2.7 million annual operating budget, 20 percent from industry and the rest from the state.
The academy also offers an array of programs that would be unnecessary in a school with more privileged students. There are coast-to-coast bus tours every year to visit colleges, for instance, modeled on the trips that many middle- and upper-income teen-agers make at spring break with their parents. There is dormitory space for students living in especially chaotic circumstances, like a girl who had witnessed a murder in her home and a boy whose family was living in a garage. And there are mentors who take students to the opera or the workplace.
There is also enhanced counseling, particularly for juniors and seniors preparing for college. In addition to the two regular counselors, both experts in college placement from the Los Angeles Unified School District, the academy has another at work half time during application season. And the school's full-time fund-raiser, an unheard-of position in most public schools, seeks grant money for the bus tours.
Incoming freshmen, who are at the end of a monthlong summer orientation on the campus, say they are a bit disoriented to be out of their familiar neighborhoods and away from their friends, but grateful to be on a campus without gangs, guns and despair.
Cynthia Zarate, for one, marveled at being in a school where rowdy classmates did not interrupt lessons, where firecrackers did not explode in hallways, where homework assignments were actually collected and where teachers "put positive thoughts in your mind."
Cynthia said that her junior high school friends here in Carson, her sisters and her cousins all asked with scorn why she chose to go to such a "nerdy" school. "But I was starting to see the way they were going," she said. "It's a two-way thing, and they're taking the left turn and I'm taking the right."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Mixed; Bonds Give Back Gains

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday as the bond market gave back much of its earlier gains after a Government report showed a sharp drop in June new-home sales because of higher interest rates.
Bonds were given a lift from a stronger dollar amid optimisim that talks between the United States and Japan would produce a compromise to avert a potential trade war. 
 The price of the 30-year bond slipped 3/32 , to 8611/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 7.40 percent, from 7.39 percent on Monday. The yield on a two-year note dropped 2 basis points, to 5.97 percent, while the yield on a seven-year note fell a basis point, to 6.88 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
 
New-Home Sales Decline
 The Commerce Department reported yesterday that sales of new homes fell 14.1 percent in June, which was weaker than expected.
Home sales are typically the first area of economic activity to be slowed by higher interest rates, said Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist for the PNC Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh.
"While housing might have contributed heavily to past economic growth, from here forward those contributions will be smaller and will not give the boost to the economy going forward as it has in the past year," Mr. Hoffman said. As a result, he sees economic growth slowing to 2.5 percent, from nearly 3.5 percent in the last two quarters. "Hints are now appearing that growth is cooling," he said.
Analysts said it was important to keep in mind not only the volatility of the homes sales data, but also the tendency for the Government to make sharp revisions to past data. Many analysts said that the June report almost certainly overstated the degree of weakness in housing. Many analysts expect that the Fed will weigh tomorrow's retail sales report and Friday's employment report and may tighten credit on Aug. 16, after the Fed's policy-making panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, meets. Some expect a rise in short-term rates of about a half-point depending on the strength of the employment and retail reports for July.
Mr. Hoffman said he expected that the Fed would raise rates again, but with a gentle touch.
Elsewhere, investors in the municipal bond market found the New York State Thruway Authority's $375 million negotiated sale of revenue bonds attractive enough to cause orders to outstrip the amount of bonds available for sale and in some cases lower the bond yields about 5 basis points.
Underwriters led by Smith Barney Inc. repriced the shorter-maturity serial bonds to yield from 3.75 percent for an issue due in 1995 to 5.95 percent in 2011. For longer maturities, a bond due in 2014 was priced to yield 6.15 percent.
The financing, except for the triple-A rated insured securities which run from 2000 through 2011, is rated A by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the corporate bond market, Sears, Roebuck & Company was busy selling $783.5 million of global bonds backed by credit cards, in two parts.
In the first part, underwriters led by CS First Boston priced $750 million of senior securities with an average life of five years at $998.44 for every $1,000 of debt, to yield 7.141 percent, or about 43 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.
The remaining $33.5 million of subordinated securities with average life of 6.1 years was priced at $998.13 for every $1,000 of debt to yield 7.40 percent, or about 60 basis points more than a Treasury with a comparable maturity.
Traders said the senior debt was rated triple-A by Moody's and S.& P., while the subordinated debt was rated A1 by Moody's and A by S.& P.

HEADLINE: Stocks Are Listless as Dow Falls 1.95

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market was listless yesterday and ended with no distinctive trend.
"The burned-out bulls and burned-out bears let the chips fall where they may," said Alan R. Ackerman, executive vice president of Reich & Company. "This was a market that had more than a split personality. It went nowhere fast." 
 Stocks were up strongly early in the day as traders reacted to the unexpected news that sales of new homes plummeted 14.1 percent in June, the slowest pace since June 1992 and an indication of slackening economic growth. The Dow Jones industrial average advanced to 3,811.44 at one point and continued above Monday's closing level for most of the day.
But at the end of the session, all three major market averages were just below the previous day's close, after three consecutive days of increases. The Dow closed at 3,796.22, off 1.95 points, and has not wound up above the 3,800 level since June 16.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index closed at 460.56, off 0.45 point, and the Nasdaq composite index closed at 724.80, off 0.05 point.
Advancing stocks, however, outnumbered declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange, 1,268 to 906. Volume on the Big Board totaled 295.6 million shares, slightly higher than the yearly average of 287 million shares but significantly greater than Monday's turnover of 258.5 million shares.
International oil companies faltered yesterday, following reports that crude oil for delivery in September dropped 41 cents, to $20.14 a barrel. There was speculation that a monthlong oil strike in Nigeria, which has sharply reduced the country's crude oil production, might end soon. Exxon fell 7/8, to 59 1/4, Royal Dutch/ Shell Group declined 1 1/8, to 111 3/4, and Mobil dropped 5/8, to 83 3/4..
Gold stocks fell as the price of gold was pushed down to a three-month low amid signs of potentially slower inflation. Gold fell $5, to $384.40 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Echo Bay Mines closed at 11, down 5/8; Placer Dome closed down 5/8, at 20 1/8; Homestake Mining closed at 18 1/8, down 5/8, and American Barrick closed at 22 1/8,, down 3/8.
But paper stocks moved higher as a result of plans to increase the price of linerboard and optimism among analysts that demand for cardboard boxes would grow. Stone Container advanced 1/2, to 18 1/8, International Paper increased 1 3/8, to 75 1/4, and Georgia Pacific rose 3 1/8, to 69.
Utility issues were also on the plus side, moving in tandem with the bond market, which generally moved higher, except for the 30-year bond. Con Edison rose 1/8, to 29 3/8; Public Service Enterprises gained 1/4, to 28 1/4, and American Electric Power advanced 3/8, to 31 1/2..
A major standout yesterday was American Cyanamid, which stopped trading late in the day with the stock at 93 -- 30 points higher than Monday's close -- after a $95-a-share takeover offer was announced by American Home Products.
Other stocks in the drug group rose in response to this offer. Pfizer climbed 2, to 63 1/2; Upjohn jumped 2, to 32; Eli Lilly increased 1 1/2, to 49 7/8, and Schering-Plough surged 3 3/4, to 66 1/2.
Among other advancing issues, Compania Telefonos de Chile advanced 5 7/8, to 88 3/8. Goldman, Sachs & Company added the company to its recommended list.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Traders' Reborn Optimism On Japan Talks Spurs Dollar

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the yen and most other leading currencies yesterday as concern about trade relations between the United States and Japan faded.
The dollar fell sharply in early trading Monday before trimming its losses, after negotiations aimed at getting Japanese Government agencies to buy more American goods broke down apart over the weekend. 
 But the outlook for the dollar improved yesterday, traders said, as it it appeared to them that the two nations would try to keep negotiating.
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, has established a 60-day timetable for resolving the dispute. A month after that, the Administration is authorized to retaliate with sanctions.
"People are looking at the situation and thinking, 'We've got 60 days, that's plenty of time for them to get things sorted out,' " said Chris Furness, currency strategist at a market consulting firm in London, IDEA.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 100.36 yen, up from 99.41 yen on Monday. The dollar also gained against the German mark, rising to 1.5835 marks, from 1.5787 on Monday.
The dollar also gained yesterday because more traders and analysts are becoming convinced that the White House no longer wants to use the dollar's weakness to wring trade concessions out of the Japanese.
"There's been a policy shift from benign neglect to apparent concern," said Peter Gloyne, manager of institutional foreign-exchange trading at the First National Bank of Chicago. "People think the U.S. doesn't want to see the dollar go lower because of what it could do to the Government bond market and international investors' confidence."
The dollar tumbled last year after officials said a strong yen would curb Japan's trade surplus by making Japanese exports more costly. The Administration shifted its stance after the dollar's weakness spurred an exodus from bonds, driving up American interest rates.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen reiterated the Administration's new position on Monday, saying he wanted a strong, stable dollar.
"The trade dispute is a tired story for the currency market," said Anil Agarwal, currency specialist at Brown Brothers Harriman. Even with the trade dispute, he said, Japan's $60 billion annual surplus with the United States will start to shrink later this year, taking pressure off the dollar.
Other analysts cautioned that the dollar was making its gains in a slow summer market, a time of relatively light trading. Many Europeans are away for the month on vacation, noted David Solin, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics. "This is how August always is," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Mexico Says U.S. Makers 'Dump' Steel

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 2

 BODY:
The American steel industry, one of the most aggressive complainers that it had suffered because of foreign competitors' "dumping" their products in the United States, stood accused today by Mexico of the same violation.
The Mexican Commerce Department imposed tariffs on two types of United States steel imports, arguing that the step was necessary to prevent the Americans from selling their products at unfairly low prices here. 
 The Mexican action came at a time when the United States-Mexico economic relationship is expanding, partly as a result of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Steel tariffs are scheduled to be phased out in the next decade under the trade agreement, which is intended to make North America a single market where most goods and services can flow freely across borders.
 
A Prevalent Accusation
 Dumping is the selling of a product in a foreign market at a price lower than that in the home market or selling below the cost of production abroad to shed excess product. It is one of the most prevalent accusations in international trade disputes.
"After a thorough investigation, the department decided to impose definitive compensatory tariffs of up to 78.46 percent on sheet plate and up to 38.21 percent on galvanized laminated steel," the Mexican Commerce Department said.
The department said that sheet plate makers affected by the compensatory tariffs were the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, with a tariff of 46.18 percent; USX, 76 percent; the Geneva Steel Company, 78.46 percent, and Lukens Inc., 44.9 percent.
Arthur J. Roth, a spokesman for Bethlehem in Bethlehem, Pa., said the company had only begun to review the Mexican Government decision. However, Mr. Roth added, "We disagree with the decision because it is contrary to the facts and the law and are considering an appeal."
He said the company exported only about 1,300 tons a year of steel plates to Mexico, or about 10 percent of its total steel shipments to that country. Other accused United States steelmakers did not respond immediately.
 
Some Companies Not Named
 The announcement added that other United States companies suspected of dumping sheet place on the Mexican market would face tariffs of 78.46 percent. Those companies were not identified.
The Government also imposed a 38.21 percent tariff on steel manufacturers that export galvanized laminate steel, including USX, Mitsui, New Process and World Metals Inc.
The accused "have shown that they were exporting to Mexico at dumping prices that have or threaten to damage the national industry," the statement said.
Under the trade agreement, steel tariffs are to disappear by the year 2004. Tariffs will also be phased out by that year on textiles, cotton, lumber and cosmetics. Duties on such goods as glassware, orange juice, sugar and peanuts are to be phased out within 15 years.
