HEADLINE: In Mandela's South Africa, Foreign Investors Are Few

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 2

 BODY:
Courting South Africa last year, the advance scouts of Western money brought an alluring message: make peace and take the free-market pledge, and a thousand projects will bloom.
But 10 months after Nelson Mandela formally invited foreign business to come back, and three months after the elections that secured this reborn capitalist the presidency, South Africa has yet to see the surge of investment needed to fuel growth and jobs. 
 The country reached an almost miraculous political consensus, leading to the end of economic sanctions and the resultant isolation. Mr. Mandela has adopted a sober, growth-oriented economic policy. But investors have found a host of reasons to hold back.
The labor force is costly, unskilled and militant. Trade barriers and currency exchange controls have yet to fall. There are doubts about the Government's long-term commitment to capitalism, about whether Mr. Mandela can contain the expectations of the impoverished majority.
As an investment opportunity, South Africa is an oddball -- part third world, part first world, situated at the bottom of the globe, and attached to a continent that Western investors tend to see, at best, as terra incognita, and, at worst, as doomed.
"In just about every presentation, there's somebody who stands up and asks me, 'What about Rwanda?' " said Charles H. Allison, executive director of New Africa Advisors, an American firm that has been trying to get pension funds to buy a stake in new South African businesses.
Rwanda, that tiny country ruptured by ethnic hatred, is 1,500 miles to the north and is as economically relevant to South Africa as Bosnia is to Boston. But to many Americans, it is all Africa.
"None of the big pension funds are involved in Africa," Mr. Allison said. "The trustees and consultants get off the plane in Johannesburg, and they're shocked that there's an airport, and you don't have to run with lions chasing you."
Mr. Allison, whose company is owned by African-Americans bent on opening that psychological frontier, believes the money will come, and so do many business-savvy South Africans. They point to South Africa's sophisticated business infrastructure and natural bounty. They say the main problem is that big institutional money moves like sludge.
But so far, it is still an open question whether Mr. Mandela will ever get the kind of investment he needs, the kind that produces exports, growth and jobs.
The foreign capital inflow so far has consisted mainly of bargain-seekers buying shares in long-established companies listed on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange.
American and British investment houses set up funds to buy South African stocks and bonds, and at the turn of the year net purchases jumped to 1.094 billion rand, or $299.6 million at current exchange rates, more than double the 440 million rand, or $120.5 million, in December, but since April more foreign money has flowed out than in, a trend that brokers attribute partly to a worldwide anxiety about stocks, but partly to cold feet about South Africa.
With great fanfare, dozens of American companies, led by computer and software concerns and including such brand-name giants as Pepsico and Sara Lee, have opened offices here. But most are either reacquiring subsidiaries that they sold during sanctions, or they are essentially storefronts for goods made elsewhere. They represent little new investment and few new jobs.
"The U.S. companies have historically been there to market to South Africa," said Meg Voorhes of the Investor Responsibility Research Center, a Washington-based group that monitors trade with South Africa. "They can serve the 40-million-strong market in South Africa with goods produced elsewhere. South Africa is not seen as a major sourcing point for exporting globally."
With good reason, said Robert A. J. Irwin, chairman of ASA Ltd., an investment company that buys South African shares, mainly in gold mining. Mr. Irwin recently spent a week here making rounds of bankers, businessmen and officials, investigating other opportunities, and left a skeptic.
"I cannot figure out what South Africa offers to the outside investor in the way of an opportunity to create jobs," he said, citing as its most notable attraction "abundant raw materials."
 
Neither Fish Nor Fowl
 South Africa, he continued, is neither fish nor fowl; it does not fit the profile of other emerging economies, but neither does it have the skills and industrial technology base to compete with developed countries. South Korea and Taiwan, for example, built their muscular economies by exporting cheap clothing and working up to more sophisticated goods, a route that China is now taking.
But that route starts with cheap labor. In South Africa, the manufacturing work force is heavily unionized, costing employers almost $5 an hour in total remuneration, double the cost in Mexico or Brazil and eight times the cost in China. Productivity is comparatively low.
A recent outbreak of labor unrest has been an unnerving reminder to investors -- and to Mr. Mandela -- that workers have not necessarily bought the new Government's message of restraint. Grocery clerks, court employees and construction trades are on strike at the moment. Recently, strikers shut the country's largest casino resort, Sun City. On Monday, 19,000 auto workers stopped work for a day, and they are threatening a longer strike.
 
Workers on Strike
 In the first six months of the year, South Africa lost 1.2 million worker days to strikes, up from 700,000 a year earlier, according to Andrew Levy & Associates, an industrial relations consulting firm. Nor are Westerners alone in shunning South Africa.
"Many Japanese companies invest in Southeast Asia because labor cost is cheaper than South Africa, skills are higher, and sometimes the loyalty to the company is more excellent," said Kyoji Yoshino, Japan's economics attache in Pretoria.
South Africans say that with time the Government will persuade unions to forgo wage increases in favor of training and other measures to increase productivity. But the strong union leaders who might have shaped such compromises have been drafted into Parliament and Government ministries, leaving a power vacuum.
 
Well Equipped for Busineess
 The country is as well equipped for business as most of Europe, with telephones that tend to work, accountants who know their trade, sophisticated banks, a bureaucracy that collects the taxes and delivers the mail.
"You don't have to teach debits and credits in South Africa, as you do in central Europe," said Andre Roux, a vice president in charge of investment capital at Firstcorp Merchant Bank Ltd. "There's a culture of free enterprise that does not exist in South Korea or the Philippines."
Even so, South Africa is not competitive in the developed league. For decades, an aggressive government policy of self-sufficiency directed money from exports and modernization into huge, inefficient import substitution programs. Anti-apartheid sanctions further isolated industry behind a wall of tariffs and currency controls. Cut off from the world, big companies devoured each other, creating cumbersome oligopolies.
 
Signatory to GATT
 Because South Africa has signed the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, its trade barriers are to fall over the next five years. But in the short run that may cost more jobs than it creates.
Mr. Yoshino, the Japanese attache, said Japanese concerns had no interest in putting money into the auto and electronics plants that operate here under their license, because once tariff barriers were lowered, it would become cheaper to ship in goods.
"There are seven South African motorcar manufacturers, making about 44 kinds of motor vehicles," he said. "The annual sales in South Africa are 300,000 vehicles. That is too many kinds of cars in a small market." He predicts a drastic shakeout.
Much of the optimism about South Africa centers on its potential as a gateway to the rest of Africa. But even if Africa can overcome its self-destructive impulses and become a robust market, South Africa will be wary of knocking down barriers.
"The idea that southern Africa should be opened up into one trading area is very interesting intellectually, but it means initially the exporting of jobs into other countries where labor is cheaper, like Zimbabwe and Mozambique," Mr. Irwin said.
 
A Two-Tier Exchange Rate
 Currency controls, including a two-tier exchange rate, are likely to disappear, but the Government is afraid to move too fast, worrying about a sudden hemorrhage of reserves.
"I don't see South African companies raising money to finance bold new ventures," Mr. Irwin added. "Foreigners are going to look at that and say, 'If locals aren't investing, why should we?' "
That may be changing. According to the South African Reserve Bank, the flight of South African capital overseas, an alarming trend as white rule drew to an end, seems to have slowed in recent months, so at least South African money is staying home.
Where will it go? Chris Liebenberg, the banker named as the next Finance Minister, was asked in an interview where a realistic investor might put money that would produce exports and jobs.
"Tourism," he responded instantly. "Tourism is an export industry." Asked to name a second, he pondered, then suggested "beneficiation," or processing natural resources. Most of the few major expansions under way are cases of beneficiation: aluminum smelting, exploiting cheap surplus electricity from the country's abundant coal; stainless steel, using the country's reserves of chromite ore; turning vast tree farms into pulp and paper, and chemicals synthesized from coal.
Beyond that, bankers say the best hope lies in niche manufacturers, like the BMW subsidiary that makes leather auto seats.
"Despite a lot of negative talk about the money not coming in, it is staggering to see the research going on, the good will," said David M. Lawrence, managing director of Firstcorp. "We have every reason to believe the dollars will be on the table. It will come gradually."

HEADLINE: Businesses' Failures Ebb

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Business failures dropped 20 percent in the first half of the year after economic growth in major industries nationwide, a survey released yesterday indicated.
The survey, by Dun & Bradstreet, said 36,790 businesses failed during the period, compared with 45,906 during the first half of 1993. 
 New England, among the hardest-hit regions in the recent recession, had the largest decline in failures, down 32 percent, to 2,015. New York's failure rate dropped 24 percent.
"The economic recovery appears to have taken hold as the business sector continues to make a steady comeback," said Joseph W. Duncan, a vice president of Dun & Bradstreet and its chief economist.
Also dropping was the size of the failures, as measured by the dollar value of unmet liabilities. That dropped 46 percent, to $13 billion, from $24 billion in 1993.
Among industries, failures in mining had the largest proportional decline -- 41 percent. Failures in finance, insurance and real estate fell by 28 percent. This drop "suggests that the problems the savings and loan industry has suffered over the past few years seem to have subsided," Mr. Duncan said.
Also declining were failures in transportation, utilities, agriculture, construction, wholesale and retail sales, and services.
The failure rate in California, among the states worst hit by the recession, dropped 17 percent.
Rises in failures were reported in Arkansas, 45 percent; Montana, 30 percent; Oregon, 25 percent; Maryland, 8 percent, and Washington, 3 percent.

HEADLINE: Deadliness of Breast Cancer In Blacks Defies Easy Answer

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

 BODY:
IN the two decades that the National Cancer Institute has been gathering data on breast cancer, one thing has been clear: although white women are more likely than black women to get breast cancer, black women are much more likely to die from it. But the question is, why?
Now, several recent studies indicate that breast cancer might appear in a more deadly form among black woman. The tumors tend to be more malignant, as measured by cellular indicators of a poor prognosis. 
 Cancer experts said it was too soon to say whether this indicated that more aggressive treatment was warranted for black women or whether mammography was more -- or less -- likely to make a difference in the prognosis. But they said it was becoming clear that the high breast cancer death rates among black women were not solely the result of poverty or lack of access to medical care.
"There's a difference and I don't think we can ignore it," said Dr. Brenda K. Edwards, associate director of the surveillance program at the National Cancer Institute. She added, "The jury is still out on whether these differences alter our conclusions on the effectiveness of screening."
One study, by Dr. Richard M. Elledge, Dr. C. Kent Osborne and colleagues at the University of Texas Health Science Center in San Antonio, examined more than 6,000 tumors sent to them from hospitals throughout the United States. They found that tumors from black women had more actively dividing cells than those from white women and had tumor cells that lacked hormone receptors, another indicator of a poor prognosis.
 
Signs of Poor Prognosis
 A study by Dr. Vivien W. Chen of the Louisiana State Medical Center and colleagues examined 963 newly diagnosed tumors and found that tumors from black women were more likely to have several histological features associated with a poor prognosis, including the features found by Dr. Elledge and his colleagues.
A third study, by Dr. Robert S. Siegel of George Washington University Medical Center in Washington, examined laboratory data on 708 tumors from women treated at his hospital and found that the tumors from the black women were more actively growing, were less likely to have hormone receptors and appeared more deranged.
Dr. Larry Kessler, chief of the cancer institute's applied research branch, said the racial differences in breast cancer incidence and mortality had long puzzled investigators. Breast cancer seems to strike black women under the age of 45 at a particularly high rate and to be especially deadly.
No one knows why breast cancer should be more common among young black women, but many cancer specialists have looked for sociological factors to explain why breast cancer is so deadly among blacks when it does occur.
One theory is that the high death rate reflects poor access to medical care among black women. But, Dr. Edwards said, a study she directed found that this can account for only about half of the increased death rate for blacks.
The study included 1,222 women in Atlanta, New Orleans and the San Francisco-Oakland area. The black women, the investigators found, had about twice the death rate of the white women. But, Dr. Edwards said, a substantial proportion of the increased mortality seems to result from biological differences in the cancers of black women.
Dr. Siegel said that in his study he looked at the subset of women who were members of health maintenance organizations where the black and white members had equal access to mammograms and medical care. Even so, he said, the black women tended to have larger, more advanced tumors when their cancers was diagnosed, which may reflect a faster rate of tumor growth.
And Dr. Osborne said that his study looked at the treatments that women received once the disease was diagnosed and found that this factor also did not account for the dismal survival rates for black women.
Another theory is that black women put off seeing a doctor when they find a lump in their breasts, so by the time they get treatment their cancer is advanced and their mortality rate is higher.
Dr. Edwards said investigators in her study asked women who had symptoms, like a lump they could feel or bleeding, pain or discharge from the breast, how long they had waited to see a doctor. Black women waited no longer than whites, she said. "The bottom line is that there was very little difference," she said.
 
Confirming Suspicions
 Some investigators said the new findings confirmed a widespread suspicion among cancer doctors that black women really do have more intransigent cancers.
"I'm not surprised," said Dr. Melvin Moore, who is the director of oncology at Grady Hospital in Atlanta, a hospital that serves mostly black patients. He said he directed a program financed by the cancer institute to recruit members of minorities to clinical trials using the best standard treatment in the control group as well as in the experimental group. He said the program "started with the premise that the reason for the disparate mortality figures had to do with lack of access to state-of-the art care."
Dr. Moore said it was true that blacks often had grossly inferior medical care. "The inequities were glaring," he said. But, he added, "I think there is more to it than that."
Dr. Howard Ozer, director of the Winship Cancer Center at Emory University in Atlanta, said there might be too much blaming the victim for high breast cancer death rates. When black women go to a doctor with already advanced cancer, "it is always said that they don't come to the doctor soon enough," Dr. Ozer said. But, he said, with the evidence that the cancers might also be much more aggressive, "it may not be their fault at all."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Health-Care Gap Seen for Blacks
 Las Vegas, Nev., Aug. 2 (AP) -- African-Americans face a health care system that is "stacked against them," Surgeon General Joycelyn Elders told the National Black Nurses Association today.
Dr. Elders made the assessment while campaigning for the Clinton Administration's health care plan, and urged members to lobby for its passage.
"If every criminal in our country has a right to an attorney, then it's time we gave every sick person a right to a doctor," she said in prepared remarks.
She said blacks faced the greatest threat from the health care crisis because a disproportionate number of them were uninsured and they bore a heavy burden of illness.
"African-Americans face a health care system stacked against them because they are among those Americans most at risk today of going without health insurance coverage and health care," she said.
Losing or changing jobs means losing health insurance, and African-Americans have one of the highest unemployment rates in the country, she said. Contributing factors to the high unemployment include lower education levels and a higher percentage of unmarried mothers, she said. Figures for 1991 showed that 68 percent of black mothers of newborns were unmarried, compared with 22 percent of white mothers, Dr. Elders said.
She said any health care plan must provide universal access to health care, emphasis on prevention and primary care and should stress comprehensive health education.

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
Ryan Spies Again, This Time as C.I.A. Battles Drug Lords

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN 

 BODY:
Taming the eyeball-glazing prose of Tom Clancy's "Clear and Present Danger" with the same brisk efficiency they brought to "Patriot Games," the makers of this latest espionage thriller have made their first-rate work look easy. And clearly, it was anything but. No amount of exercise under the hot sun will beat the workout involved in following this story, with its dozens of locations, interchangeable-sounding character names (Cutter, Ritter, Clark, Ryan, many more) and high-tech military jargon. A film with a "cellulose encased laser-guided bomb" for a conversation piece is not to be watched casually.
Yet "Clear and Present Danger" (photographed crisply by Donald M. McAlpine and scored by James Horner) looks so lean and moves so vigorously that it actually seems streamlined most of the time. As directed by Philip Noyce, who also did "Patriot Games," this becomes another fast, gripping spy story with some good tricks up its sleeve, and with a much more economical style than that of Mr. Clancy's best-selling novel. Three distinctive screenwriters -- Steven Zaillian ("Schindler's List"), John Milius ("Apocalypse Now") and Donald Stewart (co-writer on "Patriot Games" and "The Hunt for Red October") -- deliver dialogue that is both colorful and swift. 
 Harrison Ford, making only his second screen appearance as Mr. Clancy's heroic C.I.A. agent, Jack Ryan, has already become Old Faithful in this role. Mr. Ford may be the most reticent of American movie stars, but he brings considerable subtlety to the job of humanizing Jack Ryan. In a film that opens with the sight of a waving American flag, subtlety may not be foremost on anyone's mind. But Mr. Ford's wary intelligence does wonders for a potentially one-dimensional character. Jack's heroism on screen has much broader appeal than it does on the page.
Jack is now deputy director of the C.I.A., once his much-admired superior, Adm. James Greer (James Earl Jones, giving a touching, unmannered performance), becomes gravely ill. And one of this film's minor pleasures is the sight of Jack flashing his prestigious C.I.A. business cards at some of the Latin American drug lords who set the story in motion.
"Clear and Present Danger" begins with the discovery of a yacht whose passengers have been murdered, a crime that turns out to be the drug lords' handiwork. Complicating this event are the facts that the principal victim made off with huge sums of money belonging to a drug cartel, and that he was a close friend of the President of the United States. The President, played by Donald Moffat with a Reaganesque mixture of caginess and imperfect hearing, tacitly authorizes a bit of payback.
Unbeknown even to most top C.I.A. personnel, a covert Latin American anti-drug operation is instigated by Cutter, the National Security Adviser (Harris Yulin), with the help of Ritter (Henry Czerny), a rogue C.I.A. man. Mr. Czerny, a Canadian actor who will eventually be familiar to American television audiences when he is seen starring so effectively in "The Boys of St. Vincent," makes a perfect spook. Fidgety, intense, loaded with menace, he becomes the worthiest and most sinister of Ryan's many adversaries in this story.
One of the film's cleverest sequences pits these two in a computer espionage battle, as Ryan and Ritter both try frantically to access Ritter's top-secret files while they also make small talk on the telephone. ("You play tennis?") Only in the brave new world of Mr. Clancy's techno-thrillers does this sort of thing define the meaning of suspense.
Another standout episode, and one of the few here to involve graphic bloodshed, finds Ryan and a group of colleagues suddenly ambushed on a narrow street in Bogota. Equally effective (if a bit less personal) is the scene that follows a smart bomb through the clouds until it hits a drug czar's villa. The villa is one of dozens of varied, sharply evoked international settings here, from the mountains of Colombia all the way to the Oval Office.
The film pays great attention to the lavish, family-oriented home life of Ernesto Escobedo (Miguel Sandoval), who along with his henchman Felix Cortez (Joaquim de Almeida) represents the forces of evil, debonair foreign division. Any similarity to the real drug cartel leader Pablo Escobar, whose death occurred while "Clear and Present Danger" was being filmed, is as fortuitous as it is grim.
Also figuring prominently in "Clear and Present Danger" is a tawny, physically imposing Willem Dafoe as Clark, the mysterious C.I.A. field operative who figures prominently elsewhere in the Clancy canon. The ambiguity of Clark's character suits Mr. Dafoe intriguingly, since it goes so far beyond the ordinary villainy to which he has often been confined. Scenes between Mr. Dafoe and Mr. Ford have a special edginess, since one of them has been so deeply misled about what the other is up to.
There also happen to be a few women in "Clear and Present Danger," but their roles (Hope Lange as a Senator, Ann Magnuson as a hapless pawn in the drug cartel's game) are small. The role that's not small enough is that of Cathy Ryan, the wise, smiling, insufferable wife played again by Anne Archer. Only Cathy seems out of sync with the tough, muscular manner of this story. Cathy doesn't quite ask Jack whether he's remembered his galoshes when he goes off on a dangerous C.I.A. mission, but she comes close.
"Clear and Present Danger" is rated PG-13 (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It includes violence, most of it discreet, and occasional profanity.
 
CLEAR AND PRESENT DANGER

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

DATELINE: UKIAH, Calif., July 29

 BODY:
Outwardly, little has changed in the last few years at Eagle Ridge Ranch, where Hubert Germain-Robin makes what may be the best brandy in the United States.
There are still the wheat-colored slopes of the California coastal range, the sheep huddled in the shade to escape the 100-degree heat, the barns, the little distillery, the chai where the brandy ages, and the buzzing of cicadas. 
 But there has been change here, high in the mountains 100 miles north of San Francisco, and it has been harsh. The economic downturn was not kind to the fledgling brandy business. It dried up discretionary income -- no one needs expensive brandy. It also sounded the death knell for the country's traditional distribution system for wine and spirits. As major distributors closed their doors or merged, small producers like Germain-Robin found themselves with no one to sell their product.
"We're just now about where we were in 1990," said Ansley Coale Jr., who owns Eagle Ridge Ranch and is Mr. Germain-Robin's partner in Alambic Inc., their small brandy business.
Hard times occasioned some hard thinking. The two partners decided that they would concentrate on direct sales and that the product would be expensive. "People want something different," Mr. Coale said, "and they seem to be willing to pay for it. Our most expensive brandies sell out first." Currently, the most expensive Germain-Robin brandy is the V 57 Single Barrel, at $130 a bottle.
But Germain-Robin's most innovative move has been packaging brandy in individual casks. Private individuals, restaurants and wine and spirit merchants can order their own casks for $550 to $1,000. The price includes a 10-liter oak cask and a case of Germain-Robin brandy. The quality of the brandy determines the price. A case of 12 bottles holds 9 liters.
The basic Germain-Robin fine brandy is $550 with cask; the Christmas Blend is $720, and the Reserve is $1,000. For brandy connoisseurs, Mr. Germain-Robin will create a custom blend for $850.
The casks are made by Tonnellerie Vernou, a barrel maker in Cognac, from old barrels in which Cognac had been stored. Each cask bears a plaque with the owner's name.
"The owner has a choice," Mr. Coale said. "Consider the cask a one-time thing, drain it until it's about a third full, then put the remaining brandy back into bottles. By then the cask will be drying out and the brandy will be getting quite oaky.
"Or, keep topping the cask off with more brandy. The cask will remain intact and the brandy will never be overwhelmed by oak."
"The brandy in these barrels will continue to age," Mr. Germain-Robin said, "becoming richer and more harmonious." One year of aging in the small cask is the equivalent of two years in a standard Cognac barrel, he estimates. About 50 of the 10-liter barrels have been sold. In all, 100 are planned.
Customers include the Four Seasons Restaurant and Morrell & Company, a wine and spirits retailer, both in New York; the Ryland Inn in Clinton, N.J.; Stars, Postrio and Fog City Diner in San Francisco, and the White House.
Members of Mr. Germain-Robin's family had been making Cognac in France since 1782. When their firm, Jules Robin & Company was sold to Martell, the Cognac giant, he decided to seek his fortune elsewhere.
Mr. Coale is a transplanted Easterner. He came to Ukiah and the bucolic life by way of the University of California at Berkeley, where he spent some unhappy years teaching ancient history. Eagle Ridge Ranch, which he discovered in 1973, was his ticket out. He bought all 2,000 acres "for the price of a house in San Francisco" and escaped from academia.
In 1981, Mr. Coale and his wife, Cynthia, picked up a hitchhiker on a Mendocino highway. He was Hubert Germain-Robin. Out of that serendipitous meeting came Alambic Inc. Mr. Coale had found a way to make his ranch more profitable; Mr. Germain-Robin found an opportunity to make brandy in a more personal, traditional way.
Mr. Germain-Robin returned to France and found an old, handmade copper still that was being sold for junk. It was shipped to California and reassembled by the two men, and it was soon producing about 80 barrels of brandy a year, a level Alambic has maintained.
In the Cognac region of France, the grape of choice in brandy making is called the St.-Emilion. This is an undistinguished grape known elsewhere in France as ugni blanc and in Italy as trebbiano. In California, Mr. Germain-Robin has experimented with many grapes, settling on French colombard, pinot noir and gamay beaujolais as his principal working varieties. Colombard was the principal grape in the Cognac region in the 18th and 19th centuries.
Mr. Germain-Robin recently released a single barrel of brandy made entirely of colombard, called V 16, which produced only 38 cases. Another recent creation is a Cigar Blend, which relies heavily on brandy made from the sauvignon blanc grape. "It's oakier than our usual releases and displays cedar and tobacco overtones that are the perfect complement to an excellent cigar," he said.
For the last two years, Mr. Germain-Robin has distilled a grappa from organically grown, old-vine zinfandel grapes. Grappa is usually a brandy distilled from pomace, the rough leavings of the wine-making process. The Germain-Robin version has a smoothness and elegance rarely encountered in a traditional grappa.

TASTINGS
Groot Constantia Pinotage, 1989, South Africa. About $10.
 
Pinotage is a wine unique to South Africa. The pinotage grape is a hybrid of pinot noir and cinsault, a grape called hermitage in the vineyards of the Western Cape. Pinotage was developed by South African viticulturists in the mid-1920's. The best of it, including this wine made at one of the country's oldest wineries, has little of what we in the Northern Hemisphere expect from pinot noir. The wine more closely resembles a Rhone-style wine with the refinement of a good Bordeaux. In fact, it's a difficult wine to categorize, which makes it all the more intriguing to drink. There is good fruit in this wine and a sweet aroma that is not mirrored in the taste. It is a bit tannic; another year in the bottle would not be amiss.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Broken Dreams on the Road To Country-Music Stardom

BYLINE: By BEN BRANTLEY 

 BODY:
Cabarets in the Times Square district are unlikely showcases for wholesomeness. But with only a few excisions, "Honky-Tonk Highway," a jalopy-to-limousine musical about a touring country music band at Don't Tell Mama, could play Disneyland.
This formulaic, folksy parable about the perils of fame, with a book by Richard Berg and music and lyrics by Robert Lindsey-Nassif, is a smoothly sanitized pastiche of film biographies of Nashville stars, like "Your Cheating Heart" and "Coal Miner's Daughter." And its sensibility bears roughly the same relationship to the throbbing heartache behind the best country classics that airline food does to home cooking. 
 Set in a Tennessee roadhouse in 1970, the show is built around the collective reminiscences of five former members of a band called the Mountain Rangers, who have reassembled to figure out what went wrong on the road to Nashville and to celebrate the memory of Clint Colby, their late lead singer.
Mr. Berg's book covers every conventional base of bittersweet music success stories, and the show's characters are correspondingly generic. There's the baby-faced Lothario (Rick Leon), the melancholy drinker (Matthew Bennett), the family man (Sean McCourt), the group clown (Kevin Fox) and the female vocalist (the lovely Erin Hill), who is the essential link in a chain of unrequited love. Each of the men takes turns portraying the self-destructive Clint, whose demons are pretty mild as demons go. (He is finally felled not by hard-living hedonism, but by a lonely, arrhythmic heart.) And the roles of sex, drugs and drink in the lives of the group are presented with cosmetic light-heartedness.
The director, Gabriel Barre, has made admirably efficient use of the cabaret's tiny stage. Mr. Lindsey-Nassif's imitative songs, which range from Gatlin Brothers-like harmonies to Porter Wagoner-Loretta Lynn-ish duets, are pleasantly tuneful. And the show's undeniably talented, clean-scrubbed performers sing winningly and accompany themselves on a remarkable 18 instruments, from mandolins and fiddles to pianos and guitars.
More like a vanilla milkshake than a stiff shot of Rebel Yell, "Honky-Tonk Highway" never really engages the emotions, and its blandly sweet charm wears thin over two hours. But for audiences seeking midtown entertainment that would pass Senator Jesse Helms's scrutiny, the play provides an economical alternative to "Beauty and the Beast."

HONKY-TONK HIGHWAY
 
Book by Richard Berg; music and lyrics by Robert Lindsey-Nassif; directed by Gabriel Barre; costumes by Robert Strong Miller; lighting by Carol Dorn; sound by Greg Raj czewski; general management, Bruce Birkenhead; associate producer, Boebe Productions; musical direction and arrangements, Steve Steiner. Presented by Jonathan D. Moll and Five by Five Productions and Pam Guthman. At Don't Tell Mama Cabaret Theater, 343 West 46th Street, Clinton.

HEADLINE: Senate's Promising Health Bill

 BODY:
The health-care bill that the majority leader, George Mitchell, put before the Senate yesterday looks encouraging. It would achieve universal coverage and market reform by borrowing artfully from two flawed committee bills. It is far better than the poorly designed bill before the House. Though there is a glaring fault that needs to be corrected, Mr. Mitchell has provided a workable basis for reform.
Mr. Mitchell's bill would achieve universal coverage in stages. It would first try voluntary reforms to soak up the uninsured. But if by 2000 less than 95 percent of the population is covered, Congress would vote on a plan that is independently certified to achieve universal coverage. If Congress turns down such a plan, an employer mandate would automatically kick in. Employers hiring 25 or more workers would have to pay half the cost of insuring their workers; subsidies would be provided to workers at small companies to buy coverage. 
 The Mitchell bill would create a competitive market for private insurance by requiring states to set up voluntary purchasing cooperatives that would offer workers at most companies as well as the poor and unemployed a menu of private insurance plans. The bill would also open the Federal Employees Health Benefits Plan to many otherwise uninsured people. It thereby guarantees everyone access to fee-for-service and managed-care plans.
The Mitchell bill is also noteworthy for what it does not include. Unlike the House bill, it builds in no inevitable slide toward government takeover of health insurance. Nor did Mr. Mitchell give in to powerful lobbyists for physicians by including provisions, as in the House bill, that would stagger most managed-care plans.
In these ways -- and by putting off an employer mandate for at least seven years and exempting very small companies -- he has taken much of the fear out of reform and accommodated the legitimate concerns of reform-minded critics. If conservative Democrats, like David Boren of Oklahoma and John Breaux of Louisiana, as well as moderate Republicans, like John Chafee of Rhode Island and John Danforth of Missouri, turn down Mr. Mitchell's proposal they will have unconscionably rejected the best chance of reform in 50 years.
There is one provision, however, that may give critics reason to reject the Mitchell plan. But it is remediable. Mr. Mitchell recognizes that the only way to get insurers and providers to control costs is to give consumers big incentives to choose low-cost health plans. Mr. Mitchell proposes a strange tax on health plans whose premiums are rising quickly -- no matter how low the premiums might be. Such a tax would lock in existing prices and amount to a backhanded form of price controls. The best way to make consumers, and therefore insurers, conscious of costs is to tax plans with high premiums.
Senator Mitchell has asked critics not to let the best be the enemy of the good. His plan is far from the best. But if the tax on fast-rising premiums is fixed, it would be good enough. Compared with other bills actively before Congress, Mr. Mitchell's bill should give Americans enormous hope as the House and Senate move to floor debate next week.

HEADLINE: THE WHITEWATER AFFAIR: THE OVERVIEW;
SENATORS ASSAIL TREASURY DEPUTY

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Aug. 3

 BODY:
In high dudgeon, members of both parties on the Senate Banking Committee assailed Deputy Treasury Secretary Roger C. Altman on Tuesday and into the early hours today for having been untruthful, in their view, about the Whitewater case at a hearing last February.
In a session that went on until 2:08 A.M., the most contentious day of Whitewater hearings yet, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, accused Mr. Altman of being "at the very least disingenuous." 
 At issue were Mr. Altman's responses on four different occasions at a Feb. 24 hearing before the Banking Committee. Mr. Altman was asked then whether he or anyone on his staff had made contact with anyone at the White House about issues related to the Federal investigation into the collapse of Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan. Madison's owner, James B. McDougal, was a partner of Bill and Hillary Clinton in the Whitewater real estate venture.
Mr. Altman replied each time at the February hearing that he knew of only "one substantive contact," on Feb. 2, when he and members of his staff went to the White House to explain that the statute of limitations was about to expire on civil proceedings against Madison Guaranty.
Subsequently, Mr. Altman wrote the committee four times amending his testimony, but he never gave a full accounting of contacts that have been mentioned by others.
Other Administration officials have testified about several other contacts. The Treasury Department's inspector general counted 40.
Addressing the discrepancies, Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, said, "This is totally unbelievable." Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, said the testimony of other witnesses "really calls into question how we can believe you."
And Senator Richard C. Shelby, Democrat of Alabama, who later called on Mr. Altman to resign, asked him, "Mr. Altman, do you think when someone asks you a straight question, you should give a straight answer?"
 
'I Do Not Have Perfect Recall'
 Mr. Altman insisted that he had told the truth, but no senator offered him a vigorous defense.
"Mr. Chairman," Mr. Altman said at one point this afternoon, "I do not have perfect recall, and I may have heard or understood questions in a way that was not intended by the senator asking the question. If I did so, I sincerely apologize to all members of the committee. But I do want to be clear. In no way did I intend to mislead or not to provide complete and forthright answers."
Answering Senator Shelby's question directly, Mr. Altman said he had a solid reputation for integrity and forthrightness.
The question of whether Mr. Altman told the truth at the hearing in February has gained special importance because of the limited scope of this phase of Congress's investigation into the Whitewater affair. The Senate has agreed that the only matters that can be examined at this point are the circumstances surrounding the death last year of Vincent W. Foster Jr., who was the deputy White House counsel, and the contacts between Treasury and White House officials on the Madison case.
The propriety of the Feb. 2 meeting at the White House is an open question. At the time, Mr. Altman was acting chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency that administers the nation's savings and loan bailout. In his testimony, he denied that this meeting amounted to interference with the R.T.C.'s Whitewater investigation, or to special treatment for the Clintons.
Some senators maintain that it was improper for a regulatory official to brief the White House about a case in which the Clintons had an interest. But the special Whitewater prosecutor, Robert B. Fiske Jr., has found that no crime was committed. And the independent Office of Government Ethics reported last weekend that while poor judgment may have occurred, no ethics rule was broken.
Other than that matter of propriety, hardly anything of controversy has arisen in the hearings that began last week and are expected to last at least through Friday. The civil and criminal cases against Madison are, by all accounts, proceeding apace.
 
Longtime Friend of President
 Mr. Altman, who is 48 years old, has known Mr. Clinton since they attended Georgetown University together in the 1960's. A successful investment banker, he worked as a fund-raiser and economic adviser in the 1992 Clinton campaign, and his nomination to the No. 2 post at the Treasury was one of the first announced by Mr. Clinton after the election. Last year he was instrumental in organizing the Administration's efforts to win Congressional approval of the budget and the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Until this latest controversy developed, it was widely assumed that he would one day succeed Lloyd Bentsen as Treasury Secretary. Now his prospects for continuing in office, let alone rising there, have been called into doubt.
 
Aide's Testimony on Diary
 The questioning of Mr. Altman did not begin until nearly 5 P.M. Tuesday. In a show of solidarity, B. A. Bentsen, the wife of the Treasury Secretary, sat in the first row, next to Mr. Altman's wife, Jurate Kazickas.
Earlier, four other Treasury officials testified. No new ground was broken. Mainly, the senators heard Joshua L. Steiner, Mr. Bentsen's 28-year-old chief of staff, testify that he had exaggerated when he had written in his diary that Mr. Altman was under "intense pressure from the White House" over the Madison case, that a disaster was unfolding and that Mr. Altman had "gracefully ducked" questions at his Feb. 24 hearing.
"I wish that my diary was more accurate," Mr. Steiner told the committee.
Mr. Altman took issue with the testimony on Monday of Jean Hanson, the Treasury's general counsel, that he had instructed her to keep the White House informed of developments in the criminal investigation of Madison, an activity known as a referral. Ms. Hanson said she told the White House last fall about what she believed was an impending press report that the Clintons were named as potential witnesses.
"I do not believe that I suggested that the White House be informed on any facts relating to this referral," Mr. Altman said. "But if Ms. Hanson did advise the White House of an impending press leak on it, I see nothing improper in that."
 
Exchange With D'Amato
 Mr. Altman also disputed the notion that he should have withdrawn from the Madison case long before he did on Feb. 25. "In retrospect, I perhaps should have recused myself right off the bat," he said. But he quickly added, "I don't think that taking three weeks to make such a complex decision is all that surprising. But again, the important point is that I recused myself without ever having participated in any decisions on Madison."
As is often the case in Congressional inquiries, the senators seemed more interested in making points than in asking questions.
Senator D'Amato set the pattern in his questioning early on, when, speaking in his machine-gun style, he rattled off quotations from Mr. Steiner's diary about various contacts Mr. Altman and people on his staff had with the White House: a meeting Mr. Altman had with Margaret Williams, Mrs. Clinton's chief of staff; a meeting Mr. Bentsen had with George Stephanopoulos, a senior adviser to the President; a discussion with Harold M. Ickes, another top adviser.
"Was that not about Whitewater?" Mr. D'Amato asked.
Mr. Altman tried to explain why he testified in February that there had been only one substantative contact with the White House. "Senator," he said, "I used the word 'substantive'-- --"
Mr. D'Amato cut him off: "Listen, please don't tell me about 'substantive.' "
"May I respond?" Mr. Altman asked.
"No," Mr. D'Amato said. Then he had a second thought. "Well, I see the red light's on, but go ahead."
Mr. Altman said: "Senator D'Amato, I respectfully disagree, and I do so vehemently, with the premise of the question. I responded on Feb. 24 by saying that I had one substantive contact. Now that's the way I responded. And by that I meant relating to the R.T.C. investigation of Madison. None of the conversations that you just enumerated had anything to do with the R.T.C. investigation of Madison, and I used the word 'substantive' for that purpose."

HEADLINE: State and Developer Agree to Refurbish Times Square Storefronts

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
New York State and a principal developer in the long-delayed Times Square redevelopment project yesterday agreed to a stopgap plan for refurbishing dozens of storefronts while the developer waits for the real-estate market to improve.
The Prudential Insurance Company of America and Park Tower Realty, the development partnership, agreed to pay $20 million for renovating the storefronts and $2.6 million for decorative lighting and other street improvements. 
 By doing so, the partners maintained their stake in the redevelopment project, which has been on the drawing board for more than a decade. George Klein, a principal in Park Tower, said he hoped to start building the first of four towers in three to five years.
 
An Interim Step
 But in the short term the deal sets the stage for the transformation of the empty storefronts along Broadway, Seventh Avenue and the strip of 42d Street to the west, where the state hopes that new tenants will convert what seems like a ghost town into a vibrant entertainment and retail center.
The plan to refurbish the storefronts is essentially an interim step in what planners say will eventually be the Times Square that was envisioned in 1981, with four skyscrapers clustered around the intersection of Seventh Avenue and 42d Street, revitalized theaters nearby and a hotel and trade mart on Eighth Avenue.
The tower plan, called Times Square Center, was largely put on hold two years ago when the state allowed Prudential to delay construction until the real estate market improved.
"Because the office market was weak, we knew it would be hard to get on with the project we first envisioned," said Vincent Tese, chairman of the state Urban Development Corporation, the agency responsible for the redevelopment effort. "So we agreed to a delay of the office projects. But at the same time we did not want the street to be dark."
 
Financing Paradox
 Even so, by the time the office plan was put on hold in August 1992, the state had begun condemning tens of millions of dollars in commercial property and evicting longtime tenants.
The money for the condemnation -- more than $270 million -- came from the developers, creating the paradoxical situation in which Prudential and Park Tower are now about to pay $20 million to help replace the tenants they paid to remove.
"I guess we've come full circle on this," said Ray DioGuardi, vice president and chief executive of Nathan's Famous, the fast-food chain that was evicted from one of its locations in the spring of 1990. "They put us out, and now they have to look for tenants. What's the saying? What goes around comes around."
A vivid reminder of that circle could be seen yesterday. As state officials were completing their agreement with Prudential, workers were carrying video games out of the Playland arcade on Seventh Avenue, the latest casualty of the condemnation process.
 
A Turning Point?
 "It's a shame this place is closing," said Matthew Bridges, a 28-year-old office assistant and a Playland regular. "I've been coming here since I was 12 and old enough to take the trains alone. Kids are going to come here. Playland was a nonviolent atmosphere, better than going to peep shows."
State officials said yesterday that the interim plan, which still must be approved by the board of the Urban Development Corporation, is a turning point in the redevelopment of the neighborhood which has come to symbolize urban danger and degradation.
"This contract for the interim plan is significant because it represents forward movement," said Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project, the state agency overseeing the development. "For the first time something will be happening. When stores start opening we will be able to push forward with the rest of the development. When a company like Prudential recommits, it has an impact beyond the pieces it will develop. This will help us with the rest of the development plan."
In leasing the storefronts, the state and the development team will be concentrating on entertainment and tourist-related businesses with late-hour operations, like music stores, bookstores and souvenir shops that will build upon the district's honky-tonk appeal.
 
Gaining Momentum
 Mr. Tese said the state had at least a dozen prospective retail and restaurant tenants for the vacant spaces, but he would not identify them. The new tenants would have to sign short-term leases that would allow the developers to move them out when the office towers are to be built.
Mr. Tese also called the interim plan a bridge for the long-range vision of Times Square. "For the average New Yorker and visitor, this interim plan is the important step. Times Square is primarily an entertainment district, and that is not going to change, even after the new office buildings go up."
Yesterday's contract was one more sign that the redevelopment of the area has gained momentum. Last week, the Walt Disney Company was among those submitting proposals for a new hotel at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue. If Disney is selected as the project's developer, it would be the entertainment company's second Times Square project; last year, Disney signed an agreement to renovate the New Amsterdam Theater on the largely barren strip of West 42d Street off Times Square.
 
Agreement on Signs
 The $20 million renovation costs will pay for cleaning and repair of spaces as well as for asbestos removal where needed. State officials expect the money to pay for the renovation of approximately 30 stores in 13 buildings. The contract also required that stores be leased within 24 months of final approval of the plan.
Earlier in the discussions the developers had balked at the state's requirements that Prudential erect huge signs as part of the interim plan to keep the glitzy flavor of Times Square. But in the end they agreed to include 50,000 square feet of retail and electric supersigns in the interim project.
As part of the agreement, the developers will pay the state an annual base rent of $3.3 million, which would increase with inflation. Rents on the interim leases will be paid to the developers.
Brian Murphy, senior vice president of the Prudential Realty Group, said yesterday that having new stores and attractions in the neighborhood would help sell office tenants on Times Square when new construction starts.
"This will give prospective tenants an immediate fix on what Times Square will look like," said Mr. Murphy, "and it will help create a momentum for our corner and for the rest of the development area."
In fact the plan comes at a time when the real estate market in Times Square is improving. When the developers and the state tentatively agreed to stop the clock on the office development and design an interim plan for the area, the office market was in the doldrums. Several new buildings, including a few in Times Square, stood empty or nearly so.
 
Moving In
 Since then office tenants like Morgan Stanley, the investment banking company; Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn, a law firm that relocated from Park Avenue; Viacom, the entertainment parent of MTV and Paramount, and Bantam Doubleday Dell Publishing Group have moved into the neighborhood.
As a result Mr. Klein said he expected to begin building the first of the towers within the next five years, rather than into the next decade as he and other officials predicted two years ago.
Despite yesterday's milestone, the overall redevelopment plan still has its critics. Last week the Municipal Arts Society, a longtime opponent of the project, denounced the state for the hefty tax abatements the developers will receive.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 5, 1994, Friday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the Times Square redevelopment project characterized the stance of the Municipal Art Society incorrectly. Although the group has criticized some aspects of the project over the years, it is not a longtime opponent. It had supported the overall plan, but recently withdrew its support after the state relieved the developers of their obligation to start construction of four office towers according to a set timetable.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Olivetti Chief Tries for New Direction

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: IVREA, Italy

 BODY:
At business school, nobody told Corrado Passera it might someday get this difficult.
Two years ago, Mr. Passera was given the job of fixing Olivetti S.p.A., the office-equipment company that is Europe's second-largest computer maker after Siemens Nixdorf Infomationssysteme A.G. of Germany. Since 1990, Olivetti has not had a profit, and over the last three years it has lost a total exceeding $1 billion. But if all goes according to his plan, by the end of this year Mr. Passera, chief executive of Olivetti, will finally come close to break-even. 
 "It's been a painful and difficult process, but we've now succeeded in growing with fewer and fewer people," said Mr. Passera, who has overseen much of Olivetti's effort to cut 22,000 jobs since 1989, reducing the work force by 40 percent to a current level of 35,000.
 
Attempting a Sea Change
 The turnaround is by no means certain because Mr. Passera is attempting what amounts to a makeover of Olivetti. Mr. Passera means to recast Olivetti -- a company that last year derived the bulk of its $5 billion in annual sales from hardware -- as an information technology company that within a few years would derive one-third or even fully half its revenue from computer services and telecommunications.
Already, Olivetti has farmed out a lot of its computer manufacturing, including a deal with the Digital Equipment Corporation, freeing the company to concentrate more on designing, installing and maintaining computer networks for big corporate European customers like Barclays Bank P.L.C.
And in recent months, Olivetti has signed a string of deals with large American communications companies -- including the Bell Atlantic Corporation, Pacific Telesis and the General Motors Corporation's Hughes Network Systems unit -- to provide wireless communications services in Italy and elsewhere in Europe.
In expanding beyond computers, an industry bled in Europe by cutthroat price cutting and the region's long recession, Olivetti must contend with bigger competitors that were earlier to make such moves, including Siemens Nixdorf and the AT&T Corporation's NCR computer division.
Yet, some analysts give Mr. Passera at least even odds of succeeding in his strategy for Olivetti. "Don't underestimate their strong marketing skills," said Bill Coleman, an analyst at the brokerage house James Capel & Company in London. "That's where Olivetti's skill and positioning is -- in distribution, marketing, and the positioning of its service."
 
A Dynamic Duo
 Working in Mr. Passera's favor is the company's history and the strong advisory role still played by his mentor, Carlo De Benedetti, Olivetti's president and principal shareholder. Mr. De Benedetti, an international investor with major holdings in Italy, France and Spain, took control of Olivetti in 1978 and transformed it from a sleepy manufacturer of mechanical typewriters into one of Europe's leaders in office automation.
Mr. De Benedetti, who is 59, remains "very much a part of strategic discussions," Mr. Passera said.
The slight and boyish Mr. Passera, who is 39, was the upstart business school graduate, with degrees from Milan's Bocconi University and the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, when he came to Mr. De Benedetti's attention in the early 1980's. At the time, Mr. Passera was earning high marks as a banking and finance consultant for McKinsey & Company in Italy.
Mr. De Benedetti brought him aboard as his personal assistant at the Compagnie Industriali Riunite holding group, with financial interests in electronics, retailing and other fields. There, Mr. Passera developed a reputation as a no-nonsense executive with an eye for detail -- just what Mr. De Benedetti decided was needed when he handed Mr. Passera the mess at Olivetti in 1992.
 
Good 'Underlying Factors'
 Although Olivetti reports its financial results in the Italian currency, the lira, when the data are converted to dollars at the Dec. 31 exchange rate for each year, the numbers tell the following story:
After eking out a profit of $53 million on sales of $8 billion in 1990, the company saw sales decline for two consecutive years, leading to losses of $403 million in 1991 and $440 million in 1992. Last year, the first full 12 months on Mr. Passera's watch, sales edged back up to $5 billion and the loss was reduced to $271 million.
Investors have given Mr. Passera high marks, and Olivetti remains one of Italy's most widely held stocks. But the share price, which was at a 52-week high of 3,080 lire, or about $1.95, in April has lately been trading in the 2,400 range. Some brokerage firms, like Kleinwort-Benson in London, have Olivetti shares on their "take profit" list.
"The underlying factors are good," said Fiona Marshall, a Kleinwort analyst who follows Olivetti. But she added that Olivetti has been promising a return to break-even for several years now, and investors may not want to wait to see if Mr. Passera's prediction this year is borne out.
The mainstay of Olivetti's strategy is a network of alliances, most with the common goal of putting Olivetti more squarely in the world of telecommunications. Indeed, the move reflects the latest fashion in Europe's computer industry, where companies are following the American example of helping their computer customers set up local or long-distance networks capable of sending voice, data or images.
Olivetti was actually one of the first to sniff the wind. In 1984, the company sold a 22 percent stake in its business to the AT&T Corporation for $260 million. But the deal came "too early," according to Bruno Lamborghini, Olivetti's senior vice president for corporate strategy.
The relationship soured in the late 1980's when AT&T proposed acquiring all of Olivetti and Mr. De Benedetti turned down the offer. In 1989, AT&T swapped its holdings in Olivetti for a $492 million stake in Compagnie Industriali Riunite, Mr. De Benedetti's holding company. Since then, AT&T has been selling off its Industriali Riunite position little by little.
Under Mr. Passera, Olivetti turned to another big partner, the Digital Equipment Corporation, which acquired 10 percent of the Italian company in 1992 for about $300 million. Although the deal gave Olivetti access to Digital's technically advanced Alpha microchip technology, so far Digital has sold far fewer Alpha-based computers through Olivetti than expected.
More recently, Olivetti has formed a joint venture with the Redgate Communication Corporation of Vero Beach, Fla., to develop an electronic catalogue that later this year is to enable shoppers in France to use home computers to obtain information in text, pictures and audio form about computer products offered for sale by various companies.
In another recently formed venture, with Docunet, a California-based company, Olivetti intends to develop touch-screen vending machines for theaters, airports and travel agencies in the United States for selling tickets.
But the real drive into telecommunications involves deals with big American communications companies. Olivetti is the lead partner in a group that includes Bell Atlantic and Pacific Telesis, which was authorized by the Italian Government in April to build Italy's second cellular telephone network. The network would compete directly with the cellular network operated by Italy's state-owned telephone company, Stet.
Olivetti's digital cellular network, which will transmit voice and data in the binary pulses of computer code, is to begin service next year. Mr. Lamborghini says it will not only offer crystal-clear conversations through wireless phones but will also enable users of laptop computers to transmit large amounts of data virtually anywhere reachable by conventional land-line telephones.
In June, Olivetti struck a deal with Hughes Network Systems to offer satellite communication systems in Europe using the small dish antennas that enable large corporations to distribute information among their big offices.
Telecommunications in Europe, as deregulation strides forward, is a fast-growing business. But the frenzy of arrangements Olivetti has entered only serves to underscore the need to play catch-up in a quickly moving new business. Michael Grant, a telecommunications consultant in Cambridge, England, said that Olivetti was coming late to the field.
"I'd be surprised if they made a success of it," Mr. Grant said. "There are a great number of players well down the route."
 
Going Up Against Giants
 Indeed, Olivetti is taking on some giants, as other European companies have also forged their own alliances with American carriers.
AT&T has teamed with Unisource, a joint venture of the national phone operators in Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the Netherlands. The MCI Communications Corporation recently received United States Justice Department approval to sell a 20 percent stake to BT (formerly British Telecom). And earlier this year, Deutsche Bundespost Telekom of Germany and France Telecom agreed to jointly spend $4.2 billion to acquire 20 percent of the Sprint Corporation.
All the more reason, Mr. Passera said, for Olivetti to continue its own search for partnerships.
"The times when a company could be engaged in everything from semiconductors to hardware to software are finished," Mr. Passera said. "There's a continuing need for alliances."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Again, American General Goes After Unitrin

BYLINE: By KATHRYN JONES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Aug. 2

 BODY:
The American General Corporation, one of the nation's largest providers of retirement annuities, consumer loans and life insurance, said today that it was offering $2.6 billion in cash to acquire Unitrin Inc., a financial services holding company.
Unitrin said in a statement that its board had determined that a sale was not in the company's interest. Unitrin executives did not return telephone calls today seeking further comment. 
 Last week, the board rejected a merger offer made by American General, which is based in Houston.
When American General made the merger proposal on July 12, it offered $50.375 in cash for each of Unitrin's 51.8 million outstanding shares. That represented a 30 percent premium over the $38.75 closing price of Unitrin shares on July 11.
Today's announcement -- which made the previous offer public and set a deadline for the present offer -- was made after the stock market closed. Earlier, American General's shares fell 75 cents to close at $28.125 on the New York Stock Exchange. Unitrin shares fell $1.50 to close at $39.75 n Nasdaq trading.
American General proposed the purchase in a letter that was faxed to Richard C. Vie, Unitrin's chief executive and president, at the company's headquarters in Chicago. American General said the offer would be open through Sept. 16.
 
More Money May Be Offered
 Harold S. Hook, American General's chairman and chief executive, said in a telephone interview that he had not received a response from Unitrin. But he indicated that the company would pursue the offer and would be willing to consider a higher price if Unitrin could demonstrate additional value during negotiations.
"At this stage, we are very hopeful that the shareholders will make their wishes known to the Unitrin board and we'll get a chance to put this together," Mr. Hook said.
American General also said it would be willing to consider other ways of structuring the transaction, including a tax-free exchange of American General stock to Unitrin shareholders.
Mr. Hook said American General was willing to pay a premium for Unitrin because the companies believed the combination would be a "good strategic fit" and position the company to be an even stronger player as the insurance industry consolidated.
The companies together would have more than eight million households as customers and combined assets of $50 billion and revenues of $6 billion, American General said. The company said the transaction would add to its earnings per share in the second year after its completion.
Unitrin's major lines of business are life and health insurance, property and casualty insurance and consumer finance.
"We're in a lot of common markets and seeing a similar clientele and in a similar way," Mr. Hook said. "In line with the economies of scale and competitive nature of business today, it's just a natural progression."
American General has estimated that Unitrin is overcapitalized by about $1.4 billion. Analysts have characterized Unitrin as conservatively managed, while American General is considered more aggressive.
In a recent report, analysts at Conning & Company in Hartford noted that Unitrin was overcapitalized by $1.1 billion, with the excess capital invested mainly in Treasury securities. The analysts said that Unitrin shares have traded below book value recently because of "lackluster" earnings and the absence of a "catalyst" to release shareholder value.
Unitrin earned $28.3 million in the second quarter, compared with $36.9 million a year earlier. Total revenues rose slightly to $340.8 million from $337.7 million a year earlier.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: AT THE WHITE HOUSE;
CLINTON PRESSURES G.O.P. LAWMAKERS ON HEALTH CARE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Asserting that Congress has a "historic opportunity" this year to enact universal health care legislation after six decades of failure, President Clinton accused Republican lawmakers tonight of abandoning their earlier support for guaranteed benefits and said the responsibility for finding a workable formula "now should shift to them."
But in the third prime-time news conference of his term, Mr. Clinton was also forced to answer accusations that he had abandoned his stated goal of insuring every American by endorsing the version of insurance legislation unveiled on Tuesday by the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine. 
 That bill would guarantee insurance by the year 2000 to at least 95 percent of the population, up from 85 percent now. Mr. Clinton has repeatedly pledged a veto of any bill that does not cover the entire population within a reasonable time, but he said Mr. Mitchell's bill met that goal.
"Senator Mitchell is convinced that it is the most ambitious bill he can pass, but that it meets the requirement" of eventually covering all Americans, the President said. "If it is deficit-neutral, and if it is passed in the way that it is, I think we will achieve full coverage."
Speaking shortly after Mr. Clinton accused his opponents of being unbending on health care, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, asserted that it was the President who may need to compromise. "He says he's got to have everything," Mr. Dole said. "It may mean we'll do nothing. Why don't we take care of the 20 or 30 provisions that Democrats and Republicans agree on?"
Mr. Clinton's remarks tonight underscored the political contradictions the President faced as the major initiative of his term moved toward an uncertain fate on the House and Senate floors.
The Mitchell bill would employ regulatory changes and subsidies for the working poor to reach at least 95 percent coverage. Should the country fall short of that goal, the bill would require employers to pay half the cost of a basic package of benefits for their workers.
But once the 95 percent goal is reached, the legislation offers no mechanism -- other than nonbinding recommendations by a Government board -- to extend insurance benefits to the remaining 5 percent that Mr. Clinton has promised to cover.
Only last month, at a National Governors' Association meeting in Boston, Mr. Clinton hinted he might accept 95 percent or 96 percent coverage of the population in an insurance bill. But a furious protest from his strongest backers in the Democratic Party and the labor movement led the White House to insist within hours that Mr. Clinton was misunderstood, and was truly intent on supporting benefits for each and every American.
Mr. Clinton repeated that pledge tonight, calling universal coverage "the one criteria I have set out" for health care legislation and "the one rock-solid principle" to which he adheres.
At the White House earlier today, the head of Mr. Clinton's economic council, Robert E. Rubin, said that Mr. Clinton was "where he's always been" on universal coverage and that Mr. Mitchell's bill was "a practical guarantee" of reaching that goal.
But he would not assert that it guaranteed coverage for everyone in fact, saying instead that it created "momentum," established a "structure" and set up a "mechanism" to get to that goal.
"What Mitchell is saying, what the bill says, is that he is putting in place forces which he believes will be on a trajectory toward universal coverage," Mr. Rubin said.
For his part, Mr. Clinton argued tonight that the real obstruction to universal coverage was the Republican Party, not the White House.
At one time, he said, two dozen Republican senators were sponsors of a bill to give universal coverage to all Americans. "They have all abandoned that bill," he said. "The questions now should shift to them: Are we going to cover all Americans or not?"
But Mr. Dole complained that the bills the Democrats had offered were unacceptable. The Mitchell proposal, he said, called for "a sort of government-run health care system" that relied too much on taxes.
 
Sliding Polls
 The President's appearance before reporters tonight was an unusually wide-ranging one, in part by White House design. With Mr. Clinton's standing in opinion polls in a summerlong slide, his advisers have sought a way to remind the public of the White House's successes and of what they say is his commitment to help the average American.
The President did all that tonight, recalling for viewers that under his tenure the annual budget deficit had fallen, taxes had fallen for the poor and risen for the rich, four million new jobs had been created and a trade pact approved that had substantially increased exports to Mexico.
He also made a bid to salve chafed relations with the national press, declaring that he enjoyed long news conferences, even though they have been rare events so far, and that he had already planned to hold more of them than the one per six months that he has staged so far.
But the health bills were the dominant issue. For Mr. Clinton, the passage of health care legislation has assumed a political importance that equals and maybe exceeds its gravity as a social issue. A failure to pass and sign a bill could be devastating to Democrats seeking re-election to Congress, where the President's working majority is already shaky.
It could be even more damaging to Mr. Clinton, who has embarked on an effort to show mainstream voters that he can deliver on a promise. Health care legislation is so monumental a promise, and he has campaigned on it for so long, that its success or failure has come to represent his second year in office, if not his entire term.
But Mr. Clinton began his press conference by saying he "felt good" about the progress his Administration was making, particularly on health care. For the first time, he said, health care measures are before both houses of Congress. He urged Americans to tell their representatives and senators that that they had "a historic opportunity" to pass health care legislation.
The President said he expected a close vote but noted that the legislation he originally proposed has been changed, "much of it for the better." The House and Senate measures would provide more support for small businesses, more time to institute changes and less bureaucracy.
Seeking to sharpen the differences between Republicans and Democrats, he said it was now time for the opposition party to better define its own approach. "Are we going to cover all Americans, or not?" he said. "If you don't like our approaches, in the Senate and the House, what is your alternative?"
The issues are complex, he said, but the important thing is "to keep our eye on the central reality, which is, 'How do we solve the problem?' "
Mr. Clinton emphasized that his health care plan would encourage more Americans to seek preventive health care. Better prenatal care is particularly important, he said.
Playing down business opposition to the bills, Mr. Clinton said the more noteworthy developments were that many businesses had come out for universal coverage and even a requirement that employers help finance their workers' insurance.
"We have more business interests for it than ever before," he said.
Mr. Clinton said many Fortune 500 companies agreed that employers should be required to provide coverage to employees, and he said that 600,000 small businesses endorsed that view.
The President said that "universal coverage is popular with the American people." The bills devised by the the Democratic leaders of Congress may offend "organized interest groups," but both bills "have answered the concerns of American voters in every Congressional district," Mr. Clinton said.
 
What People Want
 Some of Mr. Clinton's remarks tonight echoed those he made at a ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House earlier today to welcome the health legislation supporters who rode on bus caravans. His comments unfolded in a deeper-than-usual drawl that fit his theme: that his White House is really "the home office of the American Association of Ordinary Citizens," as he put it, and that enacting a system of national health insurance is no harder than just doing what the people want.
"When you've got something everybody wants to do but is not easy to do, the people that hired on have to make the decisions," he said. "And the members of the United States Congress hired on, just like I did.
"We didn't say, 'Vote for me, in a representative form of government, and I will make all the necessary decisions to solve the problems of the country except those that are difficult, controversial and make people mad.' That was not the deal."
