HEADLINE: Information Freeway?;
Open Data Path Is Urged

BYLINE: By ASHLEY DUNN 

 BODY:
With a tangle of cut-rate electronics and a couple of computers, the free-netters of Buffalo are campaigning to bring cyberspace to the people.
"We're built on the concept of community, not profit," said Jody Lebrenz, a founding member of the Buffalo Free-Net. "We believe that the minute you charge even $5, you're dividing people into haves and have-nots. Access should be free to the community, like a public library." 
 The Buffalo Free-Net, a volunteer group of students, librarians and residents, is part of a small but growing grass-roots movement loosely known as community networks. Its mission: to provide computer users with local services like regional news and forums on community issues. But while some community networks have fees, free-nets are championing access without charge to the global computer web Internet.
The free-access groups have opened an electronic portal that allows local residents to connect home computers, for the cost of a local phone call, to the Internet, which is now shared by an estimated 20 million people worldwide. Many free-access networks have set up computers in schools and libraries so that even those without their own equipment can reach the Internet for free.
With fewer than 100 in existence, from Big Sky Telegraph in Montana to Ocean State Free-Net in Providence, R.I., the networks are at the moment just a blip in the cosmos. Most Internet users rely on private companies like America Online, a national service, and Pipeline, in New York City, to provide Internet access for fees that begin around $9 a month.
But the free-access-network idea is spreading. Four more networks are being set up in the New York region, in White Plains, Albany, Rochester and Danbury, Conn. Organizers hope to provide access to everything from job listings to government programs.
"The Common Council agenda is not available here unless you go to City Hall," said Diane Greenwald, a Danbury librarian helping to organize that city's free-access network, which is expected to be ready by early 1996. "We can have lots of local forums. Why not something for ethnic communities? This is the reincarnation of the public library in the computer age."
 
Federal Grants Promised
 To help develop community networks, including free networks, the Federal Government has committed $26 million this year in grants, for which it has received more than 1,000 applications; $100 million has been promised next year.
Most free networks depend on state grants, donations and the largess of a university to pay for or supply computers, modems, phone lines and, sometimes, staff. They often piggyback off a nearby university, which pays the $5,000 to $25,000 for a high-capacity telephone line linking its computer system to the Internet.
A leader of the free-access movement, Tom Grundner, who created the first such network in Cleveland in 1986, has organized the National Public Telecommunications Network, a consortium of 34 networks that aims to coordinate programs. For example, the network recently sponsored an event in which schools competed in math and sports, then posted scores on the Internet.
Mr. Grundner's intent is to create a cooperative called the Corporation for Public Cybercasting, patterned after the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. A cyberspace PBS, he says, would serve as a clearinghouse for Federal funds, help develop information services for local communities and lobby for community access.
 
Access Is an Issue
 As the Internet has evolved from a low-cost computer network limited to researchers and students into a powerful tool of mass communications, free networks have found themselves at the heart of a national debate: should the public be guaranteed free access as the technology evolves? At the moment, no one can lay claim to the Internet, but the telecommunications and entertainment industries are beginning to build advanced communications systems that would put them in a position to control and charge for access.
Earlier this year, 93 civil-rights and consumer groups drafted a letter to Senator Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii, chairman of the Senate subcommittee on communications, in support of open access.
In June, Senator Inouye proposed a bill that would provide some guarantee of public access. Other measures moving through Congress demand guarantees of affordable pricing and preferential rates for schools, hospitals, local governments and libraries.
"There are always going to be niches for services that are in demand but can't be found any other place," said Heidi Kukis, spokeswoman for Vice President Gore. "The Vice President likes to tell a story about a 90-year-old woman who refused to go to a nursing home until she was hooked up to a modem so she could communicate on Seniornet. This is a perfect example of why community networks will continue to exist even as the national information infrastructure expands."
There is no pattern to how free networks are set up or financed. Seattle's is backed by the city, which has installed hundreds of computers in public libraries so residents can send electronic messages or tap into data banks.
The Buffalo Free-Net has depended on donated services from the State University of New York at Buffalo and small state grants.
In New York City, Neighborhood Houses of New York, a social-service organization, is sponsoring a community network of sorts with a plan to place scores of computer terminals with some free Internet access in settlement houses around the city.
That the free networks exist at all is a result of the unusual economics of the Internet, which was created in the early 1970's by the Defense Department to allow researchers to exchange data. The system, at first paid for by the Government, connected only researchers at universities, but eventually access spread. Universities began offering free access to students and researchers, who transformed it into a communications system that went far beyond what its creators envisioned.
It was as a student three years ago that Mr. Lebrenz, one of the founding members of the Buffalo Free-Net, discovered Internet.
"I literally spent six hours a day on the Internet for over a year just learning about it," he said. "As a librarian, I thought I had died and gone to heaven."
Mr. Lebrenz and others decided to bring the Internet to Buffalo by tapping the university's connection and using donated equipment. The Buffalo Free-Net now has 8,000 registered users, who can dial up to see who is playing Saturday night at the Lafayette Tap Room downtown, review City Council agendas or sign on to Seniornet, the bulletin board system with information for the elderly.
 
Survival Is Difficult
 Survival, however, has been a struggle, the free-netters say.
To begin with, even a small network needs staff to maintain computer systems and oversee operations. In Peoria, Ill., the Heartland Free-Net consumes $45,000 a year to keep its connection open for the 1,400 people a day who sign on, even with its free connection through nearby Bradley University.
"The bottom line is that I don't know if we're going to survive," said Karen Eggert, executive director of Heartland. "I've been in a seat for four years where every few months you look around and don't have any money left."
Free networks also have been squeezed by their own success. As small entities, they were little trouble for the universities that provided Internet connections. But as computer traffic has increased, many universities are now asking the free networks to pay their share of connection costs.
The Buffalo Free-Net this year made its first payment, $7,500, for its share of the university's Internet connection. The Free-Net, which has set up computers in the public library for residents without equipment, has also spent $7,500 to $12,500 a year, raised through grants and donations, on operations.
"We can't handle any more users," said James Finamore, another founding member. "We can't afford the phone lines or staff. It's just not the right way to run things."
Mr. Grundner, the free-access pioneer, believes government grants and mandated access requirements will go only so far in preserving the networks, and their survival depends on finding a market niche. Despite the vast resources of the Internet, he says, local networks can fill an important role: providing a connection to what is most relevant to people's lives, their communities.
"Community computing is about trying to keep people at home," Mr. Grundner said. "People have to realize that just dumping people onto the Internet isn't going to work."

HEADLINE: Outlook Improves for Industry in New York

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
When he moved his Brooklyn knitwear company to New Jersey eight years ago, Zeev Volchik joined a decadeslong exodus of industrial concerns from New York City. Like so many New York manufacturers before and after him, Mr. Volchik was convinced that he would save hundreds of thousands of dollars by locating elsewhere and avoiding all the troubles of doing business in the city.
But two years ago, Mr. Volchik, an immigrant from Israel, moved his company back to Brooklyn. Why? Even though he had been just a few miles away in Perth Amboy, N.J., Mr. Volchik found that his company, Sarig Fashions, was losing touch with the tight network of garment makers, suppliers and customers in Queens and Brooklyn that helped him survive. 
 Parts to repair his complex computer-driven knitting machines took days to arrive rather than hours. Sweater designers in Manhattan found the trek more burdensome and placed orders elsewhere. Special types of yarn were harder to come by.
"New York is the center of the industry," Mr. Volchik said one day not long ago as he surveyed his crowded, 40,000-square-foot loft employing more than 60 people in Sunset Park. "I couldn't afford to cut myself off from where the action is."
The return of Sarig Fashions highlights an unexpected turn of fortune for New York City's long-beleaguered industrial concerns: , the retreat of manufacturing jobs has recently come to a halt, according to new figures from the New York State Department of Labor. For smaller companies, particularly in Brooklyn and Queens, a modest expansion even appears to be under way.
Moreover, a yearlong study of manufacturing in New York, released at a seminar yesterday at New York University, suggests the recent flickers of life may be something more than a temporary aberration. And with a change in approach by city government, the outlook for industry, with its opportunities for blue-collar workers to gain decent jobs and higher incomes, could substantially improve.
"The future of manufacturing need not be a continuation of the recent past," says the new research report, Made in New York: The Future of Manufacturing in New York City, financed by the State Urban Development Corporation and the Sloan Foundation.
But a cautionary note was raised by the author of the study, Mitchell L. Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at N.Y.U. "Unless public policies are formulated that make New York City a more conducive environment for manufacturing activity," he said, "the rebirth of manufacturing in New York City will be limited."
The report identifies several underlying reasons why manufacturing could once again gain ground in New York. These three were found to be particularly important:
*An underlying shift in many industries away from large-scale mass-production centers makes it far easier for specialized manufacturers that operate in smaller spaces to succeed.
*Similarly, a drive to respond quickly to changes in consumer taste gives an advantage to the city's trend-oriented and services-related industries like fashion, furniture and food.
*Equally important is the collapse of New York's runaway real-estate boom at the end of the 1980's. "The decline in the residential and commercial real-estate market has limited the conversion of old industrial buildings and created an opportunity for manufacturers to thrive in Manhattan and in other boroughs," the report notes.
 
Rising Rent a Problem
 A prime example of a company that has taken advantage of its niche in New York City is the Lowel-Light Manufacturing Company, which dominates the market for lighting equipment used on location by television stations, independent film makers and still photographers.
Started 35 years ago by a former cinematographer who was frustrated by the lack of equipment designed for outdoor locations, Lowel-Light now sells its lightweight, portable lighting systems across the country and around the world. Although not deeply involved with major film studios, the company has long worked closely with the many photographers, television networks, advertisers and video specialists based in New York.
Once located at West 54th Street and Ninth Avenue, the company was driven out of Manhattan six years ago by rising rent. Determined to stay close to home, the owners found cheaper space in the Brooklyn Army Terminal, a city-run industrial complex in Sunset Park.
"We're noted for our design and innovation," said Marvin Seligman, chief executive officer of the company. "Because we listen so closely to our customers using our equipment, we're in a position to develop new products quickly that help us stay ahead of the competition."
Another successful company, J. Manheimer Inc., was also pushed out of Manhattan because of high costs. Its owners, all members of the same extended family, wanted to keep working nearby their residences in Manhattan and Long Island. So they relocated to Long Island City, Queens, home to the largest concentration of industrial companies in New York.
"We don't have to be here," said Arnold L. Manheimer, executive vice president of the company. "But we have very high value products, which makes it worthwhile to continue doing business in the city."
J. Manheimer has other important reasons for remaining in New York. The concern, which started as a spice importer in 1860, is at the nexus of the food and fashion businesses, two of the largest industries in the area. It sells more than $50 million worth of flavors, fragrances and oils to food processors, as well as makers of shampoos, beauty products, perfume and the like.
To be sure, manufacturing will never again be the major force it once was in the city's economy. Thirty years ago, almost 900,000 people worked in manufacturing; today fewer than 300,000 do.
Much of that collapse was unavoidable. Industry abandoned congested cities across the Northeast in a huge migration after World War II to large, more efficient single-floor factories in outlying areas.
But government planners and policy makers, convinced that manufacturing had little future in New York, also contributed to the decline. Redevelopment projects dislocated hundreds of manufacturing companies to make way for office towers, hospitals and large public works projects like Lincoln Center and the Brooklyn Civic Center. Tighter regulations, higher taxes and frequent fines forced many companies out of business and drove others to seek a more welcoming climate elsewhere.
At the root of New York's industrial decline "is an elitist industrial ideology embraced by an enduring political coalition," said David Friedman, a former New Yorker who directs the New Economy Project in Los Angeles, which is examining changes in the economy of southern California.
"As early as the mid-60's, New York leaders were indifferent to what they saw as 'crummy' jobs in such then-flourishing sectors as garments, metalworking and sophisticated electronics," he continued. "Instead, they wanted to build a 'post-industrial' society centered on high-tech, financial services and tourism, coupled with aggressive welfare relief."
Reversing that industrial decline will not be easy, the report by the Urban Research Center concluded. Small manufacturers, dispersed throughout the city, are not well-organized and have little clout in New York's prominent civic and business organizations. To take advantage of New York's potential new appeal to smaller, light-manufacturing companies, public officials must end years of, at best, indifference or, at worst, active hostility to gritty blue-collar industries, the report argues.
The recent signs of life among manufacturers have little to do with political changes at City Hall. Rather, it is a shift in the underlying conditions that opens a window of opportunity for industry.
To improve the outlook for manufacturing, the study recommends that outmoded zoning laws against mixed land use should be eliminated but that development of large retail stores and waterfront housing should be carefully managed to avoid disrupting viable manufacturing concerns. Municipal buying practices should encourage purchases from local manufacturers. High school vocational education and technical training at community colleges should be strengthened.
One of the biggest complaints of local companies, the report found, were costly parking fines often running into thousands of dollars a month. "The city should adopt a policy that allows vans to be treated with the same deference given to limousines parked in front of Barney's and in Rockefeller Center," it said.
"Despite all the problems that manufacturing firms encounter here, this city still has an enormous concentration of manufacturing activity," Professor Moss said. "It's time we stopped treating manufacturing as a lost cause."

HEADLINE: Cuomo Appeals to Union Leaders for Help in Campaign

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Seeking to revitalize the liberal-labor coalition that helped start his political career 12 years ago, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo implored state union leaders today to give him the foot soldiers and the money he needs to win perhaps his toughest campaign.
In a fiery speech to leaders of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O., Mr. Cuomo cast the race in grand historical themes, calling it a battle for the "heart and soul" of America and warning that a Republican victory would be a powerful blow to union workers not just in New York State but nationwide. 
 "If you understand that we stand for the same things, and you care for the things you stand for, then make this your personal crusade, your personal mission," Mr. Cuomo told 480 union leaders. "Let the word go out that when we win, you win; that when Cuomo and Lundine are returned to office, the union movement is vindicated, and so is the great history of the State of New York."
Although Mr. Cuomo left the hall with a standing ovation and an endorsement from the 2.5 million-member A.F.L.-C.I.O., there are signs that his labor support is not as ardent as it was in 1982, when unions provided the backbone for his upset victory over Edward I. Koch in the Democratic gubernatorial primary.
 
Displeasing Unions
 The state's largest public employee union, the Civil Service Employees Association, has voted to remain neutral in the 1994 race, making it the first time in Mr. Cuomo's four gubernatorial races that he has not had the support of the 250,000-member union and its sophisticated statewide political network.
The state's second- and third-largest public employee unions are expected to follow the lead of the civil service group. And some smaller but still influential unions, including the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, are also mulling the possibility of not endorsing Mr. Cuomo.
Moreover, Mr. Cuomo has done plenty to displease union members, from laying off unionized state employees to opposing labor-sponsored bills. Though he can expect support from most union leaders, there are questions about whether their fervor will trickle down to the rank-and-file members.
Asked whether union enthusiasm for the Governor is as great today as it was in 1982, the president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O., Edward J. Cleary, said: "No. He's the guy who's built up all the negatives."
But loyalty to Mr. Cuomo runs deep among union workers, Mr. Cleary said, because the Governor's overall record is considered sterling, and many workers vividly remember his support of striking workers at Eastern Airlines and The Daily News.
 
Unions' Influence
 "How many politicians get up in front of television cameras and praise the importance of the labor movement?" Mr. Cleary asked. "He does it constantly."
After 1982, Mr. Cuomo had two races where labor support was less significant because he had only tepid Republican opposition.
But this year, he is sagging in the polls and most likely to face, in either Richard M. Rosenbaum or George E. Pataki, a well-financed Republican challenger. With the influence of political parties waning, large unions will provide the workers, computers, telephone banks and literature for a statewide get-out-the-vote operation that, in a close race, could be pivotal.
For that reason, several analysts said the defection of the civil service group hurts the Governor. "C.S.E.A. matters," said Norman Adler, a political consultant and former union official who helped run Mr. Cuomo's 1982 campaign. "In 1982, they were the Cuomo campaign north of Rockland. The loss of C.S.E.A. is the loss of not inconsiderable ground forces. And that's hard to replace."
Mr. Cuomo will still receive strong support from New York City's municipal unions such as District Council 37 and Local 1199, the health and hospital workers union, both highly effective in field campaigns. His aides also said that the defection of the Civil Service Employees Association could help Mr. Cuomo among more conservative voters by demonstrating that he made tough decisions to balance the state budget.
 
Lingering Bitterness
 Danny F. Donohue, the Civil Service Employees Association's president, said the union decided against supporting Mr. Cuomo because of lingering bitterness over past contract fights, layoffs and the Governor's use of a state pension fund to close budget gaps. He said Mr. Cuomo's decision this year to support tax cuts for businesses while opposing an inflation-linked pension increase for retired government workers only worsened the relationship.
"It's hard to look at the Governor and say, 'This is the man we spilled blood for in 1982,' and then not endorse him," Mr. Donohue said. "But back then, you had a sense there was a new leadership. I think people have a question about where we are going now."
But other union leaders chastised Mr. Donohue as being shortsighted, saying that a Republican governor would be disastrous for labor. They point to New York City, New Jersey, Massachusetts and California as examples of how Republican administrations have cut budgets and laid off or threatened the jobs of thousands of unionized workers.
"It was a big mistake on the part of the state unions," said Dennis Rivera, president of Local 1199. "The 30 percent tax cuts that the Republican challengers are advancing, will that bring more money for state workers?"
In a rousing introduction for Mr. Cuomo, Mr. Cleary called the choice between the incumbent and his challengers "one of night and day, of inside the family and outside the family.
"We made the difference for him in 1982; we must make the difference in 1994," Mr. Cleary said. "He is in the toughest fight of his career. Above all, we must not defeat ourselves by lack of enthusiasm, by lukewarm support for the battle."

HEADLINE: July Vehicle Sales Fell a Bit as Dealers Ran Low on Cars

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 3

 BODY:
Car and truck sales fell slightly in July as dealers' inventories ran low with assembly plants idled for model change-overs, the leading auto makers said today.
Detroit's Big Three and the three other leading auto makers in the United States sold a total of 1,197,236 cars and light trucks during the month, off a tenth of 1 percent from a year earlier. 
 Vehicles sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 13.7 million -- the industry's worst showing in more than a year, and down from 14.6 million in June after peaking at 15.8 million in March. In July 1993, the annual rate was 13.75 million.
 
A Lack of Supply
"I think the weak sales in July -- and they were weak, there's no getting away from that -- were due mainly to lack of supply rather than lack of demand," said David Healy, the automotive analyst with S. G. Warburg & Company.
"The companies that had plenty of inventory out in the field sold cars, and the companies that didn't have inventory had weak sales," Mr. Healy added.
Domestic cars were hit particularly hard in July, with an annual selling rate of 6.4 million, down from 6.7 million a year earlier. Domestically built light trucks, however, sold at a 5.4 million annual rate, up from 4.9 million a year ago.
The General Motors Corporation was hit particularly hard, with sales of domestic and imported cars off 8.7 percent and light-truck sales down 4.6 percent.
G.M. attributed its drop to an agonizingly slow start of production for its 1995 Chevrolet Lumina and Monte Carlo cars at a plant in Oshawa, Ontario, as well as to the factory change-over for its new Chevrolet Cavalier and Pontiac Sunfire subcompacts, which are due out this fall.
But G.M. said it thought it could halt the slide. "Our share is going to depend on how fast we can get these plants on line," William E. Hoglund, an executive vice president at G.M., said in an interview. "Our Chevy dealers are hurting for inventory."
 
Chrysler Gains 5.2%
Sales for the Chrysler Corporation and the Ford Motor Company were also hampered by idle factories.
Chrysler's overall sales rose 5.2 percent, to 167,884 units, with domestic and imported cars down 8.3 percent while domestic light trucks, including mini-vans, rose 13.8 percent.
Ford's sales rose 3.7 percent to 308,767 units. Ford's domestic and imported car sales rose just 1 percent, while its domestic light-truck sales jumped 6.5 percent to set a 10th consecutive monthly record.
Analysts said sales would likely improve in the fall as the Big Three and other auto makers increased production, but some were more cautious about tighter credit conditions.
"Unfortunately, when industry supply conditions improve, the economy itself may be weaker," said Tom Webb, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association. "With our sister industry, housing, having already left the dance floor, the party may be over for us, too."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Moderate Gains Posted By Treasury Securities

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices rose moderately yesterday, as several reports provided few surprises on economic growth.
The Treasury's 30-year bond rose 6/32 , to 8617/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 7.38 percent, from 7.40 percent on Tuesday. 
 "Basically, the numbers we saw today were mixed and along the same lines of what we've seen over the past few months -- numbers that show the economy growing at a healthy pace but slower than the pace set in the fourth quarter of last year and the first quarter of this year, and about the same as the second quarter," said Greg Jones, an economist for MMS International, a market research and analysis firm.
 
Focus on Employment Report
 As such, analysts said, the bond market will be focusing more closely on tomorrow's Government report on July employment for new indications of the economy's direction and hints of inflationary pressures.
"Of all the data put out today, the real contributor to the bond market's gains was the monthly auto sales by the Big Three auto makers, which showed the slowest sales pace since September," Mr. Jones said. "Auto sales were the key, since they were the only piece of new information."
Over all, sales of new cars and light trucks slipped one-tenth of 1 percent in July from a year earlier.
Meanwhile, the Government reported yesterday that its index of leading economic indicators rose by two-tenths of a percent in June and that factory orders rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in the month. Both were close to economists' expectations.
In addition, the Federal Reserve said in its latest survey of business activity, known as the beige book, that there were scattered signs of a slowdown but also possible indications of rising prices.
 
Beige Book Not Favorable
 Mr. Jones said the beige book was not that favorable for the bond market. "It mentioned that retail activity had picked up recently and that a tight labor market has spurred faster wage growth," he said. "While the report says business activity is expanding solidly, there are some signs of slowing."
Yesterday afternoon, the Treasury announced the breakdown of its $40 billion quarterly refunding's for next week. Analysts said the refunding plans were slightly smaller than the expected $40.25 billion.
The Treasury will auction $17 billion of new three-year notes on Tuesday and $12 billion of 10-year notes on Wednesday.
On next Thursday, it will be auctioning $11 billion of 30 1/4-year bonds, instead of bonds of the usual 30-year maturity.
Economists like John Ryding of Bear, Stearns & Company noted yesterday that an odd-dated maturity bond helped out the market for zero-coupon bonds. Unless the Treasury sells odd-dated bonds, securities firms won't be able to meet demand for zeros with a May or November maturity date, the months dropped from the quarter financing schedule last year.
A zero-coupon bond is created by breaking a bond into two parts -- one with interest payments, the other with principal payments -- that are sold separately.
Also on next Thursday, the Treasury will be selling $7 billion in 38-day cash management bills.
In when-issued trading ahead of next week's auctions, the three-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.31 percent; the 10-year note at a price to yield 7.07 percent, and the 30 1/4-year bond at a price to yield 7.28 percent.

HEADLINE: U.S Intends to Raise Science and Technology Spending, Gore Says

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration announced its intention today to increase the nation's overall spending on science and technology research to a level equivalent to those of Japan and Germany.
At a news briefing, Vice President Al Gore presented a report, "Science in the National Interest," that outlines the Administration's commitment to expanding its support and making science and technology "a top priority" in future budgets. 
 Dr. John H. Gibbons, assistant to the President for science and technology, said the United States Government and industry together were spending 2.6 percent of the gross domestic product on nonmilitary science, and he said the goal was 3 percent, roughly the amount spent in Germany and Japan. But, he said, "we haven't translated that figure into specific programs for the future."
 
Shifting the Balance
 Dr. Gibbons said today's report was more a way of making a commitment to protect science budgets in a period of budget cutting. All agencies must think of the future "only in terms of present dollars, not of increases," he said, adding, "If there is to be more money, it must come from other programs or from increased productivity."
Federal spending on research has increased a few percent a year in recent years, he said, "which is pretty good in times of a tight budget."
Dr. M. R. C. Greenwood, associate director for science at the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy, said that while no figures had yet been prepared "we do have a plan to increase support."
"Each agency will be asked to come up with proposals," Dr. Greenwood said.
The shift to civilian science from military science promised by President Clinton in the 1992 election campaign has already begun, she said. In 1992, 60 percent of research money went to the military and 40 percent to civilian work, and after the President's first budget, she said, "it's now more like 55 to 45 percent."
If the shift between those two budgets continues, about one-third of the goal of reaching a total national expenditure of 3 percent of domestic product will be reached.
The White House also announced the list of members of a new Committee of Advisers on Science.
The new members are:
John A. Young, Hewlett-Packard Company.
Norman R. Augustine, Martin Marietta Corporation.
Francisco J. Ayala, University of California at Irvine.
Murray Gell-Mann, California Institute of Technology.
David A. Hamburg, Carnegie Corporation of New York.
John P. Holdren, University of California at Berkeley.
Diana McArthur, Dynamac Corporation.
Shirley M. Malcom, American Association for the Advancement of Science.
Mario J. Molina, Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Peter H. Raven, Washington University in St. Louis.
Sally K. Ride, University of California at San Diego.
Judith Rodin, University of Pennsylvania.
Charles A. Sanders, Glaxo Corporation.
Phillip A. Sharp, M.I.T.
David E. Shaw, Shaw & Company.
Charles M. Vest, M.I.T.
Virginia V. Weldon, Monsanto Company.
Lilian Shiao-yen Wu, I.B.M.

HEADLINE: Economic Data Up; Outlook Murky

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
A host of fresh economic reports was released by the Government yesterday, but private analysts said the reports shed little additional light on whether the pace of economic growth was moderating.
The Commerce Department said its index of leading economic indicators, its main forecasting gauge, rose by two-tenths of a percent in June, following a revised one-tenth of a percent increase in May. 
 Meanwhile, a separate Commerce Department report showed orders to the nation's factories posted a solid eight-tenths of a percent increase in June, the fourth straight monthly gain.
Both reports were in line with economists' expectations.
 
Fed Sees Signs of Slowing
 And in a report that provides a somewhat fresher snapshot of economic conditions, the Federal Reserve Board said in its latest survey of business activity that there were scattered signs of a slowdown but also possible indications of rising prices. The survey, known as the beige book and based on anecdotal reports from the 12 regional Federal Reserve banks, covers a period that ended in mid-July.
"If there was any surprise," in the reports, said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities Inc., "it was in the Fed's beige book, where there was a little bit of emphasis on potential price pressures. Those pressures have yet to be borne out by upward movement in either producer or consumer prices."
In its report on manufacturing orders, the Government said the rise of eight-tenths of 1 percent in June matched the previous month's increase. The gain in orders covered nearly all categories, except construction-related material and home furnishings.
 
Housing Declines Reported
 A drop in orders from those types of businesses is consistent with recently reported declines in housing. The rise in interest rates engineered by the Fed over the last six months is beginning to retard building activity.
"Growth is clearly slowing in housing and construction," Mr. Fine said, "and that partly explains the slowdown we are seeing now."
Last week, the Government reported that the economy expanded at a 3.7 percent rate in the second quarter, a more moderate pace than many private economists had expected.
Even though it is intended to predict turns in the economy by six to nine months, the index of leading indicators is widely disliked by most private analysts, who contend that its components are badly outdated.
"The index shows the economy is growing, but since some of the components are out of whack with what the economy is about today, I am not sure how much it means," said Joseph Carson, chief economist at Dean Witter, Discover Inc.
 
5 Index Components Rise
 Five of the 11 components of the index of leading indicators advanced, led by higher prices for raw materials and fewer weekly initial claims for unemployment insurance. Also, there were more unfilled orders for durable goods, more business orders for plant and equipment and higher stock prices.
On the negative side were a smaller money supply, fewer building permits, a shorter average workweek, faster business delivery times that usually are a sign of decreasing orders, a lower index of consumer expectations and fewer factory orders for consumer goods.
On balance, yesterday's reports are unlikely to help members of the Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee at its next meeting on Aug. 16, Mr. Carson said.
The meeting will get widespread attention because many analysts and participants in financial markets expect the committee to vote to raise interest rates in an effort to moderate the economy's growth path further.
But Mr. Carson said he was not so sure that the Fed was on the verge of increasing interest rates, partly because recent statements from Fed governors suggest the central bank is pleased with what is unfolding.
Mr. Carson noted that Alan Blinder, the Fed's newly installed vice chairman, said in an interview in USA Today yesterday that the economy was "not too hot, not too cold, but just right."
"Trying to predict the Fed right now is difficult," he said. "I think it will take a few months of additional data before they move."

HEADLINE: Stocks Have Aimless Day; Dow Off 3.56

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday for a second consecutive session, as traders awaited the release of important economic information this week and next. With investors focusing on individual stocks, the overall market was generally directionless.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which was down more than 9 points near 4 P.M., benefited from a last-minute buying surge of blue chips and regained ground to close at 3,792.66, off 3.56 points. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 1.11 points, to 723.69. 
 In contrast, the Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 0.90 point to close at 461.46. And advances topped declines on the New York Stock Exchange by 1,100 to 1,004. Volume was 282.4 million shares, lower than the 295.6 million shares that changed hands on Tuesday but just about the average for the year.
"The market traded in a very narrow range," said Bernard Spilko, senior vice president of Bank Julius Baer. "We're going to continue in that range until additional economic data is released, which will either fuel or quell the speculation as to the timing of the Fed's next move."
The Federal Reserve's policy-making panel is scheduled to meet on Aug. 16, and many analysts expect it to raise its target for the overnight bank lending rate -- Fed funds -- for a fifth time this year. The Fed may have received the impetus for such an increase yesterday when the index of leading indicators rose more than had been expected and the beige book, based on reports from district banks around the country, said that business activity in July expanded at a solid pace.
 
Drug Stocks Still Strong
 Drug issues were among the strongest on the list, just as they were Tuesday, when American Home Products made a hostile $95-a-share bid for American Cyanamid. A huge price gain in American Cyanamid came in after-hours trading on Tuesday, so yesterday -- after a delay at the opening -- it sold off slightly to 90 3/4, down 2 1/4. When the stock was halted for trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday, the price stood at 63 3/4.
However, many other drug companies moved upward in reaction to this hostile bid. Upjohn rose 7/8, to 32 7/8; Warner-Lambert advanced 3 3/4, to 72 1/4, and Johnson & Johnson increased 7/8, to 48.
The three major United States airline companies all closed lower by the end of the day. UAL, parent of United Airlines, fell 1 1/8, to 99 7/8; AMR, parent of American Airlines, dropped 1/8, to 58, and Delta Air Lines declined 3/8, to48 3/4.
Following yesterday's settlement by Dow Corning of 18 suits over silicone breast-implants, the stock price of one of its owners advanced and the other declined. Dow Chemical rose 1 3/8, to 71 1/8, while Corning dropped 3/8, to 31.
In another special situation, Thermo Electron, jumped 1 1/4, to 40 3/4. The company is a member of the Lockheed team that was selected by the Department of Energy yesterday to manage and operate the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chrysler Is Asking for Directions on Quality

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: TRAVERSE CITY, Mich., Aug. 3

 BODY:
Grappling with both the public's perceptions and the reality of its quality headaches, the Chrysler Corporation has turned to an outside consultant to try to improve its scores on an independent automobile quality survey.
Using the outside company, the Process Development Corporation in Taylor, Mich., is one of several extraordinary efforts by Chrysler to improve the quality of its Neon subcompact cars by this fall, when the survey, by the California auto consultant J. D. Power and Associates, is conducted. 
 The annual survey, conducted at the beginning of the model year, is widely used by the auto makers and buying public as a gauge of quality. It measures the number of defects that owners identify in the first 90 days they have a vehicle.
 
Disappointing Scores
 "We're a little disappointed in J. D. Power," Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, said today, referring to Chrysler's scores, which have been below the industry's average. "We're trying to step up and make sure that we really understand what the customers are telling us there."
Some of the complaints about the Neon have included poor fit and finish and a faulty radio.
The company said it hoped the Neon would end up ranking with the highest-quality small car, the Toyota Corolla.
Mr. Eaton emphasized that Chrysler was not trying to improve the quality of its Neons just for the three months during which J. D. Power conducted its surveys. He said Chrysler wanted all its customers "to be absolutely satisfied with our products."
Mr. Eaton made his comments at an annual automotive conference held by the University of Michigan here.
On Tuesday, John E. Fernandez, the chief engineer for the Neon program, said Chrysler was using a "three-prong attack" to prepare for the J. D. Power survey.
 
A Wide Plan of Attack
 In addition to focusing on the plant in Belvidere, Ill., where the Neon is built, Chrysler has called in its top suppliers for the car to discuss the J. D Power measurement system, and it has conducted a similar program with its dealers.
Beginning in July, the outside consultant -- which had done other quality work for Chrysler in the last year -- modified Chrysler's internal quality surveys to produce results similar to those used in the J. D. Power survey, Mr. Fernandez said. In remarks similar to Mr. Eaton's, Mr. Fernandez emphasized that any quality changes Chrysler made would benefit all its customers, not just those who bought Neons during the J. D. Power testing period.
Process Development is also helping other Chrysler vehicles prepare for the J.D. Power survey.
The consultant has performed similar quality work for the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation, said James Pongracz, the owner and chief executive of Process Development.
Mr. Eaton's comments today reflected the tone of the conference, which has been quite sober despite the record quarterly profits announced last month by the three domestic auto makers. For example, Edward Hagenlocker, president of Ford Automotive Operations, warned that the next 10 years would be more difficult for the auto companies than the last 10, during which G.M. and Chrysler endured record losses.
"When the next downturn comes, it's going to be extremely rough," he said. The cyclical nature of the auto industry, he added, is becoming more intense, as regional economies become more closely aligned.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
2 Big Eastern Railroads Said to Discuss Merger

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
Two large Eastern railroads, the Norfolk Southern Corporation and Conrail Inc., are discussing a possible merger, according to people familiar with the companies' plans.
The talks raise anew the possibility that the two railroads would join forces. Norfolk Southern, the fourth-largest railroad in terms of revenue, made its first offer to buy Conrail, currently the fifth-largest railroad, in 1984 for $1.2 billion, and pulled its final offer to buy the railroad for $1.9 billion in 1986 in part because of a six-month impasse in getting approval for its offer from the House of Representatives. 
 The Federal Government, which owned Conrail at the time, eventually sold the railroad in an initial public offering.
 
 
Consolidation Trend
 A merger of the two railroads, with combined revenues of $7.1 billion, would add to a consolidation trend that has reshaped the rail industry since it was deregulated in 1980. To cut costs, many railroads have merged to achieve economies of scale and more efficient operations.
If an agreement is reached, the combined railroad would operate track that stretches from Boston to New Orleans, and from Chicago to Jacksonville, Fla.
Spokesmen for Conrail and Norfolk Southern declined to comment on the talks, which were first reported yesterday in The Journal of Commerce.
Stocks of both railroads surged early yesterday on the news, but after a day of heavy trading, shares of Conrail ended $2.25 higher at $56.50, while Norfolk Southern's stock fell 12.5 cents a share, to $63.625.
 
 
'Makes Sense'
 Scott Flower, a transportation analyst at Kidder, Peabody, said that if an agreement was reached, it would likely be a stock swap. As the on-again, off-again courtship of these railroads suggests, a merger "makes sense for all sorts of reasons," Mr. Flower added.
Besides their extended geographic reach, both railroads are large carriers of coal and have big interests in "intermodalism," a rapidly growing part of the industry in which railroads carry truck trailers over long distances to destinations where they are then delivered by local drivers.
Two large railroad mergers were announced in recent weeks. In late June, Burlington Northern Inc. and the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation announced a plan to merge in a stock swap valued at $2.7 billion. And two weeks ago, Kansas City Southern Industries said it was selling its railroad business to the Illinois Central Corporation in a stock swap worth about $1.6 billion.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls as Dealers Await Reaction to U.S. Jobs Report

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against other leading currencies yesterday as traders grew edgy ahead of tomorrow's report on July employment in the United States.
A strong employment report could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise short-term rates, giving the dollar a boost. But if the report also raises fears of inflation, it could depress the dollar. 
 "It's a hard call," said Melissa Fairfield, an analyst with Shawmut Bank said.
Traders noted that the dollar plunged after the last three interest rate increases from the Fed because prices of fixed-income securities were hurt, setting off a flight of capital out of the United States.
Ms. Fairfield said it was unclear whether investors would "buy dollars on a strong number" for July employment, since this had proved to be a bad bet in the past.
"People may want to see how the dollar reacts rather than try to get ahead of the market because it is so difficult to read," she added.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 100.31 Japanese yen, down from 100.36 yen on Tuesday. The dollar slipped to 1.5758 German marks from 1.5835 marks.
A survey shows economists anticipate that 204,000 nonfarm jobs were added to payrolls in July, down from 379,000 in June. Job creation averaged 287,000 a month in the first six months of the year.
The Fed's latest survey of business conditions around the country, known as the beige book, showed solid business expansion with some pockets of weakness and higher commodity prices. An improving labor market resulted in some wage increases.
Anthony J. Vignola, chief economist of Kidder, Peabody & Company, said the report meant that "we have not ended the Fed tightening cycle," though the report itself was not a reason for the Fed to raise rates.
"There is no question that the 125- basis-point increase in the funds rate is not enough to reverse the trend of this economic expansion," Mr. Vignola said. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent. So far this year, the Fed has raised short-term lending rates to 4.25 percent from 3 percent.
He predicted that an increase of 300,000 payroll jobs would cause the Fed to increase the Federal funds rate on overnight bank loans by at least a quarter-point when its policy-making group, the Federal Open Market Committee, meets on Aug. 16.
The dollar did not react to two other economic reports released yesterday, which delivered no surprise. The June index of leading indicators rose two-tenths of 1 percent, and June factory orders rose eight-tenths of 1 percent.
In other currency trading in New York yesterday, the British pound edged up to $1.5423, from $1.5352 on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Recalling history, analysts in Tokyo are cool to Japan Tobacco.

BYLINE: By James Sterngold 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
IF there is one thing that stock market experts tend to understand, with their obsession for charts and tables, it is stock market history.
And that may be one reason that analysts here have been decidedly cool to what will be the biggest event to reach the Tokyo Stock Exchange in the last year, the initial public offering of Government-owned Japan Tobacco Inc., one of the world's largest cigarette companies. 
 The Finance Ministry will begin the two-step process of auctioning off J T, as it is known, later this month, and trading is scheduled to start on Oct. 27. That will be a year and a day after trading began in the shares of the last Government-owned company to go public, Japan East Railway.
It is an ill omen: Trading in J R East, as it is called, was so chaotic that it blacked out the stock exchange's computers, while driving down the overall market by 4 percent in three days.
The debacle was worsened because on the first day of trading the share price soared inexplicably, allowing the Government to dump an additional $3.4 billion of shares on the market at inflated prices; afterward the price plunged.
No matter. The Finance Ministry is sticking to its schedule, prompting many here to buckle their seat belts.
By most measures, J T is a company of questionable promise. For decades it held a monopoly on the manufacture and sale of cigarettes in Japan, where more than 60 percent of men smoke.
American trade negotiators opened the market to foreign brands in the 1980's, and since J T's market share has dropped to 82 percent, and the market is shrinking.
Kyoko Matsuyama and Eizo Uchikura, analysts with Goldman, Sachs (Japan), said J T would continue to lose one-half to one percentage point of market share every year. "We basically think this is not a growing company," Ms. Matsuyama said.
One strength in the past was that since the Government controlled the cigarette business, there were virtually no serious studies here of the effects of smoking, and little information was made public. But that may be changing. The first antismoking ad was shown on television recently, and lung cancer recently leaped into first place as the leading killer among cancers in Japan, raising the public's concern.
But the Government still protects J T's profit margins by regulating what retailers can charge for cigarettes; discounting is illegal. "That's why this company should be regarded as a utility," said Takefumi Suzuki, an analyst with Baring Securities. He added that it had used some of its excess cash -- it has some $3 billion on its books -- to try to develop new businesses like pharmaceuticals.
"Frankly, I think that will take 10 years or more to break even," Mr. Suzuki said.
But analysts say something interesting could happen with supply and demand.
The Finance Ministry has said it will sell one-third of J T's two million shares. Ms. Matsuyama and Mr. Uchikura of Goldman, Sachs said that because the company was not expected to post any growth, it was best valued through its assets. The fair market value, they said, is about $8,000 a share.
But they and other analysts said they were expecting an initial price of $10,000 a share, and that it could soar well above that.
The reason is that many big Japanese investors may have to buy the stock, because of pressure from the Finance Ministry and because investors who own huge portfolios that approximate the overall market's makeup cannot avoid holding what will be one of the most heavily capitalized companies on the exchange.
With a limited supply, even modest demand can push the price up and, analysts worry, create a repeat of last year's turmoil on the exchange.
"We could easily have a similar price movement to last year," said Shigeru Aoki, an analyst here with Jardine Fleming Securities. "With the supply so limited, you could have a 50 percent rise at the opening. I'm not sure they've prepared for that."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Why a trade dispute over roses is turning into a perennial.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
ACCORDING to Gertrude Stein, a rose is a rose is a rose. But not according to the Department of Commerce, which is on the prowl for imports that unfairly compete with American Beauties. And while it's easy to make light of the latest charges that Colombian growers are "dumping" millions of dollars worth of flowers in Miami and points north, the Colombians aren't laughing.
Nor should American consumers, suggests Robert Z. Lawrence of Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. For the case illustrates much of what economists think is askew in America's anti-dumping laws. "The whole thing's a travesty," Mr. Lawrence concludes. 
 On five occasions in the last eight years, the Colombians have been accused by domestic growers of selling cut flowers below fair value. And on all five occasions the Commerce Department has exacted only token penalties. Dumping duties have ranged from 1 to 5 percent -- sums too small to undermine Colombia's competitive position. Why, then, are the domestic rose growers trying again?
One possibility, suggests Gary Hufbauer, an economist at the Institute for International Economics, is that harassment by domestic producers is implicitly encouraged by the trade laws. Even dumping accusations with little legal merit are expensive to defend against, he notes, and Government procedures for calculating fair value are so arbitrary that bizarre outcomes are not unknown.
Another is that American flower growers are likely to find a more receptive audience in Washington these days. Previous cases were brought during the tenures of Presidents Reagan and Bush, who were sympathetic to Colombia's efforts to export something besides coffee and cocaine. This time around, Colombia won't be able to count on help from the White House.
For one thing, President Clinton is loath to offend Congress before it blesses the GATT agreement. For another, Colombia is in the diplomatic doghouse these days because it is making noises about concluding a separate peace with the drug cartel.
However dubious, the Colombian rose case does offer an example of how far the American anti-dumping law has strayed from its economic rationale.
To economists, "dumping" means exporting below the price charged in the home market. That can offend in either of two ways: The domestic price may be above cost, implying that the seller is a monopolist gouging the folks back home. Or the export price may be below cost, raising the prospect that the exporter is trying to knock out the competition and then exploit its ill-gotten monopoly power.
But American law doesn't require the Commerce Department to find that the export price is below the home price. All that is necessary to prove dumping is evidence that the foreigners are exporting below their cost of production.
Sounds simple, but it is complicated enough to keep hundreds of lawyers up to date on their BMW payments. Consider the issue of what export price to use to compare with cost. Should it be the average price over a day? A month? A year? Or should it be the price in any single transaction -- the definition favored by plaintiffs, who speak darkly of "rifle dumping" in which foreigners sell, say, 999 tons of steel above cost in order to sneak in one ton below cost.
The domestic industry argues that the Colombians sell roses below average costs during the summer. But so, of course, do domestic growers who make a killing around Valentine's Day and take whatever they can get off-season.
"If dumping assessments based on daily or monthly prices have any logic," Mr. Hufbauer concludes, it is only for goods that can be held as inventories.
Then there is the matter of computing foreigners' costs, a rat's maze of conceptual problems even where companies maintain solid financial data. To finesse the accounting issue with Colombian roses, the Commerce Department could fall back on the traditional definition of dumping. But since there is effectively no home market for Colombian flowers, the department is considering using the price of Colombian roses sold in Europe as its benchmark.
The catch there, however, is that the Colombians sell only token numbers outside the United States. And to avoid being judged by European prices, the Colombians are apparently prepared to end all rose exports to Europe. The result, ironically, would be an increase in exports to the Colombians' real market, the United States.
Could the anti-dumping laws be fixed? "You'll never get a level playing field as long as there is one set of rules for domestic production and one for imports," Mr. Lawrence argues.
The free trade agreement between Australia and New Zealand, he points out, requires each country to treat the other's producers exactly like its own. As a practical matter, that means integrating the anti-dumping laws into antitrust laws prohibiting predatory pricing against competitors, domestic or foreign.
An impossible dream for America and its trading partners? Not for optimists like Mr. Lawrence, who believes Americans will one day figure out that the gain would more than offset the pain.

HEADLINE: Right and Wrong on Trade

 BODY:
This was the week for the Clinton Administration to play tough on trade. It threatened to retaliate unless Japan reversed government procurement policies that discriminate against exports of U.S. telecommunications and medical equipment. And it bludgeoned Canada into agreeing to reduce wheat exports to the U.S. for a year while a commission reviews an ongoing dispute about such exports.
The fighting stance toward Japan is justified, though the Administration threatens to carry it to excess. The decision to shut out Canadian wheat, by contrast, amounts to an assault on U.S. consumers -- the price of Mr. Clinton's promise to bail out Midwestern farmers whose support he desperately needed in Congress to pass the North American Free Trade Agreement. 
 Government purchasers in Japan blatantly discriminate against U.S. equipment manufacturers -- perhaps because Japanese companies bribe local officials. Whatever the cause, the solution is for government procurers to adopt open bidding and contract procedures that would expose underhanded deals. So far, the Japanese have refused to do so -- which justifies the Administration's threats.
Yet even if the Japanese were to concede on procedural issues, the dispute would not end because Mr. Clinton is fixated on getting the Japanese to swallow numerical targets to measure compliance. For example, he wants Japan's Government to increase purchases from U.S. equipment manufacturers by a substantial amount over the next several years. The Japanese are dead set against numerical targets, which they label managed trade that violates free-trade principles.
But their resistance is misplaced; government purchases are not controlled by market forces. What the Japanese probably fear, no doubt correctly, is that if they feed Mr. Clinton's appetite for numerical targets for government purchases, he will extend the idea to areas where it ought not to apply -- to private markets like auto parts. The important point for Mr. Clinton to absorb is that the meager economic gains to be had by winning numerical targets are not worth risking a trade war.
There is considerably less merit to keeping out Canadian wheat. U.S. imports are high because of misguided policies that keep land out of production and subsidize the sale of U.S. wheat production abroad. Canadian wheat fills the void. By keeping Canadian wheat out, Mr. Clinton would drive up consumer prices of commodities like pasta.
The best outcome would be for the Canadian wheat deal to last only the one obligatory year and for Mr. Clinton to impose sanctions on Japan only to win more open procurement procedures. But there is little reason to expect the best. In trade disputes, as well as in its legislation to institute the Uruguay Round international trade agreement, the Administration has been all too willing to buy off powerful domestic manufacturers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: You Call This Scam Health-Care Reform?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A July 25 front-page article describes the millstones burdening Hillary Rodham Clinton as she campaigns across the country for health care reform. We're advised, Don't even think about a single-payer plan or a Canadian-style plan: they are as dead as socialized medicine. 
 This message is not really new. The spineless Washington representatives of teacher groups have dunned us with that message since the medical and health insurance lobbies compromised to give us emergency-care insurance in the late 1950's.
The millions of dollars reaching those lobbies and Government leaders have paid off. Many Americans are persuaded that single-payer plans are just not "politically feasible" for the foreseeable future. The government leaders who have been paid off are quick to tell us that what we want is to retain our choice of doctors. No. What we really want is competent doctors who have to provide good health care for all.
They're quick to insist that what we want is portability of insurance. No. What we really want is health care wherever we are, whenever we need it. Too many insist that we really want extended care. Wrong again. The poor and the middle class will settle for limited care because it is so much more than we now have.
Government spokesmen insist on quibbling over what universal coverage means, but not one of them mentions John, the street person in my neighborhood, who is typical of millions in this country who are unemployed and neglected by the health care system and by every politically feasible reform plan, even though the habits of most such outcasts constitute a clear and present danger to the health of all of us.
We are being asked to settle for more of the same. The Democrats have lost their will. The Republicans have all but declared victory. With the Democrats, they make ready to announce health care reform that will continue the present system.
Yet it's not too late. The Clintons have done the country a great service by introducing health care reform. They want good health care for every American. They made their position clear at the start and then declared their faith in the political system. Maybe it's that faith in the political system that needs re-evaluation.
What's being offered as reform now is nothing but more money in the pocket of insurance representatives, lawyers, doctors and pharmacists. It is the present system with higher rates to pay off the lobby interests.
It's time for the Clintons to repeat the words of their original challenge to the country. Let's make health care available to every American who needs it. Let's put government
controls on health costs and raise taxes to pay for phasing in a single-payer plan.
 
FRANCIS E. DYER
New York, July 25, 1994
 
The writer is a retired teacher.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chase Sets $348 Million Acquisition

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire American Residential Holdings for $348 million, or $28.25 a share, in another sign of contraction within the mortgage banking industry prompted by rising interest rates.
Following the announcement, American Residential shares set a 52-week high in Nasdaq trading at $28, before ending at $27.75, up $2.875. 
 The acquisition of the company, whose wholly owned subsidiary the American Residential Mortgage Corporation originates, sells and services first-home mortgages, would give Chase a total mortgage portfolio of $11.5 billion. Based on figures from the first half of the year, that would make Chase the nation's fourth-largest mortgage lender, a move up from No. 7. The deal also goes a long way toward making good on a pledge by Chase, the nation's fifth-largest banking company, to become one of the country's top three mortgage lenders by 1997.
American Residential, based in La Jolla, Calif., generated $4.4 billion in mortgages in the year's first half and services a $15.4 billion portfolio. Fees are earned by the company for collecting monthly payments and passing them on to investors, as well as handling delinquencies and foreclosures.
The company, which had its start in 1983 as the mortgage banking arm of the Imperial Savings and Loan Association, now defunct, earned $5.9 million, a 3 percent decline, in the quarter ended March 31.
"Strategically, it appears the two companies fit very well," Thomas P. Hanley, a banking analyst from CS First Boston, said.
Most of Chase's mortgage loans have been to affluent customers needing "jumbo" loans of $203,000 or more. Most of American Residential's clients required smaller loans.
"So it's not just volume, it's a different type of customer," Mr. Hanley said, giving the bank an opportunity to cross-sell its services.
Mortgage bankers enjoyed a boom in refinancing business in 1992 and 1993 as homeowners rushed to lock in low interest rates. That cycle peaked in October as 30-year rates on fixed mortgages then began to rise. The number of new loans written this year is expected to fall as much as 40 percent.
"It's going to be a punishing year," John M. Robbins, the chairman and chief executive of American Residential, said. As mortgage banking companies are forced to lay off employees and shrink their operations, lower earnings and depressed stock prices will follow, he said.
With that in mind, Mr. Robbins said a decision was made this spring to sell the company at a time when banking companies are scrambling to improve their market share for mortgages and bolster noninterest fee income. Last month, for example, the Chemical Banking Corporation paid $330 million for the Margaretten Financial Corporation.
"Virtually all the public mortgage companies are in play," said Guy D. Cecala, editor and publisher of Inside Mortgage Finance, a weekly trade publication. "We're still in the early stages of the trend."
Capturing a mortgage banker with a branch system also serves as a toehold for a bank seeking to expand interstate banking operations, said Gareth Plank, an analyst for Mabon Securities in San Francisco.

HEADLINE: SERBIA ISOLATING ALLIES IN BOSNIA

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The President of Serbia announced today that most political and economic links with Serbian nationalist rebels in Bosnia were being severed because the Bosnian Serbs had rejected an international plan for ending the war here.
In a statement this morning, the Government of Yugoslavia, the rump state made up of Serbia and Montenegro and dominated by Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, announced that it would bar Bosnian Serb leaders from entering Serbia and ban all trade with Serb-controlled parts of Bosnia except for shipments of food and medicine. [Excerpts, page A9.] 
 If enforced, the moves would isolate the Bosnian Serbs' self-declared state and most of the territories in Croatia that were seized by rebel Serbs there in 1991. The cutoff could also produce a feud between Serbs loyal to Mr. Milosevic and confirmed nationalists who accuse him of selling out their dream of a Greater Serbia combining all territories inhabited by Serbs.
Similar threats have been made before, and in May 1993 the Belgrade Government even claimed that it had cut off arms and fuel shipments to the Bosnian Serbs. But that embargo was soon seen to be a charade by Serbia in an effort to weaken support for international economic sanctions, which have damaged Serbia's economy.
Given Serbia's record, skepticism about the sincerity of Mr. Milosevic's remarks was widespread among Bosnian Government officials and representatives of the five foreign powers that drew up the latest peace plan. Some also questioned whether Mr. Milosevic has the political strength to cut off the Bosnian Serbs.
But Western diplomats in Belgrade said tonight that they had received reports that the Serbian authorities had stopped civilian traffic through some of the dozens of border crossings to Bosnia. Journalists reported seeing a stepped-up Serbian police presence on the border.
"It looks as though they have closed the borders pretty tightly," said a Western diplomat in Belgrade.
In his remarks today, the Serbian President was scathing in his condemnation of the Bosnian Serb leaders, describing them as "war profiteers" and "insane with political ambitions and greed."
"Their decision to reject peace cannot be in the interest of the people by any criteria of truth and justice," he said. "It can only be in the interest of war profiteers and in the interest of those people whose conscience is not clear, who are afraid of peace."
 
Muslims Accept Peace Plan
 The peace plan, which has already been accepted by the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government, was drawn up by the United States, Russia, France, Germany and Britain. They warned Belgrade that it would face punitive measures, including tightened economic sanctions as a first step, if the rebel Serbs in Bosnia turned down the proposal. The plan would force them to recognize Bosnia and Herzegovina's sovereignty and give up control of a third of the 70 percent of Bosnia's territory they have seized.
The Belgrade Government has been a major military backer of the Bosnian Serb rebels since before they started the war here in April 1992. In an unusual acknowledgement, Mr. Milosevic said today that the Bosnian Serb state "would not survive" without aid from Serbia.
The Yugoslav Army's top generals, who sent troops and war materiel to the Bosnian Serbs, expressed grave misgivings about the peace plan last month. The head of Yugoslavia's customs office, a close associate of Mr. Milosevic, has been linked with supplying arms to rebel Serbs in Croatia and Bosnia.
 
Sincerity Questioned
 "The fear now is that those quarters who want to believe that Milosevic is sincere will have plenty of ammunition to say he is a peacemaker and let's nominate him for the Nobel Prize and lift the sanctions," another Western diplomat said. "There are plenty of people who want to believe this. But we have no evidence whatsoever to believe that it is true.
"Let Milosevic give diplomatic recognition to Bosnia and Herzegovina. Let him agree to put international monitors on the border crossings leading into Bosnia and Herzegovina from Serbia."
The United Nations Security Council imposed the economic sanctions against Yugoslavia in May 1992 in retaliation for the military and economic support for the rebel Serbs.
Embargo violations, especially by Russia, Macedonia and Greece, have rendered the trade sanctions a dead letter. But an international freeze on some of Serbia's assets abroad, isolation from the world banking sector and the shutdown of Belgrade's airport have hamstrung much of the country's most important industries.
Vitaly I. Churkin, Russia's special envoy to the Bosnian peace talks, said Serbia might be able to avoid tougher sanctions by cutting the Bosnian Serbs' umbilical cord.
 
Referendum Criticized
 Mr. Milosevic's statement said, referring to the Bosnian Serbs, "They are rejecting peace at the moment that their Serbian Republic has been recognized over half of Bosnia and Herzegovina's territory, and when their acceptance of peace would bring about the lifting of sanctions against those without whom they cannot exist."
"They have called a referendum to make the citizenry responsible for a state policy about which they have not been consulted and which the citizens did not pursue," the statement said, blasting a decision Wednesday night by the Bosnian Serbs' "parliament" to hold a referendum on the peace plan on Aug. 27 and 28.
Mr. Milosevic rose to power by whipping up Serbian nationalist passions and made the "defense of endangered Serbs outside Serbia" the hallmark of his platform since 1988.
In recent weeks, however, he has tried to strengthen his grip on political power by singling out scapegoats in Serbian political life as well as its military and police to take responsibility for the country's complicity in the 1991 war in Croatia and the Bosnian war, which began in April 1992.
In a letter to Serbian leaders across the border, the Bosnian Serbs' parliament wrote that it was "insulted" by Mr. Milosevic's threats to sever ties. "For the first time in 500 years, Serbs west of the Drina River are free," the letter says. "We defended ourselves and you."
 
'Serbian National Idea' Cited
 "By accepting this plan, we would be accepting the sovereignty of Bosnia and Herzegovina," the letter says of the peace plan. "This would be an end of the peace of mind of the Serbs and the Serbian national idea."
Rebel Serb leaders in Bosnia and the Serbs' "parliament" in Croatia called again today for the unification of their lands with Serbia.
After Wednesday night's meeting, the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, said the weeks before the referendum would allow the five countries who drew up the peace plan to make adjustments, including territorial concessions to the Serbs. Dr. Karadzic also warned Serbs in Bosnia that he might be forced to declare a state of war and impose rationing.
Diplomats from the five drafting countries have denounced the referendum as a waste of time.

A woman ran past a French armored car in the capital yesterday as a soldier prepared to return fire. (Agence France-Presse)
