HEADLINE: Pollster Advises Democrats: Don't Be Too Close to Clinton

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Acknowledging that the Democrats face a grim political environment this fall, President Clinton's pollster is advising that those seeking re-election should emphasize their own records rather than link themselves too closely to Mr. Clinton or even their own party. He also recommends that they make crime the central issue, not health care or the economy.
While the pollster, Stanley Greenberg, stopped short of saying that candidates should distance themselves from the President, his recommendation amounted to a tacit recognition that Mr. Clinton's weaknesses could damage Democrats' prospects in November. It is also at odds with comments by officials like David Wilhelm, the Democratic chairman, who has publicly urged Democrats in Congress to run proudly with their President. 
 "Democrats make gains in this race running on their accomplishments and their agenda to help people at home," Mr. Greenberg wrote in a memorandum titled "Strategic Guide to the 1994 Election."
"There is no reason to highlight these as Clinton or Democratic proposals. Voters want to know that you are fighting to get things done for them, not that you are advancing some national agenda."
The document, obtained from a Democratic organizer, was distributed a month ago to a few Democratic leaders and officials at the White House. Though the memorandum said the Democrats faced "a tough year," it is not entirely downbeat. In fact, it is intended as a blueprint for how Democrats can blunt significant losses in November.
The memorandum is based on extensive interviews and focus groups with voters and candidates in four swing House districts: in a Rocky Mountain state, on the West Coast, in the Deep South and in the Midwest. All are districts where the incumbent Democrat faces "a genuine battle for re-election," it says.
The party that wins the White House almost always suffers serious losses in the next midterm election. The last time the party in power picked up House and Senate seats in the midterm election was in 1934, during the first term of Franklin D. Roosevelt, a Democrat. This year, Democrats are less fearful of losing outright control of the House or Senate than of suffering such large losses that it would be difficult to build winning margins for Administration proposals in the next two years.
"The mood of the election up to this point has energized Republicans and somewhat demoralized Democrats," said Mr. Greenberg, who did not make specific predictions about possible losses. He added, "Obviously, the White House must do more to mobilize Democrats in support of candidates this year."
The notion that incumbents should separate themselves from a President of their own party is nothing new: Some Republican officials gave such advice in 1990, after President Bush agreed to a deal to raise taxes. And in June, Donald Sweitzer, political director for the Democratic Party, told The Washington Times, "There are clearly some areas of the country where it is not going to benefit a candidate to associate himself with Bill Clinton."
Mr. Sweitzer was immediately rebuked by Mr. Wilhelm, the party chairman, for his comments. But Mr. Greenberg offered much the same message, though his memorandum was less explicit.
 
Clinton Support
 Mr. Greenberg also asserted, however, that Republicans would be wrong to try to turn the elections into a referendum on the President because people still want him to get things done. "If the Republicans choose to make this election about stopping Clinton," he said, "they are missing the mood of the electorate in these swing districts, where voters still want to see Clinton succeed."
Incumbents, Mr. Greenberg said, should discuss their legislative battles and emphasize that they were in them "not for Clinton" but "for the people at home."
The memorandum is striking in its acknowledgment that Mr. Clinton's top legislative initiative -- health care -- has not struck a chord with voters. It is not clear from the memorandum why health care has not registered more interest, though some analysts have explained that many people are confused by the issue or fear losing coverage.
But the pollster says health care could help the Democrats if a measure is passed before the elections, Democrats who have heard Mr. Greenberg present his findings said. Mr. Greenberg did not return calls today.
Another major Clinton initiative that is not registering with the voters is a welfare overhaul, but Mr. Greenberg suggested that if such a measure was passed by Congress, it would be of immense help to Democrats.
 
Emphasis on Crime
 The memorandum also advised that candidates emphasize issues, like crime, that have been the province of Republicans. Mr. Greenberg said a campaign message emphasizing the improved economy would backfire because "assertions about economic performance press up against the public's skepticism." The same, he said, would apply to a message of "breaking gridlock," because "Democrats are seen to share in the problem."
Instead, Mr. Greenberg said, the best thing that Democrats can do is portray themselves as independent fighters. That is their best hope, he said, of capturing the "clearly volatile" group of voters who voted for Ross Perot in 1992 -- the group Mr. Greenberg identified as the one the Democrats most need to win back.
"The most important accomplishment in every district is the passage of 'three strikes and you're out,' " he said, referring to a provision in the crime bill, now stalled in Congress, that would impose lifetime prison terms on criminals convicted of a Federal crime who had two previous serious felony convictions, state or Federal. "No other accomplishment even comes close, suggesting that the agenda message should give a more central place to crime. Indeed, crime is an opportunity for Democrats."
After the three-strikes proposal, Mr. Greenberg said, voters are most interested in these issues: the cutting of 250,000 jobs in the Federal bureaucracy, tax relief for working families, tax cuts and incentives for small businesses, the passage of the ban on assault weapons and the Brady bill, which imposes a waiting period on the purchase of handguns.
 
Courting Middle Class
 Mr. Greenberg said Congressional Democrats "have no reason to be defensive or timid but, instead, should take individual ownership of the agenda." He said they would do best, particularly in the South and West, by stressing middle-class issues like tax relief for small businesses and families of moderate income.
In the Rocky Mountain states and in the Midwest, Democrats would fare well with a more reformist message, he said. He advised that incumbents should concentrate on their votes for restrictions on lobbyists and changes in campaign financing law, as well as for voting for "the biggest deficit reduction in history."
While some Democrats argue that it is risky for their party to attack the Republican Party for its growing dependence on people who identify themselves as part of the religious right, Mr. Greenberg called that strategy a sound one.
"The conflict with the radical religious right favors the Democrats in every one of these swing districts," he wrote. "We gave voters a tough choice: 'What is the greater danger -- that the Democrats will pursue policies that undermine family values, like forcing gays into the military, or that the Republicans, backed by extremist religious leaders like Pat Robertson, use the Government to impose their religious beliefs on others?' In every district, voters were more worried about the extremist religious leaders."
Mr. Greenberg also said that taking on people like Mr. Robertson would help "mobilize Democratic-base voters and appeals to independent voters, particularly Perot supporters."

HEADLINE: Sol Adler, 85, Dies; Ex-U.S. China Aide

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Sol Adler, the United States Treasury Department's representative to China in World War II and a translator of Mao Zedong's works, died of cancer today in Beijing. He was 85.
Mr. Adler had been living in China for more than three decades when he signed up with the Treasury Department. He was recalled to the United States in 1947. 
 He fell victim to the anti-Communist climate in the United States and was subjected to Treasury Department and grand jury investigations for several years before eventually being cleared.
Mr. Adler then left the United States for Britain, the country of his birth, and lost his American citizenship. It was restored in the early 1970's, when Washington opened its first mission in Beijing.
Mr. Adler was also a fellow at the Institute of World Economics in Beijing.

Behind the Kidder Scandal
A three-month internal investigation by Kidder, Peabody mainly blames a complete breakdown in the firm's system of supervision, and two senior executives, for one of Wall Street's most spectacular trading scandals. [Page A1.]

HEADLINE: Auditors Say Poverty Line Should Vary Across Nation

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 31

 BODY:
For decades, the definition of poverty has been uniform throughout the country, but Federal auditors now say the poverty statistics should be adjusted to reflect differences in the cost of living in different areas.
Such a change, suggested recently by auditors from the General Accounting Office, could ultimately increase the flow of Federal money to New York City, Los Angeles, Connecticut and other places where living costs are high. Southern states could lose money if the change occurred. 
 Poverty statistics directly affect the distribution of at least $22 billion a year in Federal money for education, community development, child nutrition and other purposes.
Since the Government began collecting poverty data in the 1960's, it has set the poverty threshold at the same level for the whole country, even though living costs, especially rents, vary widely.
Jerry C. Fastrup, an economist who supervised a recent study of the question by the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said, "If you take cost-of-living differences into account, that would give you a better measurement of people in need."
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, a Democrat, and Representative Dean A. Gallo of New Jersey, a Republican, have introduced bills that would require the Census Bureau to adjust poverty data to take into account geographical differences in the cost of living. The measures are fiercely opposed by members of Congress from Sunbelt states.
 
Getting Started
 While Congress seems unlikely to pass the bills this year, the proposals have focused new attention on the issue. Instead of an overall change, lawmakers could end up revising the Federal aid formulas for specific programs to reflect regional differences in the cost of living.
The White House Office of Management and Budget has not taken a stand on the question. The officials who know most about the issue, Census Bureau experts, agree that the poverty statistics should be adjusted.
At present, the Federal poverty level is the same for all families of a particular size. A family of four was classified as poor last year if it had cash income less than $14,764, whether the family lived in New York City or Tunica, Miss.
Under the bills introduced by Mr. Lieberman and Mr. Gallo, the Census Bureau would develop a poverty threshold for each state and people with incomes below that threshold would be counted as poor.
Members of Congress from Sunbelt states acknowledge that there may be theoretical justifications for adjusting the data. But they argue that states like Connecticut have less need for Federal aid because they have more wealth and can raise revenue from taxpayers more easily than states like Mississippi and Alabama.
"States with limited resources and lower tax bases would lose money to wealthier states with greater resources and higher tax bases," said Senator Thad Cochran, the Mississippi Republican who is co-chairman of the Congressional Sunbelt Caucus.
 
Question of Fairness
 The General Accounting Office agreed that, for the sake of fairness, new Federal aid formulas ought to take into account states' ability to raise revenue from their own taxpayers, as well as local living costs.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, a longtime student of social policy, said that to him it was obvious that "you should adjust the poverty index for the cost of living." When that is done, he said, "the results are quite startling." A larger number of New Yorkers are classified as poor, he explained, and the state's poverty rate rises to a level not too far below that of Mississippi.
Dowell Myers, a demographer at the University of Southern California, said: "The current poverty measure is indefensible. It doesn't show what's happening to real people in real places. Rents in the Northeast and in California are more than twice as high as rents in Southern and Plains states. It costs much more to live in a high-rent state than in a low-rent state. But the poverty index doesn't make any distinction."
Daniel H. Weinberg, chief of income and poverty statistics at the Census Bureau, said, "With the poverty rate, you are trying to measure who doesn't have the resources to purchase the necessities of life. If those cost less in Mississippi than in New York City, we should take account of that."
Poverty statistics help determine how much money goes to state and local governments through Federal programs like Head Start, community development block grants, home energy assistance and remedial education for poor children.
Senator Lieberman said, "States like Connecticut, where the cost of living is high, get fewer Federal dollars than they deserve because cost differences are ignored. Other states, where the cost of living is low, get more than they deserve."
Paul A. Armknecht, Assistant Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, said the current version of the Consumer Price Index was intended to measure price changes at the national level, not local differences in the cost of living.
The Government samples prices around the country, but it does not have enough data to make a reliable estimate of the cost of living in each state and does not systematically collect data on prices in rural areas. In calculating the Consumer Price Index for the nation as a whole, the Government collects information on prices in 44 urban areas.
Using economic models rather than data, Mr. Armknecht said, differences in prices for food, clothing and housing in the 44 urban areas could be estimated. That could provide a useful guide to regional differences in living costs because food, clothing and housing account for nearly half of all consumer spending, he said.
In general, Federal data show that the Northeast has higher prices than the Midwest or the South. Within each region, urban areas generally have higher prices than rural areas.
Patricia Ruggles, an economist who has written a book about poverty statistics, "Drawing the Line" (Urban Institute Press, 1990), said: "The evidence for real differences in price levels across regions has become too compelling to ignore."
Ms. Ruggles said problems could arise if one poverty threshold was used for a region, because living costs can vary substantially within a region. For example, in the Northeast, prices are higher in New York and Boston than in Pittsburgh or, for that matter, Skowhegan, Me.
"The Government needs to collect more data, especially in rural areas," she said.

HEADLINE: U.N. Security Council Weighs Rewarding or Punishing Serbs

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The Security Council would crack down on Serbia with even harsher sanctions involving financial assets, weapons, fuel and possibly even food, or would ease the sanctions that now exist, depending on the wording of two draft resolutions being unofficially circulated at the United Nations.
The carrot-and-stick proposals would be to punish Serbia if it fails to persuade the Bosnian Serbs to accept the latest international peace plan for Bosnia, or to reward the Serbs if their diplomatic efforts are successful. 
 One of the two versions, which United Nations officials said were drafted by representatives of the United States, Britain, France, Germany and Russia, would reinvigorate sanctions that were imposed on Serbia and Montenegro in 1992, but which have been increasingly violated.
Provisions under consideration for the new sanctions package are a virtual blockade on traffic headed to Serbia on the Danube River, a major route for oil imports. Also under consideration are a freeze on a wide range of Serbian financial assets, and even a limit on the amount of fuel that trucks entering Serbia could carry in their gas tanks.
 
Announcement by Belgrade
 Demands for even stricter sanctions against Serbia may be undercut by Belgrade's announcement today that it was withdrawing economic and political support for the Bosnian Serbs. But the harsher version could be introduced if the Security Council doubts the sincerity of the announcement from Belgrade.
One diplomat here said that many of his colleagues remained unconvinced of the sincerity of the announcement from Belgrade and that the formal introduction of the harsher resolution might be the better choice because it would pressure Serbia to make good on its announced intentions.
But the Russian representative, Yuli M. Vorontsov, said after the announcement from Belgrade that he considered the new Serbian position to be a possible "turning point" in efforts to bring about peace in Bosnia.
The Security Council will also seek to sort out its options on the United Nations peacekeeping force in Bosnia, probably early next week.
 
Withdrawal of U.N. Force
 Last month, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali suggested that the Security Council should seriously consider whether the United Nations forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina should be withdrawn in the event of peace there. He said he felt that only the major powers could enforce a peace accord.
The peacekeeping forces in Bosnia, Croatia and Macedonia are costing more than $2 billion a year, an enormous drain on United Nations financial resources.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Warning on Arms Embargo
 WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (Special to The New York Times) President Clinton's chief of staff seemed to signal a shift in the Administration's Bosnia policy today, warning that the United States will ultimately defy an arms embargo in the region if the Serbs reject the latest negotiated peace.
But Mr. Clinton's press spokeswoman later said the Administration's policy of grudging compliance with the embargo is unchanged. She said the real threat to lift the arms ban comes from Congress, which increasingly believes the embargo gives the Serbs a military advantage and may well direct Mr. Clinton to ignore it.
Leon Panetta, Mr. Clinton's new chief of staff, appeared to align the White House with Congress's growing displeasure in an interview with broadcast reporters this morning.
"If we don't get agreement by the Serbs and they continue to fight this issue," he said, "then ultimately we will seek a multilateral lifting of the embargo, and if necessary, a unilateral lifting of the embargo."
Mr. Panetta said the United States would not take those actions until it had "put maximum pressure on them" to accept the peace terms.

HEADLINE: Pentagon Worries About Cost of Aid Missions

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Defense Secretary William J. Perry warned today that the military's relief mission for Rwanda was bleeding the Pentagon's budget and threatening combat readiness.
"We're an army, not a Salvation Army," Mr. Perry told the House Appropriations subcommittee on military spending, where he went hat in hand today to ask for $270 million more in emergency aid for Rwanda. 
 Without the extra allotment and approval to shift money from other accounts, Mr. Perry warned, some tank divisions would have to stop buying spare parts, the Atlantic fleet could only do emergency aircraft-engine repairs and a major Army command in Atlanta would have to dismiss temporary civilian workers.
 
Plea for Patience on Haiti
 The Secretary also discussed Haiti, and acknowledged that economic sanctions so far have had "very little effect" on forcing the military regime to step down. But, he said, the new ban on commercial flights into Haiti, tighter restrictions on Haitians' assets abroad and stricter enforcement along the border with the Dominican Republic should be given "some weeks" to work.
Mr. Perry's main goal today was to win support for the $270 million that President Clinton asked for on Friday. The money would be used to establish and operate airports, provide safe water and provide logistical support to United States forces in Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda and Zaire. Mr. Perry said the money was for costs estimated through Sept. 30.
Senior civilian Pentagon officials and top field commanders have expressed increasing alarm that the costs of peacekeeping and relief missions are straining their declining budget and imperiling the Pentagon's main goal: to be prepared to fight two regional wars nearly simultaneously.
Mr. Perry reiterated the Administration's position that the United States would support a United Nations peacekeeping operation in Rwanda but would not directly take part. And he said that if widespread killing resumed, the United States would withdraw.
 
A Short Stay Predicted
 "We do not plan to put in military forces to enforce the stability in the area," Mr. Perry said. "Therefore, in that case, we would have to pull out."
He also said the United States relief mission would be brief.
"We're there for emergency humanitarian aid, and as soon as the operation is up and running, we want to get out and turn things over to the relief agencies," he said. Mr. Perry has said the United States involvement would last less than a year.
Mr. Perry, who was accompanied by Gen. John M. D. Shalikashvili, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and John Hamre, the Pentagon comptroller, also heard concerns from lawmakers that relief operations could reduce combat readiness.
"We're desperately concerned about readiness being eroded by all these concerns," said Representative John P. Murtha, a Pennsylvania Democrat, who heads the subcommittee.
General Shalikashvili said he had ordered a review of the deployment of certain units in high demand, like C-130 cargo plane crews and Marine expeditionary forces, to determine if "we're running them ragged."
 
Trying to Seal a Border
 Mr. Perry's remarks on Haiti reinforced views he voiced on Tuesday in a meeting of senior national security advisers. At the meeting, Mr. Perry said the United States should fully explore all options for forcing out Haiti's military leaders before resorting to an invasion, Administration officials said.
American intelligence analysts here and in Haiti have expressed skepticism that tighter sanctions, which clearly hurt the country's poor people, are pinching the pocketbooks of the elite and the military rulers.
"The embargo to date has had a very limited effect on the regime or the elites," Mr. Perry said. "We've been very effective in blocking goods coming by sea. Meantime the back door is wide open to goods coming in through the Dominican Republic. Until that back door is closed, sanctions can't be that effective."
The Pentagon said this week that it was sending 6 helicopters, 18 military scouts and several technical experts to the Dominican Republic on Monday to help stop smuggling of fuel. The officials will be part of an international team of 88 observers who are to patrol the 186-mile border under an accord signed Monday between the United States and the Dominican Republic.
"The Dominican Republic will also be continuing to patrol, and this will be in addition to that," a Pentagon spokesman, Dennis R. Boxx, told reporters today. "Smugglers will not know precisely where the observers are going to be. They will be moving, and hopefully that'll help add a little mystery to it."

HEADLINE: Auto Stocks Lead Market In a Selloff

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The stock market sagged under the weight of a selloff in auto stocks yesterday after total sales from Detroit's Big Three auto makers came in weaker than expected on Wednesday. The July sales were the lowest annual rate in 10 months.
Market analysts said the drop in auto sales might have caused investors to be concerned that the corporate profits of companies in segments like autos, building products and semiconductors could peak sooner than expected. 
 Moreover, traders became defensive ahead of today's jobs data, waiting to see if the numbers confirmed a modest growth scenario, one that would ease the immediate need for some Fed action and higher interest rates. Expectations were for an increase of 200,000 on nonfarm payrolls.
 
 
Bond Market Weakness
 The prospect of a stronger-than-anticipated monthly employment report today that could forecast higher interest rates sometime soon was enough to keep buyers at bay. Weakness in the bond market and the dollar added to the stock market's uneasiness.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 26.87 points, to 3,765.79. With the exception of the American Stock Exchange composite index, which was up 0.76 point, to 441.35, all the other market indicators were off slightly. The Big Board composite index fell 1.31 points, to 253.27. Declining stocks outpaced advancers by 1,188 to 912.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 294.3 million shares, up from 282.4 million shares on Wednesday.
Merrill Lynch stoked investor concern about auto stocks early, citing poor sales performance and higher interest rates before downgrading its rating recommendation on the Big Three. General Motors dropped by 2 1/8, to 50 3/4; Ford Motor declined 2, to 29 1/2, and Chrysler fell 1 3/4, to 45 5/8.
Lawrence R. Rice, chief market strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said that autos were the key to market weakness, and that they in turn caused issues tied closely to the sector, like steel, to drop.
"The market's breadth, which had held all day, became more pronounced to the downside at the end," he said. "People were anticipating a rally that did not materialize. There was just too much weakness too early in the session to overcome, especially ahead of the jobs data."
Some stocks which managed to turn in some good results included Best Buy up 2 3/4, to 27 1/4, on modest retail sales gains in July, and Circuit City, up 1 3/8, to 22 1/2.
"I.B.M., which has been bucking the trend and has been a very good performer of late after a decent second quarter, has not given ground since," Mr. Rice said. Yesterday, I.B.M. stock rose 3/8, to 63 1/8.
A weaker-than-expected economic report today, he said, would help bonds and that would help stocks.
Takeover stocks continued to interest investors. While Norfolk Southern and Conrail have declined to comment on reports that they are negotiating a merger, analysts believe the report could help railroad stocks generally. Shares of Norfolk Southern closed down 1/2, to 63 1/8, while those of Conrail fell 1 1/2, to 55.
Other talked-about takeover candidates included American Cyanamid, following a $95-a-share bid by American Home Products. Speculation quickly spread to other issues like Warner-Lambert, up 2 1/8, to 74 3/8; Schering-Plough, down 1, to 66 5/8, and Amgen, down 3/8, to 50 3/4.
Unitrin, which initially rose in Nasdaq trading on news of a $2.6 billion cash takeover bid from American General, was down 2, to 46 3/4 at the close.
QVC was up 3/4 for the day at 44 3/4 on expectations of a sweetened offer from Comcast and Liberty Media. The offer, according to The Wall Street Journal, was $46 a share.
General Electric dropped 1 1/8, to 48 1/2, as investors refocused their attention on the securities trading scandal at the company's Kidder, Peabody subsidiary.

HEADLINE: White House Cites Economy To Bolster Clinton's Ratings

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
Stepping up its campaign to bolster President Clinton's sagging public standing, the White House today paraded out eight top economic officials who touted their agencies' accomplishments over the last year and a half.
President Clinton highlighted the economy's performance in the opening statement of his prime time news conference on Wednesday, the third of his term. Administration officials said this evening that he would hold another news conference in the Rose Garden on Friday morning just to discuss the economy. 
 They predicted that the President would focus on the July employment figures, which the Labor Department is scheduled to issue early Friday morning. Independent economists say the report could show that employment has risen by four million jobs since he took office, half the eight million jobs that Mr. Clinton had promised to create during his first term.
Several of the eight officials at today's news briefing on their agencies' records expressed frustration that the Administration has not received more credit for the nation's strong economic growth, low inflation and falling unemployment.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, came the closest to blaming the news media for not paying enough attention to the economy's health or to the role that White House policies may have played in the current economic expansion.
"If the economy were in trouble right now, I am sure that there would be a lot of observation to the effect that the Clinton Administration strategy was totally responsible," Ms. Tyson said when asked whether the Administration had been lucky, rather than skillful, in its handling of the economy.
"So in a sense I feel like I should start by saying I will take as much credit -- we will, the President will, the Administration will -- take as much credit for the current good situation, as I'm sure many of you would cast blame on the Administration if the economy were not performing well," Ms. Tyson said. "That's the first point, and it's actually a correct observation."
Private sector economists have been divided about the extent to which the Administration is responsible for the economy's health. Critics say that the Federal Reserve's low interest rate policy last year played the crucial role while admirers say that White House policies were also important.
These were among the main Administration accomplishments cited by the officials today:
*The halving of the Federal budget deficit as a percentage of economic output -- to a projected 2.4 percent next year from 4.9 percent in 1992.
*Congressional approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement and the negotiation of a new global free trade pact now before Congress.
*Expanded job placement services and retraining for the unemployed.
*Reduced bank regulation to make loans more available to small and medium-sized businesses.
The theme of the current spate of Administration news conferences is the approaching one-year anniversary of Congressional approval of the President's budget-deficit reduction legislation. The Senate passed the legislation on Aug. 6, 1993, with Vice President Al Gore casting the deciding vote.
Despite the strong economy and these programs, the President's approval ratings have been slowly slipping this year, from 54 percent in January to 42 percent in July, according to New York Times/CBS News polls.
 
 
'A Little Puzzled'
 The erosion of support has surprised polltakers. "I've been a little puzzled about why Clinton is doing so poorly given that all the current economic statistics are doing so well," said Fred P. Steeper, a Republican polltaker in Southfield, Mich. "I wish we'd had these numbers for Bush in '92."
One possibility, Mr. Steeper and other experts said, is that the President is getting credit for the economy but that his performance in other areas has dragged down his poll ratings.
Public approval of Mr. Clinton's handling of the economy has stayed almost flat this year, inching up to 43 percent last month from 42 percent in January, a statistically insignificant change, according to New York Times/CBS News polls. But approval of his foreign policies has plunged to 36 percent from 50 percent.
In a short conversation after the briefing in the Old Executive Office Building adjacent to the White House, Ms. Tyson said she had been trying to point out that the American public always blames Administrations for poor performance and that she had not meant to single out reporters for criticism.
 
 
'Extraordinary Job'
 But other officials also voiced frustration at today's news conference, although not quite as forcefully. "I don't think that the President has gotten the credit that he has deserved," Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said. "Any objective analysis of the economic data would have to conclude that this President has done an extraordinary job of leading this country to a period of economic growth and job creation."
Academic analyses of the linkages between economic performance and Presidential popularity have tended to look at changes in the average person's after-tax disposable income, adjusted for inflation. This has risen at an annual rate of 1.9 percent so far in the Clinton Administration, according to Commerce Department figures, compared with four-tenths of 1 percent in the Bush Administration.
John Goodman, the president of the National Center for Policy Analysis, a bipartisan public policy research group in Dallas, said that Americans might be unusually hard to please when the country was coming out of a recession, demanding nothing less than an economic boom and being dissatisfied with any slower growth. "When you come out of bad times, you expect better times," he said.

HEADLINE: David Reichmann, Israeli Executive, 34

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Aug. 4

 BODY:
David Reichmann, a member of the Reichmann family of Canada, died on Tuesday near Tel Aviv. He was 34 and lived in Israel.
His lawyer, Yehuda Raveh, said he died of a heart attack. The police found him in his car on the side of the road between Tel Aviv and the suburb of Bnei Brak, said a police spokesman, Gadi Doron. 
 Mr. Reichmann was the son of Ralph Reichman, one of the three Reichmann brothers. The family was reputed to be one of the wealthiest in the world before the collapse of its vast real estate empire in 1992.
The younger Reichmann pulled out of his family's Canary Wharf development project in London four years ago, not long before that project's financial collapse.
He moved to Israel and set up a communications company, Darcom. One of its contracts was to set up the communications link between the American Embassy in Tel Aviv and the State Department in Washington.
Mr. Reichmann studied at Jewish seminaries and contributed to religious institutions in Israel.
In addition to his father, he is survived by his wife and five children.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Fall in Late Trading

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell late yesterday after a Federal Reserve official raised concerns in the bond market that today's employment report might prompt the Federal Reserve to increase interest rates.
The Treasury's 30-year bond fell 8/32 of a point, or $2.50 per $1,000 bond. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 7.40 percent from 7.38 percent. 
 After showing little change for most of the day, bonds dropped after Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said in a speech in Salt Lake City, "We can't be certain that any slack remains" in the labor market.
Some traders interpreted Mr. Parry's remarks to mean that if the employment report shows more jobs than expected were created in July, the Fed might raise short-term interest rates to cool off the economy and head off inflationary pressures.
"Ahead of the employment number, the market's very sensitive to any comments like this on employment," said Tony Crescenzi, director of fixed-income trading at Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company.
The Fed has raised the Federal funds rate on overnight bank loans four times so far this year to contain inflation. Mr. Parry, a voting member of the central bank's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee, termed the previous rate increases "appropriate."
Economists estimate that the economy probably added about 200,000 jobs in July, down from 379,000 in June. The unemployment rate is forecast to rise to 6.1 percent from 6 percent a month earlier.
A bigger gain, of about 250,000, "would indicate we would see a pickup in inflation" by the end of the year, said Michael Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America.
Inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income securities, is running at an annual rate of 2.5 percent so far this year, down from 2.7 percent for all of last year.
Before Mr. Parry's comments, investors were reluctant to place bets before the employment report. The monthly job survey typically generates the largest market move of any economic indicator, according to a Salomon Brothers study.
Late in the day, Market News Service quoted an unidentified Fed official as dismissing the notion that the central bank was undecided about whether to raise rates again.
Bonds dropped early in the day, then pared their loss, after a report that the number of people applying for first-time jobless benefits unexpectedly dropped last week. Many analysts discounted the jobless claims figure because it may have been skewed by seasonal aberrations.
Still, the Labor Department's report that claims fell by 10,000 to 319,000, the lowest level since February, magnified concern that tomorrow's report will be stronger than expected.
"The economy seems to be doing fine," said Robert McGee, chief economist at Tokai Bank. "If the labor market stays strong, it's hard to see the economy slowing down."
The economy expanded at a 3.7 percent pace during the second quarter, the government said last week.
"There hasn't been a significant amount of slowing," in the economy, said Paul DeNoon, who manages the $1.2 billion Alliance Bond U.S. Government Fund in New York. "The big question is what the underlying rate of growth is."

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE KIDDER SCANDAL: NEWS ANALYSIS;
How Profit Was Created on Paper

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
There were virtually no genuine profitable trades. Joseph Jett, Kidder, Peabody's former bond-trading star, simply made up trades and marked them down as having made money. In the meantime, his few real trades consistently lost money.
Those are the conclusions of Gary G. Lynch's study of the phony profits at Kidder. While the report clears all of those above Mr. Jett, the chief Government bond trader, of knowledge of what was going on, it sharply chastises Kidder as an institution for monumental failures in oversight and systems that kept it from catching on long before it did. 
 The report by Mr. Lynch, former chief of enforcement for the Securities and Exchange Commission and now a partner in the New York law firm of Davis, Polk & Wardwell, confirms the brokerage firm's account of what Mr. Jett did, an account that was given in the days after he was dismissed on April 17.
 
Arbitrage and Fiction
 Mr. Jett seems to have taken advantage of a Kidder accounting system, which allowed him, by simply announcing plans to take two offsetting positions, to post a phony profit. The system would eventually wipe out that false profit, but by then Mr. Jett would have created new, similarly fictitious gains.
He did that, the report says, by alleging activity in a part of the Government bond market that has been around for many years, and whose fundamentals are well understood on Wall Street.
It consists of stripping a Treasury bond -- separating each interest payment and the eventual principal repayment, and selling them separately. Sometimes, when strips are selling for a relatively high price, the practice can be profitable. On the other hand, sometimes it is possible to make money by reconstituting a bond, that is buying all the strips and putting them back together to form a bond. That is known as a "recon" in Wall Street language.
The markets in those bonds are relatively efficient, however, and arbitrage keeps the prices of the strips and the recon close to each other. So the profit to be made in these activities is usually small, and the opportunities fleeting.
A single strip constitutes a Government promise to make a payment in the future. As a result, the price of that strip will rise as the payment date approaches, assuming no change in interest-rate levels. The Kidder accounting system, now changed, allowed Mr. Jett to take credit for whatever part of that inevitable rise he wanted to claim. It did that because he would report having agreed to sell the security in the future, at the higher price, while seemingly paying the lower, current price.
 
The Bookkeeping of Trillions
 As the later date neared, the report said, those fictitious profits would vanish from the books. So to get the profits back, he would have to put on more phony trades. The quantities got so large that he was claiming to control more than twice the total amount of some bonds that had been stripped -- something Kidder did not notice.
In the first three months of 1994, he told Kidder he had made trades involving $1.76 trillion in principal value. In fact, the report says, $79 billion of those trades were real. The 95 percent remaining -- $1.68 trillion -- was never traded.
Over time, various questions were raised at Kidder, but until this spring no one seems to have noticed the inherent implausibility of what Mr. Jett said he was doing. He was given huge bonuses for the profits he claimed to be generating, when, in fact, his real trading was producing losses.
Changes in the accounting system will prevent this particular ruse from happening again. But the Lynch report makes clear that the new bosses at Kidder, Peabody will have to pay more attention to what their supposed star traders are up to.

HEADLINE: Exchange To Build And Stay In Manhattan

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
A day after it formally completed its merger with the Commodity Exchange, the New York Mercantile Exchange announced yesterday that it would build a new office tower in lower Manhattan, keeping its headquarters and 8,100 jobs in the city.
The exchange, which has been in the World Trade Center since 1977, decided to build the tower beside the Hudson River in Battery Park City after ruling out another site in Manhattan and one in Jersey City, its chairman, Daniel Rappaport, said. 
 In a news conference at City Hall, where the announcement was made, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo praised the exchange's decision, describing it as a signal of the city's pre-eminence in the financial world.
 
Still the Financial Center
 "This would have been a blow to us had we lost the exchange," Mr. Cuomo said. "The fact that after the recession, with all the importunings by our neighboring state, with all the seductions, with all the offers, they remain here is a confirmation that this is the financial center of the world."
The decision to build a new headquarters for the exchange came after several years of searching and after it twice declared it would relocate.
The first plan involved moving with all the city's futures exchanges to a new building in TriBeCa, but the Mercantile Exchange pulled out. Then, in 1992, the exchange announced it would move into a building on Greenwich Street in Manhattan that was owned by Shearson Lehman, but that deal collapsed when Smith Barney took over Shearson and occupied the space.
 
Considered Moving
 Mr. Rappaport said the exchange's directors gave "an extraordinary amount" of thought to moving to New Jersey and at a meeting late Wednesday night voted narrowly to approve the new headquarters in Battery Park City, which is run by a state authority and has office and residential tenants.
The new tower, whose construction costs are estimated at $225 million, will rise 20 stories above the Hudson River next to the World Financial Center. It will include two 25,000-square-foot trading floors as well as offices. Construction is expected to begin in a few months and be completed in 1997.
City and state officials offered a package of incentives to the exchange, including $125 million in capital construction money, divided evenly between the city and state. The exchange also received tax abatements of $43 million, and it is eligible for lower energy costs from the State Power Authority.
With their merger completed, the Commodity Exchange, the world's largest precious metals futures exchange, is now a wholly owned subsidiary of the Mercantile Exchange, which is the world's largest futures market for oil.
Mr. Giuliani said that the merged exchange contributed $177 million in tax revenues each year to the city and state. More important, he said, "This helps to confirm the fact that New York City is the place to be if you're a player in global industry."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Job Data Today and Rumor On Haiti Push Up the Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar advanced against other currencies yesterday in largely technical trading before the July employment report, with a rumor of an American invasion of Haiti providing an early lift.
It rose to its high for the week against the German mark, despite the absence of any significant new economic data or policy statements, a move that Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Paine Webber Inc., called a "bullish signal." 
 "Big funds are moving a lot of capital into U.S. markets this week; that set the tone," he said. "There is pent-up demand for dollars."
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.5882 marks, up from 1.5758 marks on Wednesday. It also rose to 100.55 Japanese yen from 100.31 yen.
Analysts said concern that Washington would impose trade sanctions on Japan in the next few months limited the dollar's gains against the yen. "Dollar-yen is caught in a very narrow range because of the trade dispute," said David De Rosa, a director in New York for the Swiss Bank Corporation. "Nobody is willing to pay 101 for something that may be worth 95."
With Japanese monthly trade data due to be released today in Tokyo, few dealers were willing to stake new positions, he said.
The Haiti rumor was quickly dismissed by many traders and denied by officials. It was one of a number of such rumors that has made the rounds in the last few weeks. Nevertheless, it pushed up the dollar in early trading in the United States, where thin volume helped amplify the rise, and in late trading in Europe.
"The market is turning," said Dave Glowacki, senior trader at the National Bank of Detroit. "A month ago, you had a sell-dollar mentality. Now, we've turned the corner, and any excuse is used to buy."
But much of the dollar buying yesterday reflected traders' adjusting their positions in advance of the Labor Department's report today on employment in July. The figures are expected to provide a clue as to whether the Federal Reserve might again raise short-term interest rates.
"People don't want to be short going into the unemployment report," Mr. Glowacki said.
Forecasters think the report is likely to show that about 200,000 jobs were created last month, down from 379,000 in June. That would be consistent with recent reports indicating moderate economic growth and low inflation.
In trading of other major currencies yesterday, the British pound fell to $1.5355 from $1.5425, while the Canadian dollar was steady at 72.07 cents.

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims Drop

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 4

 BODY:
The number of Americans seeking state unemployment benefits declined for the second consecutive week last week, dropping to the lowest level since February, the Government reported today.
The Labor Department said initial jobless claims totaled a seasonally adjusted 319,000 in the week that ended last Saturday. That was the lowest level since Feb. 26. 
 The figure declined 10,000 from the revised 329,000 reported for the week that ended on July 23. That figure was initially reported at 331,000. It was the first time the measure had dropped in two straight weeks since May.
The Labor Department's four-week moving average of jobless claims was 350,750, a decrease of 6,250 from the previous week. That was the lowest level in four weeks. The four-week average is more closely watched by economists than the weekly number because it smooths out fluctuations.
The Labor Department said increases in initial claims were reported by eight states and territories in the week ended July 23; 44 reported decreases, and one was unchanged. State totals lag a week behind the national ones.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Who Pays China's Army?

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Two months ago, President Clinton wiped out Asian human rights as a political, economic or diplomatic concern of his Administration's foreign policy.
He did this with the help and guidance of the American China lobby, which pays for its business profits in China by supporting the interests of the Government in Beijing. 
 But only the President himself could actually do the deed and only in one way -- by tearing up the promises he had made before and after the Presidential campaign, including his own executive order. That was the one all about how the minimum trade tariffs China enjoys would be raised unless Beijing allowed Chinese and Tibetan citizens some relief from forced labor, political arrest, prison torture and religious persecution.
China, sensing the sponginess of the President's commitment to human rights before many of us who voted for him, did not give him an inch. So he caved.
Why he did I do not know or perhaps am not ready to believe. Mr. Clinton learned long ago how important the money and other support of major corporations are at election time. All American politicians learn this. But not all go along, not on such an issue of honor and heart.
At least 100 members of the House of Representatives have stated their readiness to resist the pressure of the China lobby, the President and Beijing. Next week they will vote for legislation to raise the low tariffs subsidizing the massive exports of the Chinese Army to the U.S. -- yes, the Chinese Army.
How many more will join them depends in good part on how many Americans really care, enough to show it.
Once the tariff pressure was off, the Chinese repaid Mr. Clinton exactly as he and the lobby could have foretold -- if they had cared.
Human Rights Watch/Asia reports that the noose has tightened on all dissident activity. And the political branch of the conference of American Catholic bishops says that religious persecution is increasing and so is forced abortion.
Economically China is cashing in big. This year it will sell Americans $30 billion more than it buys from them. Meanwhile Beijing, according to the C.I.A., is the chief nuclear supplier to Iran and the major missile salesman to Syria and Iran, still tests nuclear weapons and is the only major nuclear power to increase its military budget.
Here is the evil comedy: The U.S. consumer is supporting the growth of the Chinese "People's Army," which is both the major instrument of Chinese power abroad and the major weapon of repression at home.
Are we all total fools with no commitment to human rights or even our own interests? No, not all of us -- not the bishops, not the A.F.L.-C.I.O., not the human rights groups, and not those members of Congress getting ready for next week's fight.
One of them, Gerald Solomon, Republican of New York, has introduced one-paragraph legislation: Reject the President's decision, raise the tariffs. It won't win but, oh, what a pleasure it would be to vote for him in November.
The other representatives have put together compromise legislation that targets principally those products manufactured by the network of thousands of plants owned by the Chinese Army.
The Administration is now so trapped by China that along with the China lobby it is actually fighting any human rights move against the forced-labor economic power of the Chinese military or its subsidization by U.S. low tariffs.
The Chinese Army's products range from guns exported by the thousands to America to machinery, furniture and clothing -- often produced by workers paid in prison gruel.
That wipes out American competition and makes for huge profits that go to the leading Communist Party families, the party itself and the Chinese Army.
All around Asia other countries with a taste for repression are delighted with the signal from Washington -- forget that human rights stuff because when it comes to trade America does not care.
American voters have a choice. They can phone or fax their minds to their representatives about subsidizing the Chinese Army. Or they can go on making Chinese generals even merrier, more stuffed with American billions and more powerful militarily.
Either way, one day the news of the American choice will get to the Chinese and Tibetans in their subsidized torture cells and labor camps.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Big Houses Guzzle Natural Resources

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Building Small . . . Thinking Big" (news article, July 21) cites costs, demographics and environmental concerns as reasons for a trend toward smaller houses. 
 I would urge that more architects, contractors and home buyers become aware of the environmental aspects of construction. The numbers are startling:
* The American Institute of Architects estimates that the building industry consumes 40 percent of the natural resources used by the United States economy.
* The average all-electric house in Austin, Tex., consumes 19,000 kilowatt-hours of energy a year, causing the release of 10.5 tons of carbon dioxide into the air and contributing to the risk of global warming. Most of this energy is for heating, cooling and lighting needs that vary directly with the size of a house.
* Construction and demolition waste makes up 20 percent of the municipal waste stream.
With the persistent fear of the destruction of old-growth forests, the spread of monoculture timber plantations, the increasing use of fossil fuels and the shrinking amount of landfill space, it is timely to consider downsizing our needs for large houses and their appetite for lumber, energy and landfill space.
 
DAVID TODD
Austin, Tex., July 26, 1994

HEADLINE: Stop Witch Hunts for Uninsured Drivers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The police road blocks for uninsured drivers in New Jersey are reminiscent of the Gestapo in 1930's Germany. The stoppages are essentially a witch hunt against decent, working people, who because of the escalating cost are priced out of auto insurance. 
 Members of the police are disgusted with this law. One explained: "These people only have so much money. They can either feed their kids or pay their auto insurance. They feed their kids."
The first-offense penalty for driving without insurance is a mandatory six-month ban on driving, community service and a $300 fine.
Many people must drive to work, so they risk getting caught again, rather than lose their jobs and go on unemployment. The second offense brings a $500 fine, two weeks' imprisonment, 30 days of community service and a two-year driving ban. In each case a $750 surcharge on the driver's license fee must be paid.
This is especially burdensome for single, divorced and widowed women, whose income often makes compliance with the law impossible. One individual banned from driving ordered a pizza on the Saturday of the Fourth of July weekend, and it was the only food in the apartment for three days because of lack of transportation. This is how mandatory sentencing treats lower-income workers who go to their jobs every day and are otherwise model citizens.
This legislation is obviously the work of the insurance lobby, with the cost of enforcement paid from the police budget. The legislation should be thrown out and pardons immediately awarded to those sentenced. The sooner political action committees are outlawed, the sooner all citizens will be better served by their legislators.
 
PETER F. GREEN
Cinnaminson, N.J., July 29, 1994

HEADLINE: Design Team Chosen to Set Stadium Plan

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
Seeking to make the Yankees feel at home in the Bronx, the city yesterday hired a team of consultants to design a make-over of the stadium and the neighborhood around it. The aim is to create more fan-friendly transportation and parking and a more vibrant setting for the ball park.
Leading the consulting team will be the architectural firm Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, which has designed several baseball stadiums, including Oriole Park at Camden Yards in Baltimore, which is widely regarded as the premier modern urban ball park. 
 City and state officials want to present the Yankees with a master plan for the area within six to nine months and quell threats from the team's principal owner, George Steinbrenner, that the team might move out of the Bronx when its lease on the stadium expires in the year 2002.
The project manager at the architectural firm, Timothy Delorm, said he envisioned "the evolution of a South Bronx-Yankees sports and cultural district."
 
New Attractions
 In applying for the $630,000 contract with the city's Economic Development Corporation, the firm raised the possibility of creating a range of attractions other than the stadium in the ball park's South Bronx neighborhood, from a sports museum and a sports-training village to art galleries and a waterfront amphitheater.
"What we'd like to do is extend the attractions of the area," Mr. Delorm said. "The long-term future of both the Yankees and the neighborhood depends on integrating the community with the stadium and vice versa."
Mr. Delorm said plans for improving the neighborhood would be worked out with community, political and business leaders. City officials have said that renovations to the stadium could cost as much as $250 million, but no parameters for the price of the entire project have been set.
The application submitted by the firm, which is based in St. Louis, said the first thing that would need to be done would be to resolve the Yankees' concerns of "safety perception, image, access and parking" in the Bronx. The application said that creating more retail businesses and other attractions in the area would increase pedestrian traffic, "which will eliminate the perception that the area is unsafe."
Officials have not determined how much of the plan would involve renovation of the stadium itself. At the minimum, city officials said, luxury sky boxes and refreshment stands would be built.
The Yankees were silent yesterday on the city's action. "I'm not in a position to discuss it at all," said Joseph Carella, a spokesman for the team.
Yankee officials have periodically talked about leaving the South Bronx, saying attendance at games has been dampened by the fear of crime and by the difficulty of getting to the stadium and finding parking spaces.
 
Searching For New Sites
 The Yankees recently asked city and state officials to search for other sites within the city to build a new stadium, and a list was compiled. But city officials have said that their intention is to keep the Yankees in the South Bronx, and yesterday's decision to hire the team of consultants seemed to show their commitment to that strategy.
"We believe that the Yankees belong in the Bronx and can be happy in the Bronx," James A. Schmidt, the executive vice president of the Economic Development Corporation, said yesterday.
Clay B. Lifflander, the corporation president, said the city wanted to avoid the mistakes of the 1970's, when the stadium was renovated but little attention was paid to the neighborhood. "The focus was more architectural than community planning," he said.
The cost of the contract approved yesterday by the development corporation will be split between the city and the New York State Urban Development Corporation.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, noting the firm's work at Camden Yards, said, "We are counting on this very same vision to help us create a plan for the economic revitalization of this area."
Mr. Delorm discouraged comparisons between the Yankee Stadium project and the building of Camden Yards. In Baltimore, the stadium is part of the city's Inner Harbor district, which had been under renovation for more than a decade and was already a tourist destination when the stadium was built.
Not only are the Mott Haven and Highbridge neighborhoods around the stadium not tourist attractions, but such basic tasks as repaving the Cross Bronx and Major Deegan Expressways and designing other ways to get fans to and from the stadium must be accomplished before any other amenities can be added to the neighborhood.
Plans for improving stadium access have been discussed by the state Department of Transportation, including building a Metro-North train station at the stadium as well as a bridge across the Harlem River from Manhattan to a parking garage near the stadium. In those plans, which have been criticized by Bronx officials for encouraging a negative image of the area, fans would be able to reach the stadium from the parking garage by an enclosed walkway. The bridge would allow them to attend a ball game without setting foot on Bronx streets.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 6, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption yesterday about a plan to refurbish Yankee Stadium and its environs described the team's attendance incorrectly. It has risen slightly, not fallen, from the same time last season.
(August 10, 1994, Wednesday) An article on Thursday about a political dispute that has stalled final passage of the Clinton Administration's comprehensive crime bill characterized the voting patterns of Republicans in the House incorrectly. While Republicans often vote as a block to oppose key Democratic measures, they do not always do so.

(Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Q&A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Investing for College
 
Q. Our 23-year-old nanny is saving money to be used in the next four years for her education. Would a conservative stock mutual fund be good, or would another type of investment be better?
LISA G. MATTHEWS, Darien, Conn.
 
A. Each year, the stock market may go down, as well as up. At present, prices of stocks are high relative to dividends, and interest rates have been moving up. So people who will need money in a short time would be safer choosing investments with less risk than stocks.
 If your nanny will need money in each of the next four years, she should predict her annual cash flow and invest so that money will be available as required to pay tuition bills and other costs.
 "Invest your money to earn the highest interest for the longest time with little or no risk to principal," advised Madeline I. Noveck, president of Novos Planning Associates. "For example, money needed in one to three years might be invested in Treasury bills or short-term target maturity funds. For the money needed in four years, you may want to take more risk for the potential of higher return by investing in a conservative stock fund with good performance in down markets or preferably a global asset allocation fund."
 
 
Earnings Up, Shares Down
 
Q. Why does a stock's price decline when a company does well in a quarter, but its reported earnings fall below analysts' predictions?
DANIEL S. JACOBY, East Williston, L.I.
 
A. The price of a stock typically reflects investors' perceptions both about the company's immediate prospects and long-term potential. Earnings that are positive, but below the consensus of analysts' estimates, are disappointing.
 Some investors who have read news reports that earnings fell below forecasts may decide to shed their shares, as may some clients of brokerage houses whose analysts have reduced their ratings on the stock. Such selling, of course, depresses the stock price.
 "Below-estimate earnings can cause price weakness because the anticipated earnings are probably built into the stock price," said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/Twenty-First Advisers. "Investors worry about additional disappointments."
 
 
Limitations on I.R.A.'s
 
Q. Can I contribute $2,000 to my I.R.A. if I am not working and receive income only from Social Security and investments? Can I deduct my contribution from my income for tax purposes?
BERNARD SCHER, Margate, Fla.
 
A. A taxpayer's annual contribution to an individual retirement account can be made only from earned income. The contribution is limited to the amount earned or $2,000, whichever is less.
 "Social Security and investment income do not qualify as earned income," said Martin Leventhal, head of a New York accounting firm bearing his name. "Hence, no I.R.A. contribution, whether deductible or nondeductible, may be based upon income from those sources."

HEADLINE: A SURGE IN HIRING CHEERS PRESIDENT BUT ROILS MARKETS

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
The economy continued to produce jobs at a brisk pace in July, the Government said today, prompting drops in financial markets as investors expressed fear that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates again soon to prevent any increase in inflation.
Employment grew by 259,000 jobs last month while average hourly earnings rose 4 cents, to $11.12, the Labor Department announced. President Clinton welcomed the news, saying that nonfarm employment had now risen by 4.1 million jobs since he took office, half of the 8 million jobs that he promised to create during his first term. 
 But traders and investors in financial markets were much less enthusiastic. They worried that the central bank would interpret rising wages and employment as signs that the economy would overheat and that inflation, now running at slightly less than 3 percent, would pick up. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 18.77, to 3,747.02, while the interest rate on 30-year Treasury bonds rose to 7.54 percent, from 7.40 on Thursday. [Pages 34 and 41.]
While there were sharp reactions in the bond and stock markets, there is not much uncertainty on Wall Street about what lies ahead. Most analysts expect the Federal Reserve to raise its short-term interest rate target again, the fifth increase this year. The debate is just over the timing.
The jobs data released today made the increase seem more imminent, possibly as soon as Monday. But if data next week indicate a slowdown in consumer spending, traders and investors may conclude that the Fed can wait, either to the next meeting of the Fed's interest-rate-policy committee on Aug. 16, or even longer.
In separate interviews this week, five top Federal Reserve officials expressed uncertainty about the economy's direction that today's figures only partly resolve. Their uncertainty suggests that the Federal Reserve is likely to wait at least until Aug. 16 before raising rates again.
Although job growth was strong in July, the unemployment rate crept up to 6.1 percent, a statistically insignificant increase of a tenth of a percentage point from June. Unlike the figures on job creation, which come from an extensive survey of businesses, the unemployment rate is based on a survey of households.
The household survey has been producing unusual results since the Labor Department changed the questions at the beginning of this year, and even department officials have become hesitant to rely on it. "The household survey still is -- since it's a new survey instrument and it's a small survey in terms of the number of people surveyed -- is still bouncing around a little bit," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said in a telephone interview this afternoon.
Other analysts were less polite. "It's not a reliable number, particularly on a month-to-month basis," said David M. Jones, an economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company in New York.
Employment rose even faster in June, by 356,000 nonfarm jobs. But Katherine G. Abraham, the commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said that the slightly slower pace in July was not significant because some hiring in highly seasonal industries appeared to have taken place in June this year instead of in July.
 
 
'Responsible Thing to Do'
 The strong jobs figures for July suggested to some analysts that another rate increase might be imminent. No economic data are scheduled for release on Monday, so the financial markets may be quiet. A rate increase that day, said Eugene J. Sherman, the director of research at M. A. Schapiro & Company, a New York brokerage firm, might help the Treasury Department in its big auctions of securities later next week, by reassuring investors that the American central bank was on guard against inflation.
"It would be the responsible thing to do, to move and move promptly," Mr. Sherman said.
But central bankers have made clear this week that before taking action, they want answers to three basic questions: is output growing, do people have the money to buy that output, and will people actually spend the money if they have it?
The first question was answered on July 29, when the Commerce Department announced that the nation's economic output grew at an above-average annual rate of 3.7 percent. But more than half of the extra output went into business inventories, as consumer spending slowed sharply.
 
More are earning More
 So central bank officials have been waiting for evidence of whether American consumers have the money to buy these goods and whether they actually will buy them. Today's figures on jobs and wages suggest that more Americans are earning more money.
But Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Federal Reserve Board governor who heads the board's panel on consumer finance, said the increase in wages might not be enough to insure that the extra inventories would be sold.
In a telephone interview this afternoon, Mr. Lindsey said, "I feel a little bit less confident than I would like to" that there will be enough new consumer spending to empty the shelves that were filled in the second quarter.
Today's report also does not show whether Americans will spend the extra money or save it. The Commerce Department is scheduled to release next Thursday its figures on retail sales for July. Federal Reserve officials eagerly await this information as an indication of consumer spending.
 
Debating the Timing
 The Federal Reserve could raise rates next Thursday, after the retail sales figures are released. But that would run counter to the central bank's pattern of avoiding rate changes in the few days before a meeting. In addition, top central bank officials say they have found many contradictions in recent economic data, making it likely that they will want to talk over the figures in person here on Aug. 16 instead of holding an emergency telephone conference call before then.
To be sure, the Federal Reserve is also watching data on inflation itself, and not just information on whether the economy is overheating. The Producer Price Index is also scheduled for release on Thursday, with the Consumer Price Index due on Friday.
 
 
 
Lower Commodity Prices
 One possible source of optimism for Federal Reserve officials lies in the recent small drop in commodity prices. Susan M. Phillips, another governor of the Federal Reserve Board and its most influential voice on commodities, said in an interview this week that good weather seemed likely to refill grain bins emptied by bad harvests in the last two years and prevent a sharp rise in food prices.
"As each day goes by, we get in a little better situation as far as agricultural commodities," said Ms. Phillips, a former head of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
The Federal Reserve has raised overnight interest rates four times this year, to 4.25 percent from 3 percent. While the Clinton Administration has largely refrained from criticizing the Federal Reserve, another interest-rate increase could test the relationship sorely. Another rate increase could also further upset members of Congress.

HEADLINE: Clinton Goal: Avoid a War

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
The last thing President Clinton wants this week or this month is a war. Not in Haiti, not in Bosnia, and certainly not in both at the same time -- not while he is struggling to wrest from a recalcitrant Congress a health-care program that will fulfill his campaign promises.
In the minds of Democratic strategists, at least, the political situation comes very close to a matter of life and death: fail on health care, they say, and the President's chances of winning a second term, let alone limiting his party's anticipated losses in the November Congressional elections, will be severely eroded. 
 This morning, in a brazen thumb in the eye, Bosnian Serbs "liberated" one of their tanks and some other heavy weapons from impoundment by the United Nations. The action was followed by a carefully calibrated NATO air strike. But there is little prospect, Administration officials said this afternoon, that the United States will get involved in active, sustained combat as a result.
"This is a momentary flare-up, not a turning point," a senior State Department official said. "We are not about to escalate here."
As in Haiti, Mr. Clinton is trying to use economic and diplomatic activity to bring about the desired result. He has countenanced the occasional military gesture, like today's retaliatory attack by American A-10 bombers, supported by French and Dutch warplanes, on an antitank emplacement. But talk of more concerted military action is mostly just that -- talk, intended to turn up the heat.
"I think it was a good step forward today," Secretary of State Warren Christopher said of the allied response, because it kept the psychological pressure on the Bosnian Serbs to accept the peace proposal they have so far turned down. Drafted by the United States, Russia, Britain, Germany and France, the plan would return some of the Serbian nationalists' conquests to the Bosnian Muslims.
Should the President decide that the national interest requires it, there are plenty of troops and plenty of planes to carry out an invasion of Haiti and a major operation in Bosnia at the same time; cuts in the Pentagon budget have not destroyed the nation's capacity to fight two limited conflicts at once.
Rather it is the political situation that constrains Mr. Clinton.
 
No Room for Error
 "The President is standing on a precipice," said a Democratic Senator friendly to the President. "In the next few weeks, the biggest issue of his term will be decided. To win he needs to focus all his attention, and all the attention of Congress, on health care. It is close enough so that careless errors could cost him the game.
"So he won't go looking for foreign-policy trouble on the Hill."
Though there is no official acknowledgment, the feeling is widespread in Washington that Haiti, the problem in the American backyard, rather than Bosnia, the trouble spot in the European hinterland, holds the higher priority in the Administration's current calculations.
But in fact there is no widespread public clamor for quick American action either in Haiti or in Bosnia.
Mr. Clinton has made no sustained effort to build support for such action, either on Capitol Hill or among the general public, in part because doing so would inevitably detract from his evangelism on behalf of health care. And the Somalia experience has persuaded at least some of his advisers of how important it is to bring Congress and the electorate into line before committing American forces abroad.
The President got conflicting counsel today from senior Senators.
Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, the minority leader, renewed his insistent demands that the United States break with the United Nations by lifting the embargo on arms shipments to the predominantly Muslim Government in Bosnia, which is outgunned by the Bosnian Serbs.
Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, an influential figure on the Armed Services Committee, took a much less interventionist position. He warned in a floor speech that the United States might be "on the verge of a very dangerous move without the American people being consulted."
But in fact, Mr. Clinton has everything to gain from avoiding any bold new steps in Bosnia, at least in the near future, and until he steps forward, the European nations are reluctant to do much about the Balkan problem. In other words, things are stuck in just about the same place they have been for months.
That was evident last weekend in Geneva. Mr. Christopher had promised a tough new approach, but the five nations sponsoring the peace proposal in fact made only the most modest response -- a promise to seek fresh economic sanctions -- to the Bosnian Serbs' repeated rejections of the plan.
They made no threat of air strikes against Bosnian Serb positions, and they critically weakened their comment that lifting the arms embargo "could become unavoidable" by describing such a step as "a last resort." The seizure of heavy weapons by the Bosnian Serbs today, their most aggressive move since last April, demonstrated how little credibility the allied message carried.
Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, returned today to the same formulation -- "a decision by the U.N. to lift the arms embargo could become unavoidable," she said -- and the practical results seem likely to be the same: nil.
