HEADLINE: Protesters Battle Police in Havana; Castro Warns U.S.

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 5 -

 BODY:
In a rare display of political unrest, protesters clashed today with the police and Government supporters on the Havana waterfront and in the hotel zone after a series of boat hijackings by people trying to flee Cuba.
Responding to the riots, President Fidel Castro threatened to let Cubans leave without restriction for the first time since the Mariel boat exodus of 1980, which brought a flood of refugees to the United States. 
 Mr. Castro said that unless the United States stops encouraging people to flee Cuba by sea, "we will stop blocking the departure of those who want to leave the country."
"We cannot continue to guard the coasts of the United States," he said while touring the scene of the clashes. His remarks were carried by the Cuban Government news agency La Prensa, monitored here.
 
Castro Blames U.S.
 Mr. Castro accused American-based radio stations of inspiring the departures and added, "The Government of the United States has a great responsibility in this."
Demonstrators shouting anti-Government slogans confronted Communist Party militants in several places along the waterfront and in the hotel zone shortly after noon today. The Mexican news agency Notimex said the violence apparently erupted when police officers enforced security measures to stop people from stealing boats to flee.
Some people were apparently arrested, but there were no official reports of arrests or injuries, Notimex said.
The official Cuban Government news agency, Prensa Latina, said stores and hotels were attacked and "thousands of Havana workers entered the streets to confront the provocateurs and show their support for the revolution."
 
Increasing Privation
 Struggling on skimpy rations, many Cubans resent the dollar-only stores in some luxury hotels where even soap and simple foods can be too expensive for most citizens.
Mr. Castro also said that hijackers had killed two policemen to seize a ferryboat to flee Cuba on Thursday night, but the agency gave no further details about that incident.
In his remarks, the Cuban President appeared to be threatening a renewal of the Mariel exodus, when Cuba dropped all restrictions on departures and 120,000 people fled to the United States within a few months, causing massive problems for United States officials.
He said the riots were "something that had been organized for a while and the Government of the United States has a great responsibility in this."
The United States grants automatic asylum to any Cuban who reaches its shores.
 
Retaliation Threatened
 Mr. Castro hinted that any further protests would be confronted by the so-called "rapid action brigades" organized by local party committees.
"I believe that for this battle, the masses must be unleashed, because they fear the masses," Mr. Castro said of the protesters.
A Cuban reporter reached by telephone said several hundred people were involved and the clashes involved sticks and stones. Notimex reported that hundreds ran for cover when they heard what sounded like gunshots.
In Washington, a State Department official said a crowd estimated at 20,000 to 30,000 assembled at about 2 P.M. today near the ferry dock in Havana, attracted by rumors that another ferry was being diverted northward.
The Cuban reporter said he had seen hundreds of Cubans gathered on Havana's Malecon waterfront this morning to shout "Adios!" and wave at a small ferry that headed out to sea toward Florida.
 
New Taxes Imposed
 At least three Havana harbor ferries in the last 10 days have been hijacked by departing refugees. Cuba blames the United States for strictly limiting visas while granting exile to people who leave the island illegally.
Notimex said ferry service was suspended this morning and that the police imposed tight security along the harbor.
Efforts to flee the island are at their highest level in years, apparently because of an economic crisis caused by the loss of aid from the former Soviet Union and socialist backers in Europe as well as a United States trade embargo.
On Thursday, Cuba's Parliament approved the most sweeping series of taxes in a quarter century.
The law would impose a 2 percent tax on housing, boats and farms, as well as undisclosed fees on profits, sales and other items.
The Communist Government abolished most taxes 27 years ago, and services have been financed largely out of profits of state companies.

HEADLINE: U.S. Hits Bosnian Serb Target in Air Raid

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Aug. 5

 BODY:
American fighter aircraft attacked a Bosnian Serb anti-tank vehicle near Sarajevo tonight, hours after the Serbs tested NATO's resolve by seizing weapons that had been impounded by United Nations troops and attacking a United Nations helicopter.
The United Nations commander in Bosnia, Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Rose, said he had called for the attack because Serbian nationalist forces violated a NATO order prohibiting heavy weapons in a zone around Sarajevo. This morning Bosnian Serbs seized a T-55 tank, two armored personnel carriers and an anti-aircraft gun from a weapons impoundment area in Ilidza, a Serbian-held town north of the Bosnian capital. 
 General Rose said the pinprick air strike was intended to show the United Nations' concern for the "erosion of the integrity" of the zone. When NATO imposed the zone on Feb. 21, the Serbs were warned they would face air strikes if they did not withdraw or hand over to the United Nations all heavy weaponry positioned around the city.
The air strike was the first executed to enforce the Sarajevo zone. In April, allied jets raided Gorazde, a designated "safe area," after Serbs attacked United Nations personnel there.
 
A Lull, Then a Smattering
 The Sarajevo ultimatum ended a 22-month Serbian bombardment that claimed thousands of lives, but Serbian forces still surround Sarajevo, and recently small-arms fire has increased.
Bosnian Serbs made several attempts this week to withdraw heavy weapons from United Nations sites. General Rose threatened Serbian commanders this week with air strikes if weapons were seized.
"We don't regard the weapons-collection sites as some sort of supermarket," General Rose said in a news conference tonight. "There is a limit to how much infringement on that total exclusion zone we can accept."
Adm. Leighton W. Smith, NATO's commander in southern Europe, said at a briefing in Naples, Italy, that two American A-10 ground attack aircraft operating out of Aviano Air Base in northern Italy fired 600 cannon rounds at a Serbian anti-tank weapon in a sparsely populated area about eight miles south of Sarajevo, well within the 12.3-mile zone. The target was destroyed, he said.
General Rose said he received a message one hour after this evening's air strike from Gen. Manojlo Milovanovic, the No. 2 officer in the Bosnian Serb army, promising the immediate return of all Serbian heavy weapons inside the exclusion zone.
The Serbs returned the armored personnel carriers, but General Rose warned that he might call for air strikes on Saturday if the tank and a mobile anti-aircraft gun were not returned.
"I merely called a pause in the NATO operation," he said. "I expect these weapons to be withdrawn."
But the general did not impose a deadline for the return, saying, "the Balkans are the Balkans."
United Nations officials here said the anti-tank gun hit was not one seized from the compound, but was one of four targets chosen because they are far from populated areas. Cloudy weather prevented aircraft from engaging the other targets, the general said.
General Rose said he gave the Serbs a one-hour warning.
Pentagon officials said Dutch F-16 and French Mirage fighters escorted the A-10's. Each A-10 carries a 30-millimeter cannon capable of firing 3,900 depleted uranium rounds per minute.
Serbs drove some of the seized weapons to Semizovac and reportedly parked them near a school and hospital to shield them from an air attack, the authorities said.
At about 6 A.M., small-arms fire by Serbs struck a French Puma helicopter dispatched to find the stolen weapons. The crew was uninjured.
United Nations officials said they were investigating how the Serbs made off with the heavy weapons while the Ilidza center was being guarded by about 30 Ukrainian soldiers. A mortar was seized from the site this afternoon, General Rose said, adding that a soldier was injured in the incident.
 
Provocation and Sympathy
 Western diplomats here said the Serbs' seizing the weapons was a calculated attempt to provoke the United Nations and NATO to retaliate, probably in an effort to gain public sympathy from Serbia a day after Serbia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, ordered political and economic ties between Serbia and the Bosnian Serbs to be cut. His move was an effort to distance his country from the Bosnian Serbs, who have rejected the latest international peace plan for Bosnia.
Today, the Serbian police reportedly stopped hundreds of trucks from crossing from Serbia into Bosnia, and telephone connections were severed.
The United Nations has imposed economic sanctions on Serbia as punishment for its support of the Bosnian Serbs, and additional sanctions are being contemplated if the Bosnian Serbs continue to defy the international mediators.
Today's weapons seizure by the Bosnian Serbs also appeared to be a reaction to a Bosnian Government offensive that could break the siege of Sarajevo. The Bosnian Army has been trying to loosen the Serbs' grip on a swath of territory between Sarajevo and the Bosnian Army-controlled town of Visoko. The area is the most vulnerable point of the Serbian siege and has been the scene of fierce fighting throughout the 28-month war, including heavy shelling and rocket attacks this week.
United Nations officials say that by attacking south of Visoko, the Bosnian Army is exploiting the NATO exclusion zone around Sarajevo in.
"The configuration of the exclusion zone creates a tactical weakness for the Bosnian Serbs," a United Nations military officer said. "The Bosnian Army can use heavy weapons outside the zone to pound in. But the Serbs cannot have heavy weapons there."
The Visoko area has become more sensitive in recent weeks because Bosnian Army construction crews have carved out an airstrip just northwest of the town that is or will soon be capable of handling large cargo aircraft.
 
New Arms Pathway
 Badly outgunned by the Serbs at the beginning of the war, the Bosnian Government has widened its arms pipeline since it struck a deal with Croatia in the spring. Weapons shipments now arrive in Bosnia from the Dalmatian coast of Croatia. But the widespread rumor in Sarajevo is that the Croats receive one-third of each shipment. If the Bosnian Government is able to defy a United Nations-imposed ban on flights over Bosnia and open the new airstrip for arms deliveries, it could tip the balance of firepower in the war.
One Bosnian Army officer said that some aircraft carrying weapons have already landed at the airstrip.
Bosnian Army forces have advanced this week on a plateau southeast of Vares. Bosnian Army officials said they were trying to secure a main road between Sarajevo and Olovo.
A Bosnian officer said that the army was close to securing the plateau, which could be used to mount an advance southward toward Sarajevo.
United Nations officials, however, say they doubt that the Bosnian Army, suffering low morale and exhaustion, could succeed at the task.

Cronology: "Chronology of NATO in Bosnia"
July 1992 -- Agrees to use naval force in Adriatic to review compliance with U.N. sanctions imposed on Sebia and Montenegro, which make up Yugoslavia.
 
October 1992 -- Agrees to use surveillance aircraft to monitor U.N. ban on flights over Bosnia.
 
April 1993 -- Begins combat air patrols over Bosnia to enforce compliance with U.N. troops and other personnel in Bosnia.
 
August 1993 -- Threatens air strikes against Bosnian Serb forces attacking Sarajevo.
 
February 1994 -- Orders Serbs to withdraw heavy weapons from around Sarajevo or hand them over to U.N. control or face air strikes. The Serbs comply. Shoots down four Serbian light attack aircraft that violate the U.N. ban on flights over Bosnia.
 
April 1994 -- Launches two air strikes against Serbian forces around Gorazde to protect U.N. personnel.
 
August 1994 -- Hits Serbian heavy weapons violating exclusion zone around Sarajevo after Serbs remove arms from arms from a U.N. weapons depot.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
The economy continued to produce jobs at a brisk pace in July, causing drops in financial markets as investors feared the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates again soon to prevent any increase in inflation. Employment grew by 259,000 jobs last month while average hourly earnings rose 4 cents, to $11.12. President Clinton welcomed the news, saying that nonfarm employment had now risen by 4.1 million jobs since he took office, half of the 8 million jobs that he promised to create during his first term. [Page 1.] While the national unemployment rate for July rose to 6.1 percent from 6 percent in June, New Jersey's unemployment rate dropped to 6.4 percent from 7.1; New York State's edged up to 7.1 percent from 7 percent, while New York City's jobless rate climbed to 8.8 percent from 8.5 percent. [44.]
The White House is doing little to fight protectionist provisions in the legislation Congress must pass to underpin the new GATT pact, say many who wish to bring down trade barriers. [33.]
U.S. monetary authorities bought a total of $2.81 billion through the sale of German marks and Japanese yen in May and June to support the dollar. [42.]
 
Companies
The F.C.C. sternly admonished high bidders at its recent auction for slices of the broadcast spectrum to meet their obligations when their 10 percent down payments are due Monday. [33.]
Nextel agreed in separate stock deals valued at $2.4 billion to acquire Dial Page, a wireless operator in the Southeast, and the remaining American wireless licenses owned by Motorola. [33.]
Simon Property will buy 19 regional shopping malls and a management company for $1 billion from Equitable. [35.]
Fund American Enterprises said it had received a proposal to buy its Source One Mortgage Services unit. [35.]
 
International
Millions of Chinese have learned a lesson about how quickly prices can climb, collapse and climb again on what has become one of the most volatile stock markets in the developing world. [33.]
Brazil has become the South American magnet for computer companies from around the world; many have set up local production, with the broader Latin American market in mind. [33.]
 
Markets
Stocks fell on fears of another rate increase. The Dow dropped 18.77 points, to close at 3,747.02. [34.]
Prices of Treasury securities tumbled after the monthly employment numbers for July showed the economy adding jobs at a fast pace. The 30-year bond fell 114/32 of a point, to 8428/32 , for a yield of 7.54 percent. [41.]
The dollar fell against most major currencies after the bond market's sharp decline. [42.]
Oil prices plunged after a Nigerian court ordered the release of a politician whose imprisonment had set off strikes that crippled oil production in the West African nation. [42.]
 
Your Money
A new business structure that is taking the accounting profession by storm is also being recommended for a host of businesses. Called a limited liability company or limited liability partnership, the structure assures owners or partners that their personal assets will be protected if their businesses are sued. [30.]
New York City's Public Advocate wants mutual fund companies to adopt a new, standardized label that would summarize a fund's goals, strategies, risks and costs. [30.]
Adjustable-rate mortgages are making a comeback, thanks to their modest rate increases, a spate of new loan products and heightened competition among lenders. [31.]

HEADLINE: New Jersey's Jobless Rate Fell in July

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
New Jersey's unemployment rate dropped to 6.4 percent in July from 7.1 in June, while the rates in nearby states and for the nation were rising, the Labor Department reported today.
 The national unemployment rate rose to 6.1 percent from 6 percent in June. The rate in New York State edged up to 7.1 percent from 7 percent, while Pennsylvania's rate rose to 6.5 percent from 5.9 percent. 
 In addition, New York City's unemployment rate rose to 8.8 percent from 8.5 percent.
 
Governor Is 'Delighted'
 Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey expressed some cautious skepticism over the size of the decline in the state's rate, but she said it provided evidence that her program to reduce the state budget and cut income tax rates was working.
 "Obviously, I'm delighted," the Governor said. "I'm always a little concerned when there's that big a jump, even though it's in the right direction.
 "I'm assured from all the discussions I've had with labor that this a real trend. I hope we can sustain it, and certainly our position relative to surrounding states shows that we're doing something right."
 Peter J. Calderone, New Jersey's Labor Commissioner, called the statistics "unqualified good news," even though the state's unemployment rate was still higher than the national average. He said employment and labor force figures were up, as was consumer spending, while the number of business failures had declined.
 
Retail Sales Up 8.5%
 Mr. Calderone said the state's monthly survey of employers showed that the economy was generating jobs faster than it did last year and was outpacing gains in Connecticut, New York and Pennsylvania.
 In addition, he said, retail sales for the first five months of the year were up 8.5 percent from a year earlier, indicating a stronger employment picture.
 Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of labor statistics for the United States Labor Department, said the slow recovery of the New Jersey economy was "picking up steam."
 He said the employer survey earlier this year and the household survey that forms the basis for the latest figures both indicated "that more people are looking for jobs and getting them."
 But he warned, "The state's economy has been lagging for a long time and its problems are not yet over."
 
Factory Employment Stable
 Mr. Ehrenhalt said the bright spots in the New Jersey employment picture continued to be the service industry and construction jobs, along with increases in trade and financial employment. "In addition, factory employment, which had been declining for a long time, has been relatively stable since last winter," he said.
 There were 261,000 unemployed New Jersey residents in July, a slight drop from 284,000 in June. The number employed in July was 3.79 million, compared with 3.72 million in June.
 In July, the number of people employed in New York State rose to its highest point this year, 8,110,000, while 620,000 people were unemployed.
 Although the unemployment rate was up in New York City, the actual number of people employed in the city increased to 3,010,000 in July from 2,972,000 in June. There were 292,000 people out of work last month.

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: BEHIND THE SCENES;
With Long Hours and Little Fanfare, Staff Members Created a Health Bill

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
The ambitious health care bill going soon to the floor of the House of Representatives is called the Gephardt bill, in honor of the majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri. But it is really the work of the Democratic staff of the House Ways and Means Committee.
The staff includes a half-dozen experts on health policy, people who have years of experience analyzing how to regulate health costs, how to pay doctors and hospitals, how to provide care to more people. 
 The members of this elite group did not need a throng of advisers, like the 500 assembled last year by Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, to tutor them on the intricacies of health policy. For more than a decade, the largely anonymous committee staff had been studying ways to overhaul the health care system, weighing options and drafting legislation.
In the Senate and the House, scores of Congressional aides are toiling behind the scenes, trying to shape health care legislation to address the concerns of constituents or lobbyists. The basic process is the same as with other legislation and other committees, but the health care legislation dwarfs other bills in its scope and complexity.
The leader of the health care specialists on the Ways and Means staff is David S. Abernethy, a shaggy-haired man of 44, with drooping mustache and wire-rimmed glasses. In a sense, his entire professional life has been preparation for his current role.
"I am one person who is sitting in the right place at the right time for what we are trying to do," he said. "I started more than 20 years ago at the Haight-Ashbury free clinic in San Francisco, trying to provide health care to people who couldn't pay for it. I believe in this agenda."
The health specialists work for the full Ways and Means Committee, but much of their day-to-day labor is for the chairman of the panel's health subcommittee, Representative Pete Stark, Democrat of California. The relationship is intense, with continual brainstorming, hundreds of questions and answers and endless demands for instant facts.
"It has been like one long therapy group in which the leading technique is the primal scream," Mr. Stark said.
Many features of Mr. Gephardt's bill, like the expansion of Medicare to cover millions of people who are poor or uninsured, emerged from Mr. Stark's subcommittee.
In the last few weeks, the health specialists have also worked directly for Mr. Gephardt, helping him write the bill that he unveiled last week with the imprimatur of the House Democratic leadership. When the bill reaches the House floor, the staff will be busier than ever, crunching numbers and answering questions as lawmakers offer amendments.
The Gephardt bill differs from the Clinton proposal in many ways. It relies less on new, untested institutions; builds more on the foundation of Medicare and relies less on states and more on the Federal Government. In all those respects, the House bill reflects the priorities of Mr. Stark and his staff.
 
Knowing the Subject
 Even people who disagree with staff members respect them for their knowledge and thoroughness.
Charles N. Kahn 3d, executive vice president of the Health Insurance Association of America, which represents commercial insurers, said: "I see these people as classic Ways and Means staffers. They work for what is probably the most powerful committee in Congress. They understand the heavy responsibility that lies on them. All of them are people of strong views. But they are hardened professionals and probably know more about health than any other group of people on Capitol Hill."
Mr. Kahn, a Republican who worked for the committee from 1986 to 1993, often disagrees with Democrats on the staff. But he said: "These are the best people I ever worked with. They know the issues. They know the law. They worry about the details because the bills they write often become law."
Mr. Abernethy, the son of an ophthalmologist in San Mateo, Calif., has a master's degree in public health from Yale University and worked for seven years as a senior official in the New York State Health Department. Such state government experience is rare among Congressional aides.
The Ways and Means staff also includes Patricia H. Neuman, who has a doctorate from the Johns Hopkins University School of Hygiene and Public Health and worked for three years for the Senate Special Committee on Aging; James A. Reuter, a veteran of the Congressional Research Service who received a doctorate from Johns Hopkins in 1977, and Lisa Potetz, who has worked for the Senate Finance Committee, the Congressional Budget Office and an agency that advises Congress on payments to hospitals under Medicare.
Also on the staff are Ellen Magrini, a lawyer from Chicago, and Dr. Eric Trupin, a child psychologist from Seattle, who helped design the mental health benefits in the bill going to the House floor.
The role of the staff in conceiving and molding legislation is difficult to explain. The staff is continually engaged in a dialogue with lawmakers. "It's a very symbiotic relationship," Mr. Abernethy said. Ideas swirl in a creative jumble that he described as "a marble cake."
Mr. Abernethy said he knows "the loneliness of the minority health staff" because he worked several years in the late 1970's for Tim Lee Carter of Kentucky, who was then the ranking Republican on the Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Health. "Back then," Mr. Abernethy said, "health care was more bipartisan, mainly because the Republicans were less conservative than they are today."
Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of Connecticut, often quarrels with Mr. Stark. Of the staff, she said: "They are very smart, very competent, but they do come at the subject with a strong ideological bias. The way that bent affects minority members of Congress, particularly members who take a different view, is this: They are not anxious to give you information that undercuts the bill their boss is trying to get through the committee.
"Unless you ask exactly the right question," Mrs. Johnson said, "you don't necessarily get the information that you and the public need. Committee members, Democrat and Republican, don't get to see the total picture."
In response to such criticism, Mr. Abernethy said, "We are not paid to be bipartisan." But he hastily added, "We are not paid to lie or to miscast issues or to be unprofessional in presenting information."
 
Barrage of Lobbying
 Congressman Stark said of his staff: "They just don't come any better. They have no equal in any Federal agency or any committee on Capitol Hill. No one in the United States is more familiar with, or has been more active in designing, the health care reform package."
As a result, the staff members have been popular targets for lobbyists and interest groups trying to shape the outcome of the health debate.
"They're always in here making their case to us as a first line of attack," Ms. Neuman said. She said lobbyists have often tried to resolve issues with the staff, avoiding public fights in committee rooms or on the House floor.
Ms. Neuman said she has had "an unbelievable amount of contact with lobbyists" seeking insurance coverage for medical benefits as diverse as dental care, psychotherapy and chiropractic.
Many people, including Mr. Stark, suspect that Mr. Abernethy secretly favors a Canadian-style health system in which the Government would pay all medical bills. But Mr. Abernethy insisted that "I am not a closet single-payer advocate."
He said that as the son of a doctor, "I grew up thinking that Medicare was socialized medicine and that the worst possible thing in the world was government-financed medicine."
His sister, Janet E. Abernethy, chief executive of an ambulance company in Sacramento, Calif., said that their father, Dr. Rodney Abernethy, "felt people had a right of access to health care, and he instilled that view in us." He was one of the few ophthalmologists in San Mateo County who took Medicaid patients, she said, and he organized trips to provide free eye care to poor people in Latin America.
As a state official in New York, David Abernethy gained extensive experience in health planning and the regulation of hospital costs. Unlike many economists and Republican politicians, he has never seen free-market competition as a cure for the ills of the nation's health care system.
Today, he said, he likes the idea of expanding Medicare to serve as a safety net for people who have no other source of health insurance. But that, he said, is much different from having the Government as the sole source of payment for all care.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Committee staff members are pivotal in developing legislation. Four major players in the Gephardt health care bill were David S. Abernethy, left, James A. Reuter, Ellen Magrini and Patricia H. Neuman. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Off Sharply On Jobs Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities tumbled yesterday after the monthly employment numbers for July showed the economy adding jobs at a fast pace, once again raising investor fears of inflation. And the data could turn out to be a pivotal factor if the Fed decides to raise rates again.
 The Labor Department reported that last month's payrolls rose a higher-than-expected 259,000, with hourly earnings rebounding by 4 cents, to $11.12, also higher than expected. The average workweek was unchanged and the unemployment rate edged higher, to 6.1 percent.
 
 In response, the Treasury's 30-year bond fell 114/32 , to 8428/32 , or about $14.37 for each $1,000 of face value. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, jumped to 7.54 percent from 7.40 percent. It was the highest closing yield since July 27, when it was 7.61 percent.
 Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said, "The Fed will tighten in the very near future because it cannot afford the risk of an overheated economy."
 "Given that a tightening will take place," he added, "the first question is when? And Aug. 16, when the Fed conducts its Federal Open Market Committee meeting, is the most likely time period."
 There is some question in the market as to whether the Fed might act before the meeting, but analysts say the policy makers will be tempted to wait because they will be getting a great deal more economic information in coming days. Between now and Aug. 16 there will be new data on producer prices, consumer prices, retail sales, business inventories, the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment readings, industrial production, capacity utilization and housing starts.
 As to how far the Fed might move, Mr. Fine said, "At this juncture, a move of 50 basis points would seem proper to insure that the economy slows to its long-run noninflationary growth path, but with the housing and auto sectors showing signs of slowing, the Federal Open Market Committee may well choose to move a quarter of a percentage point now and thus have more time to analyze future data before acting further."
 The average rise of 300,000 in payroll jobs in each of the last five months and the acceleration in wage growth suggest a healthy momentum in the economy. And analysts say the Fed's worry now is that a lack of tightening would damage its credibility as an inflation fighter.
 
Worries About Statistics
 James P. Hale, an analyst with MMS International, observed that the sharp gains in nonfarm payrolls had not been matched by similar increases in household employment. "And given the difficulties with adjusting the new household survey, the Bureau of Labor officials are clearly putting more weight on the payroll data," he said.
 "In fact, the officials are worried that the current divergence might suggest that in September and October there will be a monstrous increase" in household employment, Mr. Hale said, adding, "If so, the Fed can look forward to the unemployment rate dipping in the mid-5 percent area and can expect to hear accusations that they are well behind in the tighening cycle."
 The Fed's last rate increase was on May 17, when it moved to raise both the discount rate, which is what it charges banks for loans, and the Federal funds rate, which is what banks charge one another for overnight loans. The Fed has raised the Federal funds rate four times this year.
 The increase in hourly wages in July was of particular interest, Mr. Hale said, given the Fed's concern about rising pressures on wages. Although the July rise followed a slight decline in June, he said the overall wage trend was clearly upward.
 "With slack in the labor market diminishing rapidly, the potential for future wage pressures is substantial," Mr. Hale said. "Wages are generally viewed as a lagging inflation indicator, so the urgency for the Fed to tighten is now much greater."
 
A Forecast of Lower Rates
 Jane Tedder, vice president and senior portfolio manager at the Security Management Company in Topeka, Kan., said the employment data did not change her longer-term outlook on bonds. "We have been anticipating that interest rates would move down between now and year end," Ms. Tedder said. "If anything, this could speed up the process."
 Her point was that a rate increase by the Fed on the shorter maturities would be positive for bonds with longer maturities. "But I will keep my seat belt tightened, because this is likely to be a bumpy ride," she said.
 Next week, the Treasury will offer debt securities as part of its quarterly refunding. In when-issued trading late yesterday, the three-year note, to be offered on Tuesday, was priced to yield 6.57 percent, while the 10-year note, scheduled for Wednesday, was priced to yield 7.25 percent. The yield for the 30-year bond, to be auctioned Thursday, was 7.43 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls, Taking Its Cue From Treasury Securities

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most major currencies yesterday, after a Government report showing stronger-than-expected employment growth drove the bond market down sharply.
 Steady in overnight trading, the dollar rose just after the Labor Department said the economy added 259,000 jobs in July, convincing many traders that the economy is strong enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to push up interest rates. Higher rates can make dollar-denominated deposits more attractive.
 
 But the dollar quickly gave up its gains after prices of Treasury securities tumbled, renewing speculation that overseas investors were selling dollar-denominated investments. The July employment report raised concerns in the bond market that inflationary pressures were rising.
 "The dollar rose, then looked over its shoulder and saw that the bonds were writhing in agony," said David De Rosa, director of foreign-exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation. "The bond market is taking this as a catastrophe."
 The Labor Department reported that nonfarm payrolls rose last month by 259,000, exceeding analysts' estimates of about 200,000, and that hourly wages rose.
 In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.5802 German marks, down from 1.5882 marks on Thursday. It had risen as high as 1.5915 marks just after the employment report was released yesterday morning. The dollar also fell to 100.25 Japanese yen from 100.55 yen.
 Currency traders look to the bond and stock markets for signs of whether dollar-denominated investments are in demand by overseas investors. Yesterday, they were not.
 "There isn't much aggressive buying of Treasury bonds from overseas investors," said Chris Iggo, international economist at the Chase Manhattan Bank. As long as that's the case, the dollar will be vulnerable to selloffs, he said.
 Even after yesterday's slump, the dollar remained well within the week's trading range against major currencies. Mr. Iggo and others do not expect the dollar to stray far from current levels until the Fed's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee meets on Aug. 16.
 "There's no direction for the dollar at the moment," Mr. Iggo said. "Most people expect the Fed's next move will be to raise rates."
 Meanwhile, the British pound rose to $1.5420 in New York yesterday from $1.5365, while the Canadian dollar was little changed at 72.11 United States cents.
 And the dollar slipped to 5.4100 French francs from 5.4340 francs, to 1.3336 Swiss francs from 1.3406 francs, and to 1,576 Italian lire from 1,585 lire.

HEADLINE: July Employment Data Spur Decline in Stocks

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stock prices fell again yesterday after a stronger-than-expected report on July employment increased speculation that the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates for a fifth time this year.
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 18.77 points to close at 3,747.02. It ended the week off 17.48 points. Broader market indicators also declined. But trading volume was moderate.
 
 Analysts said the July unemployment rate was on target at 6.1 percent, against the previous month's 6.0 percent. But nonfarm payrolls posted a larger-than-expected gain of 259,000. Wall Street had been looking for an increase of about 200,000. Adding to traders' concerns about inflation was an increase in hourly wages.
 The Government's report set off a sharp selloff in the bond market, pushing interest rates higher. The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond climbed to 7.54 percent, from 7.40 percent on Thursday.
 
Credit-Tightening Speculation
 While analysts said the July employment report did not seem to be enough by itself to push the Fed to raise rates, it nonetheless had investors doubting recent speculation that a credit tightening was not in the works.
 "It just creates that uncertainty, and therefore people are just as nervous as cats on a hot tin roof," said Ned Collins, head of United States equity trading for Diawa Securities.
 The Fed's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee is scheduled to meet on Aug. 16, so the financial markets will be focusing on other economic data, including July producer and consumer price reports next Thursday and Friday.
 Still, some analysts played down the impact of yesterday's employment report on the stock market. David Holt, director of technical research at Wedbush Morgan, said he thought traders had used the report as an excuse to continue the market's selloff on Thursday, when the Dow fell 26.87 points.
 "It's not a climactic day," Mr. Holt said.
 Fears of higher interest rates pulled down some issues that are particularly sensitive to slowdowns in the economy. Caterpillar fell 2 7/8, to 104 3/4, even after shareholders approved a 2-for-1 stock split effective Aug. 9. International Paper declined1/2, to 74 3/8.
 But Scientific-Atlanta Inc. surged 4 3/4, to 39, after the telecommunications equipment company's earnings soundly beat analysts' forecasts.
 Nextel Communications jumped 1 1/8, to 26 3/4, in Nasdaq trading on news that it had reached a merger deal with Dial Page Inc. and was buying Motorola Inc.'s remaining United States specialized mobile radio licenses.
 Dial Page slipped 1 3/8, to 30 5/8, and Motorola finished up 1/8, to 52 5/8. The news raised other wireless communications stocks, including Onecomm, which rose 1 5/8, to 26 7/8.
 Fund American Enterprises Holdings climbed 3 7/8, to 74 7/8, after it said it had received an unsolicited bid for its Source One Mortgage Service Corporation subsidiary.
 In the broader market, declining issues led advances, 1,341 to 794, on New York Stock Exchange volume of 230.3 million shares.
 The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks fell 1.31 points, to 457.09. The American Stock Exchange index was off 1.01, to 440.34. And the Nasdaq index was off 1.51, to 718.67.
 The Big Board's composite index lost 0.77, to 252.50.
 In Tokyo, Japanese stocks ended lower yesterday. The Nikkei index of 225 issues slipped 155.14 points, to 20,521.70.

HEADLINE: An End Run on GATT

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
The White House fights to open trade; Congress fights to close it. Or at least that's the way it has been for the last half a century -- and the way it was when the Clinton Administration did battle to win passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement last year.
 But to the surprise and anguish of many who wish to bring down trade barriers, the White House is doing little to fight protectionist provisions in the legislation that must be enacted to underpin the new GATT pact. Indeed, key Administration players on trade seem bent on including what Gary Hufbauer, an economist at the Institute for International Economics, calls "tools of choice for protectionists" in the bill expected to emerge from a House-Senate conference committee early next week.
 
 No member of the Administration and few knowledgeable members of Congress were prepared to talk about the unfolding negotiations on the record. But it is possible to piece together what is happening from background discussions.
In part, argues Representative Bill Archer, a Republican from Texas who specializes on trade issues and sits on the conference committee, the Administration's stance on the so-called anti-dumping provision reflects its "inclination to listen to protectionists allied with the Democratic Party." Industries including steel, autos and semiconductors have become expert at using the law against dumping, or importing goods below what is considered fair value, and they view the enabling legislation for GATT as an opportunity to increase their leverage.
 But the Administration's position is apparently also a product of skillful maneuvering by opponents of free trade within the White House. The Commerce Department's International Trade Administration, which often sees its primary task as reducing competition from foreign producers, has formed an alliance with the tiny but influential Office of the United States Trade Representative.
 And the two agencies so far have blunted the power of free traders in the Treasury and the Office of Management and Budget. Treasury officials would not comment for the record, nor would economic analysts at the White House or at the Commerce Department.
 To deliver on the promises in the new pact of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, each country that signs the pact must change its laws to conform. And under the so-called fast track provisions of American trade law, the revised laws, written by Congressional committees with a lot of help from the White House, are voted up or down in the House and Senate -- no amendments allowed.
 That narrows the room for give and take, and for politics as usually practiced. The legislation presumably cannot stray far from what was initialed in Geneva. And where there is room for interpretation, all deals must be cut in committee. Still, this reality has not guaranteed the measure an easy ride.
 Trade experts expected tough bargaining on ancillary issues, ranging from how to recoup Government revenues lost from reduced tariffs to the extension of the fast track approval mechanism for future trade accords. What caught lobbyists working for major American exporters by surprise was the fierce attack on the letter and spirit of the pact itself -- and what the free traders contend is the cooperation of the Administration with the attackers.
 Until the 1980's, domestic industries sought protection from import competition under a variety of statutes. But in the last decade the Commerce Department, the agency with wide discretion to decide whether foreigners are indeed selling goods below cost or fair value, has increasingly viewed itself as a defender of those fighting imports. And by no coincidence, Mr. Hufbauer suggests, those seeking import relief have leaned increasingly on the anti-dumping laws.
 
Battle on Several Fronts
 The Commerce Department, which dominated the American negotiating position at the GATT talks, fought against provisions that would weaken its authority. And what it lost at Geneva, it has reportedly sought to regain -- or even toughen -- through the GATT enabling legislation.
 To do that, the department needed allies beyond the protectionist lobbies in Congress. And it found one in the Office of the Trade Representative, which under Mickey Kantor has expanded its role beyond the standard one of serving as the negotiator for others in the White House.
 Together the two allies reportedly neutralized opponents in the Treasury and the Office of Management and Budget, powerful agencies that generally support open trade but have bigger policy fish to fry at the moment. The result, argues Gary Horlick, a lawyer who represents a coalition of export-minded businesses including Cargill, Caterpillar, I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard, was an Administration trade bill with the "most protectionist anti-dumping measures since the 1930's."
 Those measures require patience and generous amounts of caffeine to comprehend. But the basic principle of protection -- giving American companies a better chance in their home market -- is one that strikes a chord with most Americans. An example of what the Administration did not want in the bill makes the point.
 
Seeking an Exception
 Republicans on both the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee asked for an amendment allowing the Administration to waive anti-dumping penalties when domestic producers could not supply adequate quantities to meet domestic demand. The idea was to avoid situations like the fiasco involving flat-panel computer displays in 1992, when American computer makers had to move production offshore so they could get color screens for laptops without paying anti-dumping duties. But the Commerce Department lobbied strongly against the waiver provision and managed to defeat it in both committees.
 Some flatly deny the new interpretation of Administration actions. "We take our GATT obligations very seriously," said a senior Administration official who insisted on anonymity, adding, "we are implementing the Uruguay Round" the best way the Administration knows how. And Administration supporters and even some of its critics say that where compromises have come, they have come as a result of domestic realpolitick, to preserve the possibility of having any bill at all.
 Lobbyists for major exporters are still hoping to rally support within the White House to soften the Administration line on dumping. And Republicans, who have been shouldering the free trade burden, haven't quite given up the fight. But Representative Archer concedes that he needs "the strong hand of the Administration to prevent the bill from moving away from the spirit of Geneva."

HEADLINE: More Bought On Credit

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve reported today that consumer credit rose in June for a 15th straight month.
 Borrowing increased $10.9 billion in June after rising $11.5 billion in the previous month. The May figure was revised upward from an earlier estimate of $10.4 billion.
 
 The June credit figure exceeded the expectations of analysts. But Sandra Shaber, an economist at the WEFA Group, a forecasting service in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., said the healthy employment picture, as evidenced by a report by the Labor Department today, suggests that Americans are not borrowing excessively.
 "If we look at the whole picture, if we look at the debt-to-income ratio, borrowing is rising very slowly," she said. "People are borrowing in line with income growth. The ratio is below 17 percent. It had reached 19 percent before the recession started in 1990."
 The Commerce Department reported Monday that consumer spending rose a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in June, matching the May increase. Retail sales were up six-tenths of a percent in June.
 Consumer spending represents about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. Consumer credit includes all household debt not secured by real estate, like home equity loans and mortgages.
 The latest rise in borrowing brought outstanding debt to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $849.6 billion in June, up from $838.7 billion in May.
 Auto loans rose at an 18.8 percent annual rate, to $301.2 billion, after a 15.7 percent rise in May. Credit card borrowing climbed 15.5 percent, to $312.6 billion, after increasing 15.7 percent in May. Other forms of credit, including loans for mobile homes, education, boats, trailers and vacations, was up 11.6 percent to $235.9 billion, on top of a 17.9 percent advance in May.

HEADLINE: Japan Trade Surplus Rises

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 5

 BODY:
Japan's current account surplus rose 4.7 percent in June and was up 2.2 percent for the first half of the year, to a record $68.78 billion, the Finance Ministry said today.
 The current account is a broad measure of a nation's international economic flows and includes merchandise trade.
 
 For June, Japan's current account surplus rose 4.7 percent, to $11.11 billion, and officials said exports of ships helped lift the figure.
 The surplus for the first half was the biggest ever for any six-month period in part because of the high value of the yen against the United States dollar.
 In yen terms, the current account surplus for the January-June period was down 6.7 percent, but it was up 9.7 percent when measured in dollars because of the yen's 22.6 percent rise against the dollar since January 1993.
 It is expected the higher yen will eventually reduce Japan's surplus by forcing exporters to raise their overseas prices, making their products less attractive. At the same time, a stronger yen would theoretically encourage imports by making them cheaper in Japan.

HEADLINE: Panel Clears Fed Nominee

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5

 BODY:
President Clinton's nomination of the economist Janet L. Yellen to the Federal Reserve Board was endorsed today by the Senate Banking Committee by a vote of 18 to 1.
 Her confirmation, which is expected by the full Senate before Congress recesses later this month, would bring the seven-member board to full strength for the first time since mid-February, when the resignations of David W. Mullins Jr. and Wayne D. Angell took effect.
 
 Alan S. Blinder, a former member of Mr. Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers, was sworn in as vice chairman of the Fed in June.
 Mr. Blinder and Ms. Yellen are viewed as less likely to favor raising interest rates to quell inflation and slightly more likely to cut rates to stimulate growth than the five Republican appointees on the board.
 The only member of the committee who voted against the nomination, Senator Lauch Faircloth, Republican from North Carolina, told Ms. Yellen at the confirmation hearing that he was impressed with her academic credentials but would have preferred the President to have nominated someone with more experience in business. Ms. Yellen, 47, is a professor at the University of California at Berkeley.

HEADLINE: Inflation Index Is Up

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
A preliminary inflation index for July from the Center for International Business Cycle Research rose to 109.1 from a revised 108.9 in June, people familiar with the report said yesterday. The June index was revised down from a preliminary 109.2. The index rose seven straight months before leveling off in June. The index is closely watched by the financial markets because the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, is said to follow it. The index does not forecast the size of price increases, just that they will occur, and has a lag time of about six months. The research center is based at the Columbia Business School.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
New Choices in Bonds, Gold and Real Estate

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
The new Franklin/Templeton Strategic Income Fund aims for income by investing in issues of the United States and foreign governments, junk bonds, mortgage-backed securities, preferred stocks and convertible securities. Strategic income funds are a form of one-stop shopping, providing bond investors broad exposure around the world. But given the possibilities of currency moves, economic changes or political shifts in the issuing countries, the fund's share price may be volatile.
The Gabelli Gold Fund is managed by Caesar Bryan, who recently resigned from Lexington's Goldfund and Strategic Investments fund. The Lexington Strategic fund was the best-performing mutual fund in 1993, as Mr. Bryan nimbly rode rising gold prices. His fund was highly leveraged to gold, making share prices volatile; witness Strategic's 11.7 percent decline in the first six months of 1994.
 
 The Columbia Real Estate Equity Fund is part of a boom in realty funds. The fund aims for capital appreciation and income by buying equity in real estate companies. It plans to own mainly real estate investment trusts, which are publicly traded, and a strong performance will be predicated mostly on a turnaround in the real estate market.

HEADLINE: Progress in Midtown

 BODY:
Times Square is another step closer to renewal, and none too soon. It has been 10 years since New York City and the state's Urban Development Corporation struck their first deal with developers, and twice as long since a neighborhood priest organized community pressure to clean out the area's crime and sleaze.
From the beginning, this project has been a magnet for controversy, particularly its soaring office towers at the intersection of Broadway and 42d Street. Construction of the towers is now on hold, because the last thing midtown Manhattan needs is four new empty skyscrapers. But plans for upgrading the once tawdry, now deserted block between Broadway and Eighth Avenue are well underway. 
 The 1993 deadline for starting construction of the towers was lifted two years ago in a tentative agreement that has now been completed in detail. Final official approval is expected by mid-October, but the developers -- the Prudential Insurance Company of America and Park Tower Realty -- are to start removing debris from condemned buildings in the project area right away.
Until construction begins, maybe in the next four or five years, maybe much later, there will be "interim" development, a halfway concept that involves creating new stores, eateries, bright lights and other diversions that the developers can shut down when they want to start building.
The developers have been at odds with state and city officials over how glitzy the immediate development should be. This reflects a natural tension between developers who are more interested in filling office space from 9 to 5, and the public authorities focused on creating a lively street scene for fun-seeking locals and tourists, day and night.
Times Square's trademark billboard neon and flashing lights were a big sticking point in the final round of negotiations. Signs like those are expensive. As an advertising medium, they are old-fashioned. But they are Times Square, and the developers have finally been persuaded to pay for them.
One conspicuous critic, the Municipal Art Society, is so scornful of the project's overall financing that it advocates, even at this late date, negotiating a new deal. Financial calculations apart, officials fear that further delay in a project that has already survived 47 lawsuits would risk losing the interest that Walt Disney, Warner Brothers, Madame Tussaud and others have shown in establishing themselves on a renewed 42d Street.
The street has come a long way since that first community protest in the early 1970's. It still has a long way to go -- the faster the better.

HEADLINE: Yankees Aren't to Blame for State of the Bronx

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Bombing in the Bronx" (Op-Ed, July 26): I do not disagree with all of Matt Bai's points, but he wrongly gives much of the blame to the New York Yankees for the moral and social decay not only of the area surrounding Yankee Stadium, but throughout the Bronx as well. 
 A loyal Yankees fan and onetime home-game regular, I recently attended a night game at the stadium and found myself caught in a terrible postgame traffic jam. While not being able to move for what seemed hours, motorists fell prey to four examples of "neighborhood children," with lead pipes and chains, hawking beers from a filthy trash barrel at $10 a can.
The intimidating salesmen were doing a booming business, thanks to the cooperation of the police (there were none) and a brilliant customer offer of "Buy the beer or die!"
Are these the neighborhood children who should receive discounted bleacher seats?
I'm also insulted Mr. Bai thinks fans are staying away from the stadium because George Steinbrenner, the team's owner, tells them the area is unsafe. Give fans credit for being able to assess the perils of traveling to and from the stadium without opinions from an owner they don't respect. The area is as unsafe as a child playing with matches.
The Yankees are involved with outreach programs for children in New York City. But none of those programs call on them to protect fans from thugs in children's clothing, nor should they.
 
MARC G. MCHUGH
Swampscott, Mass., July 27, 1994

HEADLINE: Yankees Aren't to Blame for State of the Bronx;
On Road to Recovery

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Bombing in the Bronx" (Op-Ed, July 26) raises an issue that is central to the episode involving Richard Kraft, the Yankees' official whose remarks about area residents resulted in his resignation. There has been bias against the people of the South Bronx for decades. 
 The image most often called to mind of the South Bronx is that of burned-out blocks with deserted buildings. Banks have left most of the area. Large retailers have written off those living here. The primary medical treatment needed by a population living in what is considered to be the poorest Congressional district in the United States remains inadequate.
But the South Bronx is on the road to recovery. The nonprofit sector has taken the initiative, at times with government aid and at times without. Affordable housing is appearing, as rehabs and new construction.
Drug treatment, homeless programs, job training and AIDS programs are empowering residents to become contributing community members. Borough President Fernando Ferrer is unifying numerous components to develop an urban revitalization that should dispel this negative bias once and for all.
The Yankee management can assume leadership in revitalizing the South Bronx. Its support and partnership in providing a strong and effective influence will reap benefits for years to come.
 
JOHN E. LAZAR
Bronx, July 27, 1994

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Offer Made To Acquire Source One

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
Fund American Enterprises Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had received an unsolicited proposal to buy its Source One Mortgage Services Corporation, another example of merger activity surging through the mortgage industry as interest rates rise and home sales level off.
 Shares in Fund American, a holding company based in Norwich, Vt., soared as much as 12 percent yesterday, closing at $74.875, up $3.85, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
 Source One, the nation's second-largest independent mortgage banker after Countrywide Credit Industries, could fetch as much as $500 million, based on prices paid for two recent mortgage banking companies, according to Guy Cecala, editor and publisher of Inside Mortgage Finance, a weekly trade publication.
 
A Flurry of Mergers
 Earlier this week, Chase Manhattan Bank said it would buy the American Residential Holding Corporation for $348 million. Industrywide merger activity was sparked in May when the Chemical Banking Corporation agreed to acquire the Margaretten Financial Corporation in a $330 million transaction.
 A possible bidder for Source One is Nationsbank, based in Charlotte, N.C., which analysts said came up a loser in bids for Margaretten and American Residential.
 Fund American declined to identify the potential buyer and cautioned that it was not committed to selling its only remaining operating unit. "We would have to get a very attractive offer before we'd consider it," Terry Baxter, a company spokesman, said.
 Source One, based in Farmington Hills, Mich., services $38.9 billion in mortgages, a portfolio twice the size of American Residential's. The company, which has 2,000 employees and 100 offices, generated just $3.4 billion in new mortgages in the first half of the year, a ranking of 17th in the industry.
 Mortgage-banking companies are alluring to commercial lenders as a result of their established branch networks and the potential cost savings to be wrung out of combining servicing portfolios, Mr. Cecala said.
 The emphasis of Source One on servicing, in which it gathers fees for collecting monthly payments and handling delinquencies and foreclosures, has resulted in poor earnings in recent years. Fee income becomes volatile during a refinancing boom such as the one set off by the three-year decline in interest rates, which bottomed out in October at 6.8 percent for a 30-year fixed mortgage.
 "Rapid refinancing hurts a large servicing portfolio the most," Mr. Baxter said.
 The ascent in interest rates, to 8.38 percent this week, has slowed new lending and depressed earnings of mortgage companies, making them takeover targets. Source One's operating profits declined 7 percent in the first half, to $21.6 million.
 A prime beneficiary of a Source One takeover would be John J. Byrne, Fund American's chairman. He owns 9 percent of the company's 8.3 million shares and has warrants that would lift his ownership to 20 percent.
 Fund American is sitting on about $1 billion in assets left over from its $3.3 billion sale of the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company in 1990. Source One had been Fireman's mortgage company.

HEADLINE: BLACKBOARD;
Uniform Diversity In California

BYLINE: By Tessa Melvin 

 BODY:
DIVERSITY describes the student population in Long Beach, Calif., where Cambodian and Spanish are heard almost as often as English. But when public schools open next month, the city's 50,000 elementary and middle-school children will all, in one important sense, look alike.
To combat "gang wear," or gang-related clothing, soothe the frenzy over designer clothing that highlights economic disparities and help pupils focus on learning, the city's school board has agreed to mandate uniforms for all the lower grades. 
 The move follows a five-year experiment involving 11 Long Beach pilot schools. The school administrators said that required uniforms cut absenteeism, reduced group conflicts and improved student performance. "In schools without uniforms, the kids are polarized along racial and ethnic lines," said Richard Van Derlaan, a spokesman for the district. "With uniforms, there's more mixing. We are really replacing one uniform with another."
Dozens of school districts in southern California have experimented with the idea, though none have gone as far as Long Beach, whose decision has prompted a flood of inquiries from around the country.
In Baltimore, economics provided the impetus for the seven-year-old voluntary-uniform program in 90 percent of the elementary schools. "As soon as people realized uniforms were cheaper, much cheaper, they all supported them," said Justin B. Wood, ombudsman for the superintendent of schools. Student uniforms, Mr. Wood said, have eliminated brand-name envy and teasing over students' designer clothing while increasing self-esteem and school pride.
Long Beach has set aside $175,000 to defend itself against possible legal challenges. And a bill explicitly permitting districts to require uniforms is before the California Legislature with bipartisan support; the measure, with a provision promoted by the American Civil Liberties Union allowing parents to opt out of the program, has been endorsed by a broad coalition of school groups. Tessa Melvin

HEADLINE: Jump-Starting Capitalism

BYLINE: By Michael Winerip 

DATELINE: SHIPROCK, N.M.

 BODY:
TERESA Whalen, an M.B.A. candidate at the University of Michigan, was having another action-packed day. She was helping develop a financing package for two Navajos who want to open a roadside stand selling roast mutton sandwiches. She was putting together an employee training program for three Burger Kings here on the reservation. She was talking to professors at Navajo Community College about creating a Navajo-owned water quality testing laboratory.
She was having a blast. "I can't wait to get my hands on that lending circle," she said as the four-wheel vehicle she was riding in bounced along a dirt road and over a mountain pass, heading toward her next appointment. 
 This was precisely why she'd decided to go to business school -- to help the poor.
Same for Jim Pfeffer, her M.B.A. classmate and partner on these Navajo projects. "You want to make a difference," said Mr. Pfeffer. "Help people who traditionally got the shaft."
Ms. Whalen and Mr. Pfeffer are members of the University of Michigan M.B.A. Domestic Corps, a program started two summers ago that places graduate business students in economically depressed areas across the country, ranging from Detroit's inner city to a Michigan suburb where a General Motors plant shut down to Indian reservations.
These M.B.A. students are trying to use their newly acquired business skills to jump-start capitalism in places that prosperity has passed by.
The idea grew out of a similar University of Michigan M.B.A. international program. In 1990 Michigan began sending M.B.A. students to Poland and the Soviet Union to work with entrepreneurs trying to establish businesses in the countries where Communism had collapsed or was losing its hold.
It soon dawned on the Michigan program director, Marian Krzyzowski, that the problems facing the new Eastern European entrepreneurs struggling to overcome 70 years of Communist rule weren't too different from those facing Indians on a reservation, where a central tribal government dominates a heavily planned economy.
Mr. Krzyzowski found Navajo businessmen like Richard Mike quite receptive to an M.B.A. domestic corps. "We need help changing the economic culture here," says Mr. Mike, who owns three Burger Kings, making him one of the six largest Navajo businessmen on a reservation the size of West Virginia. (The only large private companies, mining concerns, are not owned by Navajos).
"The M.B.A. Corps' work in Poland gives me a lot of hope," Mr. Mike says. "Poland's had three generations of Communist rule, but they're succeeding in setting up a market economy. Our people have no role models, no business culture. Being one of the few Indian businessmen, I feel like the Lone Ranger."
 
'Still in the Minority'
 The University of Michigan is not alone. "There are an increasing number of programs of this nature at business schools, though they're still in the minority," says Richard Edelstein, a director of the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business. "Michigan's is among the best."
In 1990 the Kenan Institute of Private Enterprise at the University of North Carolina started its own M.B.A. Enterprise Corps. This year 22 graduate business schools, including most of the Ivy League, Stanford University, Duke University and the University of Chicago, sent 85 recent M.B.A.'s to work in Eastern Europe and Africa. And this summer, for the first time, the Kenan Institute began a domestic spinoff, an Urban Enterprise Corps, placing 7 M.B.A.'s in minority-run North Carolina businesses and paying their salaries for a year.
Among other business schools with programs aimed at helping poor and minority communities in this country are U.C.L.A., Rutgers and Wharton. The business corps are a 1990's version of Vista and the Peace Corps. "I don't know a lot about sociology," said Mr. Pfeffer, who spent the summer of '93 working with Michigan's international corps in Poland, and last summer here. "But I have a feeling there's a social change going on in our country. A lot more people are doing what we're doing as opposed to following the money grub."
There have been many more students applying than Michigan's international and domestic corps can accommodate -- 100 applicants for three dozen slots. Next year the school plans to double its domestic corps to two dozen students. Michigan's domestic corps students are paid a $10,000 stipend for the summer. The two assigned here live in spartan Navajo Community College dorms.
After graduating from Wayne State University and working several years in a Detroit employment program, Ms. Whalen was ready to return to school. She considered getting a master's in social work, but worried it would not give her the clout she was looking for. "If you're going to have a career pushing liberal causes," she says, "for anyone in power to take you seriously, you have to have a background they understand. If you're talking about developing businesses, your background should be in business."
Still, she was nervous about going for an M.B.A. "When I came to business school," said Ms. Whalen, "I thought I'd be ostracized for not being a money-grubber."
It is hard for outsiders to understand how different the Navajo economy is from the rest of America's. As Mr. Mike says to visitors to the reservation, "You didn't realize there was a socialist government in the middle of America, did you?" Starting in the 19th century, the United States Government dominated and controlled the Navajo economy, through the Bureau of Indian Affairs. As the United States began to loosen its reins in the 1960's, the Navajo tribal government jumped in and took control, but these Navajo leaders remade themselves in the image of the Federal bureaucracy.
Today the Navajo tribal government is the major employer on the reservation -- 5,000 jobs. The utilities, the paper products company, the largest farm, the community college and much of the housing are owned and controlled by the central tribal government.
These government-controlled businesses have a history of being unprofitable and have not been able to turn the reservation economy around. The reservation unemployment rate ranges between 40 and 50 percent; 56 percent of Navajos here live below the poverty line.
Complicating matters for the entrepreneur is the Navajos' view of land -- that it is collectively owned by the tribe. An individual Navajo doesn't own land; the best he can do, if he wants to build a business or home, is lease grazing rights. So, for example, King Mike, Richard's brother, a business professor at Navajo Community College, would like to have his own home, but instead lives in shabby college-owned housing.
This causes all kinds of economic problems for aspiring entrepreneurs. If you don't own land or a home, you probably have no collateral to get a loan from a bank.
It creates crazy problems for Navajo employers and employees. Glenda Kaisem, a Navajo, is the manager of the Burger King in Chinle, where she works 14-hour days. Her family has a home 150 miles away; she'd like to rent an apartment in Chinle. But there are no rental apartments and the only trailer park is full. She is lucky, though -- she lives in a spare office above the Burger King.
 
Basic Capitalism
 And so, much of the M.B.A. domestic corps effort here is basic grass-roots capitalism, aimed at helping Navajos scrape together the initial investment to leverage a small loan and create a new business.
The students have worked closely with Adah, a new Navajo lending circle aimed at starting what M.B.A.'s call "micro-enterprises" and what a lay person here would call a flea-market booth.
The lending circle is made up of a half-dozen aspiring business people who hope to borrow $500 each. Instead of putting up collateral for a loan, they are asked to take a 15-hour business course. All six pledge to be responsible for their circle's loans; if one member defaults, the other five must make up the loss. (First Nations Development, a small, Indian-oriented investment group based in Virginia, will provide the loans when the lending circle here is ready.)
The part-time executive director of the Navajo lending circle program is David McKenzie, a Navajo and a retired Baptist minister. When the M.B.A. students asked what help he needed, he answered, "Pretty much everything."
At a lending circle meeting Shirley Montoya, a Navajo member, worried that mothers who got business loans would feel pressure from their families to use the money for personal reasons. "The way we handled that in Detroit," Ms. Whalen said, "we made the checks out directly" to the business people's suppliers.
Somebody else suggested asking for token collateral like a washing machine or bike, but Ms. Whalen said, "You don't want to make a threat you can't enforce."
The students have also worked with the Navajo Community College faculty to develop a new business course on the reservation economy. The college, Professor Mike says, "offers a regular business curriculum; however, that doesn't apply to the reservation." He would like to see a course that would teach about the tribal government's complicated building and zoning restrictions, its grazing rights leases and housing policy.
In addition, the 1993 Michigan students helped the Navajo small-business association defeat an income tax that the central tribal government had hoped to impose.
But it is still too early to say how much long-term impact the Michigan corps will have here. The students love it, and say they are inspired to continue with this grass-roots work.
Steve Uline, who served here in 1993, called it "a great experience." But, he says, "It was harder to accomplish things and change things than I'd hoped. You have to be careful about going in with the idea that you're going to change the world."
Most of the Michigan domestic and international corps students serve in the summer after they've finished the first year of the two-year M.B.A. program. Both the students and Mr. Krzyzowski, the director, worry that three months each summer is not enough time to make an impact. In contrast, the University of North Carolina program requires people to have completed their M.B.A., and has a minimal commitment of a year.
The other danger is that the program will get too good -- and too threatening to the central tribal government. There have been several instances when Peace Corps or Vista workers have been kicked out of a region.
The tribal government says it favors independent business development, but Mr. Mike is skeptical. "The way the economy's set up now," he says, "Indians on the reservation are a nation of clerks. A lot of people with safe tribal jobs would have a lot to lose if that changes. I hope the University of Michigan has enough experience to resist or take the pressure."
