HEADLINE: Shift by Nonprofits Leaves Space Behind

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
FOR SALE: the former headquarters of the United Negro College Fund. For sale: the former headquarters of the Boys and Girls Clubs of America. For sale: the former headquarters of CARE.
Nonprofit organizations are on the move. Several prominent ones, most recently the 50-year-old college fund, have relocated headquarters and back-office operations from New York City, leaving a string of empty East Side office buildings in their wake. 
 All told, New York has lost 2,000 of the 4,000 nonprofit headquarters it had 11 years ago -- "a hemorrhaging of about half our community" -- said Joel A. Dolci, president of the New York Society of Association Executives.
Although help came with the opening in 1992 of the Association Center at 120 Wall Street, where nonprofit tenants are exempt from real estate taxes, Mr. Dolci said "we still have a problem with the exodus of not-for-profit organizations."
Perhaps the biggest single beneficiary of this movement is Atlanta, to which the Boys and Girls Clubs moved in March, CARE (the Cooperative for Assistance and Relief Everywhere) moved last September and the American Cancer Society moved in 1988.
Why they left is plain. New York, they say, has become too expensive for them.
Why they settled in Atlanta can be explained in part by the quiet workings of the Robert W. Woodruff Foundation, named for the man who led the Coca-Cola Company for many decades. Its principal asset is Coca-Cola stock left to it by Mr. Woodruff, who died in 1985. The Atlanta-based foundation has made grants on the order of $2.5 million each to the three big-league transplants.
"Once we learned that Atlanta was in the running, the foundation did make commitments that were helpful to the organizations' moves," said its president, Charles H. McTier. "We do not seek them out. We only act when the organization has made its decision to look at other communities and then has expressed a strong interest in Atlanta."
Atlanta has developed a "very aggressive" reputation, Mr. Dolci said, but it is by no means alone. William H. Gray 3d, president of the United Negro College Fund, credited the Virginia Department of Economic Development and the Fairfax County Board of Supervisors with enabling the fund to move.
Last month, the fund began relocating operations out of the 20-story Equal Opportunity Building, 500 East 62d Street, to the Willow Oaks Corporate Center in Merrifield, Va., and an office in downtown Washington. The National Urban League co-owns the building.
Many organizations, of course, are bound to New York. These include groups that are based in certain neighborhoods or serve specific communities, as well as those that depend heavily on the talent and wealth that are peculiar to New York City.
For example, the American Foundation for the Blind could in theory have gone anywhere when it decided to leave its old quarters at 15 West 16th Street. Instead, it is moving to leased space at 11 Penn Plaza, on Seventh Avenue, between 31st and 32d Streets.
"We did consider sites outside Manhattan," said the foundation's president, Carl R. Augusto. But the board quickly decided to give priority to a Manhattan location. Behind that consideration was the fact that an integral part of the foundation's work is the production in eight recording studios of "talking book" tape cassettes.
"We employ actors and actresses, radio and television personalities to narrate our books," Mr. Augusto said, "and that pool of talent exists here. We wanted to be in an international city because we are involved internationally in the blindness field. And after some investigation, we felt that the real-estate costs in other cities were not dramatically better."
But housing costs can be daunting -- so daunting that organizations find themselves unable to attract the people they need.
THAT was a reason the Boys and Girls Clubs moved in March to Peachtree Street in Atlanta. Its old headquarters, a six-story building at 771 First Avenue, near 44th Street and directly across from the United Nations, is now on the market.
"We have to have a national staff of the highest quality," said the president, Thomas G. Garth. "We would have a staff position open and perhaps the best person to fill it would be from Omaha. They would say, 'I'd like the position but I can't afford the financial sacrifice.' We had an accumulation of these experiences in our hiring."
That did not mean that the organization was headed for the suburbs. "Since we are really focused on people who live in urban areas and are primarily from economically disadvantaged backgrounds," Mr. Garth said, "we wanted to stay in a city with an urban image and urban issues."
Also, Mr. Garth said, "Our staff has to be out in the field, so we needed a good airline hub that had competitive air fares."
The organization looked at Atlanta, Baltimore, Dallas, Fort Worth and Newark. Several things started to turn the tide in Atlanta's favor. For instance, Mr. Garth said, the Metro Atlanta Chamber of Commerce conveyed the "sense that they want to work really hard and want you to have the sense that you're important."
Then there was the Coca-Cola connection. Mr. Woodruff was a member of the board of governors of the Boys and Girls Clubs, Mr. Garth noted, as is Roberto C. Goizueta, the current chairman and chief executive. The Woodruff Foundation was "helpful in our acquiring a new home," Mr. Garth said.
CARE's international character fit well with Woodruff's emphasis on "broadening the dimensions of the community experience," as Mr. McTier described it.
"They think about the city in a holistic way," said Katharine Day Bremer, senior vice president of marketing for CARE, speaking about the Woodruff Foundation. "They have set the internationalization of the city as an objective and CARE's advent to Atlanta was part of that."
CARE had its own objectives. "We're not occupying much more space than we were in New York," Ms. Bremer said, "but the purpose of the move was to lower the operating costs of the organization and, because housing is more affordable, it gives us the opportunity to rotate more of the overseas staff through headquarters."
CARE opened its new headquarters last September in a five-story building in downtown Atlanta and has put its old building, 660 First Avenue, at 38th Street, on the market.
Besides the $2.5 million grant from Woodruff, Ms. Bremer said architectural, contracting and legal services had been donated to CARE, and furnishings had been made available at a discount. She said the goal of the move was the saving of $10 million over 10 years and that "we are on track."
Mr. Gray said the United Negro College Fund would "add millions to our bottom line" over the next 10 years through consolidation and relocation. His statement, contained in a news release, did not specify the savings.
The fund is already on the move but the building's other owner, the National Urban League, has not yet reached a decision. The new president and chief executive, Hugh B. Price, said through a spokesman that the organization is "looking for new space in Manhattan." He did not elaborate.
Clay Lifflander, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, said relocations were inevitable but that the flow need not always be out of New York.
"We're always going to lose some," he said. "The trick is to try to keep everything we can and attract new not-for-profit and trade organizations to the city." He cited two potential newcomers, which he did not name, with more than 800 jobs between them.
"Over 10 percent of the jobs in the city are held by not-for-profit institutions," he said. "It's one of our targeted growth industries."
The city's Industrial Development Agency has provided some $350 million to nonprofit organizations over the last seven years, he said, for projects like construction, renovation, expansion, acquisition, refinancing and installation of new building systems.
The Economic Development Corporation contributes to the Nonprofit Facilities Fund, which provides loans of up to $500,000 for the development or expansion of facilities.
ALSO, the Industrial Development Agency technically holds title to portions of the 34-story tower at 120 Wall Street known as the Association Center. Municipal ownership lets the landlord, Silverstein Properties, rent to nonprofit tenants without charging for real estate taxes, a saving that can amount to $6 to $8 a square foot a year.
The Association Center was announced three years ago by Mayor David N. Dinkins. Since then, 14 nonprofit tenants have signed leases for some 116,000 square feet of space. Among them are Freedom House, the Alan Guttmacher Institute, Center for Reproductive Law and Policy, Ms. Foundation for Women, Acoustical Society of America, Inform Inc., Society of Women Engineers, National Neurofibromatosis Foundation and American Vacuum Society.
"Close to 90 percent of them are coming from midtown or midtown south," said Ed Kulik, senior vice president of Silverstein Properties. Downtown is not normally a spot where one expects nonprofit groups to gather. However, Mr. Kulik said, "With their fundraisers, they depend heavily on financial institutions and being down in their environment, many feel, will be helpful."
Mr. Dolci, of the Society of Association Executives, said the Association Center was a success but that more was needed.
"What could be marketed and be even more successful," he said, "would be a similar building in midtown. Headquarters feel that they must be in the midtown area because of the members and delegations that come in and out of New York all the time."
To which Mr. Lifflander responded: "Would we be interested in a not-for-profit center in midtown? By all means. I'd caution one thing -- everybody knows that midtown is more expensive than downtown."
Actually, the new owners of the former Girl Scouts of the U.S.A. headquarters, 830 Third Avenue, have in mind something along those lines: a condominium for nonprofit organizations or United Nations missions.
After three years on the market, the 13-story building at 51st Street was purchased last month by the R.F.R. Holding Corporation, an investment group based in Frankfurt whose partners are Aby Rosen and Michael Fuchs. "That building was on the market for a very long time," Mr. Rosen said. "The reason was the asking price was so high."
Neither Mr. Rosen nor Mary Rose Main, national executive director of the Girl Scouts, would disclose the ultimate price.
The Girl Scouts, Ms. Main said, are "nicely settled" in the office condominium that they purchased in 1991 at 420 Fifth Avenue, between 37th and 38th Streets. Earlier this year, they were joined at 420 Fifth by the Rockefeller Foundation, which moved from 1133 Avenue of the Americas.
At 830 Third Avenue, Mr. Rosen said the plan was to sell condominium units to nonprofit organizations, which would be exempt from property taxes as owners, as the Girl Scouts and Rockefeller Foundation are. (The Association Center is the only building where nonprofits are exempt as tenants; elsewhere, their landlords pass the real estate taxes along in rent.)
FLOOR sizes range from 6,000 to 11,500 square feet, Mr. Rosen said, and prospective occupants have expressed interest in units of as many as four floors. The renovation is being designed by the Philips Janson Group of Manhattan. The 38-year-old building will get new systems and a new lobby.
An existing condominium is the Nonprofit Center of New York, 305 Seventh Avenue, at 27th Street. This 20-story loft building still has furriers but is now home to about 15 nonprofit groups, said Brian S. Waterman, a managing director of Newmark & Company Real Estate, which leases and manages the building. Recent deals include the Rabbinical Council of America and the Association for Neighborhood and Housing Development.
An office condominium is one possibility for 500 East 62d Street, which is being marketed by Grubb & Ellis New York and Webb & Brooker. The 22-year-old tower has 100,000 square feet of space. The College Fund and Urban League bought it in 1974 for $2.875 million, after selling their building at 55 East 52d Street to Fisher Brothers.
With so many medical institutions nearby, there is a special focus in marketing to nonprofit health-care agencies, said Norman K. Livingston, senior managing director of Grubb & Ellis. The building might also be converted to institutional housing, he said, or used by groups related to the United Nations.
If any one of the buildings for sale has a U.N. claim, it would be the former Boys and Girls Clubs headquarters. "We have the last piece of private property across the street from it," Mr. Garth said. "We feel a natural client is a country that wants proximity and visibility to the United Nations."
One of those countries might be the United States, whose mission is a block away.
The prime location, Mr. Garth said, was an important factor leading to the decision to move. "We had a sense," he said, "that the building might be a very valuable asset that could go into our endowment."
CARE's seven-story building with its distinctive corner dome, home to the Kips Bay Brewing Company at the turn of the century, is still being used as a regional office by CARE but it is on the market.
The American Foundation for the Blind found a buyer for its 16th Street property in the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, which sold its building at Fifth Avenue and 86th Street to the Serge Sabarsky Foundation for Expressionist Art, which is to use it as a museum.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
A Satellite Workshop for Peekskill's Artists' Colony

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

DATELINE: PEEKSKILL

 BODY:
THE campaign to enrich downtown Peekskill's artists' colony will get a boost later this month when the Westchester Art Workshop, a school in White Plains that is accredited by the State University of New York, opens a satellite campus here.
"This will bring 600 to 1,000 people into the downtown," said Mayor Frances S. Gibbs. "We worked very hard to convince the school that Peekskill would be a complementary location for them, and allow the school to get new enrollments from northern Westchester." 
 The school, which is part of Westchester Community College, will lease 10,000 square feet on the ground floor of a downtown building that once housed a Woolworth's. Part of the upper floor is now occupied by the Parole Board of New York State, said Edmond Schorno, assistant city manager for development.
"This is just another of the pieces that is taking Peekskill to the next level," Mr. Schorno said. "It's really moving in a positive direction. There's definitely momentum."
For the last several years, the city has been actively pursuing new uses for the large blocks of space left behind by departing anchor stores. In June, it completed the purchase of a 24,000-square-foot building that had been vacated by the Peekskill 5 & 10 in the fall.
The city paid $300,000 for the building and is now in the process of renovating the space to create artists' lofts and studios on the upper floors and retail space at the street level.
"We are close to a lease signing for part of the lower floor," the Mayor said. Declining to name the retailer, she did say it was a stationery and art supply store. "And we're talking to other potential tenants for the other space."
The ultimate plan, she added, is for the city to get the building fully leased and then sell it to a private investor. "We gave ourselves a year to find tenants, but in just a few months it's looking very positive. We're ahead of schedule."
Another vacant downtown building, which has 30,000 square feet, was vacated by the Steinbach department store four years ago and continues to be a blight on the downtown, Mayor Gibbs said. "The problem is that Steinbach has a lease on the building until 2007. So the landlord isn't undergoing any hardship. After we get our building leased, we're going to take a look at that situation and see if we can convince the landlord to do something."
AROUND the time that Steinbach left, Peekskill had hit its lowest point. It was characterized by empty storefronts and a generally run-down appearance. As shoppers switched to nearby malls, the downtown became a hangout for idlers, many of whom were left unemployed by the flight of business.
That's when Ralph DiBart, an urban planner and development consultant from Scarsdale, was hired by the city to transform its downtown. He decided the best use was to reinvent the city completely as an alternative community for artists from New York City.
"We had all this vacant space, especially above the retail level, some of which hadn't been occupied for 30 to 40 years," Mr. DiBart said.
The concept of attracting artists occurred to him because Peekskill was already home to the Paramount Center for the Arts, a 1,000-seat theater, built in 1930. It presents a full line of theatrical performances, as well as dance and classical music concerts. "I saw that it drew a healthy distance from the city," Mr. DiBart said. "People were already coming to Peekskill for the arts."
In addition, the Gothic and Victorian-style buildings downtown lent themselves to loft and studio conversions, Mr. DiBart said. So he began an aggressive artist recruiting campaign through direct mail and advertisements in The Village Voice.
The city then created a special purpose zoning district downtown that permitted artists to live and work in lofts above retail space. "The goal of the first two years was to have 50 artists in the city," Mr. DiBart said. "We've met that goal and now we're looking to bring in 25 more."
The biggest draw for artists continues to be the low rents, relative to Manhattan. The average living/working loft is 1,000 to 1,200 square feet and rents for $800 to $900 a month. Rents for studios average $400 for 350 to 400 square feet.
With its artist's recruiting program firmly in place, the city is now turning its attention to making badly needed repairs. This year, it received $1 million in state funds to refurbish Central Avenue, which links downtown to the waterfront. The repairs will include updating the drainage system, installing new sidewalks and landscaping, and resurfacing the street.
In addition, a $180,000 Federal grant will go to improving portions of Main Street, including landscaping, new lighting fixtures and reconstruction of curbs and sidewalks. Work on both street projects is expected to begin in the spring of 1995, the Mayor said.
PERHAPS the most urgently needed repairs involve the city's waterfront, said Dwight Douglas, director of planning. "In 1990, we did a redevelopment plan to determine what improvements were necessary for the waterfront," Mr. Douglas said. "Now we're beginning to implement those recommendations."
A $750,000 state environmental bond grant will be used to refurbish the shoreline at the 12-acre Riverfront Green, a city-owned park. "The wave action has caused considerable erosion," Mr. Douglas said, both to the shoreline and to the city's public boat launch, which is in the park. Portions of the launch have sunk, and may need to be replaced, Mr. Douglas said.
About $150,000 from the same state grant will be used to reconstruct a dilapidated pier at the one-and-a-half acre Charles Point Pier, which is slated to become a park soon. "It's just dirt now," Mr. Douglas said. "But it has a magnificent view of the river, and a deep-water port."
In the future, the city would like to create a trail connecting the Riverfront Green to the Charles Point Pier Park.
"The first step is to do the shoreline improvements," Mr. Douglas said. "All the work has to be approved by the state Department of Environmental Conservation. We're submitting permit applications within a month. Realistically, we probably won't be able to begin work on the waterfront until next spring."

HEADLINE: CRAFTS;
Sociology, Economics and Art Pottery

BYLINE: By BETTY FREUDENHEIM 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
PROVING that there can be more to a pot than its shape, glaze and function, an exhibition of American art pottery at the Newark Museum provides insights into the sociology and economics of potters and the ceramic industry from 1880 to 1930. And a display of vessels of contemporary work focuses on the esthetic goals of today's clay artists.
Dull and pedantic? Decidedly not. The work is of top quality and surprisingly varied. The show's title, "American Art Pottery: An Uneasy Evolution," hints at the obstacles faced by Victorian china painters and potters who endeavored to raise the quality and taste of handmade ceramics above the level of industrial products. 
 The examples are chosen from the museum's ceramic collection, started in 1910, the year after the museum was founded. It is now recognized as one of the best-documented and most comprehensive groups of American art pottery in the country, with more than 300 pieces.
"This show is not about the craftsmanship of art pottery," said Ulysses G. Dietz, the curator of decorative arts. "Here we see the tension between art and industry. Commerce hampered artistry, and the artists were often very impractical."
In the late 19th century, men were allotted the heavy tasks of potting and firing the kilns of the art potteries. Many women who needed to work for a living chose careers of ceramic design and decorating to escape being factory workers. In New Orleans, Sophie Newcomb College for Women established an art pottery that served as a training ground.
An 1894 brown mug, which depicts a hobgoblin on one side, suggests that ceramic designers were not always practical. Rows of holes around the rim, unless you cover them wih your fingertops, would certainly cause the contents to dribble out. No wonder it is named "Puzzle Mug."
By contrast, what could be more elegant than a tall faience bottle vase adorned with a dragonfly, a bird and raspberries all edged in gold? The background resembles ivory-toned silk with quilting.
A few artists worked in their studios. One of the three delicate bud vases by Adelaide Alsop Robineau, dated 1914, has a citron glaze that glows like crystalized frost on a window. Another, created 10 years later, has the white crackle glaze flowing down like melting snow.
Economic problems plagued most of these independent artists. Robineau was fortunate to have a husband who could support her career and help with the glaze formulas. But accidents could be costly and frustrating. After an entire kiln load turned out to be blistered and warped, he complained that "anyone who is foolish enough to do porcelains ought to be shut up in an insane asylum."
George Ohr has been called the "mad potter of Biloxi." At craft fairs, he demonstrated his skill on the potter's wheel with his 24-inch-long mustache tucked down into his shirt. Although flower pots and chimney pots provided a living, his creative life lay in his "mud babies," which are now avidly sought by collectors.
These skillful, delightfully witty pots bear the imprints of his thumbs as he twisted and bent the paper-thin clay. But pouring tea from the teapot on display could invite trouble. Its handle is too lumpy to grasp, and the lid seems very insecure. Obviously, function was irrelevant.
Ohr believed himself to be a genius; after 1900, he sold only the "gimcracks." His dream was to have the best work -- 6,000 pieces -- purchased en masse for the nation. But the pots remained in the family warehouse until 1972, when a New York antiques dealer bought them.
Sometimes ceramic artists treated pots like canvases for painting. A monumental vase from the Rockwood Pottery in Cincinnati, decorated by Maria Longworth Nichols in 1883, features a romantic scene with dragonflies and water birds, framed with bands of patterned gold.
"Fiddleheads," a vase designed by Louis Comfort Tiffany for the Tiffany Pottery in Corona, N.Y., takes on a sculptural aspect. Each fern frond rises into an ornate swirl at the top. But even the family store couldn't sell enough to keep his pottery going.
An Art Deco vase from the Fulper Pottery in Flemington, N.J., was created before a disastrous fire hit the company in 1929. The Depression brought an end to most of the other art potteries.
This show runs through June 1995.
The interplay of work by 14 contemporary ceramic artists is dynamic. Each piece expresses a distinctive personality; they harmonize in spite of the cacophony of colors and forms. Mr. Dietz created pairs of male and female ceramists and assigned one philosophic heading to both. Usually the examples are totally dissimilar.
Mary Lou Higgins and Ralph Bacerra have each created a work in "Decorated Vessel" category. Two figures recline around the outside of her bowl, which is titled "Circle of Hope; Circuit of Dreams." The hands reach out and grasp, while faces stare into the void. The mysterious landscape inside might be the very depths of the sea.
Mr. Bacerra's "Bird Platter" conveys a crazy quilt of overlapping patterns that assume the contours of birds in flight with eyes and wings of pink, gold and lavender. The flowing lines suggest the illusions found in W. C. Escher's art.
Another category is called "Perfect Pot." The impossible goal of creating such a pot is represented by Roseline Delisle's precisely striped blue and white vase. Although the contours are smooth and exact, the actual construction is complex. Its finial lid comes apart into two pieces.
Harrison McIntosh's version of perfection is a hand-thrown pot with flowing stripes of umber on beige. Although functional work had fallen into disfavor when it was formed in the 1960's, the vase could hold flowers with a quiet grace.
Beatrice Wood's "Chalice" has the brilliant gold luster of a medieval church vessel. Reflections of light and color add subtle nuances to the multiple curves of its massive form. This 101-year-old artist continues to amaze her admirers with a profusion of elegant, shimmering vessels and small erotic sculptures that she fashions for her two annual gallery shows in New York City and Los Angeles.
"Acorn Form" by Val Cushing is the other half of "Primal Pots" pairing. This large jar has a tall spinelike handle that thrusts upward on the top.
The show runs through Sept. 4. The Newark Museum is at 49 Washington Street. Hours are noon to 5 P.M. Wednesday through Sunday. Admission is free.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Catherine Taylor, John M. Berner

 BODY:
Catherine Ann Taylor, a daughter of Paul and Lucienne Taylor of Orono, Minn., was married yesterday to John Marshall Berner, a son of Robert and Elizabeth Berner of North Haven, Conn. The Rev. George Lobien performed the ceremony at the Lutheran Church of St. Andrew in Silver Spring, Md.
Mrs. Berner, 27, and Mr. Berner, 30, are graduates of Cornell University. She is the executive assistant to the president of Citizens Against Government Waste in Washington. Her father is an account executive with Corporate Financers, a factoring company in Minneapolis. Her mother is the director of the Minnesota Institute for Talented Youth, a summer program in St. Paul. 
 Mr. Berner is a senior economist with the Scientific Applications International Corporation, a high-technology contractor in Washington. His father is the Alan M. Bateman Professor of Geology and Geophysics at Yale University. His mother is a lecturer in geology at the University of Connecticut. The bridegroom's maternal grandfather, the late Marshall Kay, was the Newberry Professor of Geology at Columbia University.

HEADLINE: The Booming, Bulging Tex-Mex Border

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
M. G. (Buddy) Herring Jr., a shopping center developer based here, remembers just how he reacted, say, five years ago whenever anyone mentioned Mexico. "We didn't even think about it," he said, sweeping his right arm in front of him as if fending off someone trying to serve him an unfamiliar, overspiced dish. "We had enough opportunities in the United States."
Today, an easel in his conference room holds a map of Mexico, with orange adhesive dots on Leon, Torreon, Chihuahua and Monterrey. He is so busy building shopping centers in these cities and making plans for more that he no longer even bothers with the United States. 
 When Mr. Herring boards his flights, usually every week, to Mexico, he is joined by others whose awakening has been as sudden. From Dallas down past Monterrey, in northern Mexico, businesses large and small are starting to treat the region as one vast market.
Call it the broadening border. Or, better yet, la frontera amplianda. Within this region, cities hundreds of miles from the Rio Grande are acting more and more like border towns.
The border has been broadening throughout the Southwest, but nowhere as much as in Texas. Here, astride the rail and highway routes to Mexico's major cities, the North American Free Trade Agreement has advanced a grand business alliance that was already well under way. Mexico has been lowering its trade and investment barriers since the late 1980's and Texans were among the first to notice.
Business people in El Paso and Laredo, Tex., Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, and other border cities have long crossed the Rio Grande. Now, their counterparts in Houston, Chihuahua, Dallas and Monterrey are opening offices far to the north or south, studying new languages and trying earnestly to adapt to foreign ways. Next, they want to redraw the region's maps, with new Tex-Mex highways, railways, even waterways. [Page 6.]
Last year, Texas shipped $20.4 billion worth of goods to Mexico, 49 percent of the United States' Mexican exports and more than three times as much as any other state. Next came California, with $6.5 billion, followed by Arizona, Michigan, Illinois and New York. Although these Commerce Department figures might favor Texas slightly by including some goods made elsewhere but only stored here, few doubt that Texas is the overwhelming leader.
"The impact of Mexican trade on the American economy divides the United States neatly in two," said William A. Orme Jr. in his book "Continental Shift: Free Trade and the New North America" (The Washington Post Company). "Texas, and everywhere else." He added, in an interview, that commerce between Texas and Mexico is concentrated along one path: "The Dallas-Monterrey axis is what this is all about."
Dallas has the bankers, lawyers, consultants and financiers, as well as the rails, highways and airports, to speed Mexican commerce. Monterrey, 578 highway miles south in the state of Nuevo Leon, brings Mexico's largest manufacturers and a determination to face north no matter what the directives from Mexico City.
 
Coveting Across Borders
 Business people in these swaggering cities should know that a company across the border probably covets their customers.
Cinemark, based in Dallas, has battled Mexico's most powerful labor union and other movie houses to give Monterrey, and Mexico, its first chain of multiscreen theaters. A Monterrey-based upstart, Aeroejecutivo, has started a fare war to Houston with Continental. Among its weapons: beverage carts stocked, at least initially, with free Chivas Regal Scotch, Bacardi 1873 Solera rum and Sauza Conmemorativo tequila.
The Dallas-Monterrey axis also runs through San Antonio, the nation's largest city with an Hispanic majority, and Los Dos Laredos, or Laredo, Tex., and Nuevo Laredo, Mexico, the busiest customs posts on the border. A parallel, coastal axis includes Houston, with its port and many oil service companies that are increasingly busy in Mexico.
But if San Antonio and Houston are finding that their well-developed skills in courting Mexican business are now having a greater payoff, it is Dallas, farther north, that has shown the most startling turn from ignoring Mexico to embracing it.
Dallas, a metropolitan area of 3.9 million people, has earnestly sought recognition as a world-class city. The city's promoters tout its direct flights to Paris, London and Frankfurt, with no contaminating stops in New York required.
About five years ago, a consulting firm delicately suggested that Dallas might find it easier to cultivate ties with Mexico than with Asia or Europe. The idea aroused more amusement than immediate action.
Wealthy Mexicans are still far more likely to have houses in Houston or San Antonio than Dallas, and race relations here remain sore.
But as the home of some world-class dealmakers, at least (Basses, Hunts, Richard Rainwater, Boone Pickens), Dallas and neighboring Fort Worth always have an eye for the main chance, however risky. While Dallas is the home of the trade agreement's leading opponent, Ross Perot, even Mr. Perot's computer services company searched late last year, without much success, for business in Monterrey.
IN Dallas 1994, saying you are just back from closing a deal in Monterrey or Mexico City, or from honing your accent in Cuernavaca, confers as much cachet as saying, in Dallas 1984, that you had just topped out your office building or bought your own frisky savings and loan.
Dallas's economic growth is once again outstripping the nation's, and many here credit the opening of Mexico's markets to the region's electronics and industrial supplies, and, increasingly, its business services and consumer goods.
Neiman Marcus, with its operations based here, has just made plans to issue its first catalogue for Mexico, and J. C. Penney, in nearby Plano, will open its first Mexican store, in Monterrey, next year. The Dallas Morning News, available at Monterrey airport and hotel newsstands, now has a bureau there.
Texas, and Dallas in particular, are developing their own foreign policies. You don't hear Gov. Ann W. Richards demanding a Constitutional amendment or National Guard patrols to help keep illegal aliens out, unlike the politicians in California. Instead, Texas and Nuevo Leon are joining in business research and trade missions, and issuing brochures titled either "Vacaciones en Dos Naciones" or "Two Nation Vacation."
Just last week, the Mexican Secretary of Commerce, Jaime Serra Puche, came to the Dallas World Trade Center to seek investments and push exports. Mayor Steve Bartlett handed him a key to the city and a string tie with a Dallas bolo clip, saying, "We in Dallas have staked our economic future on Nafta."
The next morning, down another trade center hallway, Jeffrey E. Garten, the United States Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, gathered Texas exporters around a table in part to keep trade flowing in the other direction.
Next Sunday, about 100 Dallas business people, based here and in Mexico, will go to Mexico City to entertain their clients, and hunt for more, at a preseason game between the Dallas Cowboys and Houston Oilers.
Many Dallas deals that don't seem Mexican still have a Latin accent. Last month, Thomas O. Hicks, chairman here of the Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst buyout firm, agreed to buy a little-known home furnishings and decorations business from Donald J. Carter, who also owns the Dallas Mavericks basketball team. Mr. Hicks cited sales prospects in Mexico, found on his frequent trips there, as helping to justify a price of $1 billion.
If El Paso, San Antonio, Laredo and Houston have also proclaimed themselves the centers of free trade -- Muleshoe (pop. 4,551) might be the largest Texas city that still hasn't -- Dallas is trying to drown them all out. In March, when Dallas won a new North American labor secretariat, with only 16 employees and uncertain powers, United States Representative John Bryant, a Dallas Democrat, reacted as if his town had just become New York, Toronto and Mexico City all rolled into one. "We are today announcing Dallas as the capital of North America," Mr. Bryant said at a ceremony.
Dallas just might meet its match in Monterrey. It has mountains and it has many more factories, but there Dallas visitors can find the familiar, forthright dedication to profit, similarly untainted by modesty.
Monterrey has named both its baseball teams -- Sultanes and Industriales, or the Sultans and the Industrialists -- to advertise its wealth, while it schemes to start Mexico's first teams in the American baseball and basketball leagues.
AT the center of the city, population 3 million, stands not a church or city hall, but a towering monolith, flame orange with a green laser shooting from the top. Its name: the Beacon of Commerce. The only question is whether the laser is meant to vaporize competing stores a two-and-a-half-hour drive away across the border in Laredo, or to zap meddlesome politicians up from Mexico City.
"I should not be the one to say this,' said Fernando Villarreal Palomo, the director of Nuevo Leon's chamber of industry. "But among Mexican states, we now have the most opportunities of success with Nafta."
A magazine on his desk features the Dallas Cowboys, Mr. Villarreal's other passion besides industry. He tries to get to five or six games a year. An expensive habit, but as he tells his wife, "I do not drink. I do not smoke. I do not play around with other girls. I just go to the Cowboys."
Mr. Villarreal, a former executive with some of Monterrey's largest companies, is now a partner in two Sirloin Stockade restaurants in town, and another in Guadalajara, franchised from a chain based in Hutchinson, Kan.
Monterrey's industrial conglomerates have been building plants and buying companies in the United States for years. A partnership between Vitro, Mexico's major glassmaker, and Corning fell apart early this year. But back in 1989, Vitro bought Anchor Glass, the second-largest maker of glass containers in the United States, outright for about $820 million.
To follow their American investments, Monterrey executives can open El Norte, the city's leading newspaper, to a full page of news translated from The Wall Street Journal. They say they leave worries about the Aug. 21 presidential election to politicians in Mexico City.
So many United States retailers are coming to Monterrey that Marcos Merino V., a Price Waterhouse consultant there, advised another interested American department store chain last month that the market is already crowded.
"They were just trying to find out, 'Where is Mexico?' " Mr. Merino laughed, during an interview. As if to answer, he glanced through his office window at the stores (Sears, Dillard's, J. C. Penney), offices and hotel going up around the Plaza Fiesta San Agustin mall, in one of Monterrey's wealthiest neighborhoods.
The mall expansion is a joint project between Monterrey developers and Mr. Herring, of Dallas. It was only two years ago, at a Las Vegas convention, that friends introduced him to business people from Monterrey. Impressed that they knew just what they wanted to build and where, he flew down after the convention. Now he has three more Mexican projects, and prospects in Mexico City.
Unexpected costs and bureaucratic rigmarole keep him down in Mexico at least half the time. In a country where even slight changes in construction plans require state approval, the Monterrey project became entangled in a feud between the Mayor and the Governor of Nuevo Leon. "Nobody can run down to Mexico and pick up a project right away," Mr. Herring said.
IT'S not that such rapidly increasing commerce is causing the border to vanish, as some scholars and writers have insisted. Language, laws, living standards and business practices remain vastly different along the world's longest boundary between an information-age nation and one still building its sewers, phone lines and roads.
Crossing this boundary for business involves risks, costs and frustrations far beyond those at home. In many ways, the new trade pact defines the border more sharply, requiring more detailed inspections there, especially to screen out goods from beyond North America.
One result has been more European and Asian businesses building plants in Texas or northern Mexico to serve the whole continent. Japanese auto companies are joining those from the United States to turn a broad swath below Monterrey into Detroit South.
Along this broadening border, a national boundary offers less and less protection from rivals.
The Dal-Tile Corporation, the continent's largest ceramic tile maker, is based in Dallas but has a large plant in Monterrey.
Interceramic, one of Mexico's largest tile makers, has meanwhile made plans to open a factory in the Dallas suburbs this fall. Last year, as the fight over the trade pact raged, Interceramic put up a billboard here saying, "Dallas just gained 400 new jobs . . . from a Mexican company. Interceramic supports Nafta."
AN Interceramic sales office, in the Dallas area since 1988, has already made the company the largest Mexican importer of floor tile, said David Hyland, president of Interceramic U.S.A. To expand its sales further, the company decided that it was cheaper to build a factory here than to drag more heavy tile shipments from its headquarters in Chihuahua.
Dallas has become much more friendly to Mexican companies. Now, local banks are vying for Mr. Hyland's attention. "A few years ago, if you were a Mexican company, they didn't care," he said.
Going to meetings in Chihuahua is no longer an all-day ordeal, with a switch down in Mexico City, since Lone Star Airlines began direct service from Dallas this April. At first, the plane was empty, Mr. Hyland said. "Now it's packed."
Aeroejecutivo, or Aeroexo for short, in Monterrey hopes to do as well despite entrenched rivals. Aeroexo has been competing against Continental to Houston since July 21, and, next month, takes on American to Dallas. Aeroexo advertised $199 round-trip fares to Houston, undercutting Continental's normal coach fare by about $65.
Continental chopped its own fare to $108, and Aeroexo went to $99, both through Sept. 4. Taxes add about $35.
A daily 6 P.M. Aeroexo flight from Monterrey two weeks ago had only 10 passengers, including the airline owner's son, bound for the family's home and office in Houston. The free drinks added conviviality. By last Thursday, the evening flight had about 30 passengers.
Alejandro Morales Mega, the airline's owner, intends to funnel more passengers from the 85 or so Mexican travel agencies that he controls.
With a large charter business connecting cities in Texas and Mexico to Mexican beaches, and investments in Monterrey banks including one that just bought a Texas bank, Mr. Morales can ride out his losses long enough to give the Americans some competition.
Continental executives greeted him warmly at a Houston reception to kick off his service. "Like gentlemen, they said, 'Go ahead,' " Mr. Morales recalled. "Maybe that's because they don't know me yet."
 
 
 
REMAKING THE ROAD MAP
 EVER since the transcontinental railroad was completed in 1869, through the building of the interstates and the growth of air traffic, Washington has backed the creation of corridors between East and West. Now, from the broadening border come plans to draw more lines running from north to south.
It takes a good map to sort out all the rival highway schemes. The I-69 Mid-Continent Highway Coalition wants to extend an interstate, which runs from Michigan only into Indiana, down to the Mexican border. Freight that now rumbles through Dallas on I-35 toward Mexico would often go through Houston instead. Guess where this plan is popular?
Members of an I-35 Corridor Coalition have fought back by demanding improvements to their road -- perhaps special truck lanes, maybe high-speed rail -- and suggesting that Interstate 69 could be built in the next century, or two. Some who fantasize about bullet trains talk of a Dallas-to-Monterrey run.
From the tip of West Texas, El Pasoans have cooked up a Camino Real Economic Alliance to make a route from Sante Fe, N.M., through El Paso to Chihuahua the spine of North American trade.
On the rails, a new North-South trade route has been arranged just this year. Santa Fe Pacific opened a $100 million hub in Fort Worth this spring, speeding truck and rail traffic to the Mexican border. Then, in June, Burlington Northern, based in Fort Worth and with rail links to Canada but not Mexico, agreed to buy Santa Fe, in part to span the free trade zone.
Among the Gulf of Mexico ports, Houston and Veracruz, Mexico, intend to team up to send more ships between them.
But why stop there, when the United States and Mexico have no waterways inland? The Governor of the northern Mexican state of Tamaulipas wants to trench through Matamoras, Mexico, and Brownsville, Tex., to link Mexican and American intercoastal waterways -- and a top American trade official has talked the plan up.
Though these ideas might seem like multibillion-dollar dreams, just remember that many Texas politicians, from Sam Rayburn to Lyndon Johnson to Lloyd Bentsen, have turned dreams into pork.

HEADLINE: In Supercomputers, Bigger and Faster Means Trouble

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
FIVE years ago the Defense Department gave $12 million to the Thinking Machines Corporation, an innovative start-up company in Cambridge, Mass. An assignment came with the seed money: take high-performance computing to new frontiers.
So Thinking Machines began a bold bid to design a new kind of computer that, by 1995, would probably cost $80 million and be more than a thousand times faster than the most powerful supercomputers available in 1989. It was a Government-subsidized effort to build the Ferrari of supercomputers. The initiative reflected Washington's high-tech policies and priorities in the late 80's, when the Cold War was still on, Star Wars spending flowed and computing firepower was considered a measure of national security. 
 How times have changed. Last week, the executives of Thinking Machines were shuttling across the country to talk to potential investors or buyers, in a desperate effort to avoid bankruptcy. Management mistakes and falling behind schedule in product-development plans certainly contributed to the company's fall.
But the plight of Thinking Machines also shows how much tougher the supercomputer market has become with the Government no longer spending freely and competition stiffening. Several companies in the $1.7 billion-a-year supercomputer business are struggling. The Intel Corporation's supercomputer division is losing money, and industry sources say the big chip maker may be looking to sell its business. Cray Research has seen the sales of its traditional supercomputers slip. The Maspar Computer Corporation has been kept afloat by a recent cash infusion from investors. And the Cray Computer Corporation, started five years ago by supercomputer inventor Seymour Cray after he left Cray Research, remains in business only because the founder has repeatedly dipped into his own pockets for funds.
"Supercomputing is just another victim of the end of the Cold War," said Danny Hillis, the cofounder of Thinking Machines and the company's chief scientist.
The Government programs, and Thinking Machines, did change the face of supercomputing. The company pioneered the use of so-called massively parallel design, lashing thousands of inexpensive microprocessors together to build a powerful machine. Massively parallel machines work by splitting complex scientific and mathematical equations into pieces and then solving the many parts at the same time, or in parallel.
By contrast, traditional supercomputers run on a few, costly processors and process complex equations a step at a time, or sequentially. For years, they were the workhorses for military research laboratories and were used by scientists and engineers to solve a wide variety of problems from weather prediction to molecular modeling.
But parallel machines, with their low-cost microprocessors, transformed the economics of supercomputing. Even Cray Research, leader in traditional supercomputers, has had to adopt parallel models to compete.
Still the early proponents of massively parallel processing, like Thinking Machines, have foundered as the market has shifted away from machines costing $15 million and more that the Government used to buy to far cheaper machines for the commercial market. Latecomers to parallel processing, like I.B.M. and Silicon Graphics, are doing better today by selling machines that start at $300,000 to $500,000 to research laboratories and corporate customers.
"Parallel computing has the potential to create a business segment that didn't exist before," said Irving Wladawsky-Berger, the executive who heads the International Business Machines Corporation's new effort.
The companies struggling in the supercomputer field are the ones who built their business in the 80's and took their cue from Washington. In position papers and budget requests, it was an inspiring vision -- ultra-fast supercomputers that would greatly improve mankind's capacity to do everything from predict the weather to design miracle drugs. Celebrated as the race to a "teraflop" -- jargon for computers that can calculate a trillion mathematical operations each second -- the goal was like going to the moon for the makers of the world's fastest computers.
Today, it looks like a high-end, even elitist technology policy. The Clinton Administration is fond of high-tech programs. But the Administration is more interested in funding projects that will give the American public access to the so-called information highway than spending on high-performance computing efforts that will be used mainly by a relative handful of the nation's scientists.
If Washington has lost interest in subisidizing ever-faster computers, Tokyo apparently has not. A year ago, only two of the world's 20 fastest supercomputers were made in Japan. By the end of June, 10 of the top 20 were Japanese, made by NEC, Fujitsu and Hitachi. Supercomputer purists warn that giving up leadership in the supercomputer speed race could dull the nation's high-tech advantage. But to others, including some computer experts, that argument sounds like special pleading from a niche business too long dependent on Government money.
The shift in American policy has caught the makers of big, multimillion-dollar supercomputers off balance -- and unable to really compete in the commercial market. Total spending by the Defense Department, the largest customer for big supercomputers, is slated to decline 60 percent over the next decade and that will inevitably mean buying fewer big machines, warns Anita K. Jones, director of defense research and engineering at the Pentagon.
Some industry executives say the Government is partly to blame for focusing its high-performance computing initiative narrowly on high-end machines, ignoring programs that might have been directed toward commercial markets.
"You have an industry that was built by the American taxpayer," said Howard A. Richmond, vice president for high performance computing at the Gartner Group, a consulting firm. "The Government programs should have had a little more wisdom and a little more guidance for these companies."
Supercomputer makers had hoped that they would convince corporations that the fastest computers could solve their engineering problems and save them money. For the most part, that has not happened. Like the declining market for mainframe computers, demand for big supercomputers is shrinking, by more than 9 percent annually the past five years, according to the International Data Corporation, a market research firm.
"There's no commercial market at the high-end of the supercomputer business," said Larry Smarr, director of the National Center for Supercomputer Applications, in Urbana, Ill.
One big obstacle to reaching the commercial market has been designing software for massively parallel computers, which has proved more difficult than the industry pioneers had hoped. Breaking big problems into little pieces may open the way to use low-cost microprocessors as hardware, but it created a programming nightmare, particularly in the commercial market, where the variety of business applications is enormous.
"The road to programming massively parallel computers is littered with the bodies of graduate students," said Steve Steinberg, a computer science graduate student at the University of California at Berkeley.
Still, the sales of smaller, less costly parallel computing machines are growing rapidly. Both research labs and companies want the advantages of the technology, but they do not want the huge pricetags and software headaches that go with the biggest massively parallel versions. American Express, Wal-mart and other large corporations use parallel computers to mine customer records for market trends, and smaller companies want to follow their lead.
And the increasingly powerful microprocessors are allowing more modest versions of parallel computing -- like machines that use so-called symmetric multiprocessing and workstations linked together -- to do chores that once could be handled only by the biggest supercomputers. High-performance computers are generally considered to be ones that can achieve speeds of 100 megaflops or more -- or 100 million mathematical operations a second. Today, a personal computer with Intel's Pentium microchip can reach speeds of 16 megaflops or more.
"One computer center after the other is lining up to put a cluster of microprocessors on the floor," said Eugene Brooks, a scientist at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories in Livermore, Calif. "Their budgets are shrinking and these systems are much more cost effective."
The relentless advance of small-scale computing, which is dominated by big companies, at the expense of the supercomputer makers, traditionally the province of small specialists, shows no signs of letting up.
"This is the end of an era," said Nathan Myhrvold, vice president for advanced technology at the Microsoft Corporation, the largest software maker. "Huge computing problems are not going away, but it's tough to see how any supercomputer company is going to survive in the long-term."
Microsoft, in fact, is aiming for one market that supercomputer makers are hoping will be a promising new business for them.
Earlier this year, Microsoft announced its program called Tiger, intended to permit groups of microprocessor-based desktop machines to operate as video servers. If successful, the Tiger software will sharply reduce the cost of computers needed to run the video servers that will deliver movies-on-demand to American households before long.
With the market moving away from its big, costly computers, Thinking Machines has increasingly looked like an endangered species. In 1992, after a General Accounting Office study criticized its funding practices, the Pentagon's Advanced Projects Research Agency froze its spending on large massively parallel machines. Some money was eventually freed, but the shift was a setback for Thinking Machines.
The private company's sales fell from $92 million in 1992 to $83 million last year, while losses mounted from $17 million to $20 million. The company went through a management shake-up last fall when its cofounder Sheryl Handler stepped down as president; she left the company altogether last April. Richard Fishman, a corporate lawyer who became the company's president last year, acknowledges that Thinking Machines was slow to face up to its problems, adjust its strategy and go after the mainstream of the high-performance computing market.
"We didn't do what we should have done," he said. "There was a view that our technology was so superior that no one could challenge us. We were wrong."
For Mr. Hillis, the cofounder of Thinking Machines, the experience has proven to be a painful one, but not without rewards.
"The nation set a goal that was clear and specific and now they've changed the goal and we're left having made the investment," he said.
The technology the company pioneered has become an accepted standard in all segments of the computing industry.
"We may die, but we didn't fail," he said.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Foreigners Drive Tokyo's Movements

BYLINE: By James Sterngold 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
It may say Tokyo Stock Exchange over the entrance and the players are predominantly Japanese, but ask an analyst these days who is really controlling the fate of the stock market here, and the answer is likely to be the unexpected -- foreigners.
With overseas investors having loaded up on billions of dollars in Japanese equities in the first half of the year, the Japanese market was one of the strongest in the world. The Nikkei index of 225 issues shot up 18 percent to 20,521.70 on Friday from the beginning of 1994. 
 In dollar terms, the run looks even better. Since the yen rocketed in value against the dollar, the index here has risen about 31 percent on a dollar basis, making Japan, for all its economic woes, a hot investment play.
The past month, however, has been less kind, due in large part to concern over the yen and lack of progress in trade talks between Japan and the United States, which hit an impasse last weekend.
The market has drifted sideways, and several times threatened to break below 20,000. A key reason is that the foreigners, spooked by concerns over the yen, stopped buying. Government figures show foreign investors sold about $500 million more equities than they purchased last month.
Japanese institutions, among the richest in the world, just have not had the appetite to push up their own market. "The biggest question for me is, when are the Japanese going to buy?" said John Baldwin, an analyst here with Jardine Fleming Securities. "My view is they don't need to be buying their own market and they still have major balance sheet problems. If the foreigners are selling, there's nobody else to pick up the slack."
He added, "I see it as a supply and demand thing. There is still an awful lot of share disposal Japanese institutions need to do, and I don't see a lot of interest in picking that up. Some areas of the economy may be improving, but I see it as a kind of profitless prosperity."
Not everyone is that pessimistic, but it is clear that Japanese institutions -- commercial banks, trust banks and insurance companies -- are suffering from two major problems. The collapse of the stock market and the slowdown in the economy four years ago has left a potent residue of bad debts and battered balance sheets throughout corporate Japan. Most analysts say they believe it may take another several years to clean up the mess and restore confidence.
In addition, the recent steep rise in the value of the yen to a near record high of about 100 yen to the dollar, could have a harsh impact. The strong currency has hurt exporters, threatening profits and the recovery. Most expect the economy to grow only about 1 percent this year.
Every time trade talks with Washington get stuck, as they did a week ago, the yen tends to strengthen, because investors expect Japan's surplus to rise further. It does not help that the new prime minister, Tomiichi Murayama, is a Socialist whose party has traditionally tended to be protectionist.
Surprisingly, though, many analysts see this as a temporary lull. They generally expect foreigners to renew their buying because they tend to believe the yen has peaked. And, overall, few expect the economic recovery to get derailed.
"In my view, it's looking more and more like the yen's strength is over," said Jeff Bahrenburg, the strategist for Merrill Lynch Japan. "The economy is going to pick up, and that will do a lot to lower the trade surplus. If the market does decline a lot, I would see that as an opportunity to buy. This has been a bull market correction." However, he added, "It is still a problem that the domestic institutions have been so quiet."
Mr. Bahrenburg said he is forecasting that, within the next nine months or so, the market could well hit 24,000.
Kathy Matsui, the strategist at Goldman Sachs (Japan), is also confident, and has focused not on whether to buy but what to buy. She just returned from a trip to the United States, where, she said, she found many institutions neutral on Japan at the moment. She said, though, that that could be temporary.
"I think a lot of foreigners will be buying on weakness," she said. "The surprise could be on the upside." But Ms. Matsui added, "The domestic institutions are going to remain very cautious. They are still very skeptical. Foreigners are still the marginal players. They can swing things."
Ms. Matsui is focusing on second tier stocks and other shares left behind in the bull run earlier this year. She said she is recommending basic industries like chemical companies, steel companies and shipbuilders, in anticipation of a stronger economy. Ms. Matsui is even putting commercial real estate companies on her buy list.
Even Mr. Baldwin said he sees opportunities in selected areas. He said he will stay away from banks and financial stocks, but that telecommunications companies and selected retailers are benefiting not just from a slowly improving economy but a shift toward restructuring and new businesses.
Yuichi Matsushita, the strategist for Nikko Securities, said he thinks the worst is past because corporate Japan is already working hard to deal with the yen at 100 to the dollar.
"I'm relatively optimistic," he said, "because even if the yen went to 95 or so to the dollar, it wouldn't be a surprise."
He said that, while the Nikkei index might slip slightly below 20,000, it would be temporary, and that he expects the index to rise as high as 25,000 by year's end.

LENGTH: 1453 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: July 31 - August 5

BYLINE: By Brett Brune 

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
July Employment Numbers Add Up to Higher Rates
Job growth is going up, up and away -- so that the inflation-fighting Fed is likely to act this month to raise interest rates a fifth time this year. President Clinton was quick to point out that more than four million new jobs -- the number he pledged to produce by the end of this year -- have been created since he took office. That's all well and good, but he can't take all the credit. Last spring, the economy proved it sometimes has a life of its own; before the Administration was able to present its ill-fated stimulus package to Congress, payrolls jumped in May. Labor Secretary Robert Reich warned then not to "put too much weight on a single month's numbers." Last week, he said figures for July are "further proof that job growth is continuing its solid, steady course." In July, the economy created 259,000 new jobs, about 60,000 more than consensus forecasts. Average hourly earnings rose by 4 cents, to $11.12.
 
Japan Trade Is a Sticky Situation
Talk about bad timing. The Clinton Administration has decided it's time to get tough with Japan on trade. Last week, it formally accused Japan of discriminating against American companies in awarding some contracts. But the Administration is putting on the gloves amid such dizzying political turmoil in Japan that the Asian target's outline is fuzzy: Japan has had four Prime Ministers in a little more than a year. A former United States trade official said prodding a decision out of the "collection of ministries" was like "punching a marshmallow." In the process, experts say, the dollar could spill the most blood -- if the United States gets so frustrated it drives down the dollar's value to sell more goods in Japan.
 
Paul Allen's Gizmo Search
Some Lollapalooza goers are getting more than they bargained for this year. Besides jamming to their favorite alternative-rock bands and hanging loose in the summer heat, some will likely help determine what will be the next gadget or two appearing on store shelves everywhere. Last week, Paul Allen -- a software billionaire who cofounded Microsoft and owns Ticketmaster and part of Egghead Software -- flew to Providence, R.I., to check out his $3 million technology exhibition roaming the country with the music fest. His goal is to discover the next big hit in consumer electronics. Among the computerized offerings the concertgoers experienced was the "Baby Maker" software program, which lets a couple -- regardless of sex -- combine their images digitally to see what their offspring would look like.
 
Clinton Wants R-E-S-P-E-C-T
Dissatisfied with the little bit of commendation he's getting for the economy's performance, President Clinton last week held a news conference to sing his own praises. The White House also brought out backup vocals: eight top economic officials who touted their agencies' successes in the last 18 months. Commerce Secretary Brown harmonized: "I don't think that the President has gotten the credit that he has deserved."
 
Dog Days of Retail
The Gap made a little money in July. The Limited lost a little. But Sears and Woolworth lapped up gains. "The trend in July is no trend," one retail analyst remarked. "Sales are really all over the board." Those erratic sales leave few clues about where sales are headed. The only thread of the retail story is that diversified retailers -- discounters and department stores -- are doing better than stores that simply sell clothing. Sometimes, much better. The merchandise group at Sears, Roebuck announced it sold more appliances the last week of July than in any other week in its history.
 
COMPANIES
 
Upjohn Pays its Probers
Did too! Did not! Did too! Did not! Whatever happened, Upjohn last week agreed to pay $650,000 to several state investigative agencies. In New York, the Attorney General said Upjohn violated state laws against deceptive and misleading business practices when, from September 1992 to March 1993, it paid pharmacists $8 every time a patient they consulted switched from one diabetes drug (Micronase, which lost its patent protection two years ago) to another (Glynase, which is still protected). Upjohn said last week it did nothing wrong in its marketing plan but it would pay eight states -- Arizona, Iowa, Minnesota, Missouri, New York, North Carolina, Texas and Wisconsin -- about $84,000 each for their investigative costs.
 
Time Out at Nasdaq
For 34 minutes one day last week, Nasdaq trading was interrupted after a squirrel chewed through a power line and the stock trading system's backup power system failed to kick in. The hapless squirrel can be forgiven. But can the nation's second-largest stock market? It has, after all, donned the garb of a technological leader and seduced leading high-tech companies -- Intel and Microsoft -- that look mighty alluring on its arm. And the outage was only one of three technological breakdowns at Nasdaq since July 14.
 
Cyanamid Gets the Looks
Not long ago, American Cyanamid's dance card was empty. (Earlier this decade, when the company's focus was on manufacturing chemicals, it was an outcast that watched its stock price slide for two dreadfully long years.) In came a new C.E.O., who in the last 18 months has transformed the concern into a health care and agricultural products company by cutting costs and shedding sorry divisions. The makeover worked. Last week, American Home Products presented American Cyanamid with a surprise, $8.5 billion cash takeover offer, causing the company's stock to soar more than 40 percent. Several more suitors may be lining up. Securities experts say European drug and chemical concerns like Bayer, Ciba-Geigy, Hoechst and Zenaca could offer even better propositions.
 
MGM Puts Faith in Vegas
How obsessed are Americans with gambling? Very, MGM and Primadonna Resorts suggested last week when they bet $300 million on yet another Vegas gambling center. (MGM itself just opened the nation's biggest casino resort there six months ago, at a cost of $1 billion.) The latest casino -- New York-New York -- is also one in a string of projects taking shape while Las Vegas luxuriates in a record summer. "This is a sign of confidence in the Las Vegas market," said a University of Las Vegas professor, "but this rush-ahead, rush-ahead philosophy is a gamble, and the fact that MGM cut someone else in indicates that they think it is something of a crap shoot, too."
 
What Now for Barry Diller?
It's a done deal -- unless a more generous offer surfaces in the next month. Barry Diller's QVC, the home shopping channel, is set to be taken over by the cable television giants Tele-Communications Inc. and Comcast. If a better bid does come along, QVC would pay TCI and Comcast a $55 million breakup fee. Otherwise, as agreed last week, the cable duo will snare QVC for $2.5 billion. Ever since Diller joined QVC as chairman about a year and a half ago, he has been seeking a partner. He also courted Home Shopping Network, Paramount Communications and CBS. The restless Diller is not expected to stay.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Out of (South) Africa, Still
Jailed, he inspired song and sit-ins. The personification of how blacks were persecuted under apartheid in South Africa, he was the torch investor activists and students carried to light fires under American companies to divest themselves of operations there. But now that Nelson Mandela is free and leading his country, he can't get investors' attention. Last week -- 10 months after he formally invited foreign business to return -- a snapshot of investment activity since April showed more foreign money flowing out than in, despite the fact that advance scouts of Western dough last year promised investment if peace prevailed and Mandela embraced the free market. Now, potential investors complain about things like a costly labor force and trade barriers.
 
China Market's Painful Start
 When the Chinese Communist Government held its reborn stock market by the feet and slapped its bottom to get it breathing in 1990, China was unprepared for the challenge -- and pains -- the market would bring once it started walking. While the market created quick fortunes for a handful of investors and hit record highs early last year, it wasn't long before it took a fall. Recent months brought a near collapse, and when many first-time Chinese investors panicked and sold off shares, they lost their life savings. Last week, however, the index for the Chinese-only A shares more than doubled. Some frustrated investors vowed to abandon the market and its vagaries. And others talked about "winning" back their losses.

HEADLINE: GARDENING;
The Bug Battle, With Natural Weapons

BYLINE: By JOAN LEE FAUST 

 BODY:
HOLES in leaves are discouraging evidence for any gardener. They indicate that some unwanted creature is about.
Time was that a pesticide was the solution. But times have changed. Creepy crawlers are still about, but instead of rushing for a quick solution, one seeks the identity of the enemy and a safe way to eradicate it. Quite often all-out war is not really necessary. 
 Take the slug problem, for instance. (Those who are squeamish can go on to the next paragraph.) One of the easiest ways to conquer the ubiquitous slug is to hunt it at night with a flashlight. Wear gloves and take along a deep can filled with heavily salted water. Turn over leaves of the slugs' favorite plants such as hosta, dahlias, lettuce -- well, almost anything. Pick off the slugs and drop them into the can of salted water. After a few nights of hunting, no more slugs.
Or try a less direct method: diatomaceous earth. Dust it over the plants, making sure to get under the leaves, and goodbye slugs. Two cautions, however. Be sure to wear a mask during application so the dust does not get into your lungs. Also, apply this dust after rains, and, as it will make the garden look as though someone spilled flour on the plants, do not use it in show areas.
Another common hunt-and-destroy mission involves the enormous tomato hornworm. These caterpillars, about the size of your thumb, devour tomato leaves. Usually tomato plants have just a few of these critters, and the caterpillars are so slow they are easy to pick off the plants and stomp.
Since these caterpillars are the color of the tomato plant stem, they sometimes are difficult to spot. Just look for the pepperlike frass they leave behind and follow their trail.
There are so many other natural weapons in pest warfare, there should be no need to resort to chemicals. A recent manual on natural enemies published by Cornell University states, "Pesticides should be used only to prevent an economic loss."
The Cornell manual, "Natural Enemies of Vegetable Insect Pests," offers an excellent in-depth look at the subject. Written by Michael P. Hoffmann and Anne C. Frodsham, it allows readers to learn about the concepts and uses of biological controls of insects.
It is well illustrated, with color photographs of many insects as well as a number of line drawings. It is available from Cornell University (NVP), Media Services Resource Center, 7 BTP, Ithaca, N.Y. 14850 at a price of $22.50 a copy.
Of biological controls now available for insects, one of the most popular in recent years has been the Safer Products. These are basically soaps derived from fatty acids and are available at most garden sales centers.
One of the appealing things about these sprays is that they are effective on so many of the soft-bodied pests and break down in two days' time.
The Safer spray is also recommended in fighting that devastator of the hemlocks, the woolly adelgid. The recommendation now is to use a dormant oil spray in the spring, usually April, followed by an application of the Safer spray in late May to mid-June. If the horticultural oil spray was missed this past spring, then an application of the Safer spray can be made in late September.
Another popular biological control is the chain of Bt products. The initial product, Bacillus thuringiensis, is specific for the caterpillar phase of many insect pests such as codling moths, cabbage loopers and many of the bagworms. A special strain of this specific bacteria, Bti, has been developed to control mosquito and black fly larvae. It, too, can be found at many supply centers, or by mail order from the Necessary Trading Company, New Castle, Va. 24127-0305.
For those who do not like to spray there are all sorts of traps. One of the most effective traps for white fly is the obvious-looking sticky yellow sheet that can be inserted in a metal holder and poked into the soil around favorite plants. These are especially popular with house plant enthusiasts who do not like to use sprays indoors. The traps are widely available in stores or by mail from Worm's Way, 3151 South Highway 446, Bloomington, Ind. 47401.
For those who have home orchards, Gardener's Supply (128 Intervale Road, Burlington Vt. 05401) sells a kit of traps developed by researchers at the University of Massachusetts. Chief item in this arsenal is the red sphere, which looks like a ripe apple, but controls apple maggots as well as cherry fruit flies. This catalogue also lists the hard-to-find netting for fruit trees and berry bushes.
With a little effort and knowledge, the creepy crawlers can be kept out of the garden without pesticides. It just takes a change of attitude and desire to keep things under control, safely.
