HEADLINE: Head Start Expanding Despite Problems

BYLINE: By PHILLIP LUTZ 

 BODY:
HEAD START, the Federal program for preschoolers that began in the 1960's, is expanding. Despite problems nationally and on Long Island, Head Start, unlike many other Great Society programs, is serving growing numbers of people with a greater variety of services.
This summer plans are moving forward for continuing expansion. 
 But the demand for services is so strong that nearly half the children who qualify will not find places in the program in the fall, and many of those who do will attend sessions in crowded, rundown buildings.
For those children, many of whom already suffer from drugs, disease and homelessness, the benefits of Head Start could be blunted, experts in the field say.
"Head Start might be less effective than in the 1960's, because the problems are more severe," said Linda Devin-Sheehan, executive director of L.I. Head Start Child Development Services, the largest operator of Head Start programs on the Island. "Obviously there's only so much we can do, and we don't do as much as needs to be done. But we do have a tremendous impact."
The number of children in the four federally designated Head Start agencies on the Island increased 11 percent over the last two years, to more than 2,100, according to officials in the Manhattan office of the Administration for Children and Families, the bureau of the Department of Health and Human Services that oversees the programs in New York and New Jersey and on Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.
The four agencies' combined operating budgets from the Health and Human Services Department increased 23 percent, to a total of more than $12 million in the 1994 fiscal year, the officials said.
The increases locally mirrored those of the program nationally. Over the last two years Head Start's budget increased nearly 20 percent, to $3.3 billion in the 1994 fiscal year. In that period, the number of children enrolled increased, to 750,000 from 621,000.
In May, President Clinton signed legislation reauthorizing Head Start for the next four years. His Head Start budget proposal for the 1995 fiscal year is $4 billion, also a 20 percent increase. The number of participants would grow, to 840,000 nationally, an increase that would be reflected on the Island, officials said.
At the two major agencies in Nassau and Suffolk Counties the number of classrooms and employees have each expanded over the last two years, to a total of 92 and 358, respectively, officials said. Those figures would increase under Mr. Clinton's proposals, as well. The program is also growing in diversity. Head Start sites, where children receive early education, social skills and improved nutrition, are increasingly being used to deliver medical services. Under a $151,000 grant from the State Health Department up to 1,300 children in Suffolk this year will receive screenings, immunizations and other services, as well as referrals to the University Medical Center at Stony Brook.
The services will be provided or arranged by a diagnostic and treatment center, Just Kids of Middle Island, which plans to modify Head Start centers, hire two nurse-practitioners and train staff members.
Children in Head Start generally come from households with incomes below the poverty line, which is $14,800 for a family of four.
The parents of Head Start children will begin to receive medical services at program sites under an agreement between Just Kids and the Suffolk Health Services Department, said Dr. Virginia M. Barry, a consultant to Just Kids.
Nassau Head Start is expected to begin a program offering mental-health services with the North Shore Child and Family Guidance Center in Roslyn Heights, said Jean Davis, deputy director of Head Start under the Nassau Economic Opportunity Commission.
Educational services are also scheduled to expand in the fall under a program placing disabled and nondisabled children in the classroom. About 12 percent of the Head Start enrollment on the Island is classified as disabled.
Under the program, in which an affiliated preschool of Just Kids trains teachers, the number of sites with formally integrated classrooms, which increased from three to five in the last two years, is scheduled to grow to seven next month.
Head Start is also planning to provide services at a drug-treatment center for women and children that Apple, the largest drug-treatment operator on the Island, is developing in Lake Ronkonkoma.
That would be one of the first ventures into caring for infants and toddlers. About 3 percent of the budget is being devoted to the youngest children. Most programs now serve children from 3 to 5.
The growth of Head Start is partly a response to increased demands to help the children of the working poor and the influx of Haitian and Hispanic immigrants, Ms. Davis said.
Perceptions that the program is successful have generated many enrollment applications, said Junius Scott, director of program coordination and planning for the Children and Families Administration in Manhattan.
In Suffolk the program operates from September through the end of June, with some sessions split because of overcrowding. But in Nassau the program operates full-day sessions from September through early August.
Long waiting lists have become common, spurring a difficult search for new locations. "Our biggest problem is finding space," Ms. Davis said.
In Nassau the program administered by the Economic Opportunity Commission supervises nine sites that delegated agencies operate. Another agency, the Glen Cove Child Day Care Center, operates a site under a separate Federal grant.
In the last four years Nassau has added classrooms in Roosevelt and Hempstead, where the waiting list of 180 is twice the length of the enrollment list, Ms. Davis said. Waiting lists on the Island average about 40 a site, officials said.
By next month Head Start hopes to end talks for a site in Elmont, where it would add three classrooms for 45 youngsters, Ms. Davis said.
In Suffolk, L.I. Head Start operates all 14 of its sites. Another agency, Children's Community Head Start, operates two sites under a separate Federal grant.
Workers from a contractor in Port Jefferson, Construction Consultants/ L.I., have been assembling modular units for a six-room center in Brentwood. The center, being built on land on Wicks Road donated by the school district, will be a definite improvement over the last three centers that the program has had, officials said.
Between April and the end of the school year in June the 122 children in the program occupied a Hispanic social club to which they moved after encountering mice in a church-owned building that had been their home. Before that the Brentwood children were bused to Central Islip, where they shared space with children in the program there.
At least five programs in Suffolk have to move because of deteriorating conditions like leaky roofs, crowded basements and the sharing of kitchens and bathrooms with homeless adults, Ms. Devin-Sheehan said.
She declined to specify which sites had problems, but Roberta Turner, a member of the Parents Policy Council, which represents parents and guardians in negotiations, said the centers in Patchogue and Bay Shore were too small.
Ms. Devin-Sheehan said that she wanted to move the children in two years, but that could depend on obtaining a long-term lease or a donation of space. "We need an angel," she said.
The buildings in Nassau also suffer from problems like leaky roofs, broken windows and lack of parking, Ms. Davis said. "Maintenance and upkeep of a facility is difficult," she added.
Despite the conditions, the expansion of services represents a rebound from labor and financial problems in September 1990 that delayed the opening in Suffolk.
Federal officials faulted the Suffolk program then for poor record keeping, a lack of bidding documents to buy carpeting and a platform for the Brentwood center and improper documentation of travel expenses. After a review the Federal officials ordered Suffolk Head Start to resolve the problems, with assistance from the Health and Human Services Department, Mr. Scott said. There was no reason to take legal action, he added.
With the corrections in force and the program under new leadership -- Ms. Devin-Sheehan has been in her post since May 1993 -- the problems have been resolved, Mr. Scott said.
The agency was also faulted in 1990 for holding back nearly $40,000 of money from the State Social Services Department that was supposed to increase the salaries of teachers and other workers. Twenty percent of local Head Start financing has to come from sources other than the Federal Government.
"During that period there was some tension," said Ragland George, a spokesman for District Council 1707 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, which represents the Head Start workers. "Some money was held because they were in the trauma of negotiating."
"People were trying to unionize," Mr. Scott said. "Conflict arose."
After the delay in opening the program workers obtained a union contract, and the agency gave them lump-sum payments of $312 to $632 an employee. The situation is stable, Mr. George added.
Although Suffolk workers are now unionized, those in Nassau are not. "We've been able not to get involved in that," Ms. Davis said. Organizers "were at our door a couple of years ago, but it does not work well in our kind of environment."
The Health and Human Services Department does not favor or oppose unionization, Mr. Scott said.
Programs have run into other problems like charges of child abuse and mismanagement. In January 1993 a program in Farmingdale was criticized for poor management. The local director was disorganized, Ms. Davis said, and was replaced. The problem has been resolved, Mr. Scott said.
But staffing remains a problem. The salaries are low, and turnover is high. Although pay has increased, teachers in the Nassau program earn $18,000 a year, Ms. Davis said. Those in Suffolk earn $16,000, according to Ms. Devin-Sheehan.
Most of nearly $1 million in supplemental Federal grants that might be available for the four agencies this year would go to increase the salaries in an attempt to retain the best workers, officials said.
Under the reauthorization bill local programs are under pressure to maintain or improve the quality of their staffs. By Sept. 30, 1996, all classroom teachers have to have a Child Development Associate credential or another appropriate qualification.
With comprehensive training in place, Ms. Devin-Sheehan said, all the teachers in L.I. Head Start have that credential. More than half in the Nassau Economic Opportunity Commission programs have it, too, Ms. Davis said.
To improve efficiency and workers' skills Head Start has introduced technology like fully computerizing the Suffolk program. Four of the nine Nassau sites are also computerized.
But even as the program makes strides, experts say, the condition of the average enrollee is poorer.
"Today," said a report released in December by a advisory committee named by the Health and Human Services Secretary, Dr. Donna E. Shalala, "the needs of families and children who live in poverty are more complicated and urgent than ever before -- from children who have lived with violence and substance abuse to families with interrelated problems of homelessness, lack of education and unemployment."
"We've seen a decline in the condition of the kids," said Ms. Devin-Sheehan, who was the principal planner for youth services in Suffolk before moving to Head Start. "The recession has completely eroded social services. Nonprofit child-care agencies have suffered tremendously in the last five years."
"It increases the work Head Start has to do," Ms. Davis said. "Kids are coming in frightened and hungry."
That is one reason that some critics question the effectiveness of certain elements of the program and whether the growth should be limited until quality standards are more firmly in place.
Some studies of Head Start show that although children appear to make immediate intellectual gains, the effects fade quickly, and they do not score consistently better on intelligence tests than children from similarly disadvantaged backgrounds who have not been in Head Start.
Other studies show that Head Start children are less likely to be placed in special classes or to be classified as disabled than children with similar backgrounds who have not been in the program.
Few long-term studies of Head Start children have been conducted. But one widely known study, at the Perry Preschool Project in Ypslanti, Mich., showed that 20 years after leaving Head Start the children, now young adults, were more likely to have finished high school, held a job and avoided teen-age pregnancy and troubles with law enforcement.
That result is reflected in the history of Wendy Oyebode, 26, of Hempstead. Ms. Oyebode, who is married, said that when she participated in Freeport Head Start more than 20 years ago she had had a variety of experiences that she might not have had without the program, living with her aunt on very little money.
She credits good work habits in part to her early exposure to teaching materials at Head Start. While many people of her age and socioeconomic status became victims of social problems, Ms. Oyebode graduated from Rutgers University, entered a master's program at Dowling College and is looking forward to a career in special education.
"I probably wouldn't have done as well," she said.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Betting on the Sympathy Vote

BYLINE: By Andrea Adelson 

 BODY:
RANDALL D. HUBBARD, a 30-year horse breeder and chairman of Hollywood Park Inc., is making some big bets these days.
In the last year, Mr. Hubbard has begun to assemble a national race track empire, acquiring tracks in states where he hopes casino-style gambling will be legalized. His ambitious strategy is to replicate at those tracks the sort of entertainment complex that is taking shape alongside Hollywood Park's track in Inglewood, Calif., where a cavernous card parlor opened last month. 
 For investors in Hollywood Park, clearly horses are only part of a broader play on the fortunes of the gambling economy, which is growing explosively. Analysts say Mr. Hubbard is adapting to today's gambling environment by building alliances between tracks and other types of gambling, a strategy they say will make Hollywood Park's stock outperform the industry.
While Mr. Hubbard's strategy does play well on some parts of Wall Street, investors would do well to gauge political sentiment in Kansas, California and Arizona before making their own bets. Hollywood Park now has track interests in those states. But regulators say there is little chance casino-style gambling there will expand outside tribal lands. And without the casinos at the track, where bettors could play the horses or the slot machines, Mr. Hubbard's idea is in trouble.
"There are big problems in all three states," said I. Nelson Rose, a gambling law expert and professor at the Whittier Law School in Los Angeles. "I would not put my money on that."
Hollywood Park had a $2.6 million loss in the quarter ended March 31. Last year, revenue was $63 million, a 5.4 percent decline from the comparable period a year ago.
Despite these problems, Hollywood's stock has held up, especially compared to other gambling shares, which have dropped sharply since Spring.
The company's stock closed Friday at $22.75 up 1/8. That is well below its high of $35 last September. But it is still over its recent low of $15.75. At the same time, the CBOE Gaming Index has given back all its gains of the last year and a half. The sell-off began in March after President Clinton suggested a casino revenue tax and Missouri voters said no to slot machines.
The importance of the political outlook for Hollywood Park is seen in its earnings forecasts. Jason N. Ader, Smith Barney Shearson's gaming analyst, predicted earnings will jump 2.5 times to $1.20 a share next year, up from 48 cents in 1994.
But he concedes that "the company's earnings growth is dependent on uncertain legislation and it is possible that earnings could grow at a meaningfully slower pace."
Mr. Hubbard is going for the sympathy vote. His bet is that lawmakers will help track owners who have been hurt by the new gambling parlors. But they may not be sympathetic to an outsider who bought race tracks with his eyes wide open, knowing that revenues were in danger.
Overall wagering increased last year by 17 percent to $394 billion and poured $34.7 billion into the coffers of gaming companies, according to Gaming & Wagering Business magazine. But horse racing revenue declined. States that permit Indian casinos and riverboat gambling as a fiscal panacea are also seeing lottery and racing revenue decline as bettors ante up elsewhere. To keep tracks from closing, some states have helped out by allowing slot machines at the tracks.
And that is Mr. Hubbard's aim. In a $20 million deal mostly involving stock, Hollywood Park in March acquired The Woodlands, a dog and horse track in Kansas City, Kan., across the river from Missouri's floating casinos. Shareholder approval is expected this month for the company's $34 million stock acquisition of Turf Paradise, a race track in Arizona, where Indian gaming has blossomed on 10 reservations.
"I think it's a safe bet, very shrewd," said Thomas M. Ryan of Ladenburg, Thalman.
State gaming officials think otherwise. In Kansas, where lawmakers have disapproved of Indian gambling, a bill to permit casino gambling beside tracks died for lack of support during the recent session.
In Arizona, as gambling compacts were being signed with Indian tribes in 1991, four tracks, including Turf Paradise, pleaded for slot machines to offset expected losses. "It didn't go anywhere," said Gary C. Fitzsimmons, assistant to the director of the state Department of Racing. Even the closure of a track in Yuma has not softened Gov. Fife Symington's opposition to non-reservation gambling.
But if the politicians go against gambling in Arizona and Kansas, Mr. Hubbard may get a small return on his bet in California. While there is not a whisper about legalizing casinos in California, there is a proposal for a state gambling commission and a chance for a law that would allow Mr. Hubbard to reap the full profits from the card parlor opened last month at Hollywood Park.
That proposal is supported by Mr. Hubbard, who made more than $10,000 in contributions to state politicians in 1992. The bill would also revise current laws to permit the licensing of public companies for card clubs. That change would open the door to Las Vegas operators, Mr. Ryan said, and make Hollywood Park a takeover candidate.
Unless state laws are changed, Hollywood Park will be forced to continue to license its $20 million, 140 table card club through a third-party, which means Mr. Hubbard must settle for a flat lease fee and only a portion of the $25 million in projected annual operating profits. Clubs differ from casinos in that players bet against each other, rather than the house, and pay a fee per hand.
"I thought it was a terrific idea," said Michael Steiniger, one of 12,000 poker players who came to the club's opening. "Gamblers never get enough."
That may be so. But if Hollywood Park doesn't have better luck in Arizona and Kansas, what is good for the gambler may not be so good for the investor.

HEADLINE: Who Pays the Price Of a Nuclear Plant?

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
IF you owned a 1989 Buick Century and your tax bill went up because of a revaluation, you might write the check and not give it a second thought. But suppose you also owned a 1993 Century in another town nearby, and your taxes were less than one-third as much?
That's the situation facing Northeast Utilities with its Connecticut Yankee nuclear plant in Haddam. In a 1991 revaluation in which the company expected to see its assessment drop considerably, it saw it increase sharply instead. The property tax dispute, the largest in Connecticut history, is being now played out in court. Haddam says an appraisal by Dean & Associates, an engineering consulting company in McMurray, Pa., determined the nuclear plant, which cost $109 million to build in 1969, is worth about $840 million today. 
 Northeast has introduced as evidence in its behalf appraisals from two assessors that it hired: $219.4 million and $230 million.
The utility company's supervisor for property taxes, Richard S. Zajack, said an appraisal is supposed to reflect fair market value, and that anyone buying the plant would have to recover the purchase price plus $339 million in decommissioning costs for the remaining 13 years that the plant is able to be operated under its current license. "Any reasonable buyer would consider that up front, and walk away from it," Mr. Zajack said.
Marjorie W. Debold, whose election as First Selectman last year came after the dispute started, said the town stands by its appraisal, and has hired the Hartford law firm of Robinson & Cole to defend it in court.
"The town feels that it's acted in good faith and has done what was appropriate," Ms. Debold said. "The town based its findings on the information available to it."
Northeast contends the suit will have dire consequences whichever way it turns out. If Northeast wins, Haddam will be in a position where it will have to pay back millions of dollars in overbilled taxes, perhaps more than $20 million, which would be devastating for a small town. "Do they go issue bonds? Go seek some kind of legislative relief? Maybe they raise taxes?" pondered Robert A. Bersak, an assistant general counsel for Northeast. "I suppose they could even consider bankruptcy, although the state has been opposed to allowing towns to go that route."
"Certainly if I was a property owner in Haddam, I'd be concerned," Mr. Bersak said. "They'd go from having one of the three lowest tax rates in the state to one of the highest, virtually overnight."
If Haddam wins, Northeast officials say, it would mean dramatically higher tax bills for the utility's property elsewhere, as towns where 100 other generating plants are situated appraise them under the new criteria.
"We're in 168 of the state's 169 towns, and you can rest assured every one of them would be lining up already if this decision wasn't challenged," said Northeast's manager of plant accounting, David G. Lenihan. And, he said, since the law allows Northeast to pass the property taxes on to its customers via higher rates, it would mean ratepayers in all those other towns would be subsidizing taxpayers in Haddam if the tax is too high.
"Probably what they were told by Dean was that somewhere down the road we'd settle, we'd split the difference and they'd be ahead of the game," Mr. Lenihan said. "But we can't."
A spokesman for Northeast, Anthony J. Castagno, said Haddam's appraisal is particularly troubling because it is based in part on the value of modern nuclear plants, instead of 25-year-old technology.
"This argument could be used to increase the assessment on any industrial facility," Mr. Castagno said. "If it were to prevail in Haddam, every town around the state would be doing a revaluation."
"The difference is, if they did this to an industrial taxpayer, the industrial taxpayer would move out of state," Mr. Castagno said. "Obviously, we can't do that with a nuclear plant."
Mr. Zajack noted that high utility rates also hurt all businesses.
"If we can't keep our rates low we're not going to attract business to Connecticut," Mr. Zajack said. "In fact, if the rates go up we're going to drive business out of state."
Lawyers for both sides in the case are analyzing the two new appraisals done for Northeast, and will continue taking depositions until early next year. Mr. Bersak said he expected it could be 1996 or 1997 before a decision is rendered.
Connecticut Yankee has been the mainstay of the Haddam tax base since it began generating electricity on Jan. 1, 1968. In fact, the town recently formed an economic development commission to develop other industry in town to help the town though 2007, the year the plant is scheduled to be shut down, although Ms. Debold acknowledges, "It is going to be difficult to find anything to take its place."
Until the end of 1991 the plant accounted for 51 percent of the value of all taxable property in town, but because it is getting old its value was expected to drop. Instead, the value increased, to 57 percent of the taxable property in town, because of the appraisal method used by Dean & Associates.
Stephen R. Dean, managing principal of Dean & Associates, declined to comment while the assessment is in litigation, but he outlined his appraisal methods in an article he wrote with Robert S. Wilson, a lawyer for Dean & Associates, published in the September-October 1993 issue of Assessment Digest, the professional journal of the International Association of Assessing Officers.
The article said 30 percent of the appraisal was based on what it would cost to build a similar plant today, which yielded an appraisal of $987.5 million. Half the new appraisal was based on what the firm estimated the plant would earn during its remaining life, which yielded a value of $749 million, and the remainder of the assessment was based on the sale of shares in other nuclear plants, which yielded a value of $830 million.
The blended value, therefore, is $840 million, according to the Dean assessment. In the Assessment Digest, they said they rejected the company's offer to use the plant's net book value, which is used by most towns and is the value regulators use to set the company's electric rates.
"In our opinion, the utility's net book value method is improper because Connecticut law states all property is to be assessed at fair market value, and industrial property is sold every week at more than net book value," they wrote.
But Mr. Castagno said Dean's appraisal was faulty in other respects. For instance, he said, you can't set a nuclear plant's value based on what it would bring on the open market, because no one would be interested in buying it.
"Nowadays there's such a surplus of electricity I don't know of any utility that's building a plant, or in the market for a plant," Mr. Castagno said. "And even without that excess, if we were to build another plant it's highly unlikely that it would be a nuclear plant," because of the regulation, the risk and the cost.
Mr. Bersak said Northeast was going to challenge Dean's credentials in court. The Pennsylvania company had to obtain a temporary appraisal certificate in Connecticut, had never handled a nuclear plant appraisal before Haddam, and was not even familiar with some of the designations for professional appraisers, he said.
Mr. Bersak noted that the appraisers hired by Northeast -- AUS Consultants and Stone & Webster, which builds nuclear plants -- have national reputations in the utility appraisal field, and that their valuations came in within about 5 percent of each other. "It gives you some confidence that the value is meaningful," he said.
Mr. Bersak said the Ocean State Power Company in Rhode Island recently built a gas-powered plant that generates more than 500 megawatts, similar to Connecticut Yankee's 591 megawatts. It cost $406.5 million.
Also by comparison, the town of Waterford has appraised Northeast's Millstone 1 nuclear plant for $250 million, and Millstone 2 for $450 million. Those plants are both newer, and considerably larger, than Connecticut Yankee, but their combined appraisal is less than what Haddam has said Connecticut Yankee is worth.
"Something's wrong with this picture," Mr. Bersak said. "Primarily, it's a matter of economics. Towns are trying to find revenues at a time when growth has stopped, and we're an attractive target."
At Northeast, company officials are worried about the public image the company will project if it wins the case, and is forced to collect millions of dollars back from Haddam. But he said Northeast must also look out for its customers, who pay any extra taxes in the form of higher rates.
"We've always worked with every town we've done business in," Mr. Bersak said. "We've attempted to do that in Haddam. But they didn't listen. It's not us putting them in this position, it's them putting them in this position."

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 17; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1629 words

HEADLINE: The Boom in M.R.I.'s: Concerns Grow on Costs and Overuse

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW 

 BODY:
THE growth of magnetic-resonance imaging as a diagnostic tool is generating intense competition for patients, as well as concern about overuse.
M.R.I. makes images of any soft tissue in the body. Unlike conventional X-rays or CAT scans, M.R.I. does not use ionizing radiation. Instead, magnetic fields and computers provide the images, clear and precise pictures of specific areas. Bones stop X-rays, but are transparent in magnetic imaging, making it easier to examine the brain and spinal cord. 
 Magnetic imaging has been used in the United States for a decade. Its power as a diagnostic tool has led to increases in referrals for the procedure by neurologists, neurosurgeons and orthopedic surgeons.
Medical authorities generally say noninvasive and painless magnetic imaging is safe. But it is an expensive outpatient diagnostic procedure. The cost of a full-body system ranges from $1.2 million to $2.5 million. The average charge for a session of 30 to 45 minutes is $1,000, including a radiologist's interpretation.
Many insurers require prior approvals for magnetic images.
Critics contend that less expensive tests can help obtain similar results.
At the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park the imaging machine has been operating at its full capacity of 3,500 procedures a year since the hospital acquired it in 1984.
North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset gave 6,600 patients magnetic images on its two machines last year. In the first six months of this year it administered 4,000.
At Stony Brook University Hospital, 4,963 magnetic images were administered in the year ending June 30, an increase of 1,000 over the previous year.
 
Declines in Other Procedures
 Michael Cortegiano, administrative officer of the radiology department at the Stony Brook Medical School, said many standard radiographic procedures had declined in the last few years coupled with the growing use of M.R.I.'s. "For a look at the abdomen," Mr. Cortegiano said, "M.R.I. has replaced the barium enema, because it gives more information. But is it necessary? Can we get the same results with a cheaper exam? The driving factor here is cost."
At Stony Brook Hospital, Mr. Cortegiano said, guidelines indicate to referring physicians the most appropriate examinations for different sets of symptoms. For some symptoms, he added, it may be better to order an ultrasound examination, which is usually far less costly than a magnetic image.
Dr. David Katz, a radiologist at Advanced Medical Imaging of Long Island, a radiology and imaging center in Great Neck, said the public might often be misled about magnetic images. It is not a screening procedure like mammography or a chest X-ray, Dr. Katz said. Its intended use is solely for a clinical indication of a specific problem that has not been resolved by X-rays or basic diagnostic tests like a physical or laboratory examination.
"As an example, one should not use M.R.I. to locate kidney stones," Dr. Katz said. "This would be a tremendous waste of health-care dollars, in that almost 95 percent of kidney stones can be easily located with X-ray or low-cost ultrasound units. Similarly, while M.R.I. breast imaging is being developed, it is still limited in its effectiveness and cannot yet replace mammography as our best screening test for breast cancer."
A neurosurgeon with Long Island Neurological Associates in New Hyde Park, Dr. Joseph Epstein, said overuse of magnetic imaging was an example of protective medicine, in which physicians try to protect themselves against claims of malpractice.
"If they miss something in a diagnosis they're hit with a malpractice suit," Dr. Epstein said. "Sometimes with an M.R.I. you do pick up something that you never suspected. The question is, 'Does it justify the overuse of the procedure for fear of missing something?'
"As long as we're forced to practice defensive medicine you'll continue to see the overuse of diagnostic studies. It's noninvasive. All it is is money. The abuse of M.R.I. overuse is most evident when doctors prescribe an M.R.I. before even seeing a patient in order to save the time of an extra office visit."
In addition to concerns about overuse, Dr. Epstein said, new research indicates a problem with overinterpretation of images, often erroneously. An M.R.I. can show changes that can stem from the normal aging process or arthritic deformities, he said, adding: "Sometimes this is interpreted as pathology to be operated on or treated vigorously, when it's actually a normal variance. We have to remember that you don't treat the test.You treat the patient's symptoms."
A neurologist in Great Neck, Dr. Dwight Rosenstein, said he had not seen overinterpretation as a problem. "We're very cautious about surgery," Dr. Rosenstein said. "Along with an M.R.I., we always examine the patient and discuss the symptoms. All of the pieces of the puzzle must fit together before there's any surgery."
Critics also point to partnership arrangements, under which referring physicians used to have ownership interest in imaging centers and made profits from referring patients to them. New Federal and state laws prohibit such contracts.
The chief of radiology at North Shore, Dr. Roger A. Hyman, acknowledged that there had been some abuses in imaging procedures, but said that "should not negate the powerful tool we have to diagnose human disease."
"The big picture," Dr. Hyman said, "is that M.R.I. is probably the most important breakthrough in the history of medicine since 1895, when X-ray was first discovered. The phenomenal technology has changed the way we image the face of the human body. If we overreact to the abuses and the high costs, it will bring us back to the Middle Ages, when costs were low and everybody died."
As imaging technology has improved, its uses have expanded. The comptroller of East River Medical Imaging Associates in New York City, John Walczuk, said aside from the primary imaging of the brain and spinal cord, followed by joints, muscles, bones, chest, abdomen and pelvis, new areas include checking blood vessels in the neck and head, arteries in the lower extremities and detecting leaks from breast implants.
Most technology is expensive at first and then comes down in price, said Dr. Lawrence Minkoff, co-founder and chairman of Magna-Lab Inc. of Hicksville, a manufacturer of magnetic imagers. Magna-Lab has produced a lower-cost compact magnetic scanner for extremities like hands, elbows, knees and feet that is awaiting approval from the Food and Drug Administration.
Dr. Minkoff said the smaller unit would allow doctors to produce a greater variety of images of extremities, and possibly heads, at one-half to one-third the cost of whole body scanners.
"Arguments that M.R.I. is overused is not a matter of technology, but one of economics," he said. "In my opinion M.R.I. is not overused, but underutilized. We're now looking at less expensive ways to produce equipment that can do accurate medical diagnoses without invasive surgery."
Competition is growing among imaging centers.
There are basically two types of full-body scanners. In an "open" machine a patient is positioned in a partly enclosed rectangular or oval structure that contains a low- strength magnet. In a conventional, or "closed," machine, a patient is placed in a more tunnel-like enclosure with a much more powerful magnet.
Centers with open machines appeal to patient comfort, because the machines have more space and are less claustrophobic.
Dr. Epstein said 20 percent of his patients could not tolerate a closed machine. "While the magnet is weaker in an open M.R.I.," he said, "for these patients it's a better alternative, because in a closed tunnel they're jumping out of their skin. And because they're moving, the reading is useless."
Dr. Rosenstein said up to half of his patients were claustrophobic and could not tolerate a closed machine. "For much of what we need to see," he said, "open M.R.I. is O.K. But it is not as accurate for fine detail."
Carlos Rivera, manager of M.R.I. of Smithtown, one of 13 sites affiliated with Advanced Diagnostic Imaging of Suffolk County, said open machines were a marketing scheme catering to fears of people who might be claustrophobic. Open machines, he added, do not have the strength to give the clearest pictures with the best contrast. They often take 5 to 15 times as long as conventional machines.
"Unfortunately," Mr. Rivera said. "we end up repeating many M.R.I.'s from patients who go for open M.R.I.'s first and then have to have them redone."
There are differences between centers in hospitals and private offices, Dr. Peter Herman, chairman of radiology at Long Island Jewish, said, adding: "Large teaching hospitals tend to have more subspecialists. But choosing an imaging center is like choosing your internist. You have to go by reputation and recommendation."
No accreditations cover magnetic imaging. The lone board- certified subspecialty of radiology is mammography. Dr. Hyman said the American College of Radiology was studying an accreditation process for magnetic imaging.
Dr. Katz said many radiologists had limited training in magnetic imaging, because the procedure is relatively new.
"An educated consumer is a must," he said. "It's critical to get imaging done by a board-certified radiologist who has been specially trained in M.R.I., who is there not only to oversee the testing procedure and interpret the M.R.I. results, but also to greet the patient, examine him, take a brief medical history and is present during the performance of the M.R.I. itself, so that if additional views are necessary they can be performed on the spot, saving the patient time, money and stress."

HEADLINE: Seeking Protection For Wetland Areas

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

DATELINE: CHAPPAQUA

 BODY:
CONCERN about proposed weakening of Federal protection of national wetlands with the 1972 Clean Water Act scheduled for re-authorization in Congress last month, as well as threats to the county's wetlands from potential developments, prompted 40 environmentalists to attend a recent meeting at the Chappaqua Public Library to learn more about the role of wetlands in maintaining water quality.
"Wetlands issues are really happening in Westchester now," said David Osterman, co-chairman of Wetlands Watch, a committee of the Lower Hudson Group of the Sierra Club, which sponsored the Chappaqua lecture. "Some wetlands that shouldn't be developed are, like the Somers Golf Course, which is at the headwaters of the Plum Brook River and the Muscoot River. 
 "One of the ideas behind this meeting is to get out the message that it's important for local villages to get involved in wetlands regulation," Mr. Osterman added. "The only control the county has over the wetlands is persuading local town boards to have their own wetlands protection."
 
South County Losses
 Because the county can play only an advisory role in protecting wetlands, community protections can be especially important.
"The issue of wetlands and water quality is the vehicle by which local governments can recognize the need to protect wetlands," said Laura Tessier, director of environmental planning for the County Environmental Management Council, based in White Plains, who was the speaker at this meeting. "All wetlands are not created equal, but we tend to regulate them as if they were exactly alike."
Wetlands, which are defined as swamps, marshes, bogs or similar areas, play a significant role in purifying water by filtering pollutants before they reach the reservoir watersheds. Wetlands can also help reduce floods by storing water. According to the Wetlands Watch committee, 300,000 acres of wetlands are destroyed yearly in the United States. In Westchester, 25,000 acres are classified as wetlands. Total acreage in the county is 288,000.
"South county losses have been much greater then the north county," Ms. Tessier said. "Development has a negative impact on wetlands. Westchester has lost a significant number of amphibians and reptiles as an indirect impact of storm-water systems. They are the 'canary of the coal mines' for wetlands systems because these creatures are extremely sensitive to nonpoint-source pollution. The south county streams are very degraded, but our trends countywide show degradation of the wetlands."
 
Protecting by Deed or Covenant
 As a result of development, including the increase in automobile exhaust, Ms. Tessier said, the water quality in the Long Island Sound has diminished considerably from the increased presence of nitrogen in its waters. Other problems the county's wetlands face include economic pressures to develop around them, the erosion to wetlands in Rye along Long Island Sound, fertilizer and other chemical runoff from area golf courses and other sites and the lack of consistent policy on protecting remaining wetlands.
"There are significant wetland protection issues in Westchester County," Ms. Tessier said. "There's a tendency to develop in and around wetlands. Even when setbacks of 100 feet are required, over time an owner may want a deck or a swimming pool, and the buffer between the property and the wetland area is lost. There isn't any consistency of regulations. When local planning boards change, the philosophy toward protection of wetlands may change. It's very frustrating."

HEADLINE: THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE: THE HOUSE;
Health Care Issue Raises Anxiety In Most Anxious Month for House

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7

 BODY:
August in an election year is, by definition, an anxious time on the floor of the House. The balance of politics and policy at the heart of every vote, conscious or not, becomes all the more complicated.
"All those concerns increase exponentially this year, with the biggest social legislation to ever come down the pike hanging out there, completely unresolved," said Representative Bob Wise, Democrat of West Virginia. Indeed, one week before the House takes up the health care bill, the August angst could hardly be heavier for the Democrats, weighed down by every imaginable interest group, an ever more partisan Republican opposition, an ever more unpredictable Senate. 
 Most of these forces push toward caution. Yet House Democrats still seem haunted by the need to do something on health care. Many of them have held dozens of town meetings on the issue, heard the stories of the failings of the current system and had constituents write to them or approach them in shopping malls.
Representative Jim Chapman, a 49-year-old Democrat whose district covers the northeast corner of Texas, remembers how the uninsured or the underinsured would sometimes speak to him after the town meetings, having waited until the doctors and other officials who usually dominated those sessions had left.
Then, Mr. Chapman said, people would tell him their stories and say things like: "Follow your heart, Congressman. Do what's right." Mr. Chapman added, "It tends to make you realize that the people who are the least able to influence you need you the most." Moments like that, members say, help to balance the organized lobbying and carefully structured grass-roots outcry.
Representative Charles Wilson, another Texas Democrat, categorizes himself as "miserable" over the health care issue, in part because of the idea of requiring companies to contribute to the cost of their workers' insurance. The potential economic impact of that requirement, or employer mandate, has been driven home to members by the National Federation of Independent Business and other groups, and Mr. Wilson said, "I've got thousands of Wal-Marts and Pizza Huts and dealerships in my district."
But, Mr. Wilson said, he sees some faces in the political calculations.
"The Treasury Department estimates that 23.9 percent of my constituents do not have any coverage," he said. "My district is a blue-collar, hard-working constituency. I have thousands of young couples where the husband is a mechanic and works hard in a small auto shop, and the wife is a waitress, and they've got two or three kids and no insurance."
He added, "They don't go to the doctors and if a kid's got asthma, the first time you see him is when he can't breathe."
Like many other Democrats these days, Mr. Wilson characterizes himself as undecided on how he will vote. But, he said, at the end of the day "I'm going to make it possible for those young families to get some coverage."
The Administration and its allies in the House Democratic leadership are doing their best to keep the faces of the uninsured in the political equation. Hillary Rodham Clinton, among others, has turned the Treasury Department analysis of the uninsured, by Congressional district, into one of the most heavily consulted documents on Capitol Hill.
Members of the leadership, like Representative John Lewis of Georgia, a chief deputy whip, keep nudging their colleagues along. Mr. Lewis, a veteran of the civil rights movement, makes the analogy again and again that imposing a mandate on employers to achieve universal coverage is no more difficult, and no less right, than the mandates applied to achieve civil and voting rights.
Many, though, flatly reject the idea. Representative Gene Taylor, a Democrat with a district on the Gulf Coast of Mississippi, asserted, "I've lost three garment factories in my district as a direct result of Nafta." Mr. Taylor said he simply could not support a bill with an employer mandate -- or abortion -- in it.
 
Mismatched Plans
 It is August, and it is impossible to ignore the timing, the procedural mechanics and the pure politics of the issue. Democrats in the House get frustrated, especially moderates and conservatives. Why do they have to vote on a plan with a much greater level of employer contributions than the plan put forward in the Senate? (The leadership plan in the House, proposed by Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the majority leader, would require most employers to pay 80 percent of the cost of their workers' insurance; the leadership plan in the Senate, proposed by Senator George J. Mitchell, the majority leader, applies only a delayed and conditional mandate, with only a 50 percent employer share.)
"I'm not blaming the leadership, but they know the Gephardt plan has as much chance of passage in the Senate as aid to Cuba," Mr. Wilson said.
This, of course, is hardly the first time that the House will vote on a more liberal -- or just very different -- version of legislation than the Senate does. Allies of the leadership, like Mr. Wise, suggest that this is what conference committees were made for. "With some members, particularly the more skittish ones, it can make a difference," Mr. Wise said of the Senate factor. "But I think there's a realization among other members that Mitchell's going to do what Mitchell's got to do. It's politics going into the conference and substance coming out.'
Moreover, the current schedule makes it likely that the Senate will have to vote first on the basic issue of putting new requirements on employers. The old bulls of the House, like Representative John D. Dingell, scoff at the notion of deferring to the Senate on a hard vote -- "I've been afflicted with the Senate for 38 years," Mr. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat, barked when asked about the matter -- but the average member has no desire to take unnecessary risks so close to Election Day.
 
Concern for Repercussions
 Lawmakers worry, too, over the sheer scale of what they are about to do. "Members are genuinely concerned that once the fine print is written, there will be sleepers that come back and haunt us," said Representative Dan Glickman, Democrat of Kansas. "This is a bill that's going to affect every single American intimately. Most things we work on don't."
"Do something, but be careful" comes through again and again from House Democrats. "Each thing that happens as you go along causes concern and questions," Mr. Gephardt acknowledged in an interview. "But I must tell you I've been amazed and heartened in this whole thing at the willingness of members to hang in there and really want to figure out how to get this done." On Friday morning, the turnout was good at sessions to walk House Democrats through the Gephardt bill, hypothetical family by hypothetical family.
This instinct toward caution, however, raises the potential appeal of the bipartisan plan under development by Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee, and Representative Fred Grandy, Republican of Iowa. Representative Michael A. Andrews of Texas, one of many Democrats who argue that the Gephardt plan relies too much on government -- instead of the market -- to expand coverage, says that being concerned for the uninsured "doesn't mean just voting for everything."
The reception afforded the bipartisan plan, which is finally expected to be unveiled this week after much delay and reported difficulty in reaching agreement, should give some clues to the fate of the Gephardt plan. In the meantime, members are slouching through August.
"Crankiness comes," Mr. Chapman said philosophically. "It's all part of the process. Sometimes it works to a positive end."
 
DIARY
Health Care Developments
 
OVER THE WEEKEND With the House and Senate nearing showdown votes on health care bills, President Clinton is trying to mobilize support for legislation that would insure coverage for all, or nearly all, Americans.
 
WHITE HOUSE
The White House is battling critics who say the bills offered by leading Democrats in the House and Senate are too bureaucratic and too hard on business. In an advertisement broadcast on CNN, the President said the legislation had been altered to take account of the concerns of business, especially small business. And in brief remarks in Detroit on Saturday, he accused critics of Democratic health care plans of trying to deny all Americans the benefits that the critics already enjoy. "Most of them have health care and most of them have parents on Medicare," Mr. Clinton said. "Why do they not want you to have the same thing that they have?"
 
CONGRESS
 Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, noted that there were many differences between the bills Democratic leaders of the House and Senate had introduced and said that they would not be easy to reconcile. But he said he was optimistic of success. Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, said Republicans would divide up for study the Senate bill proposed by the majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, before they started to try to amend the Democratic proposals.
 
WHAT'S NEXT
Senate debate on the Mitchell bill begins on Tuesday. There is no telling when it will end; Senator Mitchell has said he will keep the Senate in session six days a week and into the Congressional recess originally scheduled to start at the end of next week until it acts on a health insurance bill. The House, whose regulations on debate allow members less time to speak, will take up its leadership's proposal on Aug. 15 and vote by Aug. 19, Mr. Foley has said.

HEADLINE: Giuliani's Patronage Power Helps Reshape Government

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL with ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
Before Rudolph W. Giuliani was elected Mayor, Albert L. Buzzeo was a caterer in Queens and serving as a Republican district leader. Leonard B. Guttman was a rabbi close to Mr. Giuliani who ran for City Council as a Republican in 1991 and lost. Today they are assistant commissioners in the Department for the Aging, making $73,500 a year.
Rosemarie O'Keefe, a Republican district leader from Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, was working as a $26,000-a-year aide to Representative Susan Molinari. Now she is an assistant commissioner of recreation at a salary of $73,500. 
 The three are part of the new face that Mr. Giuliani is putting on city government as his administration weeds out middle-level managers from the Dinkins and Koch years and replaces them with appointees selected to carry out the Mayor's priorities.
It is common for new mayors to bring with them scores of aides, deputies and new commissioners and to award jobs to campaign workers and party officials who helped get them elected. But former and current city officials say that at the middle levels of government, the Giuliani administration is carrying out the largest political housecleaning in years, with the Republican Mayor unbound by ties to the Democratic establishment.
Mr. Giuliani has said that he is selecting managers who understand his vision for the city. And he says he has put together an unusually diverse government. Democrats outnumber Republicans, 27 to 18, in his Cabinet.
Moreover, an examination of payroll records does not show that patronage is rampant under Mr. Giuliani. At least one Republican leader complains that the Mayor has forgotten the party's foot soldiers. And many of the people hired have impressive credentials.
But in scores of cases, the Mayor has given jobs to campaign supporters and officials of the parties that backed him. He has hired at least three dozen members of his paid campaign staff, 16 district leaders from the Republican and Liberal Parties, assorted campaign volunteers, and relatives and in-laws of the Mayor himself or his political allies.
Mr. Giuliani, whose battle against political corruption helped propel him to prominence as a prosecutor, called for a "dramatic break" with patronage in his first campaign for mayor in 1989. And he vowed across two campaigns to appoint people solely on merit. Earlier this year, he called it inappropriate to use the word patronage to describe any of his appointments.
"To me patronage is -- and I know it has lots of definitions -- is that some political leader has 20 jobs and gets to fill those 20 jobs and there is not any thought being given to qualifications and to the job," Mr. Giuliani said in an interview. He said that while his administration takes resumes from political leaders, "we say no as often as we say yes." And he added that his Cabinet and his political support were "so diverse that there's no danger of an outside force taking over an agency."
But Gene Russianoff, a staff attorney for the New York Public Interest Research Group, a nonprofit advocacy organization, said of the Mayor, "I think his record on patronage is disappointing because he as a candidate projected himself as a break with past bad old ways, and it turns out that he's pretty much in the same mold as his predecessors."
 
With New Mayors, New Approaches
 Each new administration has its own approach to filling the approximately 1,500 jobs that are under a mayor's direct control or that make up the management ranks of city agencies.
Mayor Edward I. Koch began his political career as a reformer against political patronage. But by the middle of his three terms, the political appointments grew, and some produced its biggest scandals. They included kickbacks and extortion in the Parking Violations Bureau and a broad patronage operation that had been billed as a "talent bank" to recruit minority laborers.
Mayor David N. Dinkins largely bucked the Democratic Party establishment, using his hiring to increase the number of women and minorities in government.
He brought in longtime aides from the Borough President's office as well as appointees from labor unions and nonprofit advocacy groups. The hiring left Democratic county leaders with so little influence that they threatened to sit out the next election, and some indeed provided lackluster support.
The Giuliani administration has created a centrally controlled appointments office for handling resumes, run by Anthony Carbonetti, a former campaign aide, and overseen by Randy M. Mastro, the Mayor's chief of staff. Mr. Mastro said the office had been established to insure an orderly hiring process. Mr. Giuliani said he became personally involved in mid-level personnel decisions only when there were disagreements among his senior staff.
Mr. Mastro said that of the 7,000 resumes collected by Mr. Giuliani's transition team, several hundred had been circulated to agency heads. Resumes submitted to the transition teams were accompanied by cover forms, party officials said, that indicated who the applicant's sponsor was and whether the sponsor knew the job-seeker personally.
As is customary, many of Mr. Giuliani's campaign staffers were hired into the Mayor's office to work directly for Mr. Giuliani. In city agencies, Mr. Mastro said, 550 people have received jobs since January. Of those jobs, he said, 100 require special technical skills. Of the remaining 450, he estimated that a quarter were given to people recommended by City Hall.
The figures did not include more autonomous agencies, like the Off-Track Betting Corporation, the Housing Authority and the Economic Development Corporation, which have dismissed dozens of employees and hired supporters of the Mayor.
 
How Much Pressure On Commissioners?
 Mr. Mastro described the hiring decisions as a "collaborative process" between City Hall and the commissioners, with some candidates identified by the appointments office and some by the commissioners themselves. He said he could not think of an instance in which he rejected a candidate over a commissioner's "ongoing objection."
Commissioners' accounts varied. "I've said no to City Hall," said Nora Chang Wang, the Commissioner of Employment. "There's no pressure."
Lilliam Barrios-Paoli, the Commissioner of Personnel, said she had reviewed 10 resumes sent by City Hall and selected two of the candidates "because I really liked them."
Several other agency heads, who would speak only when guaranteed anonymity, said the pressure to take candidates submitted by City Hall was strong, and five said that a commissioner's ability to reject such candidates varied according to how technical the agency was and how much independent standing the commissioner was thought to have.
One struggle took place in the Probation Department, city officials said, after City Hall recommended that Louis Gelormino, an attorney who had been a supporter of Mr. Giuliani, be hired for a deputy commissioner's job that was already filled.
The officials said that the Probation Commissioner, Michael P. Jacobson, a holdover from the Dinkins administration, objected, and after a bitter exchange with City Hall, the commissioner was told to find a job for Mr. Gelormino. Ultimately, Mr. Gelormino was named to a newly created $90,500-a-year position in charge of efforts to find jobs for people on probation.
Mr. Jacobson declined to comment on Mr. Gelormino's appointment. Mr. Mastro said the administration had wanted Mr. Gelormino to be hired because he had a special interest in probation and had been considered for the department's top job. He said there had been no acrimony and that it was Mr. Jacobson who found the position for Mr. Gelormino.
The city's payroll records, which were released to The New York Times only after it filed formal requests under the Freedom of Information law, showed wide variations among the departments in the number of political appointments. Some departments, like Health, appear not to have made hiring decisions that could be considered political.
In the Housing Preservation Department, Mara Neville, a spokeswoman for Commissioner Deborah C. Wright, said the department's top staff was chosen by Ms. Wright, and she cited substantial backgrounds in government or in housing policy. One official, however, had been a campaign worker: Miguel Ponce, a $70,000-a-year assistant commissioner. And Christopher Halligan, the son of one of Mr. Giuliani's cousins, was named a community coordinator with a salary of nearly $40,000 a year.
Other departments whose missions are less technical, like Parks or General Services, have taken on larger numbers of political appointees.
In General Services, which oversees office space and supplies for the government, 13 campaign workers and Republican and Liberal Party district leaders have been hired.
They include Kevin Brawley, the Liberal Party's Manhattan vice chairman, who makes $64,900 a year as director of purchase; Ronald Perry, a Harlem Republican district leader, as a $45,000-a-year associate staff analyst; Stuart Wershub, another Republican district leader from Manhattan, as a $50,000-a-year associate staff analyst, and James Najdek, a Liberal Party district leader from Queens, as a $26,000-a-year driver.
In the Parks Department, in addition to Ms. O'Keefe, Representative Molinari's former aide, at least seven politically connected applicants recommended by City Hall have been hired. They include Robert Adamenko, a Liberal Party district leader in Brooklyn, and Roberta Koeppel, a distant relative of William Koeppel, the real-estate executive who was a major Giuliani fund-raiser.
The Parks Commissioner, Henry J. Stern, said he had rejected other names sent by City Hall and was satisfied with his staff. Mr. Stern, a Liberal, added: "In the Liberal Party everybody's a district leader. To say because these were district leaders that they are of political importance, would be overreaching."
 
Appointees Defended As Well-Qualified
 Mr. Giuliani said that Ms. O'Keefe had originally been hired to be the parks official in charge of Brooklyn, which would have drawn on her experience as a Brooklyn constituent representative for Ms. Molinari. He said Mr. Stern promoted her to assistant commissioner. Mr. Mastro said she had proven herself in the public and private sector and had once run a "resort inn."
Mr. Mastro said that both Mr. Buzzeo and Mr. Guttman, who serve in the Department for the Aging, had a special interest in the elderly. Mr. Mastro said that as a caterer Mr. Buzzeo had served 100 to 500 meals a day to the elderly.
Mr. Mastro said that Mr. Guttman, a rabbi, lawyer and professor at Touro College, had worked with the elderly in community-based organizations. He said Mr. Guttman had been a board member of the Midwood Child Development Center, a director of adult-education programs and an editor of publications for the elderly, and had been involved in youth programs.
Other political figures are sprinkled throughout the agencies. At the Department of Business Services, Gilbert Klaperman, the husband of Mr. Giuliani's running mate, Susan Alter, was named an administrative attorney. At the Department of Employment, Elaine S. Reiss, the unsuccessful Republican candidate last year for Manhattan borough president, is an $80,000-a-year administrative attorney. Commissioner Wang said that Ms. Reiss had been recommended by City Hall, and that she had found her to be the most impressive candidate for the job. Ms. Reiss had previously been a general counsel and senior executive in the advertising industry.
Despite the political appointments made by the administration, several political leaders said they had not had the success they would like. State Senator Guy J. Velella, the Bronx County Republican leader, said he had forwarded 60 resumes, but only a few of his candidates had been hired.
The Queens Republican chairwoman, Fran Werner, complained that the Liberal Party was doing better than the Republicans in landing administration jobs. "Anybody who is a member of the Liberal party and in the hierarchy of the party has a job, and I don't think that's fair," she said.
Raymond B. Harding, the Liberal party leader, whose two sons have been hired into the administration, declined to comment. But asked whether his party had been rewarded for giving Mr. Giuliani its ballot line, he said, "To the extent that Giuliani is a superb Mayor, all New Yorkers have been rewarded."

HEADLINE: POP REVIEW;
Lollapalooza, as Usual, Goes Its Own Way

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

 BODY:
Lollapalooza is an alternative rock roadshow that mutates as it travels. On Saturday at the very pungent Downing Stadium on Randalls Island (there's a sewage treatment plant nearby), 6 of the 12 bands that performed at the tour's opening concert in Las Vegas, Nev., a month ago had been replaced. On the main stage, Green Day took the Japanese band the Boredoms' slot opening for the Lollapalooza stalwarts the Smashing Pumpkins, the Beastie Boys, George Clinton, A Tribe Called Quest, Nick Cave and L7. On the second stage, all five bands were new additions, and the music ranged from rap to jazz to country to rock.
What made this wide array of music alternative was its performers' relationship with the audience. Where popular acts of the last two decades swaggered like untouchable stars, culminating in the wall Pink Floyd performed behind 15 years ago on one tour, alternative acts try to break down the wall. 
 "This looks like arena rock," the Green Day singer Billie Joe complained during the band's midday set. The young California trio, which is leading a commercial renaissance of punk rock, spent much of its show sending up classic-rock cliches by asking the audience to do the wave, raise its lighters and pretend it was at Woodstock. Though three other main-stage bands made similar references, Green Day expressed the contradictions of successful alternative rock best when it brought members of the audience on stage and instructed them to sing hackneyed 80's anthems like "Eye of the Tiger" and "We're Not Gonna Take It."
When the Boredoms opened Lollapalooza, they prepared the audience for the festival's mind-opening atmosphere with incorrigible noise. Green Day, however, played accessible pop-punk songs that prepared the audience for fun. Its lyrics about being bored, unemployed, apathetic and disillusioned embraced the stereotypes that plague the Lollapalooza generation.
At the second stage, concertgoers were exposed to more diverse and challenging music, beginning with the sweet, off-kilter pop of Blast-Off Country Style and ending with an unannounced music and dance performance by the Tibetan Ganden Jangtse Monks. In between, the Charlie Hunter Trio formed slick, post-bop jazz out of guitar, drums and sax; Fu-Schnickens let loose lighthearted raps that fell flat on top of the muddy beats and canned music played by their disk jockey; Lambchop, an 11-member band, injected lap-steel guitar, washboard, saxophone and piano into beguiling country and quirky rock and Stereolab harnessed the chugging of early synthesizers to simple pop songs, adding sweetly sung and cleverly plagiarized lyrics.
After a solid and cynical performance by the singer, songwriter and doomsayer Nick Cave, a teasingly shambling rock show by the Breeders, a quick funk lesson from George Clinton (with the special guest Flavor Flav of Public Enemy) and an energetic Beastie Boys show that spanned the trio's rock and rap career, the Smashing Pumpkins closed the fourth annual Lollapalooza smorgasbord with just the right wrong attitude. Billy Corgan, the frontman, talked as if he was insecure about his success and misunderstood by his audience. But when he sang, he transformed the slippery spirit of the alternative nation into easy-to-grasp slogans: "I don't believe in God," he intoned in his set opener. "I don't believe in America, I don't believe in rock-and-roll. I believe in me."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A little stage diving at the Lollapalooza show at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island on Saturday. (Ebet Roberts)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Foreign Desk
